David Catania's Hope for Mayorship Lies in Experience
Catania: "Trust is the central theme of this election"
David Catania believes his extensive experience on the D.C. Council, spanning 17 years, will give him the edge he needs to secure the mayoral seat. In an exclusive interview with Washingtonian Editor in Chief David Kline, Catania shared his reasons for seeking the position.

input:
Drastic cuts in US funding to the United Nations would create an "insolvable problem" for the world body, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said Tuesday as he announced plans to lobby US lawmakers to reject the cutbacks.
G
continuation:
uterres warned that "the United States could never play any role" at the UN in its current state if it cuts funding, which he says are needed to "create conditions for greater accountability."
"Otherwise, this is going to be an insolvable problem for the UN. It will not be possible to move in any direction with any credibility, any coherence, with any sense of coherence, with any sense of coherence, if in the end this happens," he said in remarks at the headquarters of the UN.
"It is entirely unjustifiable if we say, 'OK, I need more money, I need more support from the United States,' when the United States is facing its own crisis, facing its own pandemic. If in order to help with these enormous needs we should decide, 'OK, let us take even more money from other countries,' it is completely unacceptable. That is why we are making this case, it is going to be important in Washington."
The UN says Washington is expected to provide more than its average annual US contribution of $6.6 billion in 2022.
It is expected to slash its funding in 2024 by nearly 30 percent, or nearly one-third, to US$4.
paraphrase:
Cutting US funding to the United Nations would create a "insurmountable challenge" for the organization, according to UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. He warned that if the US reduces its contributions, the UN's ability to function effectively would be severely compromised.
Guterres emphasized that the UN relies on funding from member states to "establish conditions for greater accountability." Without adequate funding, he claimed that the UN would lack credibility and coherence in its decision-making processes.
"It is utterly unjustifiable to expect the UN to increase its funding from other countries while the US is facing its own crises, including a pandemic," Guterres stated during a speech at the UN headquarters. "If we are to address these enormous needs, it is unacceptable to take more money from other countries."
The UN anticipates that Washington will provide over its average annual contribution of $6.6 billion in 2022. However, it is expected to reduce its funding by nearly 30% in 2024, to around $4 billion.
In summary, Guterres warned that drastic cuts in US funding to the UN would significantly impede the organization's ability to function effectively and maintain its credibility, and that it would be unacceptable to expect other countries to make up for the shortfall.

input:
A Dayton jury found a state lawmaker not guilty of assault Tuesday.
DAYTON, TN (WRCB) -- A Dayton jury found a state lawmaker not guilty of assault Tuesday.
The assault trial for State Rep. Jim Cobb opened Tuesday morning
continuation:
, with the state Representative from Pike County, Tennessee, accused of assaulting his wife.
Court was called back from recess, with Cobb's attorney, Joe Morris, saying the state Representative was "very happy" with the verdict.
"I don't think there was anything in this case, frankly, where he was wrong, I think he did what he thought was the proper thing at the time," Morris said.
Prosecutor Jody Williams disagreed. Williams said Cobb physically assaulted his wife, Heather Cobb, pushing her into her bed. Cobb, she said, grabbed her hair, grabbed her with her arms, and "pushed her into her bed."
"I think he is one of the most cowardly people in the General Assembly," Williams said.
Cobb will have to register as a sex offender. He was acquitted of second degree sexual battery, although, he was found guilty of misdemeanor domestic violence. He is also accused of obstruction of justice. He will be sentenced on August 28.
paraphrase:
A jury in Dayton, Tennessee acquitted state lawmaker Jim Cobb of assault on Tuesday.
According to the trial, Cobb's attorney, Joe Morris, stated that his client was "very pleased" with the verdict, believing that there was no wrongdoing on his part. Morris stated, "I don't think there was anything in this case where he did anything improper."
On the other hand, the prosecutor, Jody Williams, disagreed, stating that Cobb physically assaulted his wife, Heather Cobb, by pushing her into her bedroom. Williams claimed that Cobb grabbed her hair and arms before pushing her into her bed.
"I think he is one of the most cowardly people in the General Assembly," Williams added.
Cobb will be required to register as a sex offender after being found guilty of misdemeanor domestic violence. He was acquitted of second-degree sexual battery, but will face sentencing on August 28.

input: September 17, 2012 (KHARTOUM)  The rebel Sudan Liberation Movement led by Abdel Wahid Al-Nur (SPLM-AW) has urged the U.S. Administration to stop its support to the Doha Document for
continuation:
Peace, which calls for military demilitarization of Sudans Darfur region.

Speaking in Washington on Tuesday, SPLM-AW Chairman Abdel Aziz Al-Hilu said that it was unacceptable for Sudans transitional government to talk with the United States while it was still engaged in military operations in Darfur.

We reject the Darfur Peace Process which calls for demilitarization, especially given that it is still ongoing in Sudan, he said.

It is not acceptable in Sudan for it to continue. We want peace in Darfur, he stressed.

Al-Hilu stressed, meanwhile, that Sudans transitional government will maintain its commitment to end armed conflicts in Darfur and Blue Nile.

We are committed to these commitments. If this commitment is violated, he stressed, stressing, however, that any violation of this commitment will also be regarded as a breach of its commitment.

It is unacceptable that Sudan is still engaged in the military operations in Darfur, he said, adding, "Sudan should meet its commitments, especially in terms of peace in Dar
paraphrase:
On September 17, 2012, in Khartoum, the Sudan Liberation Movement (SPLM-AW) led by Abdel Wahid Al-Nur called upon the US administration to halt its support for the Doha Document for Peace, which advocates for the demilitarization of Sudan's Darfur region. Speaking in Washington, SPLM-AW Chairman Abdel Aziz Al-Hilu stated that it was unacceptable for Sudan's transitional government to engage in peace talks with the US while continuing military operations in Darfur.
Al-Hilu emphasized that the Darfur Peace Process, which includes demilitarization, is unacceptable as long as military operations are ongoing in Sudan. He stressed that peace in Darfur is a priority and that Sudan's transitional government must fulfill its commitments to end armed conflicts in the region.
Al-Hilu also noted that Sudan's transitional government will maintain its commitment to end armed conflicts in Darfur and Blue Nile, and that any violation of this commitment will be regarded as a breach of their agreement. He highlighted that Sudan should fulfill its obligations, especially in terms of peace in Darfur.

input: IN WRITING about the year gone by, the first thing that strikes one is that this was the year of the spare cash. Almost all people in the middle class seemed to have extra money to spend. In many cases it was borrowed money but
continuation: many people were already saving regularly. This was evident in the rise of people taking money from savings accounts, where interest rates were fairly low, just to invest. The savings accounts of this period were mostly in fixed deposits, where, of course, interest rates are quite low. This was in contrast with the time, a few decades ago, when interest rates in fixed deposits were around 8 per cent. That was before interest rates became competitive, too. In fixed deposit accounts, where rates are determined by government regulations, you are paying for the extra protection of insurance. The interest rates are typically above 10 per cent. One is often asked what happens when interest rates go up. If one pays in cash in the form of fixed deposit, interest is compounded, and in most cases, people get more interest than if they pay in terms of compound interest, which is, of course, interest compounded daily. If you invest in a fixed deposit, compound interest is called "double-time". For instance, if one earns 8 per cent in fixed deposit, it is compounded to 8.88 per cent. At 8.88 per cent interest, one can invest in fixed deposit of Rs 10,000, which will increase to Rs 20,000 if one
paraphrase: Reflecting on the past year, one observation stands out - it was a year of spare cash for many in the middle class. With extra money to spend, people borrowed or saved regularly. This surplus cash was evident in the rising trend of individuals withdrawing from savings accounts, where interest rates were relatively low, to invest. During this period, fixed deposits were the most popular investment option, with interest rates ranging from 8% to 10%. These rates were significantly lower than the 8% interest rates offered a few decades ago, before the competitive interest rate landscape emerged. When it comes to fixed deposits, the interest rates are determined by government regulations and provide an additional layer of protection. However, with compound interest, people tend to earn more interest than with simple interest. For instance, if one invests Rs 10,000 in a fixed deposit with an 8% interest rate, it would grow to Rs 20,000 within a year, thanks to compound interest.

input:
Great Britain have finished outside the medals at the World Wheelchair Rugby Championships in Canada.
However, their sixth-placed finish sees GB, who were ranked ninth in the world before the tournament, move three places up the world rankings.
Captain Steve
continuation:
Scutt was happy with his sides performance.
It was a hard tournament, he said.
Canada were really tough opponents, so were Japan, Serbia, Uruguay.
It was a bit more difficult because of whats happened with Russia in the past couple of years.
Its really important that we were competitive and tried to get into the final matches.
And he admitted GBs performance was hindered by the heat in Calgary.
It was really hot in Calgary, he said.
And although its something were really used to, sometimes it takes us a few games to get used to it.
paraphrase: Great Britain's lackluster performance at the World Wheelchair Rugby Championships in Canada has left them outside the medals, but their sixth-place finish has resulted in a significant jump in the world rankings, moving them up three places to ninth. Captain Steve Scutt was pleased with his team's showing, despite the challenges they faced against top opponents like Canada, Japan, Serbia, and Uruguay. The team's recent struggles with Russia also made the competition more difficult. Although GB's performance was impacted by the sweltering heat in Calgary, Scutt acknowledged that they are well-accustomed to playing in such conditions and it simply took a few games for them to adjust.

input: Versatility is a valuable skill to find in a Realtor, and Barbara Van Dyke has certainly proven her ability to market and sell a diverse assortment of properties. The Kuper Sotheby's International Realty agent gives us a peek at
continuation:
her diverse offerings and her real estate career.

Why did you choose to pursue Real Estate instead of other career fields?

I always thought Real Estate was more of an art or craft, rather than something you could put on your resume. Real Estate is about understanding people and their wants, needs, hopes, dreams, life stories, etc. It's also more collaborative. If one client is in pain, others will feel that pain too. We live in a world of technology, where people use technology, but people don't want technology. We need people in human-centric roles. That is why I want to work with people.

What is the one thing that you believe is a key to success in Real Estate?

I believe that people want a home. I believe that people want a home with privacy. I believe that people want a home with protection. I believe that people want a home with ease of maintenance. I believe that people want a home with privacy. I believe that people want privacy. I believe that people want privacy. I believe that people want privacy. I believe that people want privacy. I believe that people want privacy. I believe that people want privacy. I believe that people want privacy.
paraphrase:
Barbara Van Dyke, a skilled Realtor with Kuper Sotheby's International Realty, has demonstrated her versatility in marketing and selling a diverse range of properties. In this interview, she shares insights into her real estate career and the factors that contribute to success in the industry.
Instead of pursuing a conventional career path, Van Dyke chose to enter the real estate sector due to its more personal and collaborative nature. According to her, real estate involves understanding people's wants, needs, hopes, dreams, and life stories, as well as being able to empathize with clients' pain points. She believes that technology may provide solutions, but people still crave human interaction and personalized service.
When asked what she believes is key to success in real estate, Van Dyke emphasizes the importance of understanding people's desire for privacy and protection in their homes. She believes that clients want a home that is easy to maintain and provides a sense of privacy, and that these factors are crucial in building trust and rapport with clients.
Overall, Van Dyke's responses highlight the value of empathy, adaptability, and a people-centric approach in the real estate industry. By prioritizing her clients' needs and desires, she has established herself as a trusted and skilled Realtor.

input: And this is what happens when you take people from outside of tech, in this case Michael Pachter, an analyst at Wedbush Securities (based in LA), and collide them with topics that they dont understand, in this case,

video game design, with an almost complete absence of understanding of what is involved in it. As if this wasnt embarrassing enough, he is unable or unwilling to put himself into any context or even try to understand what hes talking about.

I dont think video game design is in a good place. I think it is in much worse shape than it was even a few years ago. The problem I am talking about is not just with new, interesting ideas, it is with the approach that is used to them. The game designers are too often too blinded by what other people are doing, rather than focusing on what should be done next. A single-minded, I, mind. Too often, new, innovative ideas are destroyed in this fashion. I think that we need game designers who are willing to say well, lets think about it in this way, Im just going to look at it from this perspective, which is its own set of challenges. At least one of these game designers should be in LA. I think hed be making game designs hed respect. I think he
paraphrase:
When unfamiliar individuals, such as Michael Pachter, an analyst at Wedbush Securities (based in LA), are thrust into conversations about complex topics they lack familiarity with, such as video game design, it can lead to awkward and embarrassing moments. Pachter's inability or unwillingness to contextualize himself or demonstrate a genuine interest in the topic only exacerbates the issue.
I fear that the current state of video game design is dire. In my opinion, it is in a far worse condition than it was just a few years ago. The primary concern I have is not merely the absence of novel and innovative ideas, but rather the approach employed when addressing these concepts. Game designers are too frequently blinded by what their peers are doing, rather than focusing on what could be done next. This narrow-minded thinking often results in the destruction of promising new ideas.
In my opinion, we need game designers who are willing to approach problems from unique perspectives and challenge conventional thinking. By adopting a more inclusive and adaptable mindset, these designers could create games that are both respected and innovative. Perhaps by bringing one of these creators to LA, we could foster a more innovative and respectful approach to game design.

input:
DEFIANT Alan Shearer has urged his relegation-haunted Newcastle side to keep the faith.
With just one point from three games since he returned to St Jamess Park, the Geordie icon has been unable to work an
continuation:
impression into his sides culture, which is why he was determined to win them back some pride.
Newcastle are still in mid-table despite beating Brighton in their previous game but defeat in the early kick-off against Tottenham will further damage hopes of going up.
Shearer, currently in his second stint in management, said he could never justify why his former club should change its style of play.
Were always going to have things which are going to frustrate us, he said.
Newcastle fans will always find something to criticise. We are always going to find it in this league, I am here, Im going to find it, its just how I am.
Its always going to be difficult. We are going to find a way to get out of this slump. We are going to find a way.
My record is quite good, I always get what I want. If I said this game is going to win it, Id lose it. If I said this game is going to lose it, Id win it. That is life.
paraphrase:
Alan Shearer has implored his underperforming Newcastle side to stay united in the face of adversity. Despite their lackluster start to the season, Shearer remains optimistic about his team's potential, citing his own track record of success as evidence.
Shearer acknowledges that his team's style of play may not be to everyone's liking, but he believes that they have the ability to turn things around. "We're always going to have our critics, but we can't let them get us down," he said. "We're going to find a way to get out of this slump and prove our doubters wrong."
Shearer's confidence in his team's abilities is reflected in his own approach to the game. Rather than trying to predict the outcome of each match, he takes a more pragmatic approach, focusing on the process rather than the outcome. "If I said this game is going to win it, I'd lose it," he said. "But if I said this game is going to lose it, I'd win it. That's just the way it is."
Despite the challenges facing his team, Shearer remains steadfast in his belief in their potential, citing his own success as evidence of what they are capable of achieving.

input: This years monster El Nio is truly a monsterits been blamed for killing coral reefs. Add another die-off to the list: Southern California beaches are blanketed in hundreds of thousands of tiny crabs. So many that
continuation: its created a massive algae problem. And these creatures are bad news: The crab-eating critters are sucking more oxygen from local waterways. The state is concerned that without major action, the sea will be underwater before many people even hit the shore.
paraphrase: This year's intense El Nio event has caused significant damage to coral reefs, and now it appears to be responsible for another marine die-off. Hundreds of thousands of tiny crabs have washed up on Southern California beaches, creating a large algae bloom in the process. Unfortunately, these crabs are not just a nuisance - they are also consuming oxygen from the local waterways, which has the state concerned about the potential long-term impact on the ocean's health. If action is not taken, there is a risk that the sea could become underwater before many people even have a chance to enjoy the shore.

state were also touched. We will provide further information on these later.

This information will not replace the local fire departments current level of response. If any new information is available, it will be made available.
In general, Governor Schwarzenegger has been working with local communities, elected officials, fire departments, insurance companies, and other resources. He is working hard to find innovative ways to help them get their hands on resources from other states. If youre in a fire or other emergency situation, or if you
paraphrase:
Governor Schwarzenegger has been actively involved in the ongoing efforts to combat the uncontrolled wildfires in Southern California, holding a press conference to provide updates on the situation. As of now, 6,300 firefighters are working tirelessly to contain the fires, which is a significant increase from the 1,500 personnel in recent years. The state has invested over $500 million in fire retardant, with private fire companies playing a crucial role in this effort. input: If you are willing to take the time to calculate the needed calories to bulk up, the process should be relatively simple. Bulking up or building muscle means getting a mass stimulus from resistance-training and then supplying your body with adequate
continuation:
calories (calories needed) to compensate for the fat gained from weight-lifting.
Thanks. I'm not really looking to bulk. I think I'll just try to stay lean and avoid gaining fat. I don't feel like I need to buy any more clothes. I'm going to get away with just one more month of vacation. Then it's back to gym.  I'll just stop lifting weights, try running.  I just want to feel better, I'm not really looking into getting muscles.  Thanks.
Calories are calories, even when you are not lifting weights. The only way to gain weight is from lifting. input:
Airlift of a Marine Corps battalion to Lebanon demonstrated that deploying contingency forces from the continental United States to an overseas operation was feasible and expeditious.
During the Cold War, the United States deployed its Armed Forces to support the national objectives of various
continuation:
countries in Europe, Africa, Asia, Latin America, Africa, and the Pacific. At the same time, United States forces were also deployed in support of peacekeeping operations in various countries.
Although this was a "temporary" deployment, it included considerable time, energy, resources, and human resources. In recent times, United States military forces in the Western hemisphere have been deployed in support of peacekeeping operations, humanitarian aid operations, and even, in times of crisis, military operations in Latin America.
Prior to the current deployment of United States Marine Corps (MARCOM) forces in support of Operation Spartan Shield, it was often difficult and expensive to provide MARCOM with airlift capability from continental United States. This problem was exacerbated when United States forces in overseas assignments (e.g. Iraq, Panama, Lebanon, etc.) did not receive sufficient support in terms of airlift support.
Furthermore, MARCOM forces were also limited in terms of airlift options when these forces operated in support of peacekeeping operations. Many peacekeeping operations were conducted in remote locations, where it was difficult or even impassible to provide airlift. This made it difficult, if not impossible, to provide MARCOM forces with adequate airlift support.
paraphrase:
The successful deployment of a Marine Corps battalion to Lebanon demonstrated the feasibility and efficiency of deploying contingency forces from the US mainland to an overseas operation. During the Cold War, the US military deployed its forces to various countries around the world, including Europe, Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Pacific, in support of national objectives. This deployment also involved the use of US military forces in peacekeeping operations, humanitarian aid missions, and even military interventions in times of crisis.
Prior to the current deployment of MARCOM forces in support of Operation Spartan Shield, it was challenging and costly to provide airlift support for MARCOM from the US mainland. This issue was further exacerbated when US forces deployed overseas, such as in Iraq or Panama, did not receive adequate airlift support. Additionally, MARCOM forces faced limitations in airlift options when conducting peacekeeping operations in remote locations, making it difficult to provide adequate airlift support.

The actor also teased a new show hell appear in with
paraphrase: The editors of People and Us Weekly are overjoyed: Both Jennifer Aniston and her husband Brad Pitt have received Emmy nominations Thursday. Aniston has been nominated for Best Comedic Actress for her portrayal of a pregnant character on Friends, while Pitt has been nominated for a guest appearance in HBO's critically acclaimed drama Tyrant. The former couple will also share hosting duties for the upcoming Emmy awards, which will be held live from the Los Angeles Staples Center on September 17. They will also make a special appearance on an upcoming episode of the CBS comedy, Young Sheldon, which is based on the film My Big Fat Greek Wedding. Aniston expressed her surprise at the nomination, stating that it was "too crazy" for her to handle. Pitt, on the other hand, joked that his wife was going to win, but was quick to add that he was excited to share hosting duties with his wife. The actor also hinted at a new project he will be starring in alongside his wife.

input:
A British entrepreneur 'committed a deliberate fraud over a sustained period of time' to artificially inflate the value of his software company by billions of dollars ahead of its sale, the High Court has heard.
Hewlett-Packard (HP
continuation:
) was due to buy British software company Autonomy for 11 billion in 2007, but when Autonomy was sold for 11.1 billion in January 2008, it was revealed that Hewlett-Packard had only acquired Autonomy for 5.6 billion in 2007.
In his opening statements to jurors, which began this week, Hewlett-Packard's (HP) counsel said the business 'collided with a wall of mistrust' in Autonomy's relationship with investors. He said Autonomy was unable to raise funds in the US, due to 'a series of transactions in which HP was involved'.
It is believed that these transactions were carried out by Hewlett-Packard. Autonomy was subsequently'sold into parts,' with Autonomy getting a fraction of its former value.
As a result, Hewlett-Packard incurred'substantial' losses of 1.8 billion. 'In essence, Mr Hewlett-Packard was committing a deliberate fraud,' Hewlett-Packard counsel Barry Williams said. 'HP is a business with an international business in which Mr Hewlett-Packard played an important, significant role.'
Williams said Hewlett-Packard believed it was under'significant pressure
paraphrase:
A British entrepreneur allegedly engaged in a deliberate fraud by overstating the value of their software company over an extended period, falsely inflating its worth by billions of dollars before its sale, a High Court hearing has revealed. In 2007, Hewlett-Packard (HP) was set to acquire Autonomy for $11 billion, but when the company was sold in 2008, it was revealed that HP had actually paid $5.6 billion for it.
HP's legal counsel claimed that Autonomy's relationship with investors was marked by mistrust, making it impossible for the company to secure funding in the US. The counsel alleged that Hewlett-Packard was involved in a series of transactions that contributed to Autonomy's inability to raise funds.
It is believed that these transactions led to Autonomy being "sold off" and losing a significant portion of its value. As a result, Hewlett-Packard incurred substantial losses of $1.8 billion. Hewlett-Packard counsel Barry Williams argued that the actions of the entrepreneur amounted to deliberate fraud, emphasizing the importance of the entrepreneur's role in the company.
Williams stated, "HP is an international business in which Mr. Hewlett-Packard played a significant role." The counsel asserted that the entrepreneur engaged in fraudulent actions, significantly impacting the company's financial well-being.

input:
The fight against Ottawas proposed tax changes for small corporations isnt over, even after watered-down policies were proposed in the latest federal budget following months of business community backlash.
The Coalition for Small Business Tax Fairness, a
continuation:
small business association lobbying the Harper government to back away from its proposed policies, said its members will not stand idly by while Ottawa continues to advance its business-killing, one-size-fits-all approach to corporate taxation.
The coalition said its members will press Ottawa to repeal its corporate tax reforms, which it said were poorly drafted, unnecessary, or inconsistent with international practice, or else go to court.
While the final details are yet to be negotiated, it is still apparent that these cuts are hurting hard-working small business, said Bill Linton, co-chairman of the coalition.
Small business is already in distress, struggling to survive due to the uncertainty created by these corporate tax policies, which are going to be further exacerbated by the imposition of a new payroll tax.
Tax expert says new policies will push small businesses into insolvency
In its own analysis, The Globe and Mail said Ottawas corporate tax overhaul is likely to create thousands of jobs in small business, even with a business-killing payroll tax, while also stimulating growth in sectors of the economy like tech.
Despite government promises, Linton said his organization is concerned that its members are still paying
paraphrase: The ongoing resistance to Ottawa's proposed tax changes for small businesses continues to mount, as the Coalition for Small Business Tax Fairness and other stakeholders refuse to back down from their opposition. The coalition has vowed to fight the policies, which they deem harmful to small businesses, and may take legal action if necessary. Despite the government's claims of job creation and economic growth, small business owners remain skeptical and fearful of the impact on their bottom line. Tax experts have warned that the new payroll tax could push small businesses into insolvency, further exacerbating the already challenging economic environment. While the government may see the policies as a means to stimulate growth, small business owners fear the consequences will be detrimental to their livelihoods.

input:
This opinion piece is by Valarie Kaur, a civil rights lawyer, filmmaker, and interfaith leader who founded Groundswell, the nations largest multi-faith online organizing community.
Gunshots in a sanctuary of peace. C
continuation:
ries of, no gun, no peace, from a mother. The sound of tear gas. The sound of people being injured. The sound of children in cages.
We stand here in shock. We are here in horror. We are here in anger. But what is more important is: We are here in love. Love for our neighbors. Love for one another. Love that transcends politics, religion, ethnicity, and skin color.
What will it take for people in this country to listen to one another? The pain of people around the world is too overwhelming. The grief of people here in this sanctuary of peace is too heavy. The pain of police brutality is too much. We need one another. We need love. We need healing. We need one another.
As human beings, we are all connected. As women and people of color, we are connected. As Jews, we are connected. As LGBTQ people, we are connected. As people of faith, we are connected. As people of conscience, we are connected. We are a people. We are one. We are one.
We will remember. We will honor. We will grieve. We will love. We will rise.
paraphrase:
This piece, written by Valarie Kaur, a prominent civil rights lawyer, filmmaker, and interfaith leader, conveys a powerful message of love and unity in the face of tragedy. Kaur describes the horror and anger that follows the senseless violence that took place in a sanctuary of peace, where innocent people were injured or killed by gunshots.
The author emphasizes the need for people to listen to one another and to transcend political, religious, ethnic, and racial differences in order to heal and move forward. Kaur argues that as human beings, we are all connected, and that as women, people of color, Jews, LGBTQ individuals, people of faith, and people of conscience, we are all part of a larger community that needs to come together in the face of adversity.
Through her use of powerful imagery and emotive language, Kaur inspires readers to remember, honor, grieve, and love, and ultimately to rise above the pain and tragedy that has affected so many lives. The author's message is one of hope and resilience, encouraging readers to come together in a show of solidarity and support for one another.

input:
The Nuggets Nikola Jokic, left, is defended by the Celtics Aron Baynes during the first quarter Monday at TD Garden in Boston.
BOSTON  Isaiah Thomas got his due, and the Nuggets got their win.
continuation:
Both were deserved. But one of them was more so.
Jokics block with 0.1 second left and Denvers comeback win over Boston was just as important, if only in the sense of getting the No. 8 seed back into the playoff hunt.
Its a big win, one Nuggets fans were desperate to see, one Nuggets who played his worst game of the season, and one Nuggets fan who didnt want to. Jamal Murray said afterward, I was kind of feeling it, as if it was the game he wasnt thinking of. He had one of his worst shooting nights of the season. He wasnt aggressive, he wasnt happy, he didnt seem like himself. The Nuggets (32-28) were in the game, too. A win is a win. A loss is a loss. Both of these are important, too. But this one was special.
"It was important for us, Murray said of the win. "In this league, anything is possible.
Its easy to say, given Denvers record, whats
paraphrase:
The Denver Nuggets' Nikola Jokic, left, fends off Boston Celtics' Aron Baynes during the first quarter at TD Garden in Boston.
The Nuggets' thrilling victory over the Celtics was a testament to their determination and resilience. Despite struggling with his shot, Jamal Murray led his team to a hard-fought win, proving that he is a true leader on the court. The Nuggets' 32-28 record may not be the most impressive, but this victory shows that they are a force to be reckoned with in the playoffs. As Murray noted, anything is possible in the NBA, and this win will surely give his team a much-needed boost of confidence.

input:
If a wall or shelf in your home could use an infusion of art, youre in luck.
The Haven Lamb Shop is having its third annual fine art, prints and frames sale Friday and Saturday, Sept. 15 and 16.
continuation:
Its our way of giving back to our community, said co-owner Kari Tammara.
On Friday from 6:30 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. Tammara, with co-owner Alissa Scott, will offer various works in print, art, photography, fine art and fine jewelry. The event also offers photo framing, while its new addition, The Haven, will offer unique artwork from local, regional and national artisans.
It is Tammaras way of giving back, she said. The Haven is a women-owned business which also supports womens causes.
On Saturday from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. and Sunday from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. artisans will offer various types of jewelry, from bracelets, pendants, necklaces, pendants, earrings, ornaments, ornaments, earrings, cuff links and chains. There will also be photography, jewelry, art and photography, Tammara said. Tammara will offer photography from her photo studio, while Scott will offer art. Tammaras home is
paraphrase:
Looking for a creative boost for your home decor? Look no further! The Haven Lamb Shop is hosting its third annual fine art, prints, and frames sale this Friday and Saturday, September 15 and 16. As a way of giving back to the community, co-owners Kari Tammara and Alissa Scott are offering a diverse selection of works in print, art, photography, fine art, and fine jewelry.
On Friday, from 6:30 a.m. to 8:30 p.m., visitors can browse a range of artisanal pieces, including photo framing. The Haven, a women-owned business, also features unique artwork from local, regional, and national artisans.
On Saturday and Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. and 1 p.m. to 5 p.m., respectively, artisans will showcase their talents in jewelry-making, offering a variety of bracelets, pendants, necklaces, earrings, ornaments, and more. Photography and art lovers will also find something to their taste, as Tammara and Scott will be displaying their work from their respective photo studio and art studio.
Don't miss this opportunity to infuse your home with some creativity and support local artisans. See you there!

input:
There are people who insist that Super Bowl Sunday or the Kentucky Derby is the most exciting day in sports. I always argue that there is no day in sports better than tomorrow. Nothing beats the Saturday of college basketball's Final Four.
There is still
continuation:
football, which is the most exciting day in sports.
Funnily enough, I don't really like football. I think it's kind of boring, like, "you could play golf anytime" kind of boring. But hey, what are you going to do, right?
I think people don't watch football to get away from it.  I think people watch it with their families, or their significant other, or friends, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or, or
paraphrase:
While some individuals hold the view that particular sporting events, such as Super Bowl Sunday or the Kentucky Derby, are the most exhilarating days in sports, I personally believe that there is no day in sports that can compare to the Saturday of college basketball's Final Four.
While football is often considered the most exciting day in sports, I must respectfully disagree. I find it to be a rather dull and uninteresting activity, much like playing golf, which can be enjoyed anytime. However, I recognize that many people enjoy watching football with their loved ones or friends, and I respect their preferences.
In my opinion, people watch football not to escape it, but to spend quality time with their families, partners, or friends. They find joy in sharing this experience together and immersing themselves in the excitement of the game.
In conclusion, while the sentiment that Super Bowl Sunday or the Kentucky Derby is the most thrilling day in sports may hold water for some, I firmly believe that the Saturday of college basketball's Final Four is the pinnacle of sporting events.

input: Red Hat bought IT automation-centric configuration management DevOps-friendly firm Ansible, okay so we know that part. Retaining the Ansible brand and names as it does, this month sees Red Hat launch Ansible Container, but what is
continuation:
it, where it comes from, what kind of use cases will it be more popular with, and what will it offer users? Well also check in with key folks from Ansible in advance of its live release this Tuesday, September 8th, with more hands-on sessions, demos, and interviews from us. Get ready for this one, folks!

And if you think thats too much, check out this sneak peak into whats new in Fedora 32s software repositories!

More importantly, this release also features new technologies, new approaches, new releases, new
paraphrase:
Red Hat recently acquired IT automation-focused configuration management and DevOps-friendly firm Ansible, and this month marks the launch of Ansible Container. While retaining the Ansible brand and names, this latest release offers users a range of exciting features and improvements. input: Most of you are part of the problem, these kids bodies are not even cold yet and you are all having the same tired argument. Wake up, regardless if you blame guns or people, we have a big problem that can only be cured with love
continuation:
. I dont say its going to be easy, but if this is how you feel, change it. Its time.
Im with u.  Im with u.  Im with u.  But I want more.  I want to help.  But Im getting tired.   Im getting sick.  Im going to sleep.  Im going to stay here.   Im going to stay here.   The world will change with or without us.   We are just a small voice.
paraphrase:
Most of you are contributing to the issue at hand, and these young lives have not even had the decency to rest yet, and you're all engaged in the same stale debate. Wake up! It's time to recognize that our problem stems from a lack of love and compassion, not from guns or people. I understand that change won't come easily, but if this is how you feel, it's time to make a difference.
I stand with you, and I will continue to fight for a better tomorrow. But I'm getting tired, and the world won't wait for us. We may feel small and insignificant, but our voice matters. Let's not give up, let's keep pushing for a world where love and empathy reign supreme.
The clock is ticking, and we must act now. Will you join me in this fight? Together, we can make a difference.

input: Top Pentagon officials said this week that they are aiming to make President Trumps Space Force service as small as possible and are resisting the White Houses proposal to establish a fully independent sixth branch of the armed forces.
continuation:
Space is a war-fighting domain. Space is a war-fighting domain. Space is a war-fighting domain, Pentagon Press Secretary Jonathan Hoffman said at a recent event with military, business and academic stakeholders.

Youre going to get in your own way if you dont get with it, he said.

Mr. Hoffman spoke on the first full day of the Space Symposium, which was jointly sponsored by The Aerospace Corporation and The Defense Writers Group. The event was also hosted by The Washington Examiner.

While Mr. Hoffman said he doesnt expect any major changes in Mr. Trumps Space Force proposal, he said he is concerned that the presidents Space Force proposal could be used to justify more military spending.

Youll hear in due course whether or not [the Space Force proposal] will be used in terms of justification for military spending, he said.

Space operations are often more expensive, he said, especially if a military operation involves more satellites.

A 2018 report from the Defense Departments Inspector General found that more money is being spent on military
paraphrase:
Top Pentagon officials are aiming to minimize President Trump's Space Force service, despite the White House's proposal for a fully independent sixth branch of the armed forces. Pentagon Press Secretary Jonathan Hoffman emphasized at a recent event that space is a war-fighting domain and noted that attempting to get in the way of space operations could hinder military efforts.
While Hoffman did not expect any significant changes to the Space Force proposal, he expressed concerns that it could be used to justify increased military spending. He hinted that the public would soon learn whether or not the Space Force proposal would be used in this regard.
Hoffman highlighted the added expense of space operations, particularly when satellite numbers are higher in a military operation. A 2018 report from the Defense Department's Inspector General also revealed that more funds are being spent on military operations in space.

input: New Delhi: Prime Ministers Employment Generation Programme (PMEGP) is a credit-linked subsidy programme aimed at generating self-employment opportunities through establishment of micro-enterprises in the non-farm sector by helping traditional artisans and unemployed
continuation:
youth with Rs 20,000-30,000 monthly assistance.

An estimated 20 crore rural women are eligible to receive monthly assistance of Rs 1,500, Rs 1,600, Rs 3,500, Rs 4,000, Rs 6,500, Rs 7,500, Rs 8,500, Rs 11,500, Rs 14,500 or Rs 30,000.

At its third year, the initiative is getting a major push, with the inclusion of 100 more districts in its coverage this year. Out of these, 100 will receive Rs 7,500-Rs 15,500 assistance per month. At least 1,049 villages will also benefit under this scheme.

These beneficiaries will generate job opportunities in sectors like brick kilns, handicrafts, construction, brick making, textiles, leather, etc. This will in turn create employment opportunities in other sectors which are facing challenges. It will also promote rural-urban mobility. The scheme will help in strengthening rural economies in general.

With this, total coverage of this scheme has increased from 3.45 crore rural women in 2016-17 to 4.28 crore in 2019-20. A total of 7.67 crore rural women benefited under
paraphrase:
The Prime Minister's Employment Generation Programme (PMEGP) is a credit-linked subsidy initiative aimed at fostering self-employment opportunities in the non-farm sector. The programme provides monthly assistance of Rs 20,000-30,000 to eligible beneficiaries, including traditional artisans and unemployed youth.
An estimated 20 crore rural women are eligible to receive monthly assistance of Rs 1,500-Rs 30,000 under the programme. This year, the initiative is expanding its coverage to 100 more districts, with 100 districts receiving Rs 7,500-Rs 15,500 assistance per month. In total, 1,049 villages will benefit under this scheme.
The programme's impact is expected to generate job opportunities in various sectors, including brick kilns, handicrafts, construction, brick making, textiles, leather, and more. This will promote rural-urban mobility and strengthen rural economies. Since its inception in 2016-17, the programme has increased its coverage from 3.45 crore rural women to 4.28 crore in 2019-20, with a total of 7.67 crore rural women benefiting under the scheme.

input: A new year means a new me. Long gone are the days of my subtle judgment on the current climate of the music industry. With the weather having gone from cold to unearthly, and Boston looking incredibly unfamiliar to a Texas native, so I
continuation:
ready for more of what Im already loving: alternative. But with this years album season fast-approaching, Im curious to know what youve been listening to. If any of these tracks have made their way into your setlists, or if youre making new favorites, let me know. Here are just a few of my favorite songs of 2016.

1. King Crimson  The Crimson Wave  This album from King Crimson is a perfect choice if you want to get into alternative. Its a complete album from beginning to end, with even more tracks from The Crimson Queen. The album is only 20 minutes in length, but this is more than enough time for it to stand as its own entity. The album was produced by Keith Morris, and features songs from Robert Fripp, Steve Hackett, John Wetton, and more. Its amazing to listen to this album and realize its from 1972. The album is also available in many other formats, including a vinyl reissue of The Crimson Queen.

2. Explosions in the Sky  The Man Made World  If youre looking for something
paraphrase:
As the new year approaches, I can't help but feel a sense of excitement and renewal. Gone are the days of my cautious approach to the music industry, and with the unpredictable weather and unfamiliar surroundings of Boston, I'm ready to embrace the alternative sound that has captured my attention. I'm eager to know what you've been listening to this year, and if any of the tracks on my list have made it into your setlists.
Here are some of my favorite songs from 2016:
1. King Crimson - The Crimson Wave: This album from King Crimson is a fantastic introduction to the alternative genre. At just 20 minutes long, it's a complete and cohesive work, featuring songs from The Crimson Queen. Produced by Keith Morris and boasting talents from Robert Fripp, Steve Hackett, John Wetton, and more, this album is a testament to the enduring power of alternative music. Released in 1972, it's amazing to hear how well it holds up today. The album is also available in various formats, including a vinyl reissue of The Crimson Queen.
2. Explosions in the Sky - The Man Made World: If you're looking for something new and exciting in the alternative genre, I highly recommend Explosions in the Sky's The Man Made World. With its intricate guitar work and emotive vocals, this album is a must-listen for any fan of the genre. Whether you're a seasoned alternative listener or just discovering the genre, The Man Made World is sure to leave a lasting impression.

input:
Employers rushing to automatically enroll workers in retirement plans and directing the money to one-stop life-cycle funds are leaving old-fashioned investment advice behind in a cloud of so much dust.
That may be a mistake, say advice providers, who
continuation:
say retirees are still clamoring for it. Its easy, fast, convenient, free, accurate and free from legal risk. But its also expensive, with life insurance policies costing more than 3 percent of household budgets.
Its easy, fast, convenient, free, accurate and free from legal risk. But its also expensive, says Michael Zabot, CEO of Plan Advisor, which focuses on creating retirement savings. As more people look at it, I think its really apparent that its something thats important.
Zabot, Plan Advisors co-founder, grew up in rural Illinois, where his grandfather ran a local insurance business. Hes also a former investment adviser. He says many retirees are unaware of whats possible in retirement. Zabot, 41, remembers clients in his mid-20s or early 30s, when he worked in retirement, who asked him how much money he put into his employer-sponsored retirement accounts. Hed shrug his shoulders and offer, I dont remember.
Zabot
paraphrase:
Employers are rapidly adopting automatic enrollment in retirement plans and directing the funds to one-stop life-cycle investments, leaving traditional investment advice in the dust.
However, some experts believe this approach may be misguided, as many retirees still crave personalized investment advice. It's quick, easy, convenient, free, accurate, and legally safe. But it also comes with a hefty price tag, with life insurance policies costing over 3% of household budgets.
While it's easy, fast, and free from legal risk, many retirees are unaware of the possibilities in retirement. Michael Zabot, CEO of Plan Advisor, notes that as more people explore this option, it's becoming evident that it's a crucial aspect of retirement planning. Zabot, who grew up in rural Illinois and has experience as an investment advisor, notes that clients in their mid-20s to early 30s, when he worked in retirement, would often ask him how much they contributed to their employer-sponsored retirement accounts. He would shrug and reply, "I don't remember."
Zabot, 41, emphasizes the importance of understanding what's possible in retirement and offers personalized advice to help clients make informed decisions.

input: In summertime, many women shelve their foundation and reach for beauty products that proffer a sheer, sun-kissed glow. In unpracticed hands, however, tinted moisturizers and bronzers can streak and pool faster than a
continuation:
poolside margarita, creating a crepey sheen rather than the flawless glow we all crave. (After a few hours, even SPF-protected tinted moisturizer will look dewy, while SPF-free bronzers will look greasy.) If you dont want your beauty look to look like the one scene from Paris is Burning, choose natural options for brightening, de-tinted or matte finishes. If you dont want to go dark, stay with light-filtering formulas. Here, beauty pros share what you should look for in skin-care ingredients this season.

Keep It Simple

Beauty is all in simplicity, says Leigh Ann Roper, a celebrity skincare trainer. You dont need a ton of ingredients, just the basics. Its also important to look for ingredients like shea butter, aloe vera, tea tree oil, and coconut oil. A big mistake women make is mixing more ingredients with more product, says Roper. Just use one or two things (think aloe vera, shea butter, coconut oil, or tea
paraphrase: This summer, many women are opting for lightweight, natural beauty products that offer a sun-kissed glow without the streaks and pooling of traditional tinted moisturizers and bronzers. While SPF-protected tinted moisturizers may still appear dewy after a few hours, SPF-free bronzers can quickly become greasy. To achieve a flawless glow without resorting to heavy, oily products, beauty experts recommend selecting formulas with natural ingredients such as shea butter, aloe vera, tea tree oil, and coconut oil. According to celebrity skincare trainer Leigh Ann Roper, simplicity is key when it comes to beauty products. Using just a few, high-quality ingredients can lead to better results than over-complicating with a multitude of products. By avoiding the mistake of mixing too many ingredients together, women can achieve a more even, natural-looking glow.

input:
LOS ANGELES  Dusty Baker has had a distinguished baseball career, through 19 seasons as a major league player and 22 more as a manager (and three Manager of the Year awards).
Yet Baker, who turns 69 in a week, readily acknowledges
continuation:
that he didnt think of himself as much of a leader. Its only been in recent years  since he was hired to manage the Los Angeles Dodgers in early 2016  that hes been able to stand beside the likes of Justin Turner, Kenley Jansen and Cody Bellinger. The Dodgers, who are expected to contend this season, are his fourth team. Hes been one of the most successful, making two trips to the World Series in six seasons. The only place hes not been back-to-back was in Boston, where he managed the Red Sox from 2000-02. He was fired in August of that year, when he led Boston to the World Series, which the Indians swept.
I dont really like being called one of the faces of the game. But I think if Im going to stand here today, I want people to know I was one of the faces of this game, Baker said.
His journey was not without difficulty. At 6-foot-1, 195 pounds, he was often called "Dusty" growing up in Fort Worth, Texas. The nickname, he said, was inspired
paraphrase: Dusty Baker has had an illustrious career in baseball, spanning 19 seasons as a player and 22 as a manager, earning him three Manager of the Year awards. However, Baker, who turns 69 in a week, admits he never considered himself a natural leader. It wasn't until his hiring as the Los Angeles Dodgers manager in 2016 that he began to feel confident in his ability to lead a team, alongside players like Justin Turner, Kenley Jansen, and Cody Bellinger. This marks his fourth team, and he has had the most success with the Dodgers, making two World Series appearances in six seasons. Although he was fired by the Boston Red Sox in 2002, leading them to the World Series that year, he remains proud of his achievements in the game. Despite his success, Baker is hesitant to embrace the label of "one of the faces of the game," preferring to let his actions speak for themselves. His journey has not been without challenges, including being nicknamed "Dusty" growing up in Fort Worth, Texas, due to his height of 6-foot-1 and weight of 195 pounds.

input: What if the research agenda of the University of Texas College of Natural Sciences were drafted not by the professors who actually conduct the studies but by, say, the alumni who funded the department? We might end up with research on the stickiness of Mr.
continuation:
Magoos fur, or why its hard to get kids in Africa to buy yogurt. We could, say, find ways to help people eat spinach  or whatever  while also making it easier to get people to eat more meat. No, its not possible. Its like asking us to find ways to help people like Steve Jobs eat more meat. And what if it were possible, what if it were desirable? That, too, is the challenge of evolutionary biology. If it were possible, it might change what the world thinks it knows.

Darwin, in his Origin of the Species, wrote that he hoped his ideas would guide the evolutionary process. But what if, as Charles Darwin put it, "I did not expect to have anything which was new, or which I was confident in, confirmed by observation, or experiment, or even by argument." Would that change the worlds ideas about life, nature, or evolution? Thats what this book is  something new, or something confirmed by observation, or something experimentally demonstrated, or something in-between. The ideas, the questions, the arguments are here. The chapters are here. The debate
paraphrase:
Imagine if the research agenda of the University of Texas College of Natural Sciences were shaped not by the professors conducting the studies, but by the alumni who fund the department. We might find ourselves delving into peculiar areas of research, such as the stickiness of Mr. Magoo's fur or why it's challenging to get kids in Africa to consume yogurt. Perhaps we could explore ways to make it easier for people to consume more meat while also encouraging them to eat more spinach. The possibilities are endless, but the likelihood of success is slim.
Charles Darwin's Origin of Species posits that he hoped his ideas would influence the evolutionary process. However, what if his predictions were proven incorrect? What if, as Darwin himself noted, "I did not expect to have anything which was new, or which I was confident in, confirmed by observation, or experiment, or even by argument"? Such a discovery could drastically alter the world's understanding of life, nature, and evolution.
This book represents a fresh perspective, a new confirmation through observation or experimentation, or even an in-between. The ideas, questions, and debates are all present, organized into chapters for your convenience. The possibilities are endless, and the implications could be profound. So, embark on this journey with us and discover something new, or perhaps something confirmed by observation or experimentation. The world may never be the same.

input: Most of mobile right now is focused on trying to figure out where the whales arethe big dollar advertising, says Jeffrey Peden. Seems to be an accurate statement, considering the big deal activity Boston has seen lately with major mobile

It also ranked fourth in mobile traffic from Google.com in April)
paraphrase: Most mobile activity currently revolves around locating whales, according to Jeffrey Peden. This observation appears accurate, given the recent surge in large-scale mobile advertising in Boston. One of the major players in this space is Google, which recently released mobile data from its second annual Cost of Connected mobile report. Moreover, Boston generated the fourth-highest mobile revenue from Google.com in April, accounting for nearly 7% of total mobile revenue from the platform in that month. input:
A quick run-through of basic measures of investment value for shares and stock markets.
The most widely used calculation, this ratio compares a companys value with its profits. To work it out, you take the share price and divide it
continuation:
by its profits. This ratio gives the current share price, divided by its profits, which gives you a basic measure of how much it is undervalued. If it was rising, its undervalued. If it was falling, its overvalued. Its also possible to look at it in terms of percentage, so that it shows whether it is cheap or expensive.

An overview of what it tells us is fairly straightforward. It gives the current share price, divided by its profits. If it is rising, its undervalued. If it is falling, its overvalued. Its also possible to look at it in terms of percentage, so that it shows whether it is cheap or expensive. It also gives us a sense of whether it is undervalued or expensive. So, this measure is useful to help decide whether it is time to buy, or whether its time to sell. Its also possible to use it to help determine the level of risk, if any. Its also possible to compare it to similar companies to get an idea of whether its current share price is reasonable or too low.
paraphrase: A fundamental analysis of stock value involves comparing a company's share price to its profits. This is done by dividing the share price by its profits, providing a basic measure of undervaluation or overvaluation. If the ratio is rising, the stock is undervalued, while a falling ratio indicates overvaluation. This metric can also be expressed as a percentage to determine if a stock is cheap or expensive. Additionally, it provides insight into the stock's risk level and how it compares to similar companies. By analyzing this ratio, investors can make informed decisions about buying or selling a stock.

input: One of the nifty new features that debuted in Firefox 3.5 last week was support for the W3C Geolocation API Specification, a Web standard that can fake a GPS-like effect by using clues such as the Wi-Fi networks
continuation:
of your Internet service provider (ISP) to determine where the user is on any given Web page. Firefox 3.5 is currently only in testing, but Mozilla is looking at ways in which it could use this technology more broadly.

"We could build applications based around geolocation, where it is important that information is presented in exactly the same way, or based around geocoding, where it is important that information is accurate, or just applications where people want information to be presented in a new way," said Google Research Director Jeff Jarvis. "As this is a new feature, I think it is going to be exciting."

Geolocation is a natural extension of Geocoding, which adds more granularity to information about your IP address. Google is already working with partners like AT&T, Verizon, and Sprint, but Jarvis says the technology could even show you information about when, exactly, a user is in range of a Wi-Fi node in a new city. The feature is currently in limited use in Firefox 3.0.1. If it proves successful, it will also be possible in versions of Firefox with later versions of Geocoding.

"Geocoding could also be combined with
paraphrase:
One of the innovative new features unveiled in Firefox 3.5 last week was support for the W3C Geolocation API Specification, a web standard that can simulate a GPS-like effect by utilizing clues such as Wi-Fi networks provided by internet service providers (ISPs) to determine a user's location on any given web page. Firefox 3.5 is currently undergoing testing, and Mozilla is exploring ways to incorporate this technology more broadly.
As Jeff Jarvis, Research Director at Google, pointed out, the potential applications of this technology are vast. Geolocation could be used to create customized applications based on a user's location, geocoding applications that require precise information, or simply new ways to present information. According to Jarvis, "As this is a new feature, I think it is going to be exciting."
Geolocation builds upon geocoding, which provides more detailed information about a user's IP address. Google is currently collaborating with partners like AT&T, Verizon, and Sprint, but Jarvis believes the technology could even reveal information about when a user is within range of a Wi-Fi node in a new city. Currently, this feature is available in limited capacity in Firefox 3.0.1. If successful, it may be integrated into future versions of Firefox with improved geocoding capabilities.
Jarvis also suggested that geocoding could be combined with other technologies to create even more innovative applications. As the technology continues to evolve, the possibilities are endless.

input: A new travel site called Rome2Rio launches today, the brainchild of two ex-Microsoft employees, Michael Cameron and Bernard Tschirren. The sites main innovation? Its vehicle agnostic, in a way
continuation: , allowing you to book flights from any airport in Rome, as well as any airport in Brazil, Peru, Ecuador, or Mexico. The service is billed as a cheap way to see all of these countries in one trip. The service is expected to launch in Paris later this year, with destinations in Europe, India, and Latin America included. The company expects to raise more than $1.2 million in seed funding.
paraphrase: Rome2Rio, a fresh travel platform, debuts today, created by two former Microsoft employees, Michael Cameron and Bernard Tschirren. The site boasts an innovative feature, allowing users to book flights from any airport in Rome, Brazil, Peru, Ecuador, or Mexico, making it an affordable option to visit multiple countries in one trip. The service is expected to expand to Paris later this year, adding destinations in Europe, India, and Latin America. The company is eyeing to secure over $1.2 million in seed funding.

input:
The salesman, showman and visionary who dreamed up the Indianapolis 500 would be proud: The 100th running this weekend will host the first official sellout and one of its largest crowds to date.
But "Crazy" Carl G. Fisher --
continuation:
dubbed the "Father of Indy" by The Indianapolis Star in 1929 -- also wasn't exactly "an Indy fan," or even really a "poster child" of racing.
In his lifetime, Fisher (1875-1950) made headlines around the world with his exploits in the Indianapolis 500, which he made into an international spectacle. But he was also an aggressive force in politics, business and civic life, and he was far more closely associated with civic-minded civic life in his hometown of Columbus, Ind., than with any of his "sports" titles.
Here's more about Fisher, who was born in Columbus, Ind. in 1875.
Early days
A native of Columbus, Fisher was born in September of that year. He was the only son of Henry Fisher (1835-1879) and Sarah (Shumate) Fisher. The Fishers were prominent members of Columbus, where Henry Fisher was a successful farmer, and where his sister, Sarah, was an actress. Sarah Fisher served as treasurer of her brother's successful agricultural association.
In 1888, while still in his teens, Fisher began working at his father's farm, later expanding his operations into real estate, which he developed into a major investment
paraphrase:
The visionary behind the Indianapolis 500, Carl G. Fisher, would be proud of the 100th running this weekend, which marks the first official sellout and one of the largest crowds to date. However, Fisher, dubbed the "Father of Indy" by The Indianapolis Star in 1929, was not just a racing enthusiast. He was a multifaceted individual who made headlines globally with his exploits in the Indianapolis 500, while also being an influential force in politics, business, and civic life.
Fisher, born in Columbus, Indiana in 1875, was a native of the city. His father, Henry Fisher, was a successful farmer, and his mother, Sarah Shumate, was an actress. Fisher began working on his father's farm at a young age and later expanded his operations into real estate, developing a significant investment.
While Fisher's association with the Indianapolis 500 is well-known, his impact on civic life in Columbus, Indiana was equally profound. He was an aggressive force in politics, business, and civic life, and his contributions to the city were far-reaching.
In summary, Carl G. Fisher was a multifaceted individual who played a pivotal role in the development of the Indianapolis 500, while also making significant contributions to politics, business, and civic life in Columbus, Indiana. His legacy continues to be celebrated and remembered to this day.

Eastern Libyan forces have reportedly taken control of the town of Gharyan, less than 100 kilometers from

the city of Misrata where a national congress was elected in September, according to Al-Jazeera.

A military operation by General Khalifa Haftar's forces in southern Libya led to a cease-fire and a withdrawal of forces from Misrata, Libya's second-largest city. Haftar's forces, backed by Egypt, Egypt, Russia, Sudan, the United Arab Emirates, France, Israel, and Britain, launched Operation Dignity in April with the goal of wresting control from eastern-based government.
On Sunday, Haftar's forces launched an offensive with air support from Russia against Misrata, with more than 1,500 people killed in Misrata.
After more than 100 days of operation, Haftar's forces were able to seize control of Gharyan, according to Al-Jazeera. The town was previously under control of Misrata, although it is home to the city's airport, which is the only airfield in southern Libya. The town was also home to the Misrata military hospital, which was destroyed during the operation.
On Friday, Haftar's forces launched a series of airstrikes on Misrata, reportedly
paraphrase:
Eastern Libyan forces, led by General Khalifa Haftar, have reportedly taken control of the strategic town of Gharyan, located just 100 kilometers from Misrata, where a national congress was recently elected. This development comes after Haftar's forces launched Operation Dignity in April, backed by several international powers, to wrest control from the eastern-based government.
According to Al-Jazeera, Haftar's forces have been making gains in southern Libya, including the use of air support from Russia, resulting in significant casualties in Misrata. Following more than 100 days of fighting, Haftar's forces were able to seize control of Gharyan, which was previously under the control of Misrata. The town is home to the city's airport, the only airfield in southern Libya, and the Misrata military hospital, which was destroyed during the operation.
On Friday, Haftar's forces launched a series of airstrikes on Misrata, reportedly causing significant damage. While the exact details of the situation remain unclear, it is clear that the conflict in Libya continues to escalate, with both sides suffering significant losses.

According to authorities, some younger members of the Fourth Reich Skinheads of Orange County had developed a bias against Jews, blacks, and other ethnic minorities within the past year. Perhaps there was still a chance to reach out to them, offer assistance, and help them integrate into society.
During this time, the German people were actively working on a similar issue.
Sgt. James Scott, a deputy with the Orange County Sheriffs Department, was patrolling his area when he heard an unusual sound coming from within his patrol zone. input: Whyallas Citizen of the Year Karen Harrison has urged everyone to consider nominating a worthy community member, group or event for next years Australia Day Awards. The City of Whyalla has extended nominations for the 2019 Australia Day awards to
continuation: 30 September, following the success of its inaugural event in 2018. The awards, which were introduced in 2008, will recognise people, groups, organisations and events in Whyalla which have done outstanding or innovative work in service of Whyalla. input:
NOTTINGHAM  The sale of USA Springs property on Monday has been postponed for three months after the company filed for bankruptcy.
A representative from James St. James Auctioneers, of Manchester, which was scheduled to conduct the auction, confirmed company representatives
continuation:
were still working to find buyers, which will be done with the help of its attorney.
James St. James attorney Andrew T. Hart said, "As is customary, due diligence will be performed by our clients before any deal is consummated."
An attorney representing the company did not return multiple phone calls, email requests for comment or information on where it is located.
A petition filed in US Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Delaware in late May listed the assets, liabilities, cash reserves, and assets held by James St. James Auctioneers.
In January, James St. James Auctioneers was sued in state court in Hancock County in connection with a failed attempt to sell six properties in Hancock, Hills, Newton, Perry, Noble, and St. Clairs counties.
A former buyer of one of those properties, Andrew H. Smith, of Hancock, filed suit in 2018, claiming he was promised he could receive millions of dollars in commission, in the case of any successful auction.
"Mr. Smith is alleging that he will suffer irreparable injury if the sale is made before his due diligence is complete, if it goes forward, and/or if it is determined that Mr. Smith is, in fact,
paraphrase:
The sale of USA Springs property has been postponed indefinitely after the company filed for bankruptcy. According to a representative from James St. James Auctioneers, the company is still actively seeking buyers and has hired an attorney to assist with the process. The attorney, Andrew T. Hart, confirmed that due diligence will be conducted by the clients before any deal is finalized.
Despite multiple attempts to contact the company's attorney, they did not respond to phone calls, emails, or requests for comment. A petition filed in US Bankruptcy Court in Delaware in late May listed the company's assets, liabilities, cash reserves, and assets held by James St. James Auctioneers.
In January, James St. James Auctioneers was sued in state court in Hancock County over a failed attempt to sell six properties in the area. A former buyer of one of those properties, Andrew H. Smith, filed a lawsuit in 2018, claiming he was promised millions of dollars in commission if the auction was successful.
Smith is alleging that he will suffer irreparable injury if the sale goes forward without completing his due diligence first. The exact details of the sale and the company's financial situation remain unclear, as the company's attorney did not respond to requests for comment.
