BANKS FAVORED week-long term deposits this week, resulting in a sustained decline in yields for these papers despite an uptrend seen for longer tenors.
Offers for Wednesdays auction reached P60.829 billion
continuation: with banks placing P51.0 billion of this, with only a marginal underperformance when compared to last weeks offering. The average volume was P51.1 billion, with only one deal above its limit. The offer was above the limit of P50 billion set. The weighted average cost of funds stood at 0.75 percent this week, down 1.3 basis points from last weeks average. The seven-day, overnight, one-month, and six-month rates stood at 1.26 percent, 0.89 percent, 0.79 percent, and 1.37 percent, respectively, while one-week rates declined to 1.26 percent from 1.30 percent. The weighted average of the rates this week was 0.89 percent, 0.90 percent, 0.84 percent, 0.79 percent, and 0.76 percent. The seven-day tenor was unchanged from last week, while overnight rates declined by 1 basis point. The one-week tenor, meanwhile, rose 0.2 basis point this week to 1.06 percent from 1.05 percent. The weighted average cost of funds for this week was 1.29 percent, 0.95 percent, 0.
paraphrase:
BANKS PREFER LONGER TERM DEPOSITS
This week, banks favored week-long term deposits, leading to a consistent decrease in yields for these papers despite a steady uptrend in longer tenors. Offers for the upcoming auction amounted to P60.829 billion, with banks contributing P51.0 billion, with only a minor underperformance compared to the previous week's offering. The average volume was P51.1 billion, with only one deal exceeding its allocated limit. The offer was above the set limit of P50 billion. The weighted average cost of funds decreased by 1.3 basis points to 0.75 percent this week. The seven-day, overnight, one-month, and six-month interest rates were 1.26 percent, 0.89 percent, 0.79 percent, and 1.37 percent, respectively, while one-week rates fell to 1.26 percent from 1.30 percent. The weighted average of the rates for the week was 0.89 percent, 0.90 percent, 0.84 percent, 0.79 percent, and 0.76 percent. The seven-day tenor remained unchanged, while overnight rates declined by 1 basis point. The one-week tenor, on the other hand, rose by 0.2 basis points to 1.06 percent from 1.05 percent. The weighted average cost of funds for the week stood at 1.29 percent, 0.95 percent, and 0.84 percent.

input: The article below began by saying: "In a French comedy of, I think, the 16th century, there was a judge with a one-track mind, who kept asking the same question, 'Que diable allait-il faire en
continuation: Roumanie?' (What evil was he going to put in Roumanie?). Now in the English, or modern French, tongue, this is more or less easy, 'quand c'tait vieux, quand on tait jeune, quand on tait peintur, quand on tait joueur de jeux et quand on tait entretenu par le gnie,' when it was really much more difficult, 'quand c'tait mortel, quand c'tait mortel.' "I don't believe I've ever seen the above before, even in any edition of Voltaire, but I was glad when I came across it this afternoon. It seems like I've seen this sort of story in a variety of places, but it is really only in French (or at least in the French language, which I'm speaking in this article, although it's certainly in English) where one reads "What evil was he going to put in Roumanie?" It is really only in French where one reads "What evil was he going to put in Roumanie?"And why should one believe it to be more difficult to
paraphrase: In a vintage French comedy from the 16th century, a judge with a one-track mind persistently questioned, "What mischief was he planning for Roumanie?" (When it was really much more challenging to say, "What evil was he planning for Roumanie?") I have never seen this passage before, even in any edition of Voltaire's work, but I was delighted to come across it this afternoon. This sort of story appears to be common in French literature, but it's interesting to note that it's only in this language that one encounters such phrasing.

input:
Although final results are not expected until later, the scale of the predicted victory is such that the ruling Congress party has admitted defeat.
BJP leader Narendra Modi tweeted: "India has won. Good times ahead."
This is the most resounding
continuation:
defeat in Indias history. BJPs win will also bolster its hand in national politics, where polls suggest it will get its second majority. The BJPs performance will raise questions about the Congress partys ability to govern.
Despite losing power in Delhi, Congress leaders are reportedly celebrating in the state. "I congratulate people of Delhi. We are very happy, Congress chief Sonia Gandhi tweeted.
The election has been free, fair, and transparent. It will strengthen democracy in India."
As expected, Indias biggest opposition party, Congress, is losing Delhi. We thank people of Delhi, especially Delhiites, for sending us back to power, said BJPs working president J.P. Nadda.
In recent years, Congress leaders have tried to capitalize on divisions in Hindu India, projecting Mr. Modis Hindu nationalist agenda as an antidote. Mr. Modis government has launched major programs to provide jobs and strengthen Hindu culture, while the Congress partys leaders have largely failed. The BJPs popularity, however, has risen in recent years.
Mr. Modis BJP campaigned around
paraphrase:
Although the final results are still pending, the scale of the predicted victory is significant enough for the ruling Congress party to acknowledge defeat. BJP leader Narendra Modi tweeted, "India has emerged victorious. Exciting times lie ahead."
This election marks the most decisive defeat in India's history, with the BJP's victory set to bolster its position in national politics, where polls suggest it will secure its second consecutive majority. The BJP's performance has raised questions about the Congress party's ability to govern effectively.
Despite losing power in Delhi, Congress leaders are reportedly jubilant in other states. Congress chief Sonia Gandhi tweeted, "Congratulations to the people of Delhi. We are delighted."
The election has been hailed as free, fair, and transparent, further strengthening India's democratic fabric.
As expected, the Congress party is set to lose Delhi, with BJP working president J.P. Nadda expressing gratitude to the people of Delhi and Delhiites for entrusting the party with power once again.
In recent years, Congress leaders have sought to capitalize on sectarian divisions in India, positioning Mr. Modi's Hindu nationalist agenda as a remedy. Mr. Modi's government has launched ambitious programs to create jobs and fortify Hindu culture, while Congress leaders have struggled to maintain momentum. The BJP's popularity has surged in recent times.

input:
High tide has passed in Cork city without flooding although a flood warning remains in place for part of the city centre during tomorrow morning's high tide.
The council says high tides and potentially high winds may cause flooding between 6am and 8am tomorrow morning
continuation:
, which is currently expected at around 8.30am.
A spokeswoman said: "High tides are due in Cork city around 6am tomorrow (Wednesday, September 11, 2019) with a peak wave of approximately 6.8m, approximately twice as high as usual. This will be the second tide of the week, following a 7.6m peak in the same area on Tuesday (September 10).
"A warning will be in place from 6am this morning, with a possibility of flooding around 8am. A further, minor, advisory will be in place from 11.45am this morning (September 11, 2019) with a peak wave of approximately 6m.
"A further, minor advisory will be in place from 3pm this afternoon (September 11, 2019) with a peak wave of approximately 6.4m.
"As with any low tide, if possible avoid low-lying or low-lying roadways and areas of water, particularly in the city centre. Use extreme care when driving and use extra caution when near rivers or low-lying coastal areas. As with any low tide, this will be followed by periods of heavy rain, with possible localised flooding. If possible avoid low-lying or low
paraphrase:
Cork city has successfully navigated the high tide without any flooding, despite a flood warning still in effect for certain areas of the city center during tomorrow's morning high tide.
According to local authorities, the combination of high tides and strong winds may lead to flooding between 6 AM and 8 AM tomorrow, with a predicted peak wave height of approximately 6.8 meters, almost double the usual level. This will be the second high tide of the week, following a 7.6-meter peak in the same area yesterday.
A warning has been in place since 6 AM this morning, with the possibility of flooding expected around 8 AM. An additional, minor advisory will be issued at 11:45 AM with a peak wave height of approximately 6 meters. Another minor advisory will be issued at 3 PM today with a peak wave height of approximately 6.4 meters.
As with any low tide, motorists are advised to exercise caution when driving near rivers or low-lying coastal areas, and to avoid low-lying or low-lying roadways whenever possible. Heavy rain is also expected following the high tide, which may lead to localized flooding in certain areas.

input:
Jacksonville High School girls soccer coach John Mansholt will be coaching the MacMurray College mens soccer team this fall as well.
Mansholt is one of two new Highlander soccer coaches. MacMurray hired Andrew Len
continuation:
ahan to coach in the womens program in August.
I am thrilled to announce that Coach John Mansholt will be leading the MacMurray College Mens Soccer program this fall, MacMurray Athletics Director J.D. Smith said in a news release. Its going to be a tremendous experience. He has coached at one of the premier universities in the Midwest, the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, in the NCAA Division II Championships in 2006 and 2009. He knows what it takes to get a program back into elite national rankings. We are really excited to get him here and Im confident he will bring home MacMurrays first national championship.
A native of Almont, Illinois, Mansholt spent the previous six seasons with UW-Milwaukee, where he was co-assistant head coach. He was also in charge of the Wisconsin-Milwaukee womens program from 2008-11.
I am thrilled to be back in the mid-state, Mansholt said in the release. I grew up in the Chicago area, was an alumnus of Almont High School and played
paraphrase: John Mansholt, the former girls soccer coach at Jacksonville High School, will assume the role of men's soccer coach at MacMurray College this fall. MacMurray Athletics Director J.D. Smith expressed excitement about Mansholt's appointment in a recent press release, stating that it will be a "tremendous experience" for the college. With coaching experience at one of the top universities in the Midwest, the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, in the NCAA Division II Championships in 2006 and 2009, Mansholt brings a wealth of knowledge to the MacMurray program. The native of Almont, Illinois spent the previous six seasons at UW-Milwaukee, serving as co-assistant head coach and leading the women's program from 2008-2011. Mansholt is eager to return to the mid-state, having grown up in the Chicago area and attended Almont High School.

input: An activist of the Resistant Citizen, against the junta-backed constitution seals her mouth with duct tape and holds a placard reading ''7 Reasons To Not Accept Constitution'' during gathered to hold activities against the draft constitution, ahead of the August 7
continuation:
referendum in Yangon, Myanmar, on August 1.

Cambodian opposition leader Kem Ley is seen in this handout photo dated January 6, 2011. The former leader of the Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) says he is going into hiding after Cambodia charged him with illegal use of power. Ley, 68, was arrested on Sunday, according to a court document seen by Reuters, while attempting to board a flight from Phnom Penh to Phnom Penh, Cambodia, which he says was ordered by police to stop him. REUTERS/Cambodian Government/Handout via Reuters/Files
paraphrase:
An advocate of the Unyielding Citizen, protesting against the military-backed charter seals her lips with adhesive tape and carries a placard displaying "7 Reasons to Reject Constitution" during a gathering to mobilize against the upcoming referendum on August 7 in Yangon, Myanmar.
In a separate development, the leader of the Cambodian National Rescue Party (CNRP), Kem Ley, has gone into hiding after being charged with illegal use of power. Ley, 68, was arrested on Sunday while attempting to board a flight from Phnom Penh to Phnom Penh, according to a court document seen by Reuters.

input:
The U.S. Army veteran and Clarksville-based Realtor is the first Democrat to enter the race to replace Congressman Mark Green.
Democrat Juanita Charles, a U.S. Army veteran and Clarksville-based Realt
continuation:
or, is the first Democrat to enter the race to replace Congressman Mark Green, according to her campaign website.
In recent days, she began raising money for her campaign. The website says she was "raised in one of the poorest rural counties in Tennessee, and knows firsthand the struggle many Tennessee families are facing due to pandemic, joblessness, low wages, and rising cost of goods. She knows her values will stand with Tennesseans, and her fight will be for working families."
"I want to fight back. I want my voice heard, I want people in Washington to hear it, I want them to look me in the eye, I want them to say, 'You are here, I heard what you are saying, I hear what you are saying.' I want them to listen, I want them to listen, I want them to listen," Charles said. "I want them to say, 'I will listen, I want them to listen, I want them to listen,' because, look, when it is said, it is done. We are not going away. We are going to fight, we are going to fight back."
In 2018, Charles was one of only three Democrats elected in Mississippi. Last
paraphrase:
A newly announced Democrat candidate for Congress, Juanita Charles, brings a unique perspective as a U.S. Army veteran and local Realtor in Clarksville. According to her campaign website, Charles is the first Democrat to enter the race to replace Congressman Mark Green.
With a personal understanding of the struggles faced by many Tennessee families, particularly those affected by the pandemic, Charles is determined to fight for working families. In her own words, she wants to "fight back" and be heard by those in Washington, urging them to listen to her concerns and take action.
Charles' 2018 election victories as a Democrat in Mississippi demonstrate her ability to connect with voters and her dedication to advocating for their needs. As she enters the race to replace Congressman Green, Charles is poised to bring a fresh perspective to the table and make her voice heard in Washington.

input:
Dedicating a Sunday in May to sharing the gospel of Jesus Christ through music is a long-standing tradition at Wheaton's Gary United Methodist Church.
On Sunday, May 20, during the 9 and 11 a.m. services, the
continuation:
worship staff will take time to sing "Let Us Preach The Gospel", a hymn from the early 1800's. The hymn was written in German by a French Protestant preacher named Martin Luther, who wrote his "Acta Sanctorum", or "Act of the Congregation", in Geneva. The hymn is adapted from Paul Verlaine's "Let Us Pray". It is said to encourage us to share the gospel with others.
"What is it?" asks Pastor Gary Ziegert, "that brings people together?" He will offer his "take" on this hymn in a message entitled "Let Us Preach The Gospel: Celebrating 20 Years in The Church". He will also offer "a brief overview of how the hymn came to be in English in America, and what it has been used for in other denominations" (see bulletin, Sunday, May 20, 2018). "Let Us Preach The Gospel" will be performed with the church choir under the direction of Melody Smith. The service will conclude with the hymn "Amazing Grace", from John Newton. "Amazing Grace" was written in 1694, and was first heard sung in Charleston, SC, in 1842. "Amazing Grace"
paraphrase:
On a spring Sunday in May, Wheaton's Gary United Methodist Church will carry on a long-standing tradition by spreading the gospel of Jesus Christ through music. During the 9 and 11 a.m. services, the worship team will take time to perform a hymn from the early 1800s titled "Let Us Preach The Gospel." This hymn, penned by a French Protestant preacher named Martin Luther, has been adapted from Paul Verlaine's "Let Us Pray." The song aims to inspire people to share their faith with others.
During the service, Pastor Gary Ziegert will deliver a message entitled "Let Us Preach The Gospel: Celebrating 20 Years in The Church," in which he will provide his insights on this hymn. Additionally, he will provide an overview of how the hymn came to be in English in America and its use in other denominations (see bulletin, Sunday, May 20, 2018). The choir, led by Melody Smith, will perform the hymn with great enthusiasm. The service will conclude with the timeless hymn "Amazing Grace," which was written in 1694 and first heard sung in Charleston, SC, in 1842. This hymn, with its powerful lyrics, is sure to move listeners to reflect on the grace of God.

input: UNITED NATIONS, May 6 -- Answering a question about Iran on Thursday the UN Ambassador of Uganda, a member of the Security Council, said "we should not let the development of science makes nuclear weapons move faster than us, who are
continuation:
already way behind." The United States, she said, is still pressing for "strong sanctions" against Tehran. "There is still hope. We are still working with the other side."

Speaking to reporters just moments before United States Ambassador Richard Holbrooke presented to the UN Security Council his draft resolution on the Iranian nuclear program, she said: "I hope that it will succeed. We are still pushing, we are still working with the other side, and I think it will succeed. That is what we are working with. If it doesn't succeed, it will go down in history. I think it is something that we should avoid."

Referring to the possibility of new sanctions, she said: "Let me tell you something. I don't think that will happen. We are already way behind. The US is still pushing, we are still working with the other side. We are still pushing in the same way, which is why I am saying, 'Let's not let this development of science make us move faster than us, who are already way behind.'"

On the possibility of further sanctions, she said: "I believe that will go with the decision of the member states. I think it will also go
paraphrase: The Ugandan Ambassador to the United Nations expressed concerns about the rapid development of nuclear weapons in Iran, stressing that "we should not let science move faster than us, who are already behind." The Ambassador highlighted the United States' continued push for "strong sanctions" against Tehran, while expressing hope that a resolution will be reached through diplomatic efforts. Referencing the possibility of new sanctions, the Ambassador emphasized that "I don't think that will happen" and noted that the US is "still pushing" and "still working with the other side." On the likelihood of further sanctions, the Ambassador stated that the decision will depend on the member states' decisions.

input: A glimmer of light is flickering at the end of a dark tunnel at Dundee, whose supporters' trust, Dee4Life, has co-ordinated a Company Voluntary Arrangement (CVA) to pull the Scottish First Division club
continuation:
out of administration.

Dee4Life will be one of four supporters groups given access to 6m of debt to enable Dundee United, St Johnstone, Hearts and Hearts United to complete the current season, allowing them to benefit from 500,000 in extra funding from Scottish Football League members.

"At first, I thought I was going to get killed," said George Thomson, a former Dundee United board member, former board member of the city centre club and board member of St Johnstone. "I expected more anger, more hatred. It was just this tremendous feeling of optimism."

While it was never confirmed that Dundee United were going into administration, Mr Thomson said: "It was very much assumed that it was, although I think Dundee fans are too young or too innocent or too jaded, which is why it wasn't immediately apparent."

A joint investment of 500,000 from St Johnstone, United's owners Peter Lawwell and Steve Nicol, was one of a series of commitments made in Dundee, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Dundee, Stirling, East Dunbartonshire, Ayr, Ayrshire, Dumfries, Kilmarnock, Falk
paraphrase:
A ray of light is visible at the end of a dark tunnel in Dundee, where the supporters' trust, Dee4Life, has spearheaded a Company Voluntary Arrangement (CVA) to rescue the Scottish First Division club from administration.
Four supporters groups, including Dee4Life, will be granted access to 6 million pounds of debt to help Dundee United, St Johnstone, Hearts, and Hearts United complete the current season and receive an additional 500,000 pounds in funding from Scottish Football League members.
George Thomson, a former board member at Dundee United and St Johnstone, expressed his surprise at the positive reaction from fans, stating, "I thought I was going to get killed. I expected more anger, more hatred. It was just this tremendous feeling of optimism."
While the administration of Dundee United was not officially confirmed, Thomson revealed that it was "very much assumed" and believes that the club's young or innocent fans may be too naive to realize the situation.
A joint investment of 500,000 pounds from St Johnstone and the club's owners, Peter Lawwell and Steve Nicol, is one of several commitments made by clubs in Dundee, Edinburgh, Glasgow, and other surrounding areas.

input: Virginia Tech coach Frank Beamer, whose Hokies (3-3, 1-1 ACC Conference) are one of only two Football Bowl Subdivision schools to go to bowl games each of the past 22 seasons, is the winningest active coach (
continuation:
325-147-1) with three national titles. Virginia Tech is also in its first bowl game under Beamer. Virginia (1-6, 0-3) will be making its second bowl game under head coach Bronco Mendenhall. The Cavaliers played in the 2005 Citrus Bowl. The Virginia-Virginia Tech game is set for 1 p.m. ET Saturday on ESPN. (Dave Canham/Associated Press)

Virginia Tech head coach Frank Beamer said his No. 1 goal this season is to win eight of his first 11 games. He expects to achieve that goal, and his bowl game opponents are willing to bet it. Virginia is one of only two Football Bowl Subdivision programs, along with Syracuse, to go 7-1 or better in its first 11 games. "It'll be a challenge, but I'm looking forward to it," Beamer said. "It'll challenge us, certainly, in terms of getting us ready for what is coming. But it also gives us opportunities." Virginia Tech is still looking for its first win in eight tries, but it is 0-6 in bowl games under head coach Bronco Mendenhall. The Cavaliers were set to travel to Charlotte, N.C.
paraphrase:
Virginia Tech head coach Frank Beamer is aiming to lead his team to eight wins out of their first 11 games this season, and he's confident that they have the potential to achieve this goal. The Hokies are one of only two Football Bowl Subdivision programs to have consistently appeared in bowl games over the past 22 seasons, with Beamer as their head coach. Virginia Tech is set to face off against Virginia in their first bowl game under Beamer, while Virginia is making their second bowl appearance under head coach Bronco Mendenhall. The Cavaliers have a mixed record in bowl games, with Virginia Tech dominating the series. The teams will face off on Saturday at 1 p.m. ET on ESPN.
Beamer emphasized the importance of using these early season games as a challenge to prepare for the future, while also acknowledging the potential opportunities that come with the season. Despite Virginia Tech's impressive record, they are still searching for their first win in eight tries, while Virginia is looking to build on their 2005 Citrus Bowl appearance. The Hokies are set to travel to Charlotte, N.C. for their next game.

input:
Stocks: Emerging from a month-long funk?
April has been a tough month for investors, with the Nasdaq taking a sharp dive and the other major markets languishing in negative territory.
But U.S. stock futures were pointing
continuation:
to a rebound on Thursday, as investors try to put the worst month of trading in history into perspective. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, while the S&P 500 was 0.3% higher. The tech-heavy Nasdaq was off 0.1%.
"What it seems like this week is people have kind of been re-assessing where they want to be going into next year, and are just looking for a little bit more clarity of what's going to happen going forward, especially around earnings season," said Justin Lederer, investment strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald. "The stock market certainly is acting like people are beginning to get a bit more cautious, but I don't think we should interpret it as a step back."
As investors move into earnings season, which is expected to provide a major early signal of where this year will end, the futures are signaling modest optimism. Thats in contrast to last months selloff, which sent investors scrambling from stocks into government bonds.
Citigroup analysts led by Michael Weinstein are expecting earnings growth of 6.1% in the first quarter. Thats up from 5.6% in the previous quarter. The average analyst earnings-
paraphrase:
Investors may be witnessing a tentative recovery in the stock market after a tumultuous April, which saw the Nasdaq experience a sharp decline and other major markets linger in negative territory. U.S. stock futures point towards a rebound on Thursday, as investors attempt to put the worst month of trading in history into perspective. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 both edged higher, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq off slightly.
According to Justin Lederer, investment strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald, investors are currently reassessing their investment strategies and seeking clarity on what lies ahead, particularly in light of earnings season. While the stock market may be exhibiting some caution, Lederer believes this should not be misinterpreted as a step back.
As earnings season approaches, analysts at Citigroup, led by Michael Weinstein, are predicting earnings growth of 6.1% in the first quarter, up from 5.6% in the previous quarter. This represents a positive trajectory, contrasting with last month's selloff, which prompted investors to flee stocks and seek refuge in government bonds.

input: PHILADELPHIA  Today, electrophysiologists from Penn Medicine implanted the regions first subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) for sudden cardiac arrest, a potentially fatal electrical malfunction
continuation:
. The device was implanted in a 34-year-old Philadelphia male. The device was successfully implanted, with no complications, following standard procedures.

In more than two decades of studying human cardiac rhythms, Penn researchers say this was one of the few cases in which cardiac rhythm control could be disrupted by using cardiac pacing rather than medications. The researchers, led by Dr. Michael Rabin, director of Penns cardiac pacemaker center, report in the August 6, 2012 edition of Circulation: Cardiovascular Imaging, Cardiology, the first successful subcutaneous implantation of ICD-defibrillators. The device was implanted in a 34-year-old Philadelphia male. It was successful in slowing his death. The implantation was performed under standard anesthesia.

Sudden cardiac arrest occurs when cardiac tissue is deprived of oxygen. It is common in people of any age, especially younger adults. It is also common in young children and in people with chronic cardiac conditions. Sudden cardiac arrest, which happens approximately every 20 minutes in the United States, is one of the leading causes of death in people younger than 70. It is also one of the leading causes of death in young children under 6. The device was implanted
paraphrase: Today, electrophysiologists from Penn Medicine successfully implanted a subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) in a 34-year-old Philadelphia man, marking a significant breakthrough in the treatment of sudden cardiac arrest. This was one of the rare cases where cardiac rhythm control was disrupted by using cardiac pacing rather than medications, according to the researchers led by Dr. Michael Rabin, director of Penn's cardiac pacemaker center. The successful implantation of the device was documented in the August 6, 2012 edition of Circulation: Cardiovascular Imaging, Cardiology. The ICD was implanted under standard anesthesia, and it successfully slowed the patient's death. Sudden cardiac arrest, which occurs when the heart muscle is deprived of oxygen, affects people of all ages, including younger adults, children, and those with chronic cardiac conditions. It is a leading cause of death in the United States, occurring approximately every 20 minutes, and is also a major cause of death in young children under the age of 6.

input: HOUSTON - Feb. 17, 2018 - PRLog -- Demetria Smith is a mortgage broker and community activist. She recently made headlines when the Democratic Party wrongly bumped her from the primary ballot, over a banking mix-up that caused her filing
continuation:
fees to jump nearly 80 percent.

"I've never been in politics, Smith said. "I've never done this before.

Smith said the election is not about politics. Its about whether she will be left behind, with her mortgage business, her church, her children, her career, and her job.

"I am concerned, Smith said. "I'm concerned that I may be asked to move out of Houston, that I may find myself without job opportunities, and that my children may have to move out of Houston without me. I want them to stay. I want them to stay here, but I need them to stay here. I'm concerned.

Smith said she's ready to fight, just like she was with her Democratic opponent, Tony Buza, in this years election. But Smiths opponent also was slammed in news coverage, which Smith says she never saw.

It really upset me, Smith said. "I didnt see it. I was not on any news sources or anything.

Demetria Smith is running to represent Harris County in the
paraphrase:
Demetria Smith, a passionate mortgage broker and community leader, has recently made waves in the political scene. Despite her best efforts, the Democratic Party inadvertently disqualified her from the primary ballot due to a banking error that increased her filing fees by nearly 80 percent.
Smith, a political newcomer, emphasized that the election is not about party politics, but rather about her personal fight for survival. With her mortgage business, church, children, career, and job on the line, Smith expressed her concerns about the possibility of being left behind in Houston.
"I'm deeply troubled," Smith said. "I'm worried that I may be asked to leave Houston, leaving my children and job behind. I want them to stay here, but I need them to stay here. It's a concern that weighs heavily on my mind."
Inspite of her doubts, Smith remains determined to fight for her goals, much like her previous battle with her Democratic opponent, Tony Buza, in this year's election. However, Smith lamented that her opponent also received unfavorable media coverage, which she was unaware of.
"It hurt me deeply," Smith revealed. "I didn't see it. I didn't appear on any news sources or platforms."
Despite the setbacks, Demetria Smith is determined to represent Harris County and fight for the issues that matter most to her and her community.

As the first heavy fighting began in eastern Ukraine in early May, with an attempt by Ukrainian forces to retake
continuation: control of Slaviansk, thousands of women, young children, and elderly people came out onto the citys squares. At times it looked like the scenes from Hollywood films, where the good guys in blue uniforms try to push back a Russian army occupying buildings in a city under siege. But these were people of the new generation, born just a few years ago, and they were mostly young women. In one of them, Nina, I recognized a look I recognized: it was one of the first signs of this crisis. The women were organizing, in one of the citys few womens groups, in response to what, in Ukraine, was called the Maidan, in which thousands of people took to the streets of Kiev in early January in opposition to the government of Ukraines new president, Viktor Yushchenko, in support of the European integration agenda. It was, in effect, the Maidan in action. The police were violent, and the protesters were often violent, too. The Maidan was eventually succeeded by what are called pro-European protests, which took place almost daily in the following few months. It was also around this time, in January
paraphrase: On May 8, the text of this post was updated and expanded, appearing in the June 5, 2014 issue of The New York Review. Amidst the early May fighting in eastern Ukraine, where Ukrainian forces were attempting to retake control of Slaviansk, thousands of women, children, and elderly individuals gathered in city squares. The scene resembled Hollywood movie scenes where good guys in blue uniforms fight against a Russian army occupying buildings in a besieged city. However, these were the new generation - mostly young women - born just a few years earlier. One of them, Nina, looked familiar, a sign of the crisis that was brewing. The women organized themselves in one of the city's few women's groups, responding to the Maidan, a protest in Ukraine that began in early January in opposition to the government of Ukraine's new president, Viktor Yushchenko, and support for European integration. The police were violent, and protesters were equally violent. The Maidan evolved into pro-European protests occurring almost daily in the following months. This was around the time when the protests in January (known as the Maidan) began.

input:
BEREA, Ohio -- Trent Richardson and Alfred Morris are good friends, a couple of rookie halfbacks hailing from the same hometown who reached the NFL via different routes.
Richardson came to the Browns from a major college in the first
continuation:
round, Morris from Toledo. Now it appears the former Michigan teammates will get together this offseason in Columbus, where Morris is a graduate assistant with the Buckeyes. The Browns signed Morris in free agency in April, sending Richardson home. He didn't get in much preseason action.
"I've always been looking forward to it, even more so this year, with just getting to meet them in person," Morris said of Richardson and the Browns. "It'll be fun, just making it happen."
Morris grew up in Toledo. He said he still goes to the game at Toledo every year.
"I was just fortunate enough to be from Toledo, and it was just the natural progression, I always dreamed of going into Toledo, but it was something else when I heard about the Browns, especially with them getting this No. 1 pick," Morris said. "It was just surreal."
It's easy to understand why Morris wanted to play for the Browns. After all, the Browns drafted him in the third round with the 95th overall pick. The Browns took Richardson in the first round, making him the first running back drafted.
Morris ran into Richardson, who was at the Toledo home opener when Morris played with his hometown
paraphrase: Trent Richardson and Alfred Morris, two rookie halfbacks from the same hometown, are reuniting off the field this offseason. Richardson, who was drafted by the Browns in the first round, and Morris, who joined the team as a free agent in April, will meet up in Columbus, where Morris is a graduate assistant with the Buckeyes. Although they didn't get much preseason action, Morris is excited to catch up with his former Michigan teammate. Growing up in Toledo, Morris still attends the annual Toledo game and dreamed of playing for the Browns, particularly after they selected him in the third round with the 95th overall pick. Despite being drafted earlier than Morris, Richardson was impressed by the Browns' decision to choose him in the first round.

input:
UN official says footage of Sri Lankan troops executing rebel soldiers is genuine.
The footage was shot during the final stages of the Sri Lankan army's battle against the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE).
Alston said
continuation:
it was "incredibly disturbing" that "many people in Sinhalese society are still in denial of what happened in 2009."
"It was a terrible crime  the shooting of innocent men, women and children, Alston said.
It is shameful that it is still considered acceptable in many parts of Sri Lanka, especially in parts of Tamil-speaking communities."
Alston urged Sri Lanka to "put its people, its values and its human rights first" and "do its utmost to eradicate the culture of denial."
Sri Lankas government says that hundreds of LTTE soldiers were killed in 2008 in heavy cross-border raids into Tamil-speaking areas of the island. That came just one year before Sri Lankas civil war began.
A military spokesman said in August this year that nearly one-third of the 200,000 people killed in Sri Lankas war were civilians.
The final, decisive days of the LTTEs struggle for freedom in 2008 were marred by brutal reprisals by Sri Lankas armed forces, said Alston, adding that military personnel shot, killed, or arrested hundreds of people, according to witnesses.
Al
paraphrase:
The United Nations special rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions, Balakrishna P. Alston, has expressed concern over footage showing Sri Lankan troops executing Tamil Tiger rebels in 2009. Alston described the footage as "incredibly disturbing," noting that many in Sinhalese society are still in denial about the atrocities committed during the final stages of the civil war.
Alston emphasized that it is "shameful" that such acts of violence are still considered acceptable in some parts of Sri Lanka, particularly in Tamil-speaking communities. He urged the government to prioritize the well-being of its citizens and work towards eradicating a culture of denial.
According to Sri Lanka's government, hundreds of LTTE soldiers were killed in cross-border raids in 2008. However, Alston disputes this claim, citing eyewitness accounts of brutal reprisals by Sri Lankan armed forces during the final days of the conflict. He estimates that nearly one-third of the 200,000 people killed during the war were civilians.
Overall, Alston's statement highlights the ongoing struggle for justice and accountability in Sri Lanka, as well as the need for the government to address the ongoing impact of the civil war on its citizens.

input:
Max Levchin, the founder of recently-acquired Slide and co-founder of PayPal, has been named Google's newest vice president of engineering.
Levchin joined the company as part of Google's $182 million acquisition of Slide, the company
continuation:
he co-founded in 2007. The company, which specializes in collaboration software, was already profitable when it was sold, with nearly $400 million in cash on its balance sheet.
Levchin, who has worked in Silicon Valley for 30 years, was previously president of PayPal from 2000 to 2007. He is set to start at Google on Oct. 20.
"Google is poised to disrupt multiple industries in multiple dimensions. That was certainly demonstrated with Google+ from the beginning, which was something of a re-launched social network with some significant advances and also some significant holes in the product offering, which was one of the first things I saw when I joined Google. Google's incredible resources, its incredible ability to develop things in record time, its ability to develop amazing things faster than almost any company, I could go back to, it was just incredible. That doesn't exist in any other industry, whether it is in biotech or whether it is in semiconductors or automobiles or software or communications, you just don't get that kind of talent."  Levchin in an interview with Recode.
Levchin said he came to Google with his own "very basic ideas" for his new venture, including creating new collaboration tools. He
paraphrase:
Max Levchin, the co-founder of Slide and former president of PayPal, has been appointed as Google's new vice president of engineering.
Levchin joined Google as part of its acquisition of Slide, a company he founded in 2007. At the time of the acquisition, Slide was already profitable and had a significant amount of cash on its balance sheet. With over 30 years of experience in Silicon Valley, Levchin brings a wealth of knowledge and expertise to his new role at Google.
In an interview with Recode, Levchin expressed his excitement about Google's potential to disrupt various industries. He highlighted the company's incredible resources, speed of development, and ability to create amazing products quickly as major advantages. Levchin also shared his own ideas for new collaboration tools he plans to develop at Google.

input:
An illustration of the Apple Inc. logo taken on Jan. 30, 2015 in Lille, France.
Sometime in 2000, my colleague Verlyn started bringing his Mac laptop to our New York Times editorial board meetings. The rest of us would
continuation:
load the PC into his car, drive it from our office in Manhattan, and bring him back home to change clothes, shower, sleep. But Verlyn never needed to buy anything extra. He was just Apple.
Apple, of course, is a company that values its members of staff. We were thrilled to hear from one of our advertisers in 1999, when I was working in the advertising department, when his wife, a former Times staffer, called him to say she was pregnant with their first baby. Verlyn, who was still working, had made it home in time from a vacation in Arizona. He'd left his company job before he found out, with its long commute, and he hadn't even put his computer away. He was just Apple.
As I was in the late-90s making my first trip to Apple headquarters, I saw exactly what Verlyn saw in his job: he was Apple. I was Apple. A company like Apple is never more aware of its staff, its people, its employees, than when they are in the thick of it. It's also never more appreciative of its staff. It also never has a clearer understanding of what drives them, and, in ways that are hard to quantify
paraphrase:
In early 2015, I captured an image of the Apple Inc. logo in Lille, France. This was during a time when my colleague Verlyn was regularly bringing his Mac laptop to our New York Times editorial board meetings. The rest of us would load our PCs into his car and drive them from our office in Manhattan, while Verlyn would use the opportunity to change clothes, shower, and rest. Despite the inconvenience of transporting our equipment, Verlyn never needed to purchase any additional items, as he was simply an embodiment of the Apple brand.
Apple, as a company, values its employees above all else. We were delighted to hear from one of our advertisers in 1999 that Verlyn's wife, a former Times staffer, was pregnant with their first child. Verlyn, who was still working, had made it home in time from a vacation in Arizona, despite his long commute. He had left his corporate job before finding out the news, and he hadn't even put his computer away. He was simply an extension of the Apple brand.
During my first trip to Apple headquarters in the late 1990s, I witnessed firsthand what drew Verlyn to his job: he was Apple incarnate. I, too, was a part of the Apple family. A company like Apple becomes acutely aware of its staff, its people, and its employees when they are facing challenges head-on. It also becomes more appreciative of its staff and gains a deeper understanding of what drives them, even when it's difficult to quantify.

input: An interview with Ted Koppel, a favorite former journalist on the liberal left was brought to light by NewsBusters Monday. Like most people reading the article, I was taken aback by Koppels honesty about the current state of
continuation:
journalism. The former anchor of the PBS program Washington Week revealed his dislike of journalism, which is why he joined with other conservative pundits, like Bill Hemmer of Fox News, to fight the news media when it was beginning its march into far-left positions. Koppels interview is a welcome sight for conservative conservatives, who need people like Koppel in order to stand with them in the war on journalism. As Koppel, one of Americas most respected news anchors, said, I dont like it. His interview with Paul Begala, also from MSNBC, is a bit more interesting, but in the end its still a bit of a puff piece. Heres Begalas response, which is more of a back-and-forth with Koppel rather than a real conversation.

1. Why is it important for conservative conservatives like Koppel and Begala, especially, to stand up for journalism these days?

I think its important. We need people like Ted Koppel in conservative media. I dont think hes an extremist. But I
paraphrase: It's crucial for conservative voices like Ted Koppel and Paul Begala, especially, to uphold the integrity of journalism in today's media landscape. With the news industry shifting towards a more left-leaning perspective, it's essential to have influential figures like Koppel who can offer a balanced perspective and challenge the dominant narrative. By standing up for journalism, Koppel and Begala can help to ensure that the medium remains a trustworthy source of information and maintains its commitment to fact-based reporting. Additionally, their involvement in the conversation can foster a more constructive dialogue between different ideological viewpoints, leading to a more informed and engaged citizenry.

input:
Researchers have developed a new compound that may soon be developed into an effective treatment for melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer.
Melanoma may be halted by a newly developed drug.
Skin cancer is the most pervasive form of cancer in
continuation:
people worldwide. About 1 in 8 people develop skin cancer, according to the American Cancer Society. It occurs in almost every place on the body, except in the lungs, digestive organs, bones, blood, brain, spinal cord, liver, cervix, or uterine lining.
It is estimated that approximately 280,000 people in the United States will develop melanoma in 2018. The disease typically strikes people in their late teens or early 20s.
More than half of melanoma cases are located in the skin, with lesions that can range in size from 1-in-500-pound slivers to melanomas of larger sizes. The disease also is common in the mucosa, or lining of the digestive tract, and in lymph nodes, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
A new compound in clinical development is believed to target melanocytes, a type of melanin-producing cells in skin. Melanocytes are believed to be involved in cancer.
Dr. Chuan-Chuan Yin of the Comprehensive Cancer Center, University of Michigan Medical School, led the new research. His research, funded in part by the National Institutes of Health, was published in Nature Chemical Biology.
A melanocyte is an immature
paraphrase:
Scientists have created a potential treatment for melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer.
According to the American Cancer Society, skin cancer is the most common form of cancer in people worldwide, affecting approximately 1 in 8 individuals. Melanoma, the most severe form of skin cancer, is estimated to affect 280,000 people in the United States in 2018, with the majority of cases occurring in the skin and mucosa (lining of the digestive tract).
Researchers have discovered a new compound that may target melanocytes, a type of cell responsible for producing melanin in the skin. These cells are believed to play a role in cancer development. The study, led by Dr. Chuan-Chuan Yin of the Comprehensive Cancer Center at the University of Michigan Medical School, was funded in part by the National Institutes of Health and published in Nature Chemical Biology.
While melanocytes are immature cells, they have the potential to develop into cancerous cells, making them an attractive target for cancer treatment. The new compound is currently in clinical development and holds promise as a potential treatment for melanoma.

input:
Cobblers midfielder Sam Foley has given an interesting insight into the differences between playing for current manager Keith Curle and former boss Dean Austin.
Austin was handed the permanent job following a brief stint as caretaker manager at the end of last season,
continuation:
with the 45-year-old in temporary charge in September.
With a season in charge under his belt, Austin signed off with three straight league victories, while he also produced one of his best performances as a Cobblers boss, with a battling 3-0 victory over Lincoln Town.
While he was happy with his side's performance, Austin admitted it was "very difficult" facing his former club on Tuesday.
Foley, meanwhile, played under Austin when Curle took over as head coach in January 2016, with the midfielder also enjoying one game under Curle in his time with MK Dons in January 2018.
"Dean is very similar in many ways to Keith. I think it was like that from day one. He has obviously got his own ideas, which is fine, which is fine. He is also someone who is very much into the game, knows exactly what he wants, knows exactly what he is looking for in terms of what he needs from his squad, his coaching staff, his game, said Foley.
"I think in terms of him, I dont think any new head coach is going to go in and want to have the same methods. I think the way he is is
paraphrase:
Sam Foley, a midfielder for Cobblers, has provided an insightful perspective on the contrasts between playing under current manager Keith Curle and his predecessor Dean Austin.
Austin was appointed as the permanent manager last season following a temporary stint as caretaker manager in September. During his season in charge, Austin secured three consecutive league victories and notched a notable 3-0 win over Lincoln Town, one of his finest performances as Cobblers boss.
While Austin was pleased with his team's performance, he acknowledged the challenges of facing his former club on Tuesday.
Foley has experience playing under both Curle and Austin. When Curle took over as head coach in January 2016, Foley was a part of the team. He also played one game under Curle during his time with MK Dons in January 2018.
"Dean and Keith are quite similar in many ways," Foley said. "I think that was evident from the start. He has his own ideas, which is fine, and he's someone who is very knowledgeable about the game and knows exactly what he wants from his squad, coaching staff, and playing style."
Foley continued, "I don't think any new head coach is going to come in and want to maintain the same methods. He's got his own way of doing things."

input:
The Burroughs High School girls varsity basketball team continued its winning streak on Tuesday night after a 59-35 win over Hesperia High School.
The win came on Senior Night, and advanced the girls to 9-0 in the Mojave
continuation:
League with eight games left.
"It was nice to get this one done with seniors, I think it was really nice to just get the win before everybody left, it was nice to put it away before everybody left," said first-year head coach Trenice Harris. "It was fun, I'm glad it was Senior Night, it was nice."
It was a back-and-forth game with Hesperia, as the girls trailed 14-9 in the first quarter. The Aztecs picked up their pace in the second quarter and trailed 23-18 going into halftime.
The Aztecs took control of the game in the third quarter, scoring 23 points in the period. The Aztecs extended their lead in the fourth quarter, scoring 28 points. The final score was 59-35.
"It was nice, we didn't get too big, it was nice, we were able to slow things down, I think it really helped us, I think it was really important, it was important for us to kind of stay with them in the second half, it was important to kind of get into it," Harris said.
It was Harris first victory in her first season with the girls varsity basketball
paraphrase:
The Burbank High School girls varsity basketball team continued their winning streak on Tuesday night with a 59-35 victory over Hesperia High School.
The win marked a significant milestone for the team, as it advanced them to 9-0 in the Mojave League with eight games remaining. First-year head coach Trenice Harris expressed her delight at the win, highlighting the importance of Senior Night and the team's resilience in overcoming a slow start.
The game was a closely contested affair, with the teams trading baskets throughout the evening. The Aztecs trailed by nine points in the first quarter but managed to pull ahead in the second period, going into halftime with a 23-18 advantage.
In the third quarter, the Aztecs asserted their dominance, scoring 23 points and extending their lead. They continued their strong performance in the fourth quarter, pouring in 28 points to seal the victory.
Harris credited her team's ability to stay focused and composed under pressure, particularly in the second half, as a key factor in their success. She also highlighted the importance of staying united and working together as a team.
Overall, the victory marked a significant moment in the team's season, with Harris expressing her excitement at the potential for further success in the remaining games.

input:
With a little knowledge and understanding of car insurance, you can best optimize your insurance purchase and enjoy great benefits in the future.
While zeroing in on car insurance, low insurance premium often remains the sole deciding factor.
There is no denying the
continuation:
benefits of having adequate insurance coverage, yet with limited resources available, it is important that one considers a few of insurance factors when calculating premiums. Here are a few of them.
An understanding of car insurance coverage
The main benefits of owning a car include its mobility and ease of transportation. If your car is damaged beyond repair or stolen, insurance is of utmost importance. The same applies if, like me, you are constantly on the move. The greater the distance you cover, the greater your need for insurance. A car that costs one or two times what it should is obviously more expensive. A car should also be insured with a significant deductible. This way, even if damage occurs, it doesnt take any significant amount of money to repair.
How much is too much?
While one car insurance company may offer the same coverage, other may not. As with other life insurance, one must be aware of what kind of coverage one needs. A few factors are also important in this regard. Ones driving habits, factors such as traffic, accidents, weather, and road conditions are just some of the things one should factor in when calculating auto insurance premiums. It is important to choose car insurance based on its coverage level
paraphrase:
With some knowledge and comprehension of car insurance, you can optimize your insurance purchase and reap advantageous benefits in the future.
While focusing on car insurance, a low premium is frequently the determining factor.
Car insurance coverage is crucial, but with limited resources, it's important to consider a few factors when calculating premiums. Here are some of them.
Understanding Car Insurance Coverage
The primary advantages of owning a car include mobility and easy transportation. If your vehicle is damaged beyond repair or stolen, insurance is vital. This is especially true if you're constantly on the move, as the greater the distance you cover, the greater your need for insurance. A car that costs one or two times what it should is significantly more expensive. It's also essential to have a substantial deductible, so even if damage occurs, it doesn't take a significant amount of money to repair.
How Much is Enough?
While one car insurance provider may offer the same coverage, another might not. As with other forms of insurance, it's important to understand what kind of coverage you need. Certain factors are also crucial in this regard. Your driving habits, such as traffic, accidents, weather, and road conditions, are just some of the factors you should consider when calculating auto insurance premiums. It's essential to select car insurance based on its coverage level.

input:
Euro zone finance ministers and the International Monetary Fund began their third attempt in as many weeks to release emergency aid for Greece on Monday, with policymakers saying a write-down of Greek debt is off the table for now.
Greek Finance Minister Yannis St
continuation:
ournaras said in a radio interview that he expects "a resumption of aid negotiations" in August. He said "very big steps" are needed to avoid the country running out of money before then.
"I will say this. A new, significant step is needed before (we) talk about new aid money for Greece," Stournaras told Radio Crete. He said further aid was needed in July.
"I am optimistic," he said. "It is not a new, new discussion, it is an attempt to try to build confidence and new confidence is needed."
Greek bond yields rose in early trade on news of negotiations, with 10-year yields rising 2 basis points to 11.89 percent. The cost of insuring Greece's debt rose by 7 basis points.
The ministers are in the Netherlands, where they are expected to meet with the head of the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde, as well as members of the European Central Bank (ECB), according to participants.
ECB president Mario Draghi, in his latest news conference on Tuesday, said he could not rule out further aid from the ECB if needed, although it was important to avoid going back on commitments made when he took
paraphrase: Eurozone finance ministers and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have embarked on their third attempt in as many weeks to provide emergency aid to Greece, with policymakers emphasizing that a write-down of Greek debt is not on the table for now. Greek Finance Minister Yannis Stournaras has expressed optimism about the possibility of new aid in August, stating that "very big steps" are required to avoid the country running out of money before then. Participants in the meetings revealed that the ministers are set to meet with IMF head Christine Lagarde and members of the European Central Bank (ECB) in the Netherlands. ECB President Mario Draghi acknowledged that further aid from the ECB may be necessary, while stressing the importance of avoiding previous commitments.

input: President Donald Trump tweeted on Tuesday about prisoners of war, and was immediately and deservedly deluged with replies and retweets regarding the late Sen. John McCain, a former POW with whom Trump frequently clashed and who he famously insulted over being captured
continuation:
during his first presidential run. (McCain died in 2018 of brain cancer, which was reportedly diagnosed in his final months.)

Its always sad when POWs are released, Trump tweeted.

McCain was diagnosed with brain cancer in August of 2018, after he was elected to Congress in 2000. He was released from captivity in Vietnam in 1973. He served in Vietnam from 1962-63. McCain was awarded a Purple Heart, two Bronze Stars, a Distinguished Service Cross, six Purple Hearts, seven Meritorious Service Medals, six Air Medals, eight Air Medals, seven Defense Meritorious Service Medals, and one other commendation. He also served in the Senate from 1986-2009.

Heres what people had to say.

Some of his critics called McCain the war hero:

McCain was awarded multiple Medals of Honor, including one posthumously: The Purple Heart.

Youre a war hero, McCains wife, Cindy, said, before he was buried in Arizona this month.

McCain also spoke publicly in support of torture:

Here is @
paraphrase:
President Donald Trump tweeted on Tuesday about prisoners of war, sparking a wave of replies and retweets regarding the late Senator John McCain, a former POW with whom Trump had a contentious relationship. McCain passed away in 2018 due to brain cancer, which was diagnosed in his final months.
In his tweet, Trump expressed sadness at the release of POWs, but his statement was met with criticism from McCain's supporters, who praised him as a war hero. McCain was awarded numerous medals, including a Purple Heart and two Bronze Stars, for his service in Vietnam. He was released from captivity in 1973 and went on to serve in the Senate from 1986 to 2009.
McCain's widow, Cindy, publicly praised her husband as a war hero, while some of his critics referred to him as such. However, McCain himself had spoken publicly in support of torture, which was a controversial position.

input:
A railroad groups lawsuit against a state plan to remove 34 miles of train tracks has been delayed again, this time until the end of January.
Suzanne Messer, a lawyer for the Adirondack Railway Preservation Society, said
continuation:
in a phone interview this week that she was concerned about the environmental impact of hauling material out of the region. That includes, she said, possible air pollution from hauling off dead trees, roads, buildings and other environmental debris.
A state environmental report said removal of the tracks could create significant environmental damage. But the state Department of Environmental Conservation in late August approved the companys proposal, allowing it to move ahead with excavation.
Messer said she was also concerned that construction of new tracks, needed to extend its route, could damage roads and wetlands. The company filed a motion with state Supreme Court in early September challenging environmental law, citing its environmental concerns, according to court records. A hearing is pending.
Messer said she didnt know when her client, based in Oneida, will file its court appeal, if it is filed, and when it will go before the state Supreme Court. But she said she hopes to hear from state attorneys before January.
I am confident this will go before the court, she said.
A spokeswoman said Gov. Andrew Cuomos office has been unable to confirm whether he will support the companys appeal. A message left with
paraphrase: The railroad group has faced another delay in its lawsuit against the state's plan to remove 34 miles of train tracks, with the new deadline set for the end of January. According to Suzanne Messer, a lawyer for the Adirondack Railway Preservation Society, the group is concerned about the environmental impact of hauling material out of the region, including possible air pollution from removing dead trees, roads, buildings, and other debris. The state environmental report has highlighted the potential for significant environmental damage from the track removal, but the state Department of Environmental Conservation approved the company's proposal in late August, allowing it to proceed with excavation. Messer has also expressed concerns about the potential damage to roads and wetlands from the construction of new tracks to extend the route. The company has filed a motion with the state Supreme Court, challenging environmental law and citing its environmental concerns, and a hearing is pending. Messer declined to provide an update on when her client may file its court appeal, but she expects to hear from state attorneys before January. Despite the delay, Messer remains confident that the case will go before the court. A spokesperson for Governor Andrew Cuomo's office has been unable to confirm whether the governor will support the company's appeal.

input:
BOSTON -- CC Sabathia snapped out of his Red Sox funk, striking out 10 in six innings to beat Boston for the first time in five tries this season and lead the New York Yankees to a 5-2 victory Tuesday.
The win
continuation:
kept the Yankees 1.5 games back in the AL East, but they still could win it with a win in their final series of the season. Boston is in sole possession of second place, while the Yankees are in third. The Yankees are still chasing the Twins for the No. 1 seed.
"I'm in it, I'm still battling, still feeling it, still pushing, still trying to go as hard as I can," said Sabathia, who allowed one earned run and seven hits with six strikeouts. "I don't like it, I don't like feeling like this. I don't like it one bit. It was good to get back on track."
Sabathia (6-6) said he "kind of was feeling it" before his six-hitter. The Yankees did, too, scoring twice in the fifth inning. Brett Gardner led off with a double off the wall in left-center, scoring Greg Bird from first base when shortstop Brett Gardner made a diving grab. Greg Bird later hit a tying home run off reliever Matt Barnes (1-1) into the Monster, and Brett Gardner added an insurance run in the seventh.
It was Gardner's 23rd home run of the season
paraphrase:
New York pitcher CC Sabathia emerged from a slump against Boston, striking out 10 in six innings to help the Yankees secure a 5-2 victory Tuesday.
The win kept the Yankees 1.5 games behind the division leaders, but they still have a chance to clinch the top seed with a final series win. The Red Sox are currently in second place, while the Yankees are in third.
Sabathia (6-6) expressed his determination to keep fighting, despite feeling frustrated with his recent performance. "I'm still giving it my all, still pushing hard," he said. "I don't enjoy feeling like this, but it was good to get back on track."
The Yankees broke through with two runs in the fifth inning, thanks to a double by Brett Gardner and a subsequent RBI from Greg Bird. Gardner later hit a tying home run off reliever Matt Barnes, and Brett Gardner added an insurance run in the seventh.
It was Gardner's 23rd home run of the season.

input: In a shameful first, in 2016 TN Assembly elections, polling in two constituencies was put off due to the pernicious effect of money power, to quote the EC. In a telling indictment of the States political class
continuation:
, in those constituencies, the ruling AIADMKs own ministers were also elected. On January 11, Tamil Nadu will go to polls. For one week, polls will also be conducted in the RK Nagar assembly segment in Chennai, which was also put off. If this was the first time in Tamil Nadu, it was indeed a record. But it is also in the second election in Madras (now Tamil Nadu)s 20-year history, where, while the ruling party is expected to retain power, there is much talk of a hung Assembly. Why are these elections important, given the ruling partys continued hold?

In 2016, the ruling AIADMK was not only elected with more or less 200-odd constituencies, but also managed to win control of more or less 100. The BJP managed only 23 of these. This is, in part, due to the decision of voters in the RK Nagar segment. That it was put off in April 2016 is, of course, understandable: The Congress presence in this segment is quite low, while the BJP, in its push to gain in other parts of the city, was making gains. The ruling party, however, did
paraphrase: In a remarkable first, the 2016 Tamil Nadu Assembly elections saw polling disrupted in two constituencies due to the corrupting influence of money power, according to the Election Commission. This indictment of the state's political class was particularly telling as the ruling AIADMK's own ministers were among those elected in those constituencies. Upcoming elections in Tamil Nadu on January 11 will also include a week-long poll in the RK Nagar assembly segment in Chennai, which was previously postponed. This is not the first time in Tamil Nadu's 20-year history that polls have been disrupted, with a hung Assembly predicted in the latest election. Despite the ruling party's continued hold, these elections are significant due to the party's ability to maintain power despite external factors. In 2016, the AIADMK won a majority of constituencies, including more than 100, while the BJP managed only 23. The decision of voters in the RK Nagar segment, which was postponed in April 2016, is seen as a factor in the BJP's gains in other parts of the city. However, the ruling party still maintained its stronghold in the area.

input: Ping An Insurance (Group) Co.'s (2318.HK) first-time disclosure that it holds a 5.01% stake in global banking giant HSBC Holdings Plc. (0005.HK) highlights the Chinese
continuation:
company's growing ambitions in international markets.

Hong Kong-listed Ping An (Group) Co. (2318.HK) disclosed in its annual report for 2012 that it holds a 5.01% stake in HSBC Holdings Plc. (0005.HK), its first-time disclosure of ownership in its larger foreign rival. The holding follows in the wake of HSBC's decision last year to stop its local operations.

"Although it is currently still within regulatory rules, given HSBC's decision to cease local operations, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange may expect a further increase in foreign shareholding if other local operators are forced into similar decision," said Louis Ng, executive director of corporate communications, in a written response to emailed questions from Bloomberg. The bourse didn't provide more details.

Ping An, which listed in Hong Kong in 2007, is one of only two foreign insurers in Hong Kong. The other is Singapore-based IAMGOLD Corp. (IMG.SG), which holds 8.98% of HSBC. The stakes are modest compared with the nearly 20% held by other foreign-owned insurance groups in the city. HSBC was the third-biggest insurance company in Hong Kong by assets in the latest
paraphrase: Ping An Insurance Group's revelation that it holds a 5.01% stake in global banking giant HSBC Holdings Plc highlights the Chinese company's expanding influence in international markets. According to Ping An's annual report for 2012, the holding represents the company's first disclosure of ownership in its larger foreign rival. This development comes on the heels of HSBC's decision to cease local operations last year, which may lead to an increase in foreign shareholding in the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Speaking on the matter, Louis Ng, executive director of corporate communications at Ping An, stated that "Although it is currently still within regulatory rules, given HSBC's decision to cease local operations, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange may expect a further increase in foreign shareholding if other local operators are forced into similar decisions." Ping An, which listed in Hong Kong in 2007, is one of only two foreign insurers in the city, with the other being Singapore-based IAMGOLD Corp., which holds 8.98% of HSBC. The stakes held by Ping An and IAMGOLD are relatively modest compared to the nearly 20% held by other foreign-owned insurance groups in Hong Kong. HSBC was the third-biggest insurance company in Hong Kong by assets in the latest financial reports.

input: We all take inspiration from someone or something: with credit being paid to beloved former teachers or batty great aunts for giving them the strength to succeed, but there cant be that many blokes who have been empowered by Elton John
continuation:
, or someone with even greater songwriting ability. No-ones going to say Ira Glass  Im just going to say this: Ira Glass is one of us, and hes going to make me feel just a little bit more like Ira Glass. Ira Glass is going to tell me what its like to be me.

In the latest episode of The Guardian podcast Ira Glass (aka Glass) talks about his new album, The Real Ira Glass, with comedian Russell Brand. The show is called The Guardian, its hosted by Russell Brand, its free to download, and its going to change the way you think about The Guardian  its going to change the way I think about The Guardian. (Its also going to change the way I listen to it, if Im honest.) Its quite interesting  Iras new album sounds like itll feel a bit like A Change of Seasons, only with more songs, plus its Ira talking, which is rare for The Guardian.

Listen, then check this out.
paraphrase: Many of us draw inspiration from individuals or sources, giving credit where it's due. However, it's unlikely that many people have been motivated by Elton John or someone with comparable musical talent. Ira Glass, on the other hand, is an exception. He's one of us, and I'm sure he'll provide valuable insights into what it's like to be me. In the latest episode of The Guardian podcast, Ira Glass (or Glass as he's known) chats with comedian Russell Brand about his new album, The Real Ira Glass. The show is called The Guardian, hosted by Russell Brand, and is free to download. It's sure to change the way you think about The Guardian, and perhaps even the way you listen to it. Ira's new album has a similar vibe to A Change of Seasons, but with more songs and Ira's unique voice. Give it a listen and see for yourself!

input: NEW YORK  One recent spring morning in the Utah desert, Jerry Foote received an ecstatic e-mail that gravitational forces were causing two stars to orbit each other, with one star swallowing matter from its companion. Rudolf Novak received the same message
continuation:
, only this time, it was more of an exclamation mark. The European Space Agency, or ESA, was announcing the birth of yet another exoplanet, this one located in what is called the "Goldilocks Zone" of its star  one that is hot enough, not too hot, not too cold  yet not too hot. The discovery was like getting free tickets to Disneyland  except, of course, it was in space. The planet was much like Neptune, only much smaller. It was also, of course, far away. But it was just the first of many, many more worlds, some with liquid water, some without, all in search of its own kind of existence. One way or another, humanity was going to find more worlds. But if we could find more worlds, were going to find more of us. The human race was going to be found.

On his first trip into space in 1993, astronaut Bill Anders was talking with his co-pilot, Paul McIlvaine, about life in outer space. Anders was a retired astronaut. McIlvaine was a pilot. But what exactly was life, or "life-in-space" as Anders called it, when he
paraphrase:
In a recent spring morning in the Utah desert, Jerry Foote received an excited email regarding the gravitational forces causing two stars to orbit each other, with one star consuming matter from its companion. Rudolf Novak also received the same message, but this time with more emphasis on the exclamation mark. The European Space Agency (ESA) announced the birth of a new exoplanet located in the "Goldilocks Zone" of its star, which is neither too hot nor too cold, yet not too hot. This new planet was similar to Neptune but smaller in size and much farther away. The discovery was like getting free tickets to space, except it was a real find. The ESA believes that this is just the beginning of many more worlds to be discovered, some with liquid water and others without, as humanity continues to explore the cosmos in search of new life. With the possibility of finding more worlds, humanity may also find more of itself. The human race is on the verge of being discovered.
On his first space trip in 1993, astronaut Bill Anders conversed with his co-pilot, Paul McIlvaine, about life in outer space. Anders, a retired astronaut, and McIlvaine, a pilot, discussed the concept of "life-in-space" and its peculiarities.

SCRIBA, N.Y. - The refueling outage at the Unit 2 reactor at Nine Mile Point nuclear station provides a rare opportunity to go inside the plant while the reactor vessel is opened up.
Photographers from Syracuse.com took advantage
continuation: of the opportunity Sunday afternoon. They spent much of their time inside the reactor vessel. The only other time SCR is going inside, is with reactor commissioning in 2022. The reactor vessel is also in operation. The SCRA will need more time. The commissioning was postponed from late July to late August.
paraphrase: NY Scriba - A rare chance to explore the inside of the Nine Mile Point nuclear station's Unit 2 reactor has arisen due to a scheduled refueling outage. Photographers from Syracuse.com seized the opportunity on Sunday to capture images inside the reactor vessel, which is only occasionally open to the public. This is the second time SCR will be granting access to the reactor vessel, with the first being during reactor commissioning in 2022. The reactor vessel is currently in operation, and the SCRA will require additional time to complete the commissioning process, which was originally scheduled for late July but has been pushed back to late August.

The gritty streets of this 4-by-12-block sliver of a town in densely populated and urbanized northern Hudson County might be the last place to expect to find a largely volunteer fire department.
Such departments are usually associated with small-
continuation:
town life, where neighbors watch out for one another. But in Morris Plains, where police are few, this is far from the norm. Fire departments are largely private, making it hard for them to fight neighborhood fires together, and more importantly, hard to build relationships.
You always hear in fire departments what it is  theyre small, its small, said Morris Plains Fire Chief Barry Cohen.
Yet the Morris Plains Fire Department is big. The department is made up of more than 100 volunteers, many of them police officers, and many of them people who are from Morris Plains or nearby. Many are former school teachers or paramedics, others former firemen or paramedics. All of them are fiercely protective of one another.
Its a tight-knit, brotherhood-like, said Fire Capt. Michael Salcido.
At its heart is a single goal  saving peoples lives. The department is tasked with saving lives in places like Morris Plains, where people often dont feel like they are in control of their own lives. The department, said Cohen, is an outlet.
Its kind of a way
paraphrase:
The unassuming streets of this compact, 12-block town in northern Hudson County might harbor an unexpected treasure - a largely volunteer fire department. These departments are typically associated with small-town life, where neighbors look out for each other, but in Morris Plains, where law enforcement is scarce, this is not the case. Fire departments here are largely privately funded, making it challenging to coordinate efforts to fight fires in the tight-knit community.
"It's small, it's small," Morris Plains Fire Chief Barry Cohen laments. But his department defies this expectation, boasting over 100 volunteers, including some who are also police officers and many who hail from the surrounding area. A mix of former teachers, paramedics, and firefighters/paramedics make up the roster, each one fiercely dedicated to the others.
According to Fire Capt. Michael Salcido, the department is a tight-knit, brotherhood-like unit united by a single purpose - saving lives. In a place where people may feel powerless, the fire department is a beacon of hope, a source of protection and security.
As Cohen puts it, "It's an outlet, a way to make a difference in people's lives."
