MALAYSIA IS willing to help Thailand end the ethno-religious conflict in the deep South using peaceful means, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said yesterday, suggesting the root cause of the problem was not religion but injustice.
G
continuation:
ambara/Phra Wisanakorn/Chitra Chawattana/A. Jothanon/A. Charoenkraphai
Thailand's government, he said, was ready to talk to Malaysia to end the current deadlock. "We are ready for dialogue with them, or anyone else who really wants peace. All we want is justice. We want to resolve this problem peacefully. We are willing to talk with anyone else."
Malaysia is one of the few countries where Thailand maintains friendly ties. The Thai-Malaysian civil war ended in 2005 with Malaysian forces retreating in what was regarded as "a major victory" in Asia's longest-running insurgency. Malaysia, which is facing rising Islamic extremism, has called for international help in quelling the insurgency. It hosts 1.7m Muslim migrants from Myanmar, Bangladesh, Nepal, India, Sri Lanka, and the Philippines.
Malaysian police arrested Malaysian-born preacher Zulkifli, commonly known as "Preacher Z" and his deputy, Abdur Razak Dawood, in May last year, accused of masterminding a series of bomb blasts in Bangkok. The Malaysian government is reportedly looking to deport
paraphrase:
Malaysia is eager to support Thailand in resolving the ethnic and religious conflict in the Deep South through peaceful means, according to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. He believes the root cause of the issue is not religion, but rather injustice.
Thailand's government is open to dialogue with Malaysia to find a solution to the current stalemate, the Prime Minister said. "We are willing to talk to them, or anyone else who genuinely desires peace. All we want is justice. We want to resolve this problem peacefully."
Given Malaysia's amicable relations with Thailand, the Prime Minister sees this as an opportunity to work together in ending the conflict. As a country that has successfully brought an end to its own civil war, Malaysia is eager to offer its support to Thailand. With its expertise in dealing with rising Islamic extremism, Malaysia is eager to lend a hand in quelling the insurgency in Thailand's Deep South.
Notably, Malaysia has also taken steps to address the issue of migrant workers in the region. With 1.7 million Muslim migrants from various countries, including Myanmar, Bangladesh, Nepal, India, Sri Lanka, and the Philippines, Malaysia is well-positioned to help mediate a resolution to the conflict.
Furthermore, Malaysian authorities have arrested two individuals suspected of masterminding bombings in Bangkok, including Malaysian-born preacher Zulkifli and his deputy, Abdur Razak Dawood. The Malaysian government is now considering deporting these individuals as a means of demonstrating its commitment to resolving the conflict peacefully.
In summary, Malaysia is dedicated to helping Thailand find a peaceful solution to its ethnic and religious conflict in the Deep South, while also demonstrating its commitment to addressing the issue of migrant workers in the region.

On environmental issues, he said Ireland is "working

Green party leader Eamon Ryan has urged the government to ban plastic bags, citing the significant amount of plastic bags used in Ireland each year, with only 3% being returned. UNIONDALE, N.Y. - The talk before the season was that the Los Angeles Kings were ready to contend for a playoff berth. Five games into the season, they're turning words into deeds.
The Kings made it four wins
continuation:
in a row with a 4-1 victory over the New Jersey Devils on Tuesday. It was their third win in five nights. All three victories have been by one goal.
"You get frustrated when you don't win, especially when you don't have a lot of time in it, where you could kind of settle in or get a couple of leads," said Drew Doughty, who recorded his second career two-goal performance. "I don't think any of us were really thinking too far in the future. We were just focusing on the next game."
Kobe King also scored for the Kings, while Cal Petersen made 28 saves. The victory puts them in third place in the Pacific Division with 28 points. They are currently six points back of the first-place Anaheim Ducks.
New Jersey is 0-6-1 in its past eight contests. Cory Schneider made 28 saves in his first win of the season. The Devils are 1-6-1 in their past eight.
"It's been going from bad to worse lately," Schneider said. "I think it's just been one step back, one step forward. I'm going to go back and look myself in the mirror here and try to figure it out
paraphrase:
LOS ANGELES, Calif. - The Kings are proving their words with actions, having won four consecutive games. Their most recent victory, a 4-1 win over the New Jersey Devils, marks their third win in five nights. These triumphs have all been decided by a single goal, a testament to their resilience and determination.
"We're just taking it one game at a time," said defenseman Drew Doughty, who notched his second career two-goal performance. "We're not getting too far ahead of ourselves. We know we have a lot of work to do, but we're feeling good about our chances."
Forward Kobe King also found the back of the net, while goaltender Cal Petersen made 28 saves to secure the win. With 28 points, the Kings have moved into third place in the Pacific Division, trailing the division-leading Anaheim Ducks by six points.
The Devils, on the other hand, have hit a rough patch, with eight consecutive losses. Goaltender Cory Schneider made 28 saves in his first win of the season, but the Devils remain in last place in their division.
"It's been a challenge, that's for sure," Schneider said. "We've been trying different things, but it seems like one step forward, two steps back. I'm going to take a closer look at my game and see if there's anything I can do to turn things around."

"And then she asked me to dance with her, said Jordan. "And I was like, 'Alright.' I'm
paraphrase:
Jordan Rogers and JoJo Fletcher were anticipating a peaceful dinner on Saturday night, but his 27-year-old former football player's family had other plans.
Jordan's family organized a surprise engagement party for him and JoJo in Nashville, which he was in town celebrating his friend's bachelorette party.
The engagement party took place at Hotel Shabazz in Nashville, where the couple's other friends joined them. The party was only two days before Jordan was set to play his first NFL game.
"It was just a great couple of days, Jordan said of the engagement party. "My mom showed up, said, 'Ah, this is great. I'm so excited. We sat down, and she said, 'Can I get a picture of you guys?'
"And I said, 'Sure,' and I took her picture," Jordan continued. "And I said, 'You want to hear something special?' She said, 'I love you, which was nice of her. I said, 'I love you, too.

"And then she asked me to dance with her," Jordan said. "And I was like, 'Okay.' I was hesitant at first, but then I was like, 'Alright.'

Once upon a time, Ronald Reagan inaugurated America's Strategic Defense Initiative, a missile defense program that critics immediately derided as "Star Wars" -- pure fantasy.
Ronald Reagan's "Star Wars."
continuation:
photo: US Government website. The program was based on the "polaris" missile. It is still, of course, "polarizing" because it imagines the existence of other possible missile-carrying super-weapons, or "hypothetical super-weapons" as it is more commonly called, or hyperspace weapons. If the program, which was in its early stages, succeeded in slowing the growth of Soviet missile technology, it may even be seen as a success in terms of maintaining peace, or "security" in the world. But of course, it is only one aspect of a broader, much more dangerous approach to managing our national security, which is based around maintaining control of the international airwaves. That is why this episode is significant in shaping current concerns with international broadcasting.
In late 1986, Ronald Reagan was facing a popular backlash due to his handling of the arms race with the Soviet Union. On the heels of this, Senator Edward Kennedy (D-MA) introduced into the Senate an "International Broadcast Act of 1986" (IBAA), which he called "a bill that will prohibit foreign broadcasters from using radio frequency frequencies reserved for national broadcasting purposes for any program, broadcast or other service which promotes,
paraphrase:
During Ronald Reagan's presidency, he launched America's Strategic Defense Initiative, a missile defense program that critics dubbed "Star Wars" - a term that has since become synonymous with science fiction. This program was based on the "Polaris" missile, which, despite its age, remains a contentious issue to this day due to its ability to "polarize" opinions on the matter. While some view it as a potential game-changer in terms of global security, others see it as a dangerous overreach that could lead to a costly arms race.
In the late 1980s, Reagan faced mounting criticism for his handling of the arms race with the Soviet Union. Amidst this backlash, Senator Edward Kennedy (D-MA) introduced the "International Broadcast Act of 1986" (IBAA), which aimed to restrict foreign broadcasters from using radio frequencies reserved for national broadcasting purposes for any content that promotes conflict or undermines international cooperation.
This passage highlights the complex and often contradictory nature of political discourse, where even seemingly innocuous measures like international broadcasting can become entangled in broader geopolitical struggles.

MANIC STREET PREACHERS, returned to their punk roots tonight (March 8) at CARDIFF COAL EXCHANGE, with a violent hometown show.
The band performed their first UK date since their New Years Eve
continuation:
show in Leeds back in January, with special guests The Real McCoy (from Leeds The White Wiggle), as well as special guests The Scam, from Leeds. The band played an intense live set, with plenty of hits, before making way for more of their popular new songs. The band is from Manchester, England, and formed in 2005. The band consists of guitarist Steve Rothery, bassist Mikey Scardini, drummer Charlie Kincaid, keyboard player Joe Wetherall, vocalist Will, guitarist Gary Smith and vocalist/ bassist Jody. The band recorded their debut album in the mid-90s in Nashville, Tennessee. Manic Street Preachers was named one of MTVs Top 10 Theories of Rock & Roll back in 2003. The bands third album, Walking Wound, was released in 2007. After forming in 2005, Manic Street Preachers were signed by Capitol Records. The band toured extensively in support of their third album in 2008. After breaking up in 2016, the band reformed in 2018. Manic Street Preachers are also set to tour in support of their fourth album in early 2022.
Related

Manchester-based rock band Manic Street Preachers returned to their punk roots at Cardiff Coal Exchange on March 8, with a high-energy hometown show.
The band performed their first UK date since their New Year's Eve gig in Leeds back in January, with special guests The Real McCoy from Leeds and The Scam from Leeds joining them on stage. The band delivered an electrifying live set, featuring a mix of classic hits and newer songs, before handing over the reins to their support acts.
Formed in 2005, Manic Street Preachers hail from Manchester, England, and have been making waves in the music industry for over two decades. The band consists of guitarist Steve Rothery, bassist Mikey Scardini, drummer Charlie Kincaid, keyboard player Joe Wetherall, vocalist Will, guitarist Gary Smith, and vocalist/bassist Jody.
Manic Street Preachers were named one of MTV's Top 10 Theories of Rock & Roll back in 2003 and have released three critically acclaimed albums, including their debut album recorded in the mid-90s in Nashville, Tennessee. The band has toured extensively in support of their albums, including a comprehensive tour in 2008. After disbanding in 2016, the band reformed in 2018 and are set to embark on a tour in support of their upcoming fourth album early next year.

Tennessee's state-run Achievement School District, which takes over low-performing schools and either runs them directly or hands them over to charter organizations, has run into partisan political trouble.
Several Democratic state lawmakers say they will propose bills this upcoming legislative
continuation:
session to end the contract, which is currently slated to expire in 2024.
A news release says Democratic state Rep. Angela Turner Ford, of Knoxville, will propose one bill  one bill  "to put an end to this troubled school contract." The release did not indicate if Ford will introduce any other bills. The release did say Democratic state Rep. Barbara Johnson, of Memphis, will introduce one bill, one bill, to end the contract. Johnson did not immediately return calls from The Tennessean.
The release did say Democratic state Rep. Harold Love, of Nashville, will propose one bill, one bill, to change the contract. The release did not indicate if Love will introduce any other bills.
Tennessee was one of nine states named in a 2018 report from The Tennessean, which found dozens of school contracts are in the state. The report said "the state school finance program is riddled with conflicts of interest, conflicts of interest, conflicts of interest." The report also said "credible accusations" were leveled against charter school groups in nearly half of school contracts  an analysis of 42 contracts.
It also said that "Charter school executives are regularly involved in politics, sometimes by secretly donating money." The report
paraphrase:
Tennessee's state-run Achievement School District, which has taken over low-performing schools and handed them over to charter organizations, has faced political opposition from Democratic state lawmakers. Several lawmakers plan to introduce bills during the upcoming legislative session to end the contract, which is currently set to expire in 2024. These bills aim to put an end to the troubled school contract and address the concerns raised in a 2018 report by The Tennessean, which found conflicts of interest and accusations of charter school groups involvement in politics.
Democratic state Rep. Angela Turner Ford of Knoxville plans to introduce one bill to end the contract, while Democratic state Rep. Barbara Johnson of Memphis will introduce another bill. However, Johnson did not immediately return calls from The Tennessean for comment. Similarly, Democratic state Rep. Harold Love of Nashville plans to propose one bill to change the contract, but it is unclear if he will introduce any other bills.
The 2018 report by The Tennessean found that the state school finance program is riddled with conflicts of interest, and credible accusations were leveled against charter school groups in nearly half of the analyzed school contracts. The report also revealed that charter school executives are regularly involved in politics, sometimes through secret donations.
In summary, Tennessee's Achievement School District has faced political opposition from Democratic lawmakers, who plan to introduce bills to end the contract and address concerns raised by a 2018 report on conflicts of interest and political involvement in the school system.

input: Magic Johnson has no regrets about the public nature of his conversations with New Orleans Pelicans general manager Dell Demps during the past two weeks as the Lakers tried to trade for Anthony Davis. Johnson believes his players are professional enough to handle hearing their names in trade
continuation:
conversations, even if its in public. The Lakers are pursuing the Pelicans star big man in hopes of signing him to a maximum contract this summer.
Its just life. Its business. Its just whats going on. Everybody handles it in different ways, Johnson said. Youve got to deal with it. Its like everybody else. Im dealing with it. Everybodys dealing with it. But what are you going to do, just say, Im never going to do this, or Im never going to say this, or whatever. Like I said, life goes on.
Johnson said he didnt expect Demps to show him anything, because he doesnt think he will offer him any help in getting a deal done. Johnson said Demps never even approached him, which is unusual. But he hopes his talk with Demps will get him closer to getting what he needs from his teammates. Johnson said he is confident his players will listen when its time to trade.
paraphrase:
Magic Johnson recently shared his thoughts on the public nature of his conversations with New Orleans Pelicans general manager Dell Demps during the Lakers' pursuit of Anthony Davis. While some may view these conversations as unprofessional, Johnson believes his players are mature enough to handle the scrutiny. The Lakers are eager to sign Davis to a maximum contract this summer, and Johnson feels that dealing with trade rumors is simply part of the job.
In Johnson's opinion, everyone handles these situations differently, but ultimately, it's about moving forward and dealing with the circumstances at hand. He acknowledges that Demps may not have shown him anything concrete, but he remains hopeful that their conversation will lead to a resolution. Despite the lack of direct communication, Johnson is confident that his teammates will be receptive when the time comes to make a trade.

input: Senate President Chuck Morse has a plan to absorb a nearly $30 million budget shortfall created by a lawsuit over hospital payments. But it could come at the expense of a host of other legislative priorities, potentially putting spending bills in jeopardy, he said Monday.
continuation: The Senate president said hell propose using money from special revenue sources  which is what lawmakers used in 2013, when they found themselves facing nearly $37 million in budget shortfalls. Morses plan relies on funding sources that are already allocated, he said. But Morses proposal could be more limited, putting funding sources into limbo, while the legislature continues to debate the states fiscal year budget. The General Assembly is working on the states next state spending plan, which is due in January, and the spending plan will include appropriations to cover ongoing operations of state government. Morse said if hes asked to find money from special revenue sources, hell likely propose using money from various special revenue sources, including gas and excise taxes, hotel tax, cigarette tax, excise tax from liquor, gas taxes, alcohol taxes and motor fuels taxes. But he could also use money from a variety of sources, like general obligation bonds, to plug a shortfall. What I intend to do is just simply plug these holes, Morse said. But if Morse is asked to find money from special revenue sources, hell need to find out how much. Hell
paraphrase: Senate President Chuck Morse has devised a plan to address a budget shortfall of nearly $30 million resulting from a legal dispute over hospital payments. However, this plan could potentially jeopardize other legislative priorities, as it may require dipping into special revenue sources. Morse revealed that he would propose using funds from existing sources, such as gas and excise taxes, hotel tax, cigarette tax, excise tax on liquor, gas taxes, alcohol taxes, and motor fuels taxes. He may also consider utilizing general obligation bonds to plug the gap. According to Morse, his primary objective is to simply fill the holes in the budget, but he will need to determine the exact amount of funding required from special revenue sources if asked to do so.

input:
The family of the limousine driver involved in a deadly crash in upstate New York says they believe he was unwittingly assigned an unsafe vehicle.
The family of Scott Lisinicchia released a statement through their lawyer Tuesday asking the public to not
continuation:
speculate on what caused the crash.
Police say Lisinicchia, 46, of Rochester, was driving alone in a stretch Ford Excursion SUV on Sept. 14 when it left a suburban Rochester, New York, intersection. It ran off the road, overturned, smashed into a tree and eventually came to rest in a farm field.
Family members say Lisinicchia worked in maintenance for RCS Transportation, which also owns a stretch Ford Excursion. A spokeswoman for RCS says the company "does not comment" on individual clients.
___
Information from: The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle, http://www.democratandchronicle.com
paraphrase:
The family of the driver involved in the fatal crash in upstate New York believes he was unknowingly assigned an unsafe vehicle. They have asked the public to refrain from speculating on the cause of the accident.
According to police reports, the 46-year-old driver, Scott Lisinicchia of Rochester, was driving alone in a stretch Ford Excursion SUV when it left an intersection, crashed into a tree, and came to rest in a nearby farm field on September 14.
While the driver's family members have expressed their condolences, they have also highlighted Lisinicchia's maintenance work for RCS Transportation, which owns the same type of vehicle involved in the accident. However, a spokesperson for the company has declined to comment on the incident.
Source: The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle.

input:
What's behind the jolt that performers get from being onstage? The necessity, the difficulty, the possibility of connecting with the audience.
Sam Pressler knows that the connection is everything, and is a master at helping people, specifically those with military
continuation:
backgrounds, feel more comfortable performing. Pressler says he was just 11 when he first performed, in a military show. "I've never forgotten that. It was just me, this 11-year-old, in this little green army jacket. I remember this scene in 'American Graffiti.' " He didn't really get it, he says. "I think, 'I'm going to try this.' " He took it in stride, "but I didn't understand what I was doing. I don't think I understand it."
After graduating from Southern Illinois University, Pressler found himself in the military. He had always been interested in theater, but hadn't been thinking of what he wanted to do with it. "I was going into a new world." He made it through basic training in a theater major, earned his bachelor's degree in theater, and found himself teaching military theater. "I always found myself really learning what it takes to become successful in theater." At the same time, he was also thinking more about what he was getting into when he left theater. "I'm in this environment where I'm trying to find myself." He also wondered if it was something he really wanted. "I was kind of in
paraphrase: The electrifying feeling that performers experience on stage can be attributed to a combination of factors, including the need to connect with the audience, the challenge of conveying emotions, and the thrill of being in the spotlight. For Sam Pressler, the draw of performing stemmed from a childhood memory of performing in a military show at the age of 11. Despite not fully understanding the experience, Pressler found himself drawn to theater and went on to study it in college. After graduation, he ended up teaching military theater, which allowed him to not only hone his craft but also reflect on his own goals and aspirations. Through this process, Pressler discovered the importance of connecting with the audience and found that it was a key aspect of his own performance journey.

input:
Swirling dust devils on Mars have given NASA scientists both a scientific treat and a very welcome power boost.
On 10 March, the rover Spirit captured images of two dust devils in one day. It is the first time any have been seen on Mars
continuation:
, which has a thin, mostly dry atmosphere.
Although they looked very similar to what is seen in Earth's western hemisphere, the features in this video were distinct. The first, spotted on 20 March, was located just southwest of where Spirit was working, while its larger cousin was located northeast of it. The first spotted dust devil was larger, which could help researchers understand why it was more difficult to find.
"As it occurred in late afternoon, it was hard to discern details, like a larger size or what its air pressure was," said Peter Ramey, a planetary scientist at JPL, in a press release. "It could be seen with some difficulty from where Spirit was."
A second video, which was released on Tuesday, shows just one dust devil. It is located in the same area as the first, which was more difficult to spot. "The size of the second video video was difficult to determine based on color alone, although I found it interesting that the motion of the second video is similar to the first one. The second video is still too dark to tell the difference, which is why I'm working with the color team on this."
The same goes for other features of the video. It is
paraphrase:
Mars' dust devils have provided NASA scientists with a fascinating scientific discovery and a valuable power boost. On March 10th, the rover Spirit captured images of two dust devils in a single day, marking the first time such phenomena have been observed on the Red Planet.
The initial dust devil spotted on March 20th was larger than its counterpart, allowing researchers to gain insight into the reasons behind its elusive nature. According to Peter Ramey, a planetary scientist at JPL, "As it occurred in late afternoon, it was challenging to discern details, such as its size or air pressure, due to the fading light."
A subsequent video, released on Tuesday, showcased a single dust devil in the same location as its predecessor. While the second dust devil was more difficult to spot, its motion was found to be similar to the first. "The color team is currently working with me to analyze the footage," added Ramey.
The unique features of the video continue to intrigue researchers, with the color and motion of the dust devils offering valuable information for scientific study.

input: Standard & Poor's said on Wednesday it was more likely than before to cut General Electric Co's credit rating in the next two years after activist investor Nelson Peltz's purchase of a $
continuation:
1.1 billion stake in the world's No. 3 industrial conglomerate.

Peltz, head of the Trian Fund Management hedge fund, said GE was saddled with too much cash and failed to provide investors with information they were entitled to. GE shares dropped almost 6 percent in premarket trading, sending its dividend down. The stock is down more than 20 percent this year.

"We believe GE is set to weaken in the next few quarters, especially if we are unable to agree with GE on key issues around its cash, credit, earnings, strategy and growth prospects," Standard & Poor's analysts said in a note.

Analysts at Nomura expected GE to eventually be sold or restated to meet its own accounting standards. "It is difficult to get too far ahead of one of the world's worst-performing major industrial names."

In recent days, GE has been under pressure from activist investors. Last month, hedge fund Elliott Management, which holds about 3 percent of GE stock, called for GE to restate its earnings from 2010. GE Chairman John Flannery said at the time he wasn't in favor of selling the company.
paraphrase:
Standard & Poor's recently indicated that they now believe it is more likely than before that they will downgrade General Electric Co's credit rating within the next two years. This comes after activist investor Nelson Peltz purchased a $1.1 billion stake in the company. Peltz, the head of the Trian Fund Management hedge fund, has criticized GE for being saddled with too much cash and failing to provide investors with the information they are entitled to. In response, GE shares dropped almost 6 percent in premarket trading, causing its dividend to decrease. The stock has fallen by more than 20 percent this year.
According to Standard & Poor's analysts, the company is likely to weaken in the next few quarters, particularly if they are unable to come to an agreement with GE on key issues such as cash, credit, earnings, strategy, and growth prospects. Some analysts at Nomura have even predicted that GE will eventually be sold or restated to meet its own accounting standards. Despite the pressure from activist investors, GE Chairman John Flannery has maintained that he is not in favor of selling the company.

input:
Over half of Europeans think that Israel now presents the biggest threat to world peace according to a controversial poll requested by the European Commission.
According to the same survey, Europeans believe the United States contributes the most to world instability along with Afghanistan, Iran,
continuation:
Russia, Sudan, Somalia, Syria and Israel.
In Europe, only six countries were seen as stable, while in Israel, 20 per cent were considered stable. The US ranked fifth. The UK and Germany were in third and fourth place, says The Jewish Press.
While Israel was ranked fourth in stability in Europe, its popularity in the Middle East remained the same as in previous surveys. As per the survey, Israel remained the third-most popular place in the region, in fifth place. The US was ranked in second place.
It is interesting to note here that many European states are involved in negotiations with Israel. For instance, in April, French President Emmanuel Macron called on Israel to end its current military activities in Syria. The remarks came days after French forces killed al-Nusra Front terrorist in Syria. The French president said: "It is important that Israel ends its military activities in Syria, which are illegal according to international law, in order to build mutual confidence and respect." The same month, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said: "Germany supports Israel. This is also reflected in German-Israeli friendship. "We are determined to find a diplomatic solution. The Palestinian issue also involves us, because it involves Europe,
paraphrase: The poll revealed that a considerable portion of Europeans view Israel as the main threat to global peace, with the United States, Afghanistan, Iran, Russia, Sudan, Somalia, and Israel also perceived as contributors to instability. In contrast, only six European countries were deemed stable, while 20% of Israelis believed their country to be stable. The US ranked fifth in stability, with the UK and Germany taking third and fourth place, respectively, according to The Jewish Press. Interestingly, while Israel was ranked fourth in European stability, its popularity in the Middle East remained unchanged as in previous surveys. The US was ranked second in the region. Recent negotiations between European states and Israel, such as French President Emmanuel Macron's call for Israel to cease its military activities in Syria, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel's expression of support for Israel, highlight the complex geopolitical dynamics at play.

input: If President Clinton wants to see how activist government can solve social problems with strong public support, he should take a few days to visit Canada. With Toronto's World Series victory, the nationwide referendum on constitutional reform (including the status of Quebec), and the
continuation:
successful referendum in Quebec on proportional representation, Canadians seem ready to take government more seriously. It is difficult to overstate the importance of this referendum, or of the success of Quebec. Canadians from Vancouver to Vancouver Island seem ready to put aside differences in opinion. They don't want Quebec, they want a strong Canadian government. The new government will have little choice if it hopes to preserve national sovereignty.

This is what government is supposed to be like. But what is it going to look like in practice in Canada? This is what I want to talk about this week. It is possible, in any event, that I will return in the near future with more news. I should say this before I begin. I am working on something very interesting, although I will say little about it until it is complete. But I should say this, too. This article is a preview of my next book, The Future of Governance, which will be published in August. It is already in progress, but I am working on it, and will need more time. The cover is drawn, but much more still needs to be done. This book is already too big for me to move around. But it is almost ready. It will be available in
paraphrase:
If President Clinton is eager to observe how an active government can tackle social issues with broad public support, he could spend a few days exploring Canada. With Toronto's recent World Series triumph, the nationwide referendum on constitutional reform (including Quebec's status), and the successful referendum in Quebec on proportional representation, Canadians seem poised to prioritize government reform. This milestone is of utmost significance, as it showcases the nation's readiness to place greater trust in its government. The entire country, from Vancouver to Vancouver Island, appears united in their desire for a strong and effective federal government. As a result, the new administration will have little choice but to adapt to the changing political landscape if it wishes to maintain national sovereignty.
In essence, this development marks a significant turning point in Canada's political history. As President Clinton continues to follow this story, he will undoubtedly encounter a nation that is eager to embrace change and redefine its relationship with its government. In the coming weeks, he may find himself returning to Canada with more updates on this evolving narrative. Until then, he can rest assured that this article serves as a sneak peek into his forthcoming book, "The Future of Governance," which will be published in August. While the book is already in the works, President Clinton will need to devote additional time to its completion. The cover art is already finalized, but there is still much to be done before it can be considered complete. Nonetheless, this ambitious project is sure to offer valuable insights into the ever-changing landscape of governance.

input:
Gov. Parris N. Glendening is seriously considering vetoing legislation that would make Maryland the first state to require that all public school students take a gun safety class.
The governor has been besieged with calls from teachers troubled by the measure's
continuation:
"shall-issue" provision. The proposal is aimed at discouraging people with guns from using them in school or in parks. The law was sponsored by Rep. Paul Smith, R-Anne Arundel, and backed by many gun-control advocates.
"I don't think there's any question that if I sign this bill, I'll be sending a message to teachers in this state, especially in communities like this, that if this bill were law, I'm going to sign it, he said.
While he is reviewing it, Gov. Parris Glendening is also considering executive action.
"It's certainly something he'll look into, said his spokeswoman, Alisa Haushalter. "It's one of the things he was looking into back when he first became governor.
A new gun safety program could cost state taxpayers millions of dollars. Smith said it could cost tens of millions of dollars for teachers, counselors, law enforcement, crisis-intervention groups, mental health professionals, school nurses, police, school board members, principals, bus drivers, and school board staff. It also could require a one-time state fee of about $55. But he said it would
paraphrase:
Governor Parris N. Glendening is currently deliberating on whether to veto a bill that would make Maryland the first state to mandate gun safety classes for all public school students. The proposal, which was sponsored by Representative Paul Smith of Anne Arundel and backed by various gun control advocates, aims to discourage individuals from using firearms in schools or parks.
While reviewing the bill, Governor Glendening is also exploring executive actions. During a recent interview, his spokesperson, Alisa Haushalter, mentioned that the Governor has been looking into this issue since his initial term as Governor.
However, the implementation of a new gun safety program could prove costly for state taxpayers, with estimates suggesting that it could amount to tens of millions of dollars for teachers, counselors, law enforcement, crisis intervention groups, mental health professionals, school nurses, police, school board members, principals, bus drivers, and school board staff. Additionally, there may be a one-time state fee of around $55.
Despite these costs, Representative Smith believes that the program would be worthwhile, stating that it would help to prevent gun-related incidents in schools and parks.

I was driving and he was following me. And he was looking back at me, he was really concerned. Because I was looking back. I was like, "What? I don't know him. I haven't seen him before." I was looking back like, "Oh my god, it's weird." But I
paraphrase: If you have a paranoid mindset, you might be anticipating something disturbing in this article, such as sausages made from puppies. However, it's actually much more straightforward. Let's dive into the story without further ado, as it will only take us around ten minutes to read. I will set the scene for you: "Hi there, I'm just going to tell you what's going to happen next. But first, let me give you some background information. I've been driving for 20 minutes with this person in the car, and we're in a small town where we live." That's the gist of it.

input: At its AppsWorld developer conference, in front of an estimated 10,000 customers and developers, Oracle president Chuck Philips harped on the shows theme of software integration. In his opening keynote, Phillips noted that interoperability (getting software to
continuation:
talk to other software) is crucial in business. But integration in the cloud  where software doesnt need to talk to software, just other software  is even more important.

It is more important for me to tell people what Im going to show them, Philips said. At AppsWorld, he promised to show off an application integration service (AIS) in Oracle Application Cloud, which would let multiple applications communicate with one another. AIS could also be used to enable collaboration and other applications, Philips said. He also previewed new enterprise mobility applications, which will let IT managers create and manage mobile work flows. Enterprise mobility is the next wave of software, he said.

On the show floor, Philipss AIS presentation was a bit like what we saw in Oracles keynote earlier in the week. He promised more details in his keynote, which will also feature demos of new mobile applications, new applications running natively in the Cloud, and new Cloud-native applications. Philips also promised more integration news. Philips said he could also talk about AIS, collaboration, mobile applications, Cloud-native applications, or the Internet of Things.
paraphrase:
At the recent AppsWorld developer conference, Oracle President Chuck Philips emphasized the show's theme of software integration during his opening keynote. Philips stressed the importance of interoperability (enabling software to communicate with other software) in business, but noted that integration in the cloud (where software doesn't need to communicate with other software) is even more crucial.
Philips stated that it is more important for him to showcase the products and features he will be demonstrating, rather than just talking about them. At the conference, he promised to showcase an application integration service (AIS) in Oracle Application Cloud, which would enable multiple applications to communicate with each other. Additionally, he previewed new enterprise mobility applications that would allow IT managers to create and manage mobile workflows. Philips described enterprise mobility as the next wave of software.
On the show floor, Philips' AIS presentation was similar to what was seen in Oracle's earlier keynote, with promises of more details and demos of new mobile applications, cloud-native applications, and integration news in his upcoming keynote. Philips also mentioned the potential for discussions on AIS, collaboration, mobile applications, cloud-native applications, or the Internet of Things.

input:
Atletico Madrid and France forward Antoine Griezmann has taken home the award for the best player in La Liga last season.
But the glitzy awards ceremony in Valencia was overshadowed with no Barcelona players attending after manager Luis Enrique was overlooked
continuation:
for the Coach of the Year award.
In other news from Valencia, Spanish side Granada beat Getafe 2-1 in the Copa del Rey final in April, despite losing 6-1 in the first leg in Madrid.
Despite this, Getafe, who are also in the Europa League, were rewarded with the Europa League trophy.
It was Valencias second Copa del Rey success in four seasons, with the sides final score of 6-1 in April equalling the record score in European Cup final history.
paraphrase:
Antoine Griezmann, a forward for Atletico Madrid and France, was recently recognized as the best player in La Liga during the previous season. However, the prestigious awards ceremony in Valencia was marred by the absence of Barcelona players, as manager Luis Enrique was overlooked for the Coach of the Year award.
In other notable news from Valencia, Granada defeated Getafe 2-1 in the Copa del Rey final in April, despite losing the first leg 6-1 in Madrid. Despite this, Getafe, who are also participating in the Europa League, were awarded the Europa League trophy.
This marked Valencia's second Copa del Rey victory in four seasons, with the final score of 6-1 in April setting a new record for the most goals scored in a European Cup final.

input:
A woman sucker punched and stabbed on the subway says the attack was motivated by hate. Wale Aliyu reports.
A woman was punched and stabbed when she got off the subway in Brooklyn by a man yelling racially charged words, her family and
continuation:
police said.
On Sunday, Wale Aliyu, 28, left a station in Canarsie with his sister around 7:45 p.m. when the stranger grabbed her from behind and hit her in the head, according to authorities.
As Aliyu tried to push her off, he was kicked, kicked and strangled, police said. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital.
Aliyu, of Fort Greene, was released from the hospital Sunday night, police said. His injuries were described as minor. The suspect was arrested Tuesday. He is facing attempted murder, assault, reckless endangerment, menacing and harassment charges.
I was just thinking, 'Im in the subway. Why are you attacking me?" Aliyu said in an interview. "I think, 'Im going to die,' but I think, 'What if I die before I get home?' I dont want to die here, in this city, in the neighborhood.
Aliyu is from Nigeria, his sister, Fatimah, said. He was born in Fort Greene, she said. The family emigrated from Nigeria, she said.
It was
paraphrase: A woman was brutally attacked on a subway in Brooklyn, allegedly motivated by hate. According to eyewitnesses, the attacker yelled racial slurs before punching and stabbing the victim. The victim, Wale Aliyu, 28, was taken to Bellevue Hospital with minor injuries after being released from the hospital Sunday night. The suspect was arrested on Tuesday and faces charges of attempted murder, assault, reckless endangerment, menacing, and harassment. In an interview, Aliyu recalled thinking, "I'm in the subway, why are you attacking me?" and fearing for his life. Aliyu is a native of Nigeria who emigrated to the United States with his family. This hateful attack has left the community shaken and demands justice.

input: Inside Rebel-Held Syria NPR's Kelly McEvers spent a week with anti-government rebels knows as the Free Syrian Army. The government holds the country's cities, but the rebels control considerable territory in rural area near the Turkish border.
continuation:
Kellie McEvers/NPR The Free Syrian Army stands in the village of al-Ain in Syria. The rebels control much of rural Syria in areas around Turkey.

Kellie McEvers/NPR The Free Syrian Army in al-Ain. It's largely comprised of Sunni Muslim rebels, many of them foreigners, and they are more or less self-defense forces. One of their more recent leaders, Ahmed Al-Hassan, is also accused of masterminding the murder of a key rebel leader.

Kellie McEvers/NPR A rebel is interviewed in al-Ain. The rebel, named Abdullah, is not a member of the Free Syrian Army. He was arrested, beaten and hung from the tree. Abdullah says he was falsely accused of masterminding the murder of his uncle, Muhammad Abdul Rahman, a rebel leader killed in January.

Kellie McEvers/NPR A rebel sits in a home in al-Ain. The rebels don't really have much of a place of worship, although one of them, Mohamed Ateeq, is studying Islam in the nearby town of Deraa. He says he was arrested for suspected involvement in
paraphrase:
Inside Syria's Rebel-Held Territory
NPR's Kelly McEvers spent a week with anti-government rebels known as the Free Syrian Army in rural areas near the Turkish border. While the government controls the country's cities, the rebels hold significant territory in the countryside.
The Free Syrian Army stands in the village of al-Ain, showcasing their control over the rural areas. The majority of the rebels are Sunni Muslims, many of whom are foreigners and act as self-defense forces. One of their leaders, Ahmed Al-Hassan, has been accused of masterminding the murder of a key rebel leader.
A rebel is interviewed in al-Ain, sharing their story of arrest, beating, and hanging from a tree. The rebel, named Abdullah, denies accusations of masterminding the murder of his uncle, a rebel leader killed in January.
In a humble home in al-Ain, a rebel sits and shares their story. The rebels lack a central place of worship, although one of them, Mohamed Ateeq, is studying Islam in a nearby town. Ateeq was arrested for suspected involvement in the murder of his uncle, a rebel leader killed in January.

input:
Today's Millennials could be tomorrow's very sweaty retirees thanks to temperatures and humidity levels that are rising so fast that, by the end of this century, simply going outside could be deadly.
The study's alarming findings put into sharp perspective not just what
continuation:
could happen, but also what needs to happen. One big reason: A heat-induced illness, like a heat-related illness, is a serious possibility. But it is also a disease that is difficult to avoid.
"While there is more research in this area, there is also more awareness that heat is getting worse, even in places like Hawaii, where people are used to it," said Jana Steins, Ph.D., a professor of environmental health sciences in Boston University's School of Public Health. "And it is increasing, with more intense heat."
Research from the Harvard School of Public Health found that while people are getting more exposed to extreme heat  especially heatwaves  more are going outside. For people with chronic diseases, it poses more of a challenge, with heat leading to more physical distress, fewer medications, and more difficulty sleeping, researchers found.
While heat is more likely to kill us, it can also lead to sickness. A heat-related illness is like any other, but one with a big fat "D" next to it. "Heat is a disease in its own right, similar to something like cancer," said William Thompson, Ph.D., professor of environmental health sciences in Boston University School
paraphrase:
As the century progresses, today's youth may become tomorrow's retired individuals who are particularly susceptible to the detrimental effects of rising temperatures and humidity levels. In just a few decades, going outside could become lethal due to the rapid increase in heat.
A recent study has highlighted the urgent need for action, as the risk of heat-related illnesses and diseases is on the rise. According to Jana Steins, Ph.D., a professor of environmental health sciences at Boston University's School of Public Health, even places like Hawaii, where people are accustomed to heat, are experiencing more intense heat waves.
Research conducted by the Harvard School of Public Health has shown that while people are spending more time outdoors, particularly during heatwaves, those with chronic diseases are at a greater risk of experiencing physical distress, difficulty sleeping, and fewer medications due to the heat.
While heat-related illnesses are similar to other diseases in many ways, they can be particularly dangerous. William Thompson, Ph.D., professor of environmental health sciences at Boston University School of Public Health, likens heat to a disease in its own right, similar to cancer.
As the world grapples with the challenges of climate change, it is essential to prioritize the health and well-being of future generations. By taking proactive measures to mitigate the effects of rising temperatures and humidity levels, we can help ensure that today's youth are protected from the potentially deadly consequences of heat exposure.

input:
Police recruits should try to answer every question on a screening exam.
2 What Are Some Disqualifications for Getting a Job With a Police Department?
For police recruits, the psychological evaluation process represents one of the last hurdles to getting hired. The
continuation:
process is also the one many departments use, especially in communities where local law enforcement is already under scrutiny.
The test, which is administered by the FBI, is designed to test participants understanding of police work. Questions range from what the goal is of police, why people report crimes, how citizens are to feel when approached by police, to where communities are going when police go into neighborhoods, or what will happen when officers are allowed to enforce laws.
It's not intended to measure if a police recruit will understand or perform in the field, just whether or not he or she is competent to do his or her job. After police get through these tests, they go into what is called "phase I" of training. That phase is when officers are put through intense physical fitness tests, which, while in theory should help them gain weight, increase endurance, and improve their physical fitness, in practice, in many cases it only leads to police departments using more weight and force. It is in phase I of this process that police recruit pools are formed.
The police department with the most applicants from a given neighborhood or neighborhood of interest is almost always going to get the job. If police departments in communities with a low unemployment rate or with
paraphrase: To become a police officer, recruits must first pass a screening exam that evaluates their competency in various areas, including understanding police work and laws, and physical fitness. The exam is administered by the FBI and is designed to assess a candidate's ability to perform their job duties effectively. After passing the exam, recruits enter phase I of training, which involves intense physical fitness tests to improve their endurance and strength. The police department with the most applicants from a given neighborhood or area of interest is typically selected for the job. However, in some cases, the selection process can lead to police departments using excessive force or weight, which can be problematic for recruits and the community at large.

input:
Sen. Tom Bakk will remain the DFL leader, but this time in the minority.
Sen. Paul Gazelka was elected by his Republican colleagues Thursday to be the new majority leader of the Minnesota Senate.
Gazelka will join
continuation:
Bakk in a bipartisan caucus in the Senate. Bakk will stay on as chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, which oversees party rules.
It wasn't easy. Bakk was elected by his Republican colleagues despite his vote against Senate Democratic rules in February. The majority caucus needed 11 Republicans to vote "yes" in order to change Senate rules. But Bakk wasn't one of them. That vote came in February when Bakk was working with Gov. Mark Dayton to try and agree on state budgets. He said he changed his vote based on concerns that Senate Democrats were still pushing too hard. It was his first vote in support of changing Senate rules.
After his vote, Bakk acknowledged his mistake. He said he still supports the Senate Democratic rules, but he wasn't happy with the process.
"I think it was hard to get this done in the time frame, which I think I've been supportive of. But I think it wasn't done fairly in this process. I was disappointed in some of the actions taken on this. I think it wasn't done fairly, I believe, in a way that was conducive to getting this done in a way that was productive, in a way that was bipartisan, in a way that
paraphrase: Senator Tom Bakk will continue to lead the DFL caucus in the minority, while Senator Paul Gazelka has been elected by his Republican colleagues as the new majority leader of the Minnesota Senate. Despite Bakk's vote against Senate Democratic rules in February, he will remain as chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, overseeing party rules. The bipartisan caucus in the Senate will now include both Bakk and Gazelka. Bakk acknowledged his mistake in voting against the rules and expressed disappointment in the process, but remains committed to supporting the Senate Democratic rules.

input:
Defensive back K'Waun Williams, shown after making a big play for the Pitt Panthers last season, has signed with the Cleveland Browns.
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- The Browns continue to add to their cornerback pile.
On Tuesday,
continuation:
free-agent cornerback K'Waun Williams, who was released by the Buffalo Bills, signed with the Browns. The Browns also announced the signing of former Pittsburgh Panthers defensive back Malik Hooker. Hooker will also join the Browns on a one-year deal.
Williams played in five games with Buffalo this season, starting two of them. He recorded six tackles and made one pass defensed, but was let go with a season-ending neck injury. He was the Bills starter in 2018. He made one start in 2018.
Williams, 26, also spent time in Washington with Josh Norman and Terrance Mitchell, where he played with James Bradberry. He also spent time in Arizona with A.J. Bouye. Williams, a former first-round pick of the Bears in 2016, spent his first season with Washington in 2018. He played in 11 games with seven starts in 2018. He played in 34 games with 23 starts in his first three seasons. He made three career interceptions. He was selected in the first round (26th overall) of the 2016 NFL Draft.
Williams, in his first year with the Panthers, recorded one career interception. He was drafted in 2016. He played with Mike Hull, Josh Norman,
paraphrase: The Browns have signed former Pitt Panthers defensive back K'Waun Williams to a deal. Williams, who was released by the Buffalo Bills due to a season-ending neck injury, will provide depth at the cornerback position. Additionally, the team has announced the signing of former Pittsburgh Panthers defensive back Malik Hooker on a one-year deal. Hooker will join Williams in the Browns' secondary. Williams, 26, has previously played for the Washington Redskins and Arizona Cardinals, and was selected in the first round (26th overall) of the 2016 NFL Draft. In his time with the Panthers, Williams recorded one interception and made three career interceptions overall.

input:
As Athens goes to the polls, has the British left fallen out of love with the EU?
In 1874, Karl Marx had an imaginary conversation with Mikhail Bakunin. Nowadays, they would just have had a Twitter spat, but back then
continuation:
it was something quite tangible. The French philosopher asked Marx what it was like to live under a state-regulated capitalist economy, where he was a private landlord. It sounded pretty brutal, Marx said, but the Russian was right: the world was capitalist. Marx said he wasn't sure whether capitalism could survive state ownership. But even if it did, Bakunin was just too much of a revolutionary: he was one of the few people in Europe who still believed in Marxism. A couple of hundred years later, it's fair to say that Marx is wrong. The only reason he was wrong in 1874 was the lack of evidence. Marx didn't know what capitalism was yet. Now, with almost universal consensus in Europe that capitalism is in crisis, Marx seems surprisingly wrong. Perhaps, though, Marx was onto something. Marx believed in a world beyond capitalism. He called this stateless communism. It didn't just have to happen in his lifetime  it could happen any time in human history. It didn't just have to happen in Britain, either. The rest of Europe, with its capitalist economy and capitalist state, is almost certainly in need of something similar.
And it's already happened in Britain. The British left has always been obsessed with
paraphrase: As Athens goes to the polls, has the British left lost its love for the EU? In 1874, Karl Marx and Mikhail Bakunin engaged in an imaginary conversation, and today, they would likely have a heated Twitter exchange. Back then, Marx lived under a state-regulated capitalist economy, where he owned private land. It was a brutal experience, he admitted, but the Russian philosopher was right: the world was capitalist. Marx questioned whether capitalism could survive state ownership, but Bakunin was an unyielding revolutionary, convinced that Marxism was the answer. Two centuries later, it's clear that Marx was premature in his conclusions. While Europe is now largely united in its belief that capitalism is in crisis, Marx's ideas appear out of touch. However, he may have been onto something with his vision of a stateless communism. This utopia could arise at any point in human history, and it's not limited to Britain. In fact, the rest of Europe, with its capitalist economy and capitalist state, is likely in need of a similar transformation. And look where we are today  the British left has become obsessed with breaking free from the EU, a move that could potentially pave the way for a more equitable society.

input: NOVOLUHANSKE, Ukraine (Reuters) - Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko thought he could rely for his re-election in part on the votes of soldiers who have spent years fighting pro-Russian separatists. But a visit to the frontline
continuation:
of the eastern Ukraine conflict reveals that, for some, his partys nationalist, xenophobic message is losing them support.

A general view of buildings damaged in shelling, in the village of Novo Lysytsia, eastern Ukraine, January 7, 2016. REUTERS/Yevgeny Matyzhak

After what happened in Europe, I was quite confident, said 23-year-old Pavel, an infantryman in Ukraines armed forces. But the presidents message of national security was losing him support. He will vote for former president Viktor Yanukovych, his partys choice, he said.

Since he came to power in 2014, Poroshenko has often spoken of national sovereignty, national pride, and European values, including free trade. But he made it clear this week that Ukraine will stay in a European order under Russian pressure, even if it is in breach of international law.

The stakes are high. Putin, who annexed Ukraines Crimea peninsula in March 2014, accuses Western powers of destabilizing Ukraine, which he says has a separatist insurgency. The United States, Europe, Russia and others say Russia is arming and
paraphrase:
KYIV, Ukraine (Reuters) - Ukraine's President Poroshenko believed he could secure his re-election by relying on the votes of soldiers who have been fighting pro-Russian separatists. However, a visit to the frontlines of the eastern Ukraine conflict revealed that some soldiers are losing faith in his party's nationalist and xenophobic message.
A destroyed building is seen in the village of Novo Lysytsia, eastern Ukraine, January 7, 2016. REUTERS/Yevgeny Matyzhak
"I was confident after what happened in Europe, but the president's message of national security is losing him support," said 23-year-old Pavel, an infantryman in Ukraine's armed forces. He will vote for former president Viktor Yanukovych, he added.
Since taking office in 2014, Poroshenko has frequently spoken about national sovereignty, national pride, and European values, including free trade. However, he made it clear this week that Ukraine will remain in a European orbit despite Russian pressure, even if it goes against international law.
The stakes are high, with Russian President Putin accusing Western powers of destabilizing Ukraine and supporting a separatist insurgency. The United States, Europe, Russia, and other countries say Russia is arming and supporting the separatists.
The conflict in eastern Ukraine has caused significant damage to buildings and infrastructure, as seen in the village of Novo Lysytsia, where a destroyed building is visible. The situation remains volatile, with both sides accusing each other of aggression and violating ceasefire agreements.

input: From the house of ZURB, creators of such apps as Bounce, Notable, Reel and Strike, comes another Web app called Spur. Its a free app that aims to help Web designers return to basics and ensure that they
continuation: dont get bogged down with extra layers of technology. The way it was described to me was like if designers were learning how to program. The program is free and, in order to get any features, I needed to sign up for one of ZURBs paid plans, which costs $99. I found this odd, since Spur didnt offer anything like the features of other Web app-sharing platforms like AppWiz or ShareASale. But when I signed up, I was sent to the AppWiz website, where I was able to pick up free items, and I could even create a free AppWiz account. Here, I could choose from hundreds of pre-built WordPress themes, use WordPress.coms easy setup, or download custom themes from ZURBs FTP servers. The only difference is that in AppWiz, I was able to upload custom themes, but in Spur, I could only use pre-built WordPress themes. I also found it odd that I needed to sign into AppWiz, since I could sign into any WordPress website using WordPress.coms free account. This created another roadblock, since it made it hard
paraphrase:
From the innovative mind of ZURB, the creators of popular apps like Bounce, Notable, Reel, and Strike, emerges a new web application called Spur. This user-friendly tool aims to empower web designers by simplifying their workflow and reducing the burden of unnecessary technological complexity. With a free sign-up process, users can unlock a wealth of features that enable them to create and customize their web designs with ease.
While some may find the requirement to sign up for one of ZURB's paid plans ($99) to be unusual, it grants access to a wealth of premium features that enhance the overall web design experience. However, users can also explore the vast library of pre-built WordPress themes available on AppWiz, ZURB's sister platform. This integration allows designers to choose from a wide range of customizable options, streamlining their design process and maximizing their creative potential.
Despite some minor inconveniences, Spur offers a unique and intuitive user experience that sets it apart from other web app-sharing platforms. By leveraging the power of WordPress, designers can efficiently create and manage their web designs with ease, without sacrificing quality or customization options.

input: What were the politics of abortion like in this country before Roe v. Wade? Different than what I thought in a couple of important ways, Ive learned from a new book, Before Roe v. Wade, by Linda Greenhouse and Rev
continuation: . Frank Norris. The book is available from T.C. Harris in its hardcover or trade paperback edition, or online. (A second edition will be available in April.) The book details the history of state laws, from whats called the "conversion therapy" period of the 1950s, through more recent attempts to enact bans on abortion in states with weak laws. The chapters cover states in which the laws are similar, like Indiana and Wisconsin. But I was really struck when reading these chapters by how different these states laws are from what I thought. That is, I was under the impression that before Roe v. Wade, states with weak abortion laws were generally more conservative. (I was wrong, of course, with regard to Indiana, which had more liberal laws. But I still found these more extreme laws, like laws in Tennessee that prohibit women from obtaining abortions if doctors think the fetus is stillborn, or laws in Georgia, where any doctor performing an abortion faces criminal prosecution, disturbing. The book offers new evidence that these laws are in fact, often, more conservative. If Roe v. Wade were decided in the next few days, its possible that these states, like Tennessee, could implement
paraphrase: Before Roe v. Wade, the politics of abortion in this country differed from what many people, including the author, initially thought in significant ways, according to a new book by Linda Greenhouse and Rev. Frank Norris, titled "Before Roe v. Wade." The book is available in hardcover or trade paperback edition from T.C. Harris, and a second edition will be released in April. The book sheds light on the evolution of state laws on abortion, from the "conversion therapy" era of the 1950s to more recent attempts to enact bans on abortion in states with lax laws. The authors delve into the legal frameworks of states with similar laws, such as Indiana and Wisconsin, but the author was surprised to discover that these states' laws were not as conservative as they thought, with Indiana having more liberal abortion laws. The book presents new evidence that these laws are often more conservative than anticipated, and if Roe v. Wade were decided today, it's possible that states like Tennessee could enact similar laws.

input: Wests have fired an early warning shot in what Rosellas coach Matt Lantry described as "close to a complete performance". The men in green and red scored at better than a point a minute for most of the first half before eventually defeating Lakes
continuation: ide United, 1-0. The win was the club's fifth in six rounds of Super League and saw the Reds end the season with more home league victories (nine) than defeats (five) for the first time in Lantry's tenure. Lantry was pleased with his side's performance in what was also his final game in charge. "I think what was pleasing was when we first came into this game, I asked them whether they were feeling 'weird' going into it or not, and I think it was one of them was, 'we're just glad to get it over with. We don't want it to go into extra-time, especially when it's this early in the season, it's too early. But it was good. I was pleased with our game. We didn't want it to go into extra-time. "I was disappointed at times with the way we played in the first 20 minutes, I was disappointed with what I saw with their pace of ball. I was disappointed with our overall performance. But I don't think it was too far off, I think it was really close, I think it was about one or two small mistakes, we made them, which is why I said in
paraphrase: Wests delivered an early warning shot in what Lantes coach Matt Lantry termed as "a near-flawless performance". The men in green and red scored at an impressive rate of over a point per minute during the first half, ultimately defeating Lakeside United 1-0. This victory marked the team's fifth win in six matches of the Super League, with the Reds finishing the season with more home league victories (nine) than defeats (five) for the first time under Lantry's tenure. Lantry was pleased with his team's performance, noting that it was a satisfying conclusion to his final match in charge. "I was pleased with how the players responded when I asked if they were feeling 'weird' going into the game. It was clear they were eager to get started and avoid extra time, especially early in the season. I was impressed with their game, despite a few minor setbacks in the opening 20 minutes. However, overall, their performance was very close to flawless."

Emaar Hospitality Group has unveiled its new hotel brand, The Address Hotels and Resorts, with three properties slated to open in the next seven months in Dubai.
Planned properties include the 143-room and 57-suite The
continuation:
Address Grand, in collaboration with Dubai-based The House Hotel Group, The Address Al Jassim, in collaboration with The House Group, The Address Al Hamra, and The Address Waterfront. The latter is located in Al Jassim, just minutes away from Jumeirah Beach Club.
The new brand aims to offer an exciting new approach to hospitality in this market, said Mohammed Saif Al-Shaibani, CEO, Emaar Hospitality Group. The company is currently working on a fourth hotel, slated to begin construction in 2018.
Dubais hospitality industry is expanding exponentially with more hotel offerings in various categories. The address brand offers luxury experiences in one location in the city, he said.
With this new concept, hospitality providers in the city will benefit from the new hospitality landscape and will offer something that is unique, innovative, and distinct in the market. We are looking forward to working with partners in this exciting segment, Al-Shaibani added.
Located in The Emirates Hills in Al Jassim, The Address Al Jassim is set in a modern, contemporary environment with contemporary decor. The property comprises six floors of pent
paraphrase:
Emaar Hospitality Group has unveiled its new hotel brand, The Address Hotels and Resorts, with three properties slated to open within the next seven months in Dubai.
The initial properties under the brand include the 143-room and 57-suite Address Grand, which is a collaboration with Dubai-based The House Hotel Group, The Address Al Jassim, which is a collaboration with The House Group, and The Address Al Hamra. The Address Waterfront, located in Al Jassim, is minutes away from Jumeirah Beach Club, offering luxurious accommodations with modern decor.
According to Mohammed Saif Al-Shaibani, CEO of Emaar Hospitality Group, the new brand aims to provide a unique and innovative approach to hospitality in the market. The company is currently working on a fourth hotel, slated to begin construction in 2018.
As Dubai's hospitality industry continues to grow exponentially, The Address brand offers a one-stop destination for luxury experiences in the city. Al-Shaibani believes that partners in the industry will benefit from the new hospitality landscape and will offer distinct offerings in the market.
The Address Al Jassim, located in The Emirates Hills, boasts a modern and contemporary design with sleek decor. The property consists of six floors of penthouse-style accommodations, catering to the discerning traveler.
In summary, Emaar Hospitality Group has launched The Address Hotels and Resorts, with three properties set to open in Dubai in the next seven months. The brand aims to provide a unique and innovative approach to hospitality, with a focus on luxury experiences in one location. The initial properties include The Address Grand, The Address Al Jassim, and The Address Al Hamra, each offering modern and contemporary designs.

input:
Paparazzi who took photographs of Princess Diana dying in a car wreck stopped police from getting to the scene, her inquest heard today.
Eyewitness Clifford Goorovadoo said: "It is true that when the first police officers
continuation:
arrive, it is just like a movie.
"It was a slow-motion scene.
"I could see it. I looked and saw it. The police car was just around the bend.
"I could hear them say'stop the car'."
Mr Goorovadoo, of Luton, said he saw the car go into a ditch off a car park, and stopped it with his car.
"I could hear police radios, I could hear them saying'stop, stop, stop, stop,' " he said. "It was like a movie."
Detective Inspector Paul Clark, from Hampshire Police, told the hearing: "I recall quite vividly hearing the radio. 'Stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop,' " he said.
"I looked around and saw a small dark car. I said 'you've hit something'. I didn't know what it was. I said'stop, stop, stop, stop, stop.'
"I said, 'you've hit something, don't go any further'."
Mr Clark said he saw lights on the car. "I could see the car was moving, it was going really fast, I could see it, I
paraphrase: A number of photographers who were nearby when Princess Diana was involved in a fatal car accident reportedly hindered the police's ability to reach the scene. According to eyewitness Clifford Goorovadoo, the first police officers to arrive found the scene in a state of slow-motion, with the car off the road and the police car stopped nearby. Goorovadoo claims he stopped the car with his own vehicle after seeing it go into a ditch off a car park. Detective Inspector Paul Clark of Hampshire Police also testified that he heard police radios shouting "stop" multiple times as they tried to reach the scene. Clark stated that he saw a small, dark car and yelled at the driver to stop, as he believed they had hit something.

input:
The CF Toronto Eaton Centre seen on Mar. 1, 2018.
Cadillac Fairview Corp. Ltd. is the latest Canadian real estate giant to make a concerted push into technology investing by backing a new $150-million venture-capital fund
continuation:
.
Cadillac is one of many Canadian real-estate operators that are exploring various opportunities to broaden its holdings beyond traditional office and retail  an area where growth is expected to slow in coming years. The companys recent acquisitions of residential-office projects from Simon Property Group Inc. and Brookfield Property Partners, for instance, show its interest in investing in technology-related activities. The new fund, called Cadillac Invest, aims to invest in software, enterprise software and technology-enabled infrastructure, with the goal of creating leading-edge technology companies, according to a company press release. It is set to raise C$250-million from investors in its first year.

input: DES MOINES, Iowa (AP)  Authorities apprehended a man Wednesday suspected in the early morning killings of two Des Moines area police officers who were shot to death while sitting in their patrol cars in what authorities described as separate ambush-style attacks.
continuation: The suspected shooter was later taken into custody in Iowa. Police say the shootings happened around 1:40 a.m. local time when a suspect, later identified as 20-year-old Robert Ator, allegedly shot Officer Linn County Sheriffs Officer Ron Helus and his partner, 24-year-old Sergeant Matt Campbell, multiple times in a case of mistaken identity. The officers, who were off-duty, were working undercover Tuesday when Ator approached them, identified himself and pulled out a handgun. Police say Ator also exchanged gunfire with other responding officers. Ator was later apprehended in his car after shooting himself. Authorities believe the shooting was random. Authorities say the shooter drove more than 20 miles from his home in Ames, where he is from, to the area where the shootings happened. Ator was also hospitalized following his arrest. Ator is charged with two counts of murder, first degree. He is expected to be arraigned in court later Wednesday. Ators mother, Mona Ator, said her son was home in Ames when he was taken into custody, but declined to talk more specifically.
paraphrase: Robert Ator, a 20-year-old man from Ames, Iowa, was taken into custody by authorities on Wednesday, suspected of carrying out the deadly shootings of two Des Moines area police officers. The officers, Officer Ron Helus and Sergeant Matt Campbell, were shot and killed in separate ambush-style attacks while sitting in their patrol cars around 1:40 a.m. local time. According to police, Ator approached the officers, who were off-duty and working undercover, and identified himself before pulling out a handgun and shooting them multiple times. Authorities believe the shooting was a random act. Ator reportedly drove over 20 miles from his home in Ames to the area where the shootings occurred. He was hospitalized after his arrest and charged with two counts of murder, first degree. Ator's mother, Mona Ator, declined to provide further details on her son's whereabouts during the incident.
