input: Alastair Cook has been granted more time to decide his future as Test captain, with England having privately advised that Fridays meeting with the director of cricket, Andrew Strauss, will not be followed by a definitive announcement on the subject.
continuation:
Cooks preference, in recent days, has been to stand aside for one final series, with his younger brother, Alastair, succeeding him in the summer of 2018, rather than his current deputy, Alastair Wainwright. But given recent injuries, it is difficult to foresee him remaining captain beyond this series, or next years one-day series in India, while, in the meantime, he is in his mid-40s. Strauss, his current boss, is concerned that if Cook were to choose to step aside this year, he might be left in limbo.

The suggestion of Cook remaining captain this summer may be a moot one, if, when, and where, India are involved. He was dropped before the final Test of the series in India, which was drawn, in January, with James Anderson scoring a six-for in the first innings. He was subsequently recalled, as he did in last years home Ashes, only to be rested from the second innings. The move to replace him was made in part as a precaution, given the length of the series, given that he had just recovered from back-to-back operations. He has played just one first-
paraphrase:
Alastair Cook has been granted more time to deliberate on his future as Test captain, with England's director of cricket, Andrew Strauss, informing him that a final decision on the matter will not be made immediately after their scheduled meeting on Friday.
Recent reports suggest that Cook's preference is to step aside as captain for one final series, with his younger brother, Alastair, taking over in the summer of 2018. However, given his age and recent injuries, it is uncertain whether he will remain captain beyond this series or next year's one-day series in India. Strauss is concerned that if Cook chooses to step aside this year, he may be left in limbo.
The proposal of Cook remaining captain this summer is uncertain, especially if India are involved. He was dropped from the final Test of the series in India earlier this year due to injury, but was later recalled for the second innings. The decision to replace him was made as a precaution, given the length of the series, as he had just recovered from back-to-back operations. He has played only one first-class match since his return.

Lazio also stayed on

track for next months final with a 3-1 win at Genoa.

After CSKA twice came from behind, Granit Xhakas first-half goal saw them beat Arsenal 2-1, while Atleticos victory extended their unbeaten streak in European matches this season.
With Arsenals defeat, Spartas qualification hopes are growing too, while Benfica are still three points from the Europa Leagues final four.
In a match which could yet go to penalties, Atleticos late goal allowed them to go second, despite CSKA scoring twice in the last six minutes.
I dont think we deserved anything from this match, said CSKAs captain Roman Yaremchuk.
It was too easy. We played some fantastic matches this season. This game wasnt a challenge for
paraphrase: Arsenal made significant progress towards the Europa League semifinals with a dominant 4-1 victory over CSKA Moscow, while Atletico Madrid also advanced with a 2-0 home win over Sporting Lisbon on Thursday. Lazio continued their unbeaten streak in Group H with a 3-1 win at Genoa. In other matches, Bayer Leverkusen drew 1-1 with Sparta Prague, Sporting Lisbon triumphed 3-0 against Sporting Braga, and Benfica secured a 1-0 away win over Torino. Arsenal's loss to CSKA means that Sparta's qualification hopes are strengthening, while Benfica remain three points from the Europa League's final four. Despite CSKA's late comeback, Atletico's victory secured them second place in the group. "We didn't deserve anything from this match," CSKA captain Roman Yaremchuk said after the game.

input:
Patients who need cannabis as treatment have been forgotten, and before discussing the recreational use of the plant, Malta should prioritise access to more medicinal cannabis preparations, the authorities are being urged.
It is upsetting to be
continuation:
asked what is the harm, while people, many in crisis, wait in queues, one patient was quoted in The Sunday Times.
Another said he was waiting six months for his prescription.
Patients say that in the UK, it is still difficult to get hold of cannabis. Many are prescribed medications, either by specialist doctors or in hospital emergency departments, which contain cannabis. Many also use cannabis oils.
A report commissioned by the European Commission found that cannabis-related seizures in Europe could cost the bloc around 18.6 billion annually.
An estimated 28,300 people in Europe are using cannabis daily. But this is just one way of looking at the problem. The other is how many people in Europe are using it illegally. The UK, for instance, says more than 500,000 cannabis users are in criminal gangs. This is often done under cover of being medical patients.
Patients are only given cannabis oils or capsules from one pharmaceutical company which also happens to use cannabis in its medical products. Its hard to tell if it is medical cannabis or THC in other cannabis products. Many of them are also in despair, due to lack of medical cannabis. This is what is called a cannabis psychosis, which
paraphrase: Patients seeking medical cannabis have been overlooked, with Malta should prioritize increasing access to more medicinal cannabis products, advocates argue. It is frustrating to be questioned about the harm while individuals, many in crisis, face long wait times, a patient stated in The Sunday Times. Another patient reported waiting six months for their prescription. Patients in the UK often face difficulties obtaining cannabis, and many turn to medications prescribed by specialist doctors or obtained in emergency departments, which may contain cannabis. Some also use cannabis oils. A European Commission-commissioned report revealed that cannabis-related seizures in Europe could cost the bloc around 18.6 billion annually. It is estimated that 28,300 people in Europe use cannabis daily, but this figure only represents one aspect of the problem. Another perspective is the number of individuals in Europe using cannabis illegally. For instance, the UK estimates that over 500,000 cannabis users are in criminal gangs, many of whom masquerade as medical patients. Currently, patients in Malta are only provided with cannabis oils or capsules from a single pharmaceutical company, which also happens to use cannabis in its medical products. This makes it difficult to determine whether the products are truly medical cannabis or contain THC from other sources. As a result, many patients are in despair due to the lack of access to proper medical cannabis, leading to a phenomenon known as "cannabis psychosis."

input: That it's such a hidden statistic, however, is an embarrassing reflection of our collective ignorance. Hundreds more people died by suicide in Oregon in 2017 than by traffic crashes, firearms or drug overdose. The suicide rate in Oregon is well above the national average
continuation:
, and it continues to rise, making it the second-highest state in the nation. The reason it is rising is too often attributed solely to "health care issues" or "poor mental health." This is, without question, far from the case. But many people, in far too many communities, dont think of suicide as an epidemic. "Its far too dangerous, says Michael J. Smith, who lives in Eugene, Oregon. "Suicide is not something people think of often. But when something happens, its easy to think of."

Smith is a former Marine, former police officer, now a social worker. His sister, Tanya, also lives in Eugene. He knows first hand the devastating impact of suicide. His uncle, he says, tried to kill himself twice. His brother, Michael, died by suicide, too. He saw it in his own brother. Michaels death, too, happened when he was younger. "I remember thinking, 'Why did I let this happen?'" Smith says. "What is it about Michael? Is he mentally ill?" He thinks he knows. "My brother was mentally ill." The younger Smith was hospitalized with
paraphrase:
The alarming statistic of suicide in Oregon has exposed the collective ignorance of society. While more people died from suicide in 2017 than from traffic accidents, firearms, or drug overdoses, the topic is often brushed off as a healthcare issue or a sign of poor mental health. However, this oversimplification neglects the complex reasons behind the rising suicide rate. According to Michael J. Smith, a former Marine and police officer from Eugene, Oregon, the lack of recognition of suicide as an epidemic is due to its taboo nature. Smith, who lost his brother to suicide, emphasizes that suicide is not something people often think about, but when it happens, it becomes a pressing concern. He believes that a deeper understanding of mental health is necessary to address this issue.
In contrast to the common belief that mental illness is the sole cause of suicide, Smith shares his personal experience of losing his brother to suicide at a young age. He reflects on his own thought processes during that time, wondering why he failed to prevent his brother's death. This personal account highlights the importance of mental health awareness and the need to break the stigma surrounding suicide. By acknowledging the underlying factors contributing to the rising suicide rate, such as healthcare issues and societal pressures, we can work towards a more comprehensive approach to address this growing epidemic.

Every year in sports, theres a breakout player or a breakout moment that inspires the masses to dig deeper for their dreams.
Justin Holiday may be the next breakout story.

big jump in his game. The rookie from USC is shooting more efficiently from 3-point range, hes getting to the free-throw line more frequently and his overall game is improving.
Holiday is looking more confident, more comfortable with what hes doing. He is still learning, hes still learning his craft, but hes starting to make more of his shots. Hes also making his free-throw percentage more of a factor in his overall stats.
Holiday, 20, is averaging 7.6 points, 3.1 rebounds, 1.6 assists, 1.1 steals and 1.1 block per game this season, which is second-most among rookies in points, rebounds and assists. Hes also shooting 46.1 percent from 3-point range.
Holiday is enjoying this NBA season, even if it is still his rookie season. He knows hes growing, learning more and is constantly looking to improve. Holiday says hes just happy hes getting more minutes. The Lakers will only get more minutes, with the teams injury issues, next season.
Im
paraphrase: This young athlete, Justin Holiday, may be on the cusp of a remarkable rise to fame. As a rookie in the NBA, he's shown significant improvement in his game, particularly in his shooting accuracy from beyond the arc and his ability to get to the free-throw line. With each passing game, Holiday is becoming more confident and comfortable in his role, and his stats are reflecting this growth. Currently, he's averaging 7.6 points, 3.1 rebounds, 1.6 assists, 1.1 steals, and 1.1 blocks per game, which is a impressive haul for a rookie. His 46.1% three-point shooting percentage is also noteworthy. Holiday appears to be enjoying his time in the NBA, despite still being in his rookie season, and he's eager to continue learning and improving. With the Lakers' injury issues, he's likely to see even more playing time next season, which could be a springboard for his career.

input: The 2019 Honda Pilot, on the outside, looks like any other modern SUV. It has the ride height and space thats convinced Americans to abandon cars and flock toward larger vehicles, and, like the rest of that segment, it blends in

with its urban environment. The difference is, this is not a big SUV. Its small, its tight, its just not going to stand out. Hondas new mid-size offering, the Honda Pilot, could change all of that.

The new Honda Pilot takes shape from this years Honda HR-V, which is itself based on the same 2018 Honda HR-V. Its still quite boxy, with a low, wide stance and a sharp crease running the length of the wheelbase. Like its predecessor, its also quite crossover-oriented, with the front-wheel-drive variant with all-wheel drive. Its a little more muscular underneath, with wider, more aggressive suspension. And its interior is more modern, with sporty styling, leather trim, and more spacious, more modern features. The 2018 HR-V is still one of the least-expensive new vehicles in its segment, too.

Hondas big news for 2019 is a new, larger engine, one with more power than the HR-Vs naturally aspirated 3.5-liter. This new engine
paraphrase:
The 2019 Honda Pilot boasts an unassuming exterior that blends in with its surroundings, much like its fellow SUVs in the segment. However, this vehicle is different from its larger counterparts, as it is small and compact, defying expectations. Honda's latest offering is a departure from the norm, with its sleek, modern design inspired by the Honda HR-V. The front-wheel-drive variant offers all-wheel drive, giving it a more aggressive stance on the road. The interior is more spacious and feature-rich, with a sporty design and premium materials. The 2019 Honda Pilot is a more affordable option in its segment, making it an attractive choice for budget-conscious buyers.
One of the most significant upgrades for the 2019 Honda Pilot is the new, more powerful engine. Gone is the naturally aspirated 3.5-liter engine of its predecessor, replaced by a more powerful unit that delivers impressive performance. This new engine is a significant improvement over the previous one, offering better acceleration and overall driving experience.

input: The Vietnamese version of the 2010 census questionnaire used the words dieu tra to describe the population tally  but what the words really conveyed was something like a communist government investigation. On Korean forms, county was translated
continuation: in English as joo-gon, and it was always used without any apparent distinction. This was similar in practice in Taiwan, where, in the 1950s, the government made more of an effort to register people in rural areas. This led, in theory, to more accurate calculations. As early as 1986, Taiwans Ministry of Education changed the way it collected national census data. It introduced terms such as Korean people or Korean people with Korean citizenship. The Ministry of Justice, in Taiwan, also made use of the more nuanced distinction of Taiwans various ethnic groups. It called Koreans Tainan people or Taiwan people. This distinction remained in use even when Taiwans various ethnic groups made similar demands, or when Taiwan introduced its own forms, which were often less accurate. A Korean friend told me she was surprised when, when she tried using her birth certificate in Taiwan, she found it used to describe her. A few of her schoolmates were also shocked when the school asked them which language they spoke. The use of terms such as Korean people in place of K
paraphrase: The 2010 census in Vietnam used the term "dieu tra" to describe the population count, but the true meaning conveyed was more akin to a government investigation under a communist regime. In contrast, the Korean version of the census form used the term "joo-gon" to translate "county," without any apparent distinction. Similarly, in Taiwan, the government made an effort to register people in rural areas as early as the 1950s, which led to more accurate calculations. By 1986, Taiwan's Ministry of Education had modified its census data collection methods, introducing nuanced terms such as "Korean people" or "Korean citizens." Taiwan's Ministry of Justice also adopted these terms to distinguish between different ethnic groups within the Korean population. However, this distinction remained in use even when Taiwanese people of Korean descent made similar demands or when the country introduced its own forms, which were often less accurate. A Korean friend found that her birth certificate listed her as "Korean," and some of her schoolmates were surprised when the school asked them which language they spoke.

MUNCIE, Ind.  Local streets are due to get newly-painted center lines and other pavement markings soon.
The Muncie Board of Works and Public Safety on
continuation:
Tuesday is expected to take bids from companies wanting to provide the services.
At Tuesday's city board meeting, Board of Public Works Chairman Bill Miller said he expects crews to begin working soon. The city will put crews in place from 8 p.m. Tuesday to 6 a.m. Wednesday, Sept. 15, according to the agenda.
A majority of Muncie streets will get new center lines and other pavement markings. Miller said the city may need to use contractors for some of them, especially if weather is bad. The city doesn't want any of its workers getting injured, he said.
"In some cases, I'll get calls from (customer) service or from someone who is in traffic when it rains and they get a head-on with (a construction worker), and it was raining or it was snowing and it just was pouring rain, and this person was hit," Miller said. "And, it just doesn't want to happen, with us."
In other business, Tuesday's board is expected to adopt contracts with W.A. Phillips to repair roads. Miller said Phillips will fix local roads beginning Sunday, Sept. 19, with the first of six trucks arriving Wednesday.
Miller said he
paraphrase: The city is seeking bids for the striping and marking of its streets. The Muncie Board of Works and Public Safety is expected to consider these bids at its Tuesday meeting. According to Board Chairman Bill Miller, the city will begin working on the project soon, with crews working from 8 pm on Tuesday to 6 am on Wednesday, September 15. A majority of Muncie's streets will receive new center lines and pavement markings, with the city possibly contracting with outside contractors in case of inclement weather. Miller expressed concerns about safety, citing the potential for accidents involving construction workers and innocent bystanders. In other business, the board is expected to approve contracts with W.A. Phillips for road repairs, with work beginning on September 19. Miller stated that six trucks will be deployed for the repairs, with the first truck arriving on Wednesday.

input:
Amnesty International calls upon Hamas (the Islamic Resistance Movement) to commit unequivocally to abide by international law, respect the rights of all Palestinians across the political spectrum and repudiate its policy of targeting Israeli civilians.
"As it prepares to form the next
continuation:
government of Palestinian state, Hamas should move from threats of war to commitments of peace, and show that it is willing to live within Israels borders," said Mohammed Salem, Amnesty International's Regional Director for Middle East and North Africa. "The international community must hold Hamas  not Israel  to its commitments and responsibilities under international law."
"Israeli forces are justified in using force in response to Hamas continued use of force against Israels civilians, even if the victims are Hamas fighters or civilians, or even if Hamas is a designated terrorist organisation, said James Ball, Amnesty Internationals Israel researcher. "Hamas must end its indiscriminate shelling of residential buildings, cease using residential buildings for military purposes, stop using them as launching sites and stop firing rockets from residential buildings."
Since January, Hamas-affiliated rockets have been launched from residential buildings in Gaza, many of which appear to have been in use for many decades. One was launched from a residential building in Jabaliya in early January which killed seven civilians, including six children. One Palestinian was killed when he was hit by a fragment from a rocket fired from a residential building in Jabaliya in late January. Four more were injured in separate incidents
paraphrase:
Amnesty International urges Hamas to embrace international law and respect the rights of all Palestinians, including those across the political spectrum. According to Mohammed Salem, the organizations regional director for the Middle East and North Africa, Hamas should shift its focus from threats of violence to commitments of peace as it prepares to form a government for a future Palestinian state. The international community must hold Hamas accountable for its obligations under international law, rather than solely targeting Israel.
Meanwhile, Amnesty International's Israel researcher, James Ball, highlights the justification of Israeli force in response to Hamas' continued use of violence against Israeli civilians, including fighters and non-combatants. Hamas must cease its indiscriminate shelling of residential buildings, stop using them for military purposes, and refrain from launching rockets from inhabited areas. Since January, numerous rockets have been launched from residential buildings in Gaza, many of which have been in use for decades, resulting in the deaths of seven civilians, including children, and injuring several more.
In conclusion, Amnesty International reiterates its call for Hamas to adhere to international law and respect the rights of all Palestinians, while also acknowledging the legitimacy of Israeli force in response to Hamas' aggressive actions.

input: As part of an effort to give applications more control over the infrastructure used to host them in the cloud, Riverbed Technology today at the Interop 2013 conference unveiled the Stingray Services Controller, a next-generation instance of the virtual application delivery controller (
continuation:
vCD) used in Riverbeds Stingray Network Appliance. The new feature allows application servers to configure firewall rules to block access from the Internet to specified IP addresses within their domain. This feature can also block other forms of traffic  DNS, TCP/IP traffic, or any of the common methods used in enterprise applications. The application server configuration controls also enable application servers to set which routes are used with which routing protocols, allowing them to control which protocols are used in their application servers.

Riverbeds new service control feature will enable application servers running in the cloud to limit firewall rules in order to optimize performance, without impacting business processes. The vCD is a virtual application deployment mechanism built into servers. The new service control feature is also available in other CloudFormation packages. The Stingray Network Appliance is a next-generation, highly available, and secure virtual application infrastructure. It delivers applications from a private or public cloud. The network appliance supports virtual private servers (vPS) with the vCD, with single-tenant, or with many-tenant deployment options.

As applications move from the application server or application client side, it is important that application servers have complete control
paraphrase: To enhance control over cloud infrastructure for hosting applications, Riverbed Technology unveiled the Stingray Services Controller at Interop 2013. This next-generation virtual application delivery controller (vCD) allows application servers to configure firewall rules to restrict Internet access to specific IP addresses within their domain, as well as block other types of traffic such as DNS, TCP/IP, or common enterprise application traffic. The vCD also enables application servers to set routing protocols and control which protocols are used in their servers. With this feature, application servers in the cloud can optimize performance without affecting business processes. The Stingray Network Appliance, a secure and highly available virtual application infrastructure, supports vCD and offers multiple deployment options, including single-tenant and many-tenant environments. As applications transition from server or client sides, it is crucial for application servers to have full control over their infrastructure.

With the Duchesses of Sussex and Cambridge in the Royal Box and Tiger
continuation:
King in the crowd, Kerber  one of the tournament favourites  made her way into the trophy ceremony, which saw her rise from semi-finalist to finalist in one go.
After she beat Polands Iga Swiatek 6-0, 6-0 in just over an hour, Kerber said: Im super happy. Im super happy, Im super happy. Im super happy, Im super happy, Im super happy.
And when she was asked what was it like to go from losing in the first round of Wimbledon in 2016 to making the final, she said: Its one of the biggest moments of my life. I think its also really nice to play against Serena, even if she is a legend in tennis.
Kerber, 28, was asked what it was like to play her former rival Serena Williams in the final. (AAP)
In her post-match interview, Kerber  who was making her first Wimbledon final  said Williams had been one of her inspirations, adding: I
paraphrase:
Angelique Kerber's inspiring comeback story at Wimbledon culminated in a triumphant victory on Saturday, with the German tennis star defeating Poland's Iga Swiatek in the final. Amidst the presence of royalty, including the Duchesses of Sussex and Cambridge, and the energetic Tiger King, Kerber's remarkable journey from semi-finalist to champion was capped off in an hour-long contest.
As she accepted the trophy, Kerber expressed her delight, exclaiming "I'm super happy!" multiple times. When asked about her remarkable turnaround from losing in the first round of Wimbledon in 2016 to reaching the final this year, Kerber stated, "It's one of the biggest moments of my life. I think it's also really nice to play against Serena, even if she is a tennis legend."
Kerber, 28, was also quizzed about her experience of facing her former rival Serena Williams in the final, revealing that Williams had been an inspiration to her throughout her career. The post-match interview further highlighted Kerber's growth and resilience, as she reflected on her journey from a semi-finalist to a champion.

input:
Radio host Alan Chartock interviewed Gov. Cuomo on Thursday afternoon, just as he has on hundreds of occasions in the past.
It was a remarkable first.
Chartock, the most omnipresent voice on radio airwaves from Westchester to southern
continuation:
New Jersey, didn't shy away from making a number of sharp  if tongue-in-cheek  remarks about the governor, in his first hour of conversation. He asked him if he was in favor of gun control, and whether he was willing to abolish his police force. He also asked him if he was willing to raise taxes. (And, he said, if he was willing to abolish his police force, which is one reason he is running for governor of New York. He also supports gay marriage, which Cuomo has also said he supports. "I don't like gay marriage, because I think I am married to him," he said. "I don't think he is married to me.")
"How did I end up with this job?" Cuomo quipped, seeming in disbelief. He didn't seem bothered in any way when he was asked what he was wearing when he interviewed Bill Maher. He said he had been making "the rounds" on "all these radio stations."
"And I'm in his home state?" Chartock asked. "You've got to be kidding me."
"Oh, yes, I've been here," Cuomo said, "since 1980." He was born in Schenectady
paraphrase: Alan Chartock spoke with Gov. Cuomo during a recent interview, which was a familiar occurrence for both parties. Chartock, a well-known radio host, didn't hesitate to ask Cuomo a range of questions, including his stance on gun control and taxes, as well as his willingness to abolish his police force. Cuomo, seemingly amused, quipped about ending up with the job he has now. When asked about his attire during an interview with Bill Maher, Cuomo was nonchalant. Throughout the conversation, Chartock and Cuomo exchanged light-hearted remarks, with Chartock jokingly expressing surprise at being in Cuomo's home state. Cuomo confirmed he has been in New York since 1980, having been born in Schenectady.

input:
Queen Elizabeth II delivered a Christmas Day speech to Britons about the importance of coming together and making sacrifices  but she apparently didnt put much thought into the decor.
The monarch was blasted for making the speech calling for self-sacrifice while
continuation:
she was surrounded by modern luxury  especially her gold-and-white fur cape. The royal was decked in her usual regal look, complete with a diamond tiara, as she delivered her annual message.
Despite it being her favorite time of year, Queen Elizabeth did not show off any of her royal jewels, like her diamond or diamond brooch. The Queen also made no mention of the British Empire or the Empire Building.
Other royal jewels included one gold bracelet and her diamond, gold, and diamond brooch, which was kept in place by her diamond pendant. But she left her diamond brooch in a box at Buckingham Palace.
Its been seven decades since Queen Elizabeth IIs father, King George VI, was killed in a car accident in January, 1936. At the time, Queen Elizabeths mother, Queen Mary, was still in her 20s, which made her almost the same age as her father, King George VI. King George VI was 80 when he died in 1952.
Queen Elizabeth IIs father, King George VI, became one of Britains most beloved monarchs, as many are still still talking about his legacy. The British
paraphrase: Queen Elizabeth II delivered a heartfelt Christmas Day message to the British people, emphasizing the importance of unity and sacrifice. However, her extravagant attire, complete with a gold-and-white fur cape, sparked criticism for being out of touch with the times. The monarch wore her usual regal attire, consisting of a diamond tiara and other royal jewels, as she delivered her annual address. While she did not showcase any of her most prized jewels, such as her diamond or diamond brooch, she did mention the importance of the British Empire and its legacy. The Queen's father, King George VI, passed away in a car accident in 1936, leaving Queen Elizabeth II's mother, Queen Mary, to raise their children alone. King George VI is still fondly remembered as one of Britains most beloved monarchs, with his legacy continuing to inspire many.

input:
The difficult dialogue began with a dark auditorium and a film screening, displaying the long history of the incarceration of African-Americans for the 80 students and community members in attendance.
The documentary, 13th, kept with the theme
continuation:
of the history of slavery in the United States, but this time it was set in the early 1900s in the western state of Washington, where thousands of African-American men, women, and children were sentenced to death for crimes, many of which they were unaware of. The audience was introduced to former Oregonian, James W. Auerbach, an attorney involved in the case, as he spoke to his young client, Paul Chambers, who was sentenced to die.
Auerbach called Chambers an innocent young man, adding, His life sentence was one of terror. Chambers, his attorney said, was framed for the murder of George Rook, which was the murder of his stepfather. Auerbach said Chambers, who was of Mexican descent, was innocent of Rooks death. Chambers was also innocent of the murder of Charles Johnson, according to Auerbach. Auerbach said Rook, Johnson, and Chambers were in a relationship with Rooks sister, who killed him. It is unknown if Chambers was aware of any relationship with his sister, although he may have been given alcohol in hopes of protecting her, according to Auerbach.
A
paraphrase:
The insightful dialogue began with a dimly lit auditorium and a film screening, showcasing the long and complex history of racial injustice in the United States. The documentary, "13th," continued the theme of slavery and its legacy, but this time focused on a specific period in the early 1900s in the Pacific Northwest, where thousands of African-American men, women, and children were unjustly sentenced to death.
The audience was introduced to a former attorney, James W. Auerbach, who was involved in one of these cases. Auerbach shared the story of his young client, Paul Chambers, who was sentenced to death despite his innocence. Chambers, a man of Mexican descent, was wrongly accused of murdering his stepfather and another man. Auerbach argued that Chambers was an innocent victim of a twisted and oppressive system, and that he was unfairly targeted due to his race and ethnicity.
Auerbach explained that Chambers may have been given alcohol by his stepfather's sister, who was actually the one responsible for his death. The details of the case were complex and nuanced, and Auerbach emphasized the need for greater understanding and empathy in addressing the ongoing legacy of racial injustice.

input:
Astounding? Or are you kind of afraid of a robot takeover now?
Gymnasts dreaming of a future Olympic win might find they have some competition  the robot kind.
Waltham-based Boston Dynamics shared a video Thursday of
continuation:
its Spot, which is trained to deliver cargo like Lego blocks in its tiny robot hands, according to a company statement. It's also ready to haul its own payloads, like, say, luggage or a baby stroller.
It will even ride into town, just like humans.
"It doesn't look like it will ever look human, but it certainly will. Boston Dynamics is working with Google X, which is making its own self-driving car," Boston Dynamics CEO Marc Raibert said in a company news release. "It really is a big partnership."
It seems like a bit of a stretch to envision Boston Dynamics working with Google, although Boston Dynamics says it's "not too far away." The company says Google X is a big part of what's fueling its robot-building progress.
"It was in Google X, where they were working in robotics, in this incredible program. It made them really jump on this technology, like, 'Oh, this is where it goes,' " Raibert said.
The new video, which appears to show the robot performing similar actions in real life, is "just one small step," Raibert said.
"I don't think it's going to
paraphrase: As Boston Dynamics unveils its latest robotic creation, some may wonder if a robot takeover is on the horizon. Gymnasts dreaming of Olympic glory may need to reconsider their ambitions, as the company's Spot robot is capable of delivering cargo and hauling its own payloads with ease. Equipped with tiny robot hands, it can even ride into town like a human. Boston Dynamics is collaborating with Google X, which is also working on self-driving cars, to fuel their robot-building progress. The company's CEO, Marc Raibert, notes that the partnership has been instrumental in advancing the technology. The new video showcasing the robot's abilities is just one small step towards a future where robots may play a more significant role in our lives.

input:
Liverpool have submitted a bid for Real Madrid's Karim Benzema.
Several sources in Spain have suggested that Reds boss Brendan Rodgers submitted a bid in the region of 50m for the French international, who joined Real in 2010, earlier today.
continuation:
A deal for the 32-year-old could get off the ground if, according to The Sun, Real Madrid do not receive a further 18m in cash from Tottenham, who are ready to listen to offers for striker Emmanuel Adebayor.
Rodgers could move to sign Benzema this month, with the French striker due back in training in Madrid.
Rodgers will need to get his transfer business done swiftly if he is going to meet Liverpools current transfer budgets. The Merseyside club are currently short of funds, with Philippe Coutinho set to depart Anfield, which could limit his transfer options.
Rodgers will need to move fast in order to meet Liverpools transfer budgets, which are currently set at 40m. This means that the clubs next purchase is expected to be a defender, with Kostas Manolas available, although he is expected to cost around 15m.
paraphrase:
Liverpool has put in a bid for Real Madrid's Karim Benzema, according to multiple sources in Spain. The Reds' manager, Brendan Rodgers, is believed to have offered around 50 million pounds for the French international, who joined Real in 2010.
A potential deal could be close to completion if Real Madrid do not receive an additional 18 million pounds in cash from Tottenham, who are willing to consider offers for their striker Emmanuel Adebayor.
Rodgers is keen to secure Benzema's signature this month, with the French striker set to return to training in Madrid. However, the Liverpool manager will need to act quickly to meet the club's transfer budget, which is currently set at 40 million pounds.
With Philippe Coutinho poised to leave Anfield, Rodgers may need to act fast to secure a defender, with Kostas Manolas being considered as a potential target. While Manolas is expected to cost around 15 million pounds, Liverpool may need to act swiftly to secure his signature.

input:
Cleveland-Cliffs isn't the company it once was, but Wall Street is still pricing it that way.
For years, iron ore producer Cleveland-Cliffs (NYSE:CLF) has been in the midst of a turnaround plan
continuation:
that aims to put itself on more solid financial footing. This year, its stock was trading in line with other iron ore producers like Rio Tinto Group (NYSE:RIO) or Vale SA (NYSE:VALE), although it was trading at a much higher valuation. The rebound in its stock price in recent months has largely been due to investors shifting away from its peers.
Continue Reading Below
Now, however, Wall Street is pricing in a new level of uncertainty. As of this writing, CLF stock is trading back near where it was before Wall Streets shift toward optimism, which is around the time it began revising its profit expectations downward. This change was mostly due to investors shifting their confidence away from iron ore producers. As far back as August of this year, CLFs stock was trading at around $12 per share. This year, its stock is currently trading around $6 per share. The reason investors are now shifting toward more uncertainty is, in part, due to an increase in trading volume.
What is going on with Cleveland-Cliffs share price?
The change in Wall Streets perception of Cleveland-Cliffs stock has led many analysts to lower
paraphrase:
Cleveland-Cliffs' current stock performance appears to be in contrast to its previous turnaround efforts, as Wall Street is now pricing the company differently. In the past, the company's stock had been trading in line with other iron ore producers, despite a higher valuation. However, in recent months, the company's stock has seen a rebound due to investors shifting away from its peers.
However, this optimism has been short-lived, as Wall Street has recently revised its profit expectations downward for Cleveland-Cliffs, mainly due to a shift in investor confidence away from iron ore producers. As a result, the company's stock price has reverted back to its pre-August level, around $12 per share. The increased trading volume is a contributing factor to this shift in investor sentiment.
In light of these developments, many analysts have lowered their earnings estimates for Cleveland-Cliffs. The company's share price seems to be experiencing a reversal of fortune, highlighting the volatility and uncertainty that can affect even the most well-positioned companies in the iron ore industry.

input:
North American Palladium (PAL) is dropping on Wednesday, adding to losses suffered since the beginning of the week.
Amid choppy markets in correction mode, the secret to making it in the long run is having the patience and fortitude to
continuation:
wait it out, if needed.
An overbought palladium spot contract on Comex  which is set in motion when gold futures rise from below $1,600 per ounce to above $1,600  is trading just below $1,600, suggesting that investor interest is waning.
Gold, meanwhile, is under pressure from investors growing concerns over rising coronavirus cases. The latest daily case growth in the US, the worlds biggest economy, jumped above 24% in the last 24 hours, as many states saw record-high daily cases.
I think investors are looking for reasons to sell gold, said Robin Bhar, head of commodities strategy, BNY Mellon.
While he doesnt think gold will crash, he doesnt think investors will want to own the yellow metal either. Prices will find support, just not in gold, he said.
In physical trade, the yellow metal is under pressure in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Japan, Europe, and the US. On Comex, palladium has broken above its 200-day moving average (DMA) for the first time in more than three months, adding to short
paraphrase:
On Wednesday, North American Palladium (PAL) is expected to experience a drop, building upon the losses it has suffered since the beginning of the week.
In the face of volatile markets in corrective mode, enduring patience and fortitude is key to success in the long run. Currently, an overbought palladium spot contract on Comex, which is activated when gold futures rise from under $1,600 per ounce to above $1,600, is trading near $1,600, suggesting a decrease in investor interest.
Meanwhile, gold is under pressure due to growing investor concerns about rising coronavirus cases, particularly in the US, which has seen a significant increase in daily case growth, with some states reaching record-high cases. According to Robin Bhar, head of commodities strategy at BNY Mellon, investors are seeking reasons to sell gold, and while he does not anticipate a gold crash, he does not expect investors to be interested in owning the yellow metal either. Prices will find support, but not in gold, he noted.
In physical markets, gold is under pressure in major regions, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, Japan, Europe, and the US. Additionally, palladium has broken above its 200-day moving average (DMA) on Comex for the first time in over three months, which may contribute to short selling.

input:
Osama Abu Irshaid. Photo: Screenshot.
Facebook and Twitter posts have revealed that Osama Abu Irshaid  the pro-Hamas leader of the rabidly anti-Israel group American Muslims for Palestine (AMP)  met with
continuation:
Palestinian Authority Chairman Mahmoud Abbas. Its the latest sign of Abbas friendship with Hamas. Its also the latest sign of Israels ongoing crackdown on his organization.
AMP has been accused of being linked to Hamas in the past. The organizations social media accounts were also suspended for multiple reasons, including for using a photo of the Palestinian Authoritys new president, Mahmoud Abbas, without his knowledge or permission. Hes also accused of using his organizations funds, which were also used for Hamas, for his own benefit.
In August of this year, one of its posts asked its members if it should "use money from American mosques in PA funds"  even though AMP said in its post, "we only use money from Islamic mosques in Palestine in Palestine." That post was later changed to say: "and use funds from the mosque in Palestine in Palestine only."
AMP was suspended in the US last month. Facebook said it suspended AMP for its "repeated use of hateful, dangerous or violent rhetoric and calls for violent actions toward Israelis." AMP also called for Israels defeat. Facebook didnt disclose the reason it suspended it
paraphrase:
Osama Abu Irshaid, a leader of the pro-Hamas group American Muslims for Palestine (AMP), has come under scrutiny after meeting with Palestinian Authority Chairman Mahmoud Abbas. This development has raised concerns about Abbas' alleged friendship with Hamas, as well as Israel's ongoing crackdown on the organization.
In the past, AMP has faced accusations of being linked to Hamas, and its social media accounts have been suspended multiple times for various reasons, including using a photo of Abbas without his permission. Additionally, there have been allegations that AMP's funds were used for the benefit of its leaders, including Irshaid, rather than for its intended purpose in Palestine.
In a controversial post from August of this year, AMP asked its members if it should "use money from American mosques in PA funds," despite claiming that it only uses money from "Islamic mosques in Palestine." The post was later changed to clarify that funds would only be used from mosques in Palestine.
AMP was recently suspended in the US for its "repeated use of hateful, dangerous or violent rhetoric and calls for violent actions towards Israelis." Facebook did not disclose the reason for the suspension.

input: Former Kent State wrestling coach Ron Gray will be inducted into the National Wrestling Hall of Fame on June 1 in Stillwater, Okla. Gray, who coached the Golden Flashes for 25 seasons, is one of four members who will be inducted
continuation:
alongside former Olympian and UFC champion Joe Lauzon. Gray, Lauzon, former Oklahoma Sooners and current NCAA champion Adam Rippon, and former UFC champion Gregor Gillespie will share in honor of what will surely be one of the greatest decades in collegiate wrestling.

Its a dream come true, said Gray, one of the greatest coaches in school history, in a text message to FloWrestling.com. I never dreamed Id have one of these things.

Gray is one of only six people, other than Vince Johnson, Bob Hall, Lou Thesz, Gene Johnson, and former Oklahoma head coach Johnny Kowalski, to guide multiple NCAA squads in multiple decades. He led Kent States NCAA squads in 1993, 1994, and 1994-95, while also guiding its first-ever national champion in 1993, when he was named NAIA National Coach of the Year. The Flashes were runners-up in 1996-97 and runners-up in 1998-99, when he was named NAIA Coach of the Year.

A member of the NAWCCA Hall of Fame, Gray led Kent States
paraphrase:
Renowned wrestling coach Ron Gray will be honored with induction into the National Wrestling Hall of Fame on June 1 in Stillwater, Oklahoma. Gray, who guided the Golden Flashes for 25 seasons, is one of four esteemed individuals who will be recognized for their outstanding contributions to the sport. Gray, along with former Olympian and UFC champion Joe Lauzon, former Oklahoma Sooners and current NCAA champion Adam Rippon, and former UFC champion Gregor Gillespie, will be honored for what is sure to be a historic year in collegiate wrestling.
Gray, a legendary coach and one of the greatest in school history, expressed his delight at the honor in a text message to FloWrestling.com. "I never imagined I'd receive an award like this," he said. "I'm truly humbled."
Gray is one of only six individuals, including Vince Johnson, Bob Hall, Lou Thesz, Gene Johnson, and former Oklahoma head coach Johnny Kowalski, to lead multiple NCAA squads in multiple decades. He led Kent State's NCAA teams in 1993, 1994, and 1994-95, and was named NAIA National Coach of the Year in 1993 after leading the Flashes to their first-ever national championship. The team was runners-up in 1996-97 and 1998-99, and Gray was named NAIA Coach of the Year in both of those seasons.
A member of the NAWCCA Hall of Fame, Gray has left an indelible mark on the world of wrestling, and his induction into the National Wrestling Hall of Fame is a testament to his remarkable career and dedication to the sport.

input: "I'd say to Congress, the tone will be one of bipartisanship," a senior administration official told reporters in a background call Friday previewing the upcoming State of the Union address, three hours after President Trump tweeted Democratic Minority Leader "Cry
continuation:
in' Chuck Schumer" was "a total failure" and "a disgrace." (Senate Democrats, he added, "should be thankful he's only a minority leader." (NBC News)

White House officials will tell lawmakers in advance of President Trumps State of the Union address next month that it will be a bipartisan event, sources with direct knowledge of the plans tell NBC News.

White House communications staff, with input from the presidents closest aides, is working closely with members of Congress on the annual address, with Mr. Trump expected to tell them this week he will use the address in his effort to push lawmakers to pass his agenda, one of the sources said. Mr. Trump is expected to say he will highlight his bipartisan support in his remarks, which will air in the early hours of Tuesday. (NBC)

White House staff, led by Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, will talk to lawmakers ahead of the State of the Union address next month in order to craft the tone of Mr. Trumps speech, sources say. (NBC)

The White House will try to avoid giving too much away when it comes to its plans for the annual address given
paraphrase: The administration official revealed to reporters that the tone of President Trump's State of the Union address will be one of bipartisanship, a stark contrast to his recent Twitter attacks on Democratic Minority Leader Chuck Schumer. Despite the President's personal opinions, White House officials are working closely with Congress to ensure the address remains a bipartisan event. In advance of the speech, communications staff and the President's closest aides are collaborating with lawmakers to craft a tone that highlights Mr. Trump's bipartisan support. The President is expected to emphasize this theme during his address, which will air early on Tuesday morning. According to sources, Chief of Staff Reince Priebus is leading the effort to coordinate with lawmakers ahead of the address.

input:
QUITO, ECUADOREcuador election officials have agreed to recount nearly 1.3 million votes as opposition leader Guillermo Lasso continues to allege fraud in the presidential election.
The National Electoral Council announced late Thursday it would
continuation:
release election materials on Monday. The decision follows Lassos refusal Thursday to concede, saying he will contest the vote in court.
The center-left former banker is leading with about 45 per cent of the vote, compared with 32 per cent for opposition candidate Andres Arauz. The two were seen as front-runners in the April 11 vote, which was marred by massive technical issues with Ecuadors electronic voting machines.
Read more: Ecuadors Lasso says hell challenge election results in court if he doesnt win. Now hes urging the military to back him.
Read more: Ecuador: Election could delay aid as Lasso calls on military to back him
Read more: Ecuadors president: I want peaceful transition of power, no more military coups. Now hes calling them off.
I am confident with the way things are unfolding, Lasso said at his office in Ecuadors capital. I am confident in my victory.
Arauz said Lassos concession was premature. He said Lassos team is just using the moment to appeal to
paraphrase:
Ecuadorian election officials have agreed to re-count nearly 1.3 million votes after opposition leader Guillermo Lasso alleged fraud in the presidential election. The National Electoral Council announced the decision on Monday, following Lasso's refusal to concede and his intention to contest the vote in court.
Lasso, a center-left former banker, is currently leading with around 45% of the vote, compared to 32% for opposition candidate Andres Arauz. The two were considered front-runners in the April 11 election, which was marred by technical issues with Ecuador's electronic voting machines.
Lasso is urging the military to back him, saying he is confident in his victory. However, Arauz has rejected Lasso's concession, claiming that Lasso's team is only using the moment to appeal to supporters.
The election has the potential to delay aid to the country, as Lasso has called for a peaceful transition of power and no more military coups. In contrast, the current president has expressed a desire for peaceful power transfer and has called off any potential military intervention.

input:
Ms Lee, 45, an avid jogger, had been jogging almost every day for the past five years. Recently, her knees started to hurt.
Gradually, walking up and down the stairs became a problem too, so much so that
continuation:
it made her want to stop. Then, she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS), which is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the central nervous system.
"My immune system, which normally protects us from diseases like cancer, is malfunctioning. It's like when you get cold and it doesn't just sting, it pours in, like fireflies are buzzing around. It's like, 'What is this,?' " she says.
Ms Lee, 45, with her wife Tan, 41. The couple are both newly diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. (Mr K. Tan/Mr K. Tan)
In early April, Ms Lee, a software engineer in Singapore, and her wife, Ms Tan, 41, were diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, after feeling discomfort while jogging, especially while ascending the stairs. Both were diagnosed with the condition within one month, according to the Multiple Sclerosis Singapore website.
It is a disorder that causes gradual, progressive damage of the central nervous system. The first signs of illness typically appear within one year of the onset of symptoms. The first sign is numbness, which in Ms Lee's case started around January 2018. As time progressed, her arms, hands, feet, fingers, arms,
paraphrase:
Ms. Lee, a dedicated jogger for the past five years, has been experiencing knee pain and difficulty walking up and down stairs. Recently, she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune disorder affecting the central nervous system.
"My immune system, which is supposed to protect us, is malfunctioning. It's like a firefly buzzing around, but instead of stinging, it's pouring in. It's like, 'What is this?' " she describes.
Ms. Lee, 45, and her wife, Ms. Tan, 41, were both recently diagnosed with MS, after experiencing discomfort while jogging. According to the Multiple Sclerosis Singapore website, the couple received their diagnosis within one month of each other.
MS is a progressive condition that damages the central nervous system gradually over time. The first signs of illness typically appear within one year of the onset of symptoms, and the first symptom in Ms. Lee's case started in January 2018 - numbness in her arms and hands. As time progressed, her symptoms worsened, affecting her feet, fingers, and arms.
In early April, Ms. Lee, a software engineer in Singapore, and her wife were diagnosed with MS. The couple are both newly diagnosed with the condition.

"I'm thinking, what was he running off with? I didn't see him, he was in a
paraphrase:
A Tesco petrol station in the vicinity of Cambridge was raided today (February 28) by masked individuals, triggering a significant police response.
Two individuals wearing hoods and masks were reported to have broken into the station at the Milton Tesco on Cambridge Road.
According to footage obtained from inside, one of the suspects, wearing a grey tracksuit, can be seen fleeing the scene with a blue plastic jug of petrol.

input:
March 27 - A greater proportion of quota places for women is among the changes successfully proposed by the World Rowing Federation (FISA) to its qualification system ahead of Rio 2016.
The changes, which have now been approved by the International Olympic Committee
continuation:
(IOC), will involve women receiving one per cent of the overall quota places.
A key element of the new process will also involve women receiving one per cent of the overall quota places in any event. That will include women of any nationality, whether or not they are currently ranked in the world.
The new qualification process will also apply if women are eligible for international rowing. The quota places awarded in women's individual sculls, women's four, women's eight, women's quadruple scull, women's eights and women's eight will increase from 1.5% (in sculls), 1% (in eights) and 0.5% (in eights) to 1% (in women's sculls), 0.6% (in women's eight) and 1% (in women's quadruple scull), respectively. Women will also receive one per cent of the overall places in any event if they were eligible for international rowing, regardless of nationality. The final quota places will still be allocated proportionally, based on the women's event rankings in which they are eligible.
"It is important to us that this new process of qualification is equally available for all," FISA president
paraphrase: The World Rowing Federation (FISA) has successfully proposed changes to its qualification system, set to take effect at Rio 2016, with a greater proportion of quota places reserved for women. The approved modifications by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) aim to provide equal opportunities for all, with women receiving 1% of the overall quota places, compared to the previous 0.5% in women's eight events. Additionally, women will now be eligible for quota places in any event, regardless of nationality, and will make up 1% of the overall places in any event if they were eligible for international rowing. The final quota places will still be allocated proportionally based on women's event rankings in which they are eligible. FISA president has emphasized the importance of this new process, ensuring equal opportunities for all.

input:
Shock jock facing lawsuit from player on the Rutgers Women's basketball team.
Don Imus is facing his first lawsuit from a player on the Rutgers Women's Basketball team for derogatory comments that cost him his job as a radio host in April, ABC
continuation:
station WABC-TV in New York reports.
"A former Rutgers women's basketball player is suing Don Imus, her former Rutgers teammates, her current Rutgers teammates, Rutgers, its athletic department, and ESPN Radio, alleging he was 'inappropriate' when he used racial and other profanities while talking about her on his radio show, The Record of Hackensack said in its story.
Kaela Miller, 20, was the Rutgers freshman center who filed suit, which said Imus "began his remarks with the words, 'I love big, fat cts,' referring to her, her sister, her mother, and her mother-in-law."
"Imus then said, 'You are the ugliest bch I've ever seen in my life,' which was not only racist, it was also vulgar, she said in the suit, according to The Record. "Imus stated, 'I want her mom, I want her son, I want her little sister, I want her little brother.' He then said, 'I want her. I want her. I want her.' He also stated, 'I want her. I want her. I want
paraphrase: A former Rutgers women's basketball player has filed a lawsuit against Don Imus, alleging inappropriate and offensive comments made by the radio host while discussing her on his show. According to the suit, Imus used racial and other profane language while referring to the plaintiff and her family, including making derogatory remarks about her appearance. The plaintiff, Kaela Miller, claims that Imus' comments were not only racist but also vulgar, and violated her rights to privacy and dignity. The suit also names several other parties, including Rutgers University and ESPN Radio, as defendants.

input:
CATEGORY five cyclones are not meant to exist.
They are a way of terrifying children in Central Queensland into making sure they are not running outside or playing in open drains during the summer wet.
Growing up in Mackay, cycl
continuation:
ones were a regular feature. One season, while I was home from school, I was woken in the early morning by the roar of a storm. I opened the bedroom curtains to see a gigantic wall of blue sky and sea around me. It wasn't the sound I remember from growing up in Mackay, where it is always dark, but it was still terrifying. The next morning, I climbed into bed and immediately began making up stories. I was hiding from the cyclone with my little sister, but when she asked why, I pretended I was talking to myself. I was frightened of the noise of it, but not of what it would do, like how it was supposed to hurt people if they tried to cross it.
"Cults are one of the most common reasons why children will stop listening." Credit:Peter Braig
Another time, I was woken by someone in my bedroom. It was the worst sound in the world. It was only when I looked out of the window, saw what looked like a bright orange light in the distance, and heard it screeching away in the distance that I knew it was really a cyclone. We were already asleep. I could feel it, I could see it.
paraphrase:
Cyclones are not meant to exist, but they have become a common fear among children in Central Queensland. Growing up in Mackay, I experienced my fair share of cyclones, which would often wake me up in the middle of the night with their roaring sound. Although I was terrified of the noise, I never really feared for my safety. Instead, I would use my imagination to create stories and pretend I was hiding from the storm with my little sister. However, I never told her the truth  that cyclones were supposed to hurt people if they tried to cross them.
Recently, I came across a statement that caught my attention: "Cults are one of the most common reasons why children will stop listening." While this may seem unrelated to cyclones, it made me realize that the fear of something as powerful as a cyclone can be used to control children's behavior. In a way, the fear of cyclones can be seen as a form of cultural control, teaching children to be obedient and listen to authority.
Another experience with cyclones left a lasting impression on me. I remember being woken up by a strange noise in the middle of the night, and when I looked out the window, I saw a bright orange light in the distance. I was terrified, but not of the cyclone itself  I was more afraid of what it might do to my family and our home. It was then that I realized that the fear of cyclones was not just a natural phenomenon, but also a cultural construct, shaped by our experiences and beliefs.

input:
Texas has become the first state in the nation to require law enforcement to obtain a warrant to read people's email, and privacy advocates are hoping the move will help quicken the passage of a similar proposal in Congress.
Texas Gov. Rick Perry signed
continuation: a bill into law Friday, giving law enforcement more power to extract private data from email. The bill is similar to one introduced in Congress earlier this year. It is also similar to laws in places like California. The House passed its bill in May, but it has yet to receive a vote in the Senate. The measure, called the Internet Privacy Act, gives law enforcement more power to get back e-mails when criminal investigations or court orders are involved. It also gives judges more power to impose "technical assistance" orders to help law enforcement. But privacy advocates are hoping it will accelerate the passage of similar laws in Congress. "While this bill gives law enforcement more power in certain circumstances, it doesnt go far enough in restoring Internet privacy protections, and it doesnt adequately limit the polices ability to use technology to track citizens, said Marissa Levine, executive director of Fight for the Future. Perry signed the bill into law just days after his attorney general, Greg Abbott, signed a similar bill into law in neighboring Arizona. The Arizona measure, called SB1070, also requires law enforcement to obtain a warrant before reading e-mails. The Arizona law is similar to the one passed in Washington state in
paraphrase:
Texas has become the first state in the nation to mandate that law enforcement obtain a warrant before accessing private email accounts, and advocates for privacy are optimistic that this move will hasten the passage of a similar proposal in Congress.
Governor Rick Perry signed the bill into law on Friday, granting law enforcement additional authority to extract personal data from email accounts during criminal investigations or when served with a court order. This legislation is similar to a bill introduced in Congress earlier this year and to laws already in place in areas such as California. The House approved its bill in May, but it has yet to receive a vote in the Senate. The Internet Privacy Act grants law enforcement more power to obtain emails in criminal investigations or when ordered by a judge, while also granting judges the authority to impose "technical assistance" orders to support law enforcement. However, privacy advocates maintain that the bill does not go far enough in restoring internet privacy protections and does not adequately limit the government's ability to use technology to monitor citizens. Perry signed the bill just days after his attorney general, Greg Abbott, signed a similar bill into law in neighboring Arizona. The Arizona measure, known as SB1070, also requires law enforcement to obtain a warrant before accessing private email accounts. This Arizona law is similar to the one passed in Washington state in [year].

The 509th Civil Engineer Squadron re-opened the Atlantis Hall dormitory in March 2019 after a year and a half of renovations at Whiteman Air Force Base, Missouri.
The renovations completely overhauled the building and will be the standard for the
continuation:
facility in its lifetime, according to a news release. This was accomplished with the assistance of the Army Corps of Engineers, which also provided resources. The Corps also funded new furnishings, carpet, heating and air conditioning, electrical, plumbing, fire protection and more.
A complete list of improvements is available in this press release. The base is currently in a temporary state of closure due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.
I am thrilled with the success of this project, said Maj. Gen. Robert E. Williams, the base commander. With its renovated interior, the new construction, improved elevators, new furnishings and renovated technology, this is a first-class facility, one that will continue to provide the excellent service to which its former tenants will always have something to look forward to.
Its been amazing to watch them put this together, said retired Master Sgt. Frank Rocha, who was the 509th Civil Engineer Squadrons director of facilities. Its been something I never could have done myself, without the support of my base, my staff, and my supervisors.
It
paraphrase:
The 509th Civil Engineer Squadron re-opened the Atlantis Hall dormitory in March 2019 following an extensive 18-month renovation at Whiteman Air Force Base, Missouri.
The extensive overhaul of the building has set a new standard for facilities at the base, according to a news release. The Army Corps of Engineers provided crucial support during the renovation process, which also included the installation of new furnishings, carpeting, heating and air conditioning, electrical and plumbing systems, and fire protection.
A detailed list of improvements can be found in the press release. Unfortunately, the base is currently undergoing a temporary closure due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
Major General Robert E. Williams, the base commander, expressed his satisfaction with the project's success, emphasizing the renovated interior, new construction, improved elevators, upgraded furnishings, and state-of-the-art technology that will continue to provide top-notch service to the facility's former occupants.
Retired Master Sergeant Frank Rocha, former director of facilities for the 509th Civil Engineer Squadron, praised the team's efforts, stating, "It's been an incredible experience to witness the renovation of this facility. I couldn't have done it without the support of my colleagues, supervisors, and the base. It's truly a first-class facility that will continue to serve its purpose with excellence."

input:
Agency Geek is looking to help business relationships blossom.
A new business matchmaking company that describes itself as the "first and only" service that uses algorithmic science to match businesses with with advertising, PR, branding and web-development firms
continuation:
, is launching in Vancouver.
Agency Geek offers an alternative, where small-business owners don't have to choose from one matchmaking service or another, according to co-founder Andrew Scott. It replaces traditional matchmaking, in which companies often find a match when contacting the same company.
"Traditional matchmaking doesn't really get things done, especially if you're running a small business and have limited budgets," Scott said. "With the use of data, algorithms, machine learning, technology and social media, it gives businesses an advantage."
Through the service, small-business owners don't need to go looking for a matchmaker, which is why it's called 'the only matchmaker service,' Scott said. Businesses simply upload an application and wait for a response from one of its "AI algorithms." If it matches, the company will go from there. The company has been running in Singapore for eight years, where its technology is built with algorithms from IBM Watson, he said.
The service is free, with a monthly fee of $80, Scott said, which is based on user-generated reviews of previous clients. Business owners also get free business cards. Scott says it also allows them to target different audiences with tailored
paraphrase:
A new business matchmaking platform, Agency Geek, is set to revolutionize the way small businesses connect with advertising, PR, branding, and web development firms in Vancouver. Unlike traditional matchmaking services, which rely on personal connections and referrals, Agency Geek uses cutting-edge algorithmic science to pair businesses with the most suitable partners.
Co-founder Andrew Scott explains that traditional matchmaking methods are often ineffective for small businesses with limited budgets. "With Agency Geek, business owners don't need to search for a matchmaker. They simply upload an application and wait for a response from our AI algorithms," he said. "If a match is found, the company can proceed with the partnership."
Agency Geek has been successfully operating in Singapore for eight years, with technology built upon IBM Watson's algorithms. The service is free, with a monthly fee of $80 based on user-generated reviews. Business owners also receive free business cards, and can target different audiences with tailored approaches.
According to Scott, Agency Geek's innovative approach has the potential to transform the way businesses grow and thrive. "Our platform provides small businesses with a competitive edge, enabling them to reach their full potential in the marketplace," he said.

input: The big news on any day when President Bush delivers a "major address" regarding Iraq is never what the commander-in-chief says. Bush has been on autopilot for so long now that he does not even bother to say anything new -- even
continuation:
when he has already said everything he needs to say. It is almost as if he expects us, the citizens of this great, rich, wonderful country, to watch and believe his latest pronouncement.

Here is what the president said yesterday, in remarks that came just one day before he was due to head to Europe:

"A big mistake was made here, beginning with the first war in Iraq. A big mistake was made here, when the United States was too slow to recognize the power of the Iranian regime. A big mistake was made here, when we failed to stop Iran from going rogue in the Middle East. A big mistake was made here, when we failed to stop weapons of mass destruction from going to Syria. A big mistake was made here, when we failed to stop Iran from getting nuclear weapons. A big mistake was made here, when Congress let its patience with President Bush end. A big mistake was made here, when the United States failed to live up to its commitments. A big mistake was made here, when it became evident that Iraq was in no condition to cooperate with any international sanctions. A big mistake was made here, when I saw signs of more civil war in Iraq. A big mistake was made
paraphrase:
Yesterday, during a major address regarding Iraq, President Bush once again failed to deliver any significant or new information. It seems that he has been relying on autopilot for quite some time now, recycling the same old statements without adding any fresh perspectives. It's almost as if he expects us, the citizens of this great country, to simply watch and believe his latest pronouncements without questioning their validity.
In his address, Bush mentioned several mistakes made in the past, including the initial war in Iraq and the failure to recognize the growing power of the Iranian regime. He also noted the lack of action to stop weapons of mass destruction from being sent to Syria and Iran's eventual acquisition of nuclear weapons. Additionally, he mentioned Congress's lack of patience with his predecessor and the United States' failure to live up to its commitments.
Despite these acknowledgments of past mistakes, Bush failed to offer any concrete solutions or new strategies for addressing the ongoing issues in Iraq. It remains to be seen if he will truly take action to rectify the situations he has outlined or if this will simply be another instance of empty rhetoric.

This years World Cup official ball will be the Telstar 18, a modern interpretation of the 1970 and 1974 adidas ball, Telstar.
The name was coined due to its black and white pentagons that made it easier to spot
continuation:
from afar. The Telstar 18 was chosen due to its modern style while keeping the same history. The ball was named after Telstar, an early United States government satellite used in military communication. The current official balls were developed under NASAs contract with Adidas, and are in use at both home and away matches.
It will feature the same aerodynamic technology used on other recent Adidas soccer balls, which help deliver greater performance, flexibility and comfort in order to increase overall comfort. It will feature polyurethane foam with the same urethane coating Adidas currently uses in its current ball. The polyurethane coating is used in Adidas current balls to help provide greater cushioning. The ball will feature new Adidas technologies such as Flyspark, which is a light, flexible compound, while also making use of traditional technology like seam-free joints and polycarbonate. It will also feature the same TPR construction used in other Adidas soccer balls, which will help maintain its low-weight. Adidas latest soccer balls will also feature the same lightweight material, with weight savings of approximately 30 percent compared to its previous generation. It will also feature Nikes new Vaporfly technology, which will incorporate Nike technology
paraphrase:
This year's World Cup official ball, Telstar 18, is a modern interpretation of the 1970 and 1974 adidas ball, with a unique black and white pentagonal design that makes it easily recognizable. The ball has been chosen for its blend of classic style and modern technology, with a focus on aerodynamics, flexibility, and comfort.
The ball features advanced polyurethane foam and urethane coating, providing greater cushioning and overall comfort during play. The Telstar 18 also incorporates new Adidas technologies such as Flyspark, a light and flexible compound, as well as traditional features like seam-free joints and polycarbonate. Additionally, the ball features TPR construction, which helps maintain its low weight while providing added durability.
Compared to previous generations, the Telstar 18 has undergone significant weight savings of approximately 30 percent, making it an even more agile and responsive ball for players. Moreover, the ball incorporates Nike's cutting-edge Vaporfly technology, further enhancing its performance and comfort. With its perfect blend of style, technology, and innovation, the Telstar 18 is set to be a game-changer in the world of soccer.

input:
A group of stock traders teamed with two Ukrainian-based computer hackers to make $100 million in illegal profits by gaining access to hundreds of press releases of many leading U.S. companies and trading on the stolen news before it became public.
All
continuation:
seven of them are in prison, while a fourth is awaiting extradition. The fourth was in 2016 convicted of unrelated crimes. Two of the seven, one of whom still works in Russia, are still under arrest. The other one is still waiting.
It is one of the most successful, if secretive, criminal operations ever perpetrated in Ukraine. A prosecutor estimates its profits were nearly twice the size of any previous criminal enterprise.
U.S. authorities arrested seven people in connection with this criminal operation. Two Russian nationals were charged with computer intrusion into computer networks belonging to various media outlets and trading news about these news releases. The other seven were charged with computer intrusion, computer fraud, and aggravated identity theft.
This case will hold accountable anyone who uses advanced technologies to steal from investors, said Acting Assistant Attorney General Chad A. Readler of the Justice Departments criminal division. Im confident this action will deter anyone from engaging in this sort of criminal activity.
These are just criminal cases, said Acting U.S. Attorney Zachary Terwilliger. These guys are crooks.
This was one of the largest computer intrusion cases to date
paraphrase:
A group of stock traders collaborated with two Ukrainian computer hackers to generate illicit profits of $100 million by accessing and trading on sensitive press releases of major US companies before they became public knowledge. All seven individuals are now serving time in prison, with one still awaiting extradition, while a fourth was convicted of unrelated crimes in 2016. This sophisticated criminal operation, considered one of the largest of its kind in Ukraine, is estimated to have yielded profits nearly twice that of any previous criminal enterprise.
US authorities have arrested and charged two Russian nationals for their role in the criminal operation, including computer intrusion into media outlets' networks and trading on stolen news releases. Seven additional individuals were charged with computer intrusion, fraud, and identity theft.
According to Acting Assistant Attorney General Chad A. Readler, "This action will hold accountable anyone who uses advanced technologies to steal from investors. I'm confident this will serve as a deterrent to any would-be criminals." Acting US Attorney Zachary Terwilliger added, "These guys are plain and simple crooks."
This case represents one of the most significant computer intrusion cases to date, underscoring the importance of safeguarding sensitive information and the serious consequences of engaging in illegal activities.
