input:
Andy Farrell looks set to leave Saracens to take up a full-time position with England following the appointment of Stuart Lancaster as head coach, Telegraph Sport understands.
Lancaster was named as permanent successor to Martin Johnson on Thursday following a Rugby
continuation:
Football Union (RFU) board meeting at which it was also confirmed his predecessor is to stay with the side.
Saracens confirmed on Friday that Farrell will step down from his role following the end of the season, although it is understood he was initially asked to stay in his current role of assistant head coach.
Farrell will replace Stuart Lancaster, who stepped down following their Grand Slam win in September, and was considered a strong contender to succeed Johnson despite his young age, only 34.
It is believed he was initially approached by Johnson when he was still in his position, but it was considered that he was too young to take up a head coaching role, and it is believed he took on his current role in order to help develop his coaching CV in preparation for his eventual move to the job.
Saracens confirmed: "Saracens can confirm that Andy Farrell will step down from his coaching responsibilities, with immediate effect.
"In order to avoid any disruption in coaching responsibilities, his current duties will cease from 31/12/18. It was also agreed that Stuart Lancaster will stay on at Saracens to help develop Stuart Farrell's coaching CV in preparation for his eventual move to head coaching."
paraphrase:
Andy Farrell is expected to leave Saracens to take up a full-time coaching position with England following Stuart Lancaster's appointment as head coach, according to Telegraph Sport. Lancaster was named as the permanent successor to Martin Johnson on Thursday, with the RFU board meeting also confirming that Johnson will remain with the team.
Farrell, who is currently assistant head coach at Saracens, will step down from his role at the end of the season, although he was initially asked to stay on. He is set to replace Lancaster, who stepped down after England's Grand Slam win in September, despite being relatively young at 34.
It is believed that Farrell was approached by Johnson for the head coaching role earlier, but it was deemed that he was too young for the position. Instead, he took on the assistant coaching role to gain experience and prepare for his eventual move into the top job.
Saracens have confirmed in a statement that Farrell will step down from his coaching duties with immediate effect, with his current responsibilities set to cease on December 31. The club also revealed that Lancaster will remain with the team to help develop Farrell's coaching CV in preparation for his eventual move to head coaching.

LIVERPOOL boss Jurgen Klopp has hinted that the club are set to tie Joe Gomez down to a new bumper contract.
Reports have been circulating this week that England defender Gomez will soon be rewarded for his recent good form with a vastly
continuation:
improved contract, which will reportedly tie him down until 2023.
But Klopp has quashed talk of Gomez making his own decision, with the club yet to decide whether it will reward him with an improved contract or offer him new terms.
Klopp said: "I dont know. I am still working with Joe. I dont know. Im here so if I know something it is not important. I just try to talk to him, if I need something he can tell me whats wrong, whats right. Then we have a discussion. I am happy if he wants more or stays here. If he doesnt want more, he will leave. I dont know. It will happen, it will happen. I will deal with it. It doesnt feel like it was a big problem to me if he doesnt want to stay."

Not only does Comcast careit also knows what you think.
The company is well aware of the fact that it has maintained one of corporate Americas worst reputations for several years by scoring near the bottom in pretty much every category from
continuation:
customer satisfaction to product quality. It also knows that its not popular. For this reason, it is spending lavishly, in one sense, to try and change its bad image. But also, in other ways, its looking to its own history, too, in an effort to understand the root of the current issues.
The companys new CEO, Brian Roberts, is using his recent trip to India, which included spending a few days in his home state of Wisconsin, to try to understand its citizens experiences. As he said in his keynote speech, I spent time with Indians in India, working with Indians, talking with Indians. Thats not just a PR ploy. The companys new culture center will feature stories about India, including one from Forbes that talks about why it took its CEO, Bob Turner, so long to visit India.
I was born in Wisconsin, said Turner. I grew up in Wisconsin. But I never, I never think of myself in Wisconsin. I think of myself in India.
Turner spoke about why India is a major investor in Comcast, especially in rural parts of the
paraphrase:
Comcast not only pays attention to customer opinions but also recognizes its poor reputation in various areas, including product quality and customer satisfaction. The company is aware that it has been struggling to regain the trust of its customers and is taking extensive measures to turn things around.
Recently appointed CEO Brian Roberts has made it a point to personally connect with the people of India during his visit to the country, to understand their experiences and perspectives. In his keynote speech, he expressed his desire to learn from the culture and traditions of India, stating, "I spent time with Indians in India, working with Indians, talking with Indians. It's not just a PR stunt."
The company's new culture center will showcase stories and experiences from India, including an article from Forbes that highlights the reason why it took CEO Bob Turner so long to visit the country. Turner himself has a personal connection to India, having been born and raised in Wisconsin but identifying more with the culture and people of India.
In an effort to understand the root of the current issues, Turner spoke about why India is a significant investor in Comcast, particularly in rural areas. By taking a proactive approach to addressing customer concerns and fostering a deeper understanding of its investors, Comcast aims to rebuild its reputation and regain the trust of its customers.

input:
AFL-CIO calls for urgent action to stop Indiana "right-to-work"
The AFL-CIO has issued a national appeal for help to stop passage of a so-called right-to-work law
continuation:
in Indiana, urging supporters to contact state representatives and urging people to participate in a national solidarity strike.
A right-to-work law is one of the worst forms of corporate welfare and it could bankrupt a state like Indiana, said AFL-CIO Secretary-Treasurer Nancy McGinn. Its hard to overstate the power of this law: It threatens millions of jobs.
McGinn said supporters are urged to encourage people in the state to participate in a solidarity strike, or strike, or even just phone in their vote. Supporters are asked to support calls for a vote of no confidence in state Rep. Matt Hansen, R-Louisville, who is sponsoring legislation to put into law House Bill 1001. The bill was placed on hold while state lawmakers debate other, more important issues, like redistricting.
House Bill 1001, if signed into law, will prohibit collective bargaining with private-sector unions. The law, which supporters say is needed to prevent layoffs and job cuts, also threatens to eliminate collective bargaining with state government.
Indiana voters need to call their state representatives, McGinn said. Please encourage voters to contact state Rep
paraphrase: The AFL-CIO is urging supporters to take urgent action to stop the passage of a controversial "right-to-work" law in Indiana. The labor organization is asking people to contact their state representatives and participate in a national solidarity strike to voice their opposition to the bill. According to AFL-CIO Secretary-Treasurer Nancy McGinn, right-to-work laws are a form of corporate welfare that can lead to job losses and bankruptcy for states. She emphasized the importance of taking action to protect millions of jobs and urged supporters to support a vote of no confidence in state Rep. Matt Hansen, who is sponsoring the legislation. House Bill 1001, if signed into law, would prohibit collective bargaining with private-sector unions and threaten the ability of state government workers to engage in collective bargaining. Indiana voters are encouraged to contact their state representatives to express their opposition to the bill.

input:
Ten years after al-Qaeda first surfaced, the US is still at war with "terrorist" groups.
In a neatly manicured garden in Nairobi, Joash Okindo limps towards a marble plaque erected in honour of those who
continuation:
were killed. The Kenyan is here with his brother, Samuel, to commemorate those killed in the April 7, 1993 bombings of the Westgate Mall and the nearby Garissa University. "You need to know this happened here, it happened here, it happened here, in Africa." That's where al-Qaeda first emerged, in Somalia, in 1993.
Okindo, 32, runs his business from his modest home in this leafy city in eastern Kenya. The business is home-based, which is his way of life: he only travels when he needs something. He is here to help his people, he says. He says he is here to "make amends" with his "mother, father and wife".
These sentiments are reflected in his choice of attire: in traditional garb, he sits cross-legged with his hands clasped around his head, his head-band tucked into his hair. His brother, Samuel, wears traditional Kenyan headgear, too: it consists of a head band, often adorned with feathers, feathers or feathers with or without feathers.
The pair are here, in Garissa, for the first time in nearly 20 years, when Samuel, 55, was a teenager. "I saw
paraphrase: Nearly two decades after the emergence of al-Qaeda in Somalia in 1993, the United States is still embroiled in conflicts with terrorist groups. Joash Okindo, a 32-year-old entrepreneur from Kenya, and his brother Samuel, 55, have traveled to Garissa, the site where al-Qaeda first took root, to pay their respects to those killed in the April 7, 1993 bombings at the Westgate Mall and nearby Garissa University. Okindo, who runs his business from his home, wears traditional garb and sits cross-legged, clasping his hands around his head, a headband tucked into his hair. His brother, dressed in traditional Kenyan attire with a headband adorned with feathers, joins him in this emotional pilgrimage. The siblings have not visited Garissa in nearly 20 years, when Samuel was a teenager. As they reflect on their journey, they are reminded of their desire to make amends with their loved ones, including their mother, father, and wife.

input:
TANYA NOLAN: The biggest medical conference Australia has ever seen is about to descend on Melbourne in a few weeks time.
AIDS 2014 will attract 14,000 of the world's leading HIV scientists, policymakers and activists to discuss progress on
continuation:
the pandemic. The conference will also feature a number of world-firsts, including:
A major new approach to treatment, called Pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP)
A "high-tech" diagnostic test that will screen more than 1.2m people in Melbourne, based on DNA tests
A new partnership with US drug company Bayer, which will provide medicines with special DNA profiles that target HIV-negative people, rather than just people with CD4 cells, which are highly effective in fighting infection
An international first  the first time doctors will be allowed to prescribe PrEP drugs before sex. PrEP  pre-exposure prophylaxis  is already available in several countries. It involves taking daily PrEP pills before sex or when exposed to someone with HIV. But it is not yet available in Australia, although PrEP is expected in the next six months. The new "high-tech" test will screen 1.2m people in Melbourne, based on DNA tests, which show people are negative, whether they are going into risky behaviour or exposed. It will also test people for other conditions, such as tuberculosis, which is nearly 100 per cent cure if detected early. Experts say this will
paraphrase:
The upcoming AIDS 2014 conference in Melbourne is expected to attract 14,000 leading HIV scientists, policymakers, and activists from around the world to discuss progress in the fight against the pandemic. The conference will feature several groundbreaking developments, including:
A novel approach to treatment, known as Pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP), which will be showcased as a major world-first.
A state-of-the-art diagnostic test that will screen more than 1.2 million people in Melbourne using DNA tests, providing accurate results in a timely manner.
A new partnership with US drug company Bayer, which will enable the provision of medicines with unique DNA profiles that target both HIV-negative and HIV-positive individuals.
A significant milestone, as doctors will be permitted to prescribe PrEP drugs before engaging in sexual activity, marking the first time this has occurred internationally. PrEP, or pre-exposure prophylaxis, is already available in several countries, but it is not yet available in Australia, despite expected availability within the next six months. The innovative "high-tech" test will also screen for other conditions, including tuberculosis, which can be cured with early detection, with an effectiveness rate of nearly 100%. Industry experts believe this will have a profound impact on the effectiveness of HIV prevention and treatment in the region.

Daniel R. Welsh, 60, of Williamsfield, OH, died Sunday, October 20, 2013, at his home.
Born March 22, 1953, in Pittsburgh, a son of Shirley L. (Gregory) Vidonic, Aliqu
continuation:
ippa, PA, and Henry J. Welsh, Williamsfield, he was a 1972 graduate of Williamsfield High School, Williamsfield.
Dan was a veteran of the US Army, having served with the 82nd Airborne Division in Vietnam. He was also honorably discharged from the US Marine Corps with the rank of Sergeant. He was of the faith of Christ, a retired machinist. He enjoyed watching sports, especially NASCAR, and playing cards. He loved spending time with his family. He is preceded in death by his mother, Shirley L. Welsh.
Survivors include his wife, Linda (Smith) Welsh, Williamsfield, his sister, Mary Jane (Robert) Landeros, Aliquippa, PA, one brother, William Welsh, Williamsfield, six nieces, Terri Landeros, Aliquippa, PA, Julie (Wesley) Shuler, Williamsfield, Debra (Dennis) Wiles, Aliquippa, PA, Heather (Mike) Staley, Williamsfield, Tiffany (Eric) Hinkle, Williamsfield, and Tiffany (Kirk) McSharry, Williamsfield, six grandnieces and one grandnephew.
paraphrase:
Daniel Welsh, a 60-year-old man from Williamsfield, Ohio, passed away on Sunday, October 20, 2013, at his home.
Born on March 22, 1953, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Daniel was the son of Shirley Gregory Vidonic and Henry Welsh, both of Williamsfield. He graduated from Williamsfield High School in 1972.
Dan served in the US Army with the 82nd Airborne Division during the Vietnam War and was honorably discharged from the US Marine Corps with the rank of Sergeant. He was a devout Christian and had a career as a machinist. He enjoyed watching sports, particularly NASCAR, and playing cards, and cherished spending time with his loved ones.
Daniel is preceded in death by his mother, Shirley Welsh. He is survived by his wife, Linda Smith Welsh, his sister, Mary Jane Landeros, and his brother, William Welsh, all of Williamsfield. He is also survived by six nieces, Terri Landeros, Julie Shuler, Debra Wiles, Heather Staley, Tiffany Hinkle, and Tiffany McSharry, and six grandnieces and one grandnephew.

input:
The narrow road to the compound, the temporary home to the US officials, remained blocked by security guards. A security official cited an "important private event" there.
The two sides are in Singapore apparently to discuss the logistical details of the summit talks
continuation:
.
The US, which is pushing for Kim's swift departure from power, hopes he'll offer to meet with South Korean envoys to resolve outstanding issues between the two Koreas, according to US officials. But a decision on whether to do so will hinge on whether Kim will be willing to do so.
On Tuesday, Kim said he hopes his first summit with US President Donald Trump will "make history" in terms of improving ties between Washington and Pyongyang, according to the state-controlled Korean Central News Agency.
Trump, in turn, told reporters that his first meeting with Kim will "be in the big house, where it was built." He did not elaborate.
Officials are concerned that Kim may not even want to meet with Trump, or may delay it if he thinks the US president is making unreasonable demands, according to a US government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The White House, meanwhile, says it has done nothing to set back its diplomatic initiative with Kim.
paraphrase:
The secure path to the temporary US facility remained obstructed by security personnel, with a security official citing an exclusive private event as the reason. The two sides are currently in Singapore to work out the logistical details of the summit talks.
The US, which is pushing for a swift change in power dynamics, aims to persuade Kim to meet with South Korean envoys to resolve outstanding issues between the two Koreas, according to US officials. However, a decision on whether to do so will depend on Kim's willingness to engage.
On Tuesday, Kim expressed hope that his first summit with US President Donald Trump will "make history" in terms of improving ties between Washington and Pyongyang, as reported by state-run Korean Central News Agency. Trump, in turn, hinted at their first meeting taking place in a grand and historic location, without providing further details.
Officials are worried that Kim may not be inclined to meet with Trump or may delay it if he perceives the US president as being unreasonable in his demands, according to a US government official speaking on condition of anonymity. The White House, meanwhile, maintains that it has not altered its diplomatic efforts with Kim in any way.

UTEP beat Rice with a score of 34-26, breaking the longest losing streak in the country.
Even when UTEP bolted out to a 34-3 lead Saturday against hapless Rice, even when every ball bounced their way and the 20
continuation:
-point deficit was never more than 14, even when the Miners were cruising in many ways, still, Rice kept it competitive, kept it in the fight. A week ago, it was easy to root for UTEP. Then, it was too easy. Now, it is a fight, still, to root for.
The Miners did just enough, just barely, in a 34-26 victory at Rice. It is still not easy. It is still frustrating. It is still messy. It is still hard. But it is also, simply, something, something. It is something. It is something, still. A week ago, it was easy. Now, it is hard. But it is still something, something. That is something. It is something, still.
Im with UTEPs Coach Dana Dimel when he says, Its hard, I understand that. Its hard. Its hard. But its something. Its something. Because it is something. It is something, still. Because it is something, it still, will it, will it, will it, will it, will
paraphrase: UTEP emerged victorious with a score of 34-26, breaking the country's longest losing streak. Despite their dominant lead, Rice refused to give up, keeping the game competitive until the very end. Last week, rooting for UTEP was a breeze, but now it's a challenge. The Miners had to fight hard for their victory, and it's still difficult to support them. Coach Dana Dimel understands the struggle, acknowledging that it's tough, but he's proud of his team for pushing through. The win may have been hard-fought, but it's something to be proud of, something that still gives them hope.

input: A Stamford woman was arrested Tuesday for allegedly driving a stolen Ford Explorer when a Greenwich Police officer noticed her driving partially in the breakdown lane for about a half mile on Interstate 95. The officer was on patrol and driving northbound on I-95 between Ex
continuation:
its 6 and 8 in Greenwich. As he was nearing Exit 8, the officer noticed a Ford Explorer traveling in the breakdown lane. The driver, identified in court records as Rachel M. Rachalsky, 32, of Stamford, drove in the breakdown lane when the officer approached her. The police report said Rachalsky admitted she was in the wrong lane, "in an attempt to bypass traffic." The police report also said Rachalsky admitted she was in Connecticut without legal permission.
Start the conversation, or Read more at Greenwich Citizen.
paraphrase: A woman from Stamford was detained on Tuesday after a Greenwich police officer observed her driving a stolen Ford Explorer on Interstate 95. The officer was patrolling the highway northbound between Exits 6 and 8 in Greenwich when he noticed the SUV traveling in the breakdown lane for approximately half a mile. As he approached Exit 8, the officer noticed the driver, identified in court records as Rachel M. Rachalsky, 32, of Stamford, driving in the incorrect lane. According to the police report, Rachalsky admitted to driving in the breakdown lane in an attempt to bypass traffic. Additionally, she confessed that she was in Connecticut without proper authorization.

input:
Heres a fantastic movie idea: Tropic Thunder takes place on the set of a big-budget Hollywood Vietnam War film also entitled Tropic Thunder.
With a finicky A-list cast causing endless delays in shooting, the studio orders
continuation:
Tropic Thunder to move its set from Hollywood to Hong Kong to get around the delay. At first it seems like a win-win, but when Tropic Thunder star Ben Stillers character takes one look at his Hong Kong set, he thinks hell rather die than live in Hong Kong. The next scene, in which his Hong Kong crew members are set upon by a Vietnamese mob boss, is a dead-on mirror of the action of Stillers first Hong Kong scene, which is also called Tropic Thunder.
What could have been, is merely one of many scenes which could have been, but Tropic Thunder is a master of its genre. Stillers performance is spot-on, his screen presence is perfect, and Stiller delivers one of his most memorable one-liners yet, which is priceless: "I have seen Vietnam. I will never go back." Its also fun to watch a scene where Tropic Thunder director Terry Gilliam and star Stillers co-star Ron Livingston are both in costume, talking in Hong Kong accents, with Stillers character in his Hawaiian shirt, Livingstons in his tux.
paraphrase:
The movie idea, "Tropic Thunder," is a riotous take on the making of a large-budget Hollywood film about the Vietnam War. The story unfolds on the set of the movie, which shares the same title as the film itself. With an elusive A-list cast causing continuous delays, the production is forced to relocate its set from Hollywood to Hong Kong. However, when the film's star, Ben Stillers character, lays eyes on his Hong Kong set, he is adamant about not wanting to film there, much like the mirroring of his initial Hong Kong scene.
Tropic Thunder is a masterclass in its genre, with Stillers performance standing out as particularly impressive. His screen presence is flawless, and he delivers one of his most memorable lines yet: "I have seen Vietnam. I will never go back." The scene where director Terry Gilliam and Stillers co-star Ron Livingston are both dressed in Hong Kong attire, speaking in accents, with Stillers character in a Hawaiian shirt and Livingstons in a tux, is a comedic highlight.

input:
Like a wave breaking against the shore, it was over in a moment.
But in that moment - noon Saturday - more than 240 people stood at the water's edge in Atlantic and Neptune Beach, clasping each other's hands, united in their
continuation:
grief.
As was said earlier, it was hard to talk, let alone hear, what was happening around them.
Not one person was allowed to look away, or even stand.
"You have people in your office, I think, who think it is only one story, only one event," said Atlantic County Prosecutor Damon Tyner, speaking to reporters moments before his staff filed in.
"I think it is going to take time, I think it is going to hurt us, and I think people are going to talk, because it is raw.
It is raw.
I think it will hurt us for awhile. "
And, he said, it is something this office, which had already been rocked this year by the senseless shootings of eight people in its courtrooms, is still working its way through.
"It is never easy, but it is something I think you guys are going to feel for us for awhile," he said.
"I just want to say, again, I am deeply, deeply sorry."
More: Here are some of Atlantic County's latest police shootings of 2016
More: Atlantic City Police Release Body Camera Footage from Fatal Shooting of Andrew Coffman
"It was like
paraphrase: The momentary wave crashing against the shore was over in an instant. However, on that fateful Saturday afternoon, over 240 people stood united in grief at the water's edge in Atlantic and Neptune Beach, holding each other's hands. Despite the challenge of processing their emotions, the gathering remained fixated on the tragedy unfolding before them. Atlantic County Prosecutor Damon Tyner addressed the media, his words filled with empathy and sincerity. "It is raw. It will hurt us for a while," he said, acknowledging the immense pain the community was grappling with. He recognized that the office had faced multiple traumas this year, including the senseless shootings of eight people in its courtrooms. "It is never easy, but it is something I think you guys are going to feel for us for a while," he expressed, his voice heavy with empathy. In a gesture of deep sorrow, he reiterated, "I just want to say, again, I am deeply, deeply sorry." As the community continued to process the loss, Atlantic City Police released body camera footage from the fatal shooting of Andrew Coffman, providing a poignant reminder of the ongoing struggle for justice and healing.

paraphrase:
The Hudson competitive cheer team excelled at the Saline Invitational, winning the Division 4 title and placing second overall with a total score of 738.44. The Tigers showed impressive consistency across events, with their highest score coming in the 1-meter bar with a second-place finish.
Led by Kayla White, the Tigers recorded impressive individual scores, including 83.55 in the 1-meter, 82.85 in the beam, and 77.95 in the preliminaries. White, Madeline McCutcheon, and Hailey Stahr also performed exceptionally, with scores of 77.75, 77.25, and 78.95, respectively.

input:
Coach shortages that have caused overcrowding on the commuter rail will persist until for a few more weeks, officials said Monday.
The shortage of coaches that has caused overcrowding on the commuter rail will persist until mid-May, officials said Monday.
continuation:
Long-haul trains, which typically fill trains with commuters from other parts of the state, are largely idled in Concord due to a shortage of coaches. The problem is expected to worsen due to the end of Gov. Jerry Browns emergency state of emergency order, which ends April 30.
We are experiencing significant challenges with respect to train service and will be addressing this in terms of operational improvements, said James Ritchie, a CSNCA spokesman.
Carpool drivers, who ferry commuters in and out of Concords train station, are also filling in. But they too are running short on time, Ritchie said.
As more people get out of their vehicles and go into the train station, he said, more carpool drivers also will be needed.
On Sunday, hundreds of Concordites boarded a carpool to meet in Concord with people in Santa Cruz, Watsonville and Salinas. The train was packed with mostly seniors. Many people said it took 30 minutes to get off in Watsonville, making it difficult for people to get in or out of the carpool. It took 45 minutes or more in Salinas.
Its frustrating
paraphrase:
Officials have announced that the shortage of coaches on the commuter rail will persist until mid-May, causing overcrowding on the trains. Long-haul trains from other parts of the state are currently idled in Concord due to the coach shortage, which is expected to worsen after the end of Gov. Jerry Brown's emergency state of emergency order on April 30.
To address the issue, the Concord Springs and Northern California Arena (CSNCA) is working on operational improvements. Meanwhile, carpool drivers are stepping in to fill the gap, but they are also facing challenges as more people use the train service. On Sunday, hundreds of Concordites carpooled to meet with people in Santa Cruz, Watsonville, and Salinas, with mostly seniors on the train. However, the long wait times in these cities are causing difficulties for carpool drivers and passengers.
Commuters are expressing frustration with the situation, citing long wait times and overcrowding on the trains.

Steve Burkus, 86, of Ambridge, died Sunday, February 21, 2010, in UPMC Cranberry Place.
Born November 11, 1923, in Ambridge, a son of the late Michael and Priscilla Szabo Burk
continuation: us, he was formerly of Ambridge, where he lived his entire life. He was a member of St. Stanislaus Kostka Church, where he served in many capacities. He retired from General Motors in East Norriton, where he was employed from 1950-1962. He was employed by St. Michaels Machine in Pittsburgh, PA, from 1964-1973, before he retired from the St. Lukes School in Ambridge, PA. He was a member of St. Stanislaus Kostka Church, former president of its board of directors, member of the Norwin Ambulance Company, former president of its board of directors, member of its board of officers, former treasurer of the St. Stanislaus Kostka Ambulance, member of the Ambulance Association, former president of its board of directors, former member of its board of officers, former president of its foundation, former president of its board of governors, former president of its Foundation Foundation, former president of its Auxiliary, former member of its Board of Officers, former board of governors, former member of its Board of Governors, former member of its Board of Trustees, former board member, former chairman
paraphrase:
Steve Burkus, a long-time resident of Ambridge, passed away on February 21st, 2010, at the age of 86, at UPMC Cranberry Place. Born on November 11th, 1923, in Ambridge, he was the son of the late Michael and Priscilla Szabo Burkus. Steve was a lifelong member of St. Stanislaus Kostka Church, where he served in various capacities, including former president of the board of directors, member of the Norwin Ambulance Company, former president of the board of directors, and former treasurer of the St. Stanislaus Kostka Ambulance.
Steve was a dedicated member of his community, having worked at General Motors in East Norriton from 1950-1962, and later at St. Michael's Machine in Pittsburgh, PA, from 1964-1973, before retiring from the St. Lukes School in Ambridge, PA. He was also a former member of the Ambulance Association, former president of its board of directors, and former member of its board of officers.
Steve will be remembered for his dedication to his faith and his community. He will be deeply missed by all those who knew him.

input:
The Best Buy logo on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in New York on Nov. 12, 2018.
In naming Corie Barry chief executive officer, Best Buy Co. hands the reins to the architect of its current growth strategy, widely
continuation:
regarded as one of the company's most successful. Barry, who will succeed Mike Scott when he retires in June, has spent 30 years in technology. As CEO of the Consumer Technology Association (CTA), her job is to support the business, advocacy, technical, and research communities in advocating for the needs of the IT marketplace. The CTA is the trade association of the world's IT industry, which according to its website is made up of more than 170,000 members. Barry was named CEO of CTA in August 2018, just days before Apple named Tim Cook CEO of Apple. (Matt Slocum/Associated Press)
NEW YORK  Corie Barry is in charge of one of the world's largest IT-marketplace corporations, ready to transform into the tech retailer it needs to succeed.
Barry is in charge of Best Buy Co.  formerly Circuit City  which will announce in a few months its third-quarter earnings. The tech-and-electronics retailer  which in January said its revenue fell in its latest quarter  said this week it will report revenue of $10.37 billion in its latest fiscal third quarter, with earnings per share of 95 cents.
The company said it expects revenue of $
paraphrase:
Corie Barry, the newly appointed CEO of Best Buy Co., takes the helm as the face of the company's growth strategy, having spent three decades in the technology industry. As the architect of Best Buy's current success, Barry brings a wealth of experience to her new role, having served as CEO of the Consumer Technology Association (CTA) and advocating for the needs of the IT marketplace. With over 170,000 members under her guidance, the CTA is the trade association of the world's IT industry. Barry's appointment as CEO of CTA came just days before Apple named Tim Cook as CEO of Apple. As she takes the reins at Best Buy, Barry is poised to lead the tech retailer into a new era of success.
Under Barry's leadership, Best Buy Co. is set to announce its third-quarter earnings in the coming months. The company has reported a decline in revenue in its latest quarter, but remains optimistic about its future prospects. With an expected revenue of $10.37 billion and earnings per share of 95 cents, Best Buy is confident in its ability to continue growing and thriving in the competitive tech industry.

input:
Helen Epstein reports in The New York Review of Books (excerpt below) on the death of Ms. Cerinah Nebanda, a fearless young member of Parliament who challenged Gen. Museveni in Uganda over corruption.
It
continuation:
been ten days since Helen Epstein wrote this, and Im still recovering.
Im just learning of Ms. Nebandas death. Its like reading about it happened a few days ago. A few days is too much. Its like its happened before, only it was a long time ago. A lifetime ago. A few lifetimes ago. A few decades ago. A few decades ago.
I was just reading The New Yorker in preparation for this interview. The story was published in April. It seems like a lifetime ago. A lifetime is too much. Its like it was just before I was born. A few years is too much. A lifetime is too much. Its like it happened just before I was born. A few generations ago. A few centuries ago. A few millennia ago. A few generations ago. A few centuries ago. A few millenniums ago. A few generations ago. A few millennia ago. A few centuries ago. A few generations ago. A few decades ago. A few decades ago. A few decades ago. A few decades ago. A few decades ago. A few decades ago.
paraphrase:
Helen Epstein's article in The New York Review of Books recounts the tragic passing of Cerinah Nebanda, a bold and determined young parliamentarian who fought against corruption in Uganda. The news of her death has left me reeling, and I am still trying to come to terms with it.
It has been ten days since I first learned of Ms. Nebanda's passing, and the shock of it still feels almost too much to bear. It's like I'm still recovering from the news, even though it happened a lifetime ago. The thought of her untimely demise is almost too painful to consider.
I was recently reading The New Yorker in preparation for this interview, and the story about Ms. Nebanda was published in April. It feels like a lifetime ago, a distant memory that I can't quite shake off. A few lifetimes ago, perhaps.
Ms. Nebanda's courage and conviction are an inspiration to us all, and her unwavering commitment to exposing corruption in Uganda's government is a testament to her strength and character. Her passing is a loss not just for her family and friends, but for the entire nation and beyond.
The weight of her loss is almost too much to bear, and I find myself struggling to come to terms with it. A few decades ago, perhaps. A few millennia ago, maybe. The thought of a world without Ms. Nebanda in it is almost too much to comprehend.
Her legacy lives on, however, and her determination to fight for what is right will continue to inspire us all. Rest in peace, Ms. Nebanda. Your bravery and conviction will never be forgotten.

Traffic deaths in California fell 9 percent last year  the biggest drop in 14 years  and crashes on Highway 17 continued their nearly decadelong decline.
State officials attribute the decline in road-related deaths statewide to more Californians wearing their seat
continuation:
belts, more attention paid to drinking-and-driving and tougher penalties for illegal alcohol consumption.
Traffic fatalities are still a significant challenge, Caltrans Director Paul McCaskill said. With the passage of Proposition 64, weve made a lot of progress in improving roads in California.
Highway 17, which leads into Yosemite National Park from Merced, continued to show progress. The states newest roadway in Yosemite is one of six freeways where fatalities dropped from 2016 to 2017, according to Caltrans. The new Freeway of the Future will eventually replace one of its freeway sections, eliminating a bottleneck in traffic. The highways completion will create a new traffic pattern from Sacramento into Yuba, with more than twice as many lanes.
As of Sunday, more than 7,500 traffic fatalities in the state were attributed to crashes on freeways. Thats fewer than 7,700 in 2016, the previous year with the greatest number of fatalities. Caltrans is in the process of redesigning Highway 1 from Sacramento into Yuba, which will also eliminate bottlenecks in traffic. The states other six freeways  Highway 76,
paraphrase:
California witnessed a notable decline in traffic fatalities last year, with a 9% drop in deaths, the largest decline in 14 years. According to state officials, this improvement can be attributed to increased seat belt usage, heightened awareness about drunk driving, and tougher penalties for alcohol-related offenses.
Despite this progress, traffic fatalities remain a significant concern. Paul McCaskill, director of Caltrans, emphasized that with the passage of Proposition 64, significant improvements have been made in California's road infrastructure.
Highway 17, which connects Merced to Yosemite National Park, continues to show positive trends, with fatalities decreasing for the ninth consecutive year. Caltrans reported that six of the state's freeways, including Highway 17, experienced a drop in fatalities from 2016 to 2017. The upcoming Freeway of the Future project will eliminate a bottleneck in traffic and provide more than double the number of lanes, creating a new traffic pattern from Sacramento to Yuba.
As of Sunday, a total of 7,500 traffic fatalities in the state were attributed to crashes on freeways, representing a decrease of over 200 deaths from the previous year. Caltrans is currently redesigning Highway 1 from Sacramento to Yuba, which will also alleviate traffic congestion. The state's other six freeways, including Highway 76, are also undergoing improvements.

input:
We all know that real estate developers can make big money; they also take significant risk. How can mom and pop real estate investors get into the development game?
Starting with a small rental development where youre adding one
continuation:
or two houses (or condos) in a desirable area, then expanding when it pays off, learning from mistakes, and improving, then growing with other successful projects, before getting into acquisitions, and ultimately, managing, owning, managing, or creating one of these projects. The road goes on, in my opinion.
How can mom and pop investors get into the development game in general? Ill share some ideas from this article:
1. Get involved in small rental projects. First, try to find some rentals in your area, or in areas where you already live. Get out and talk with local rental owners, get information from them, talk to investors, talk to prospective investors, talk to rental brokers, talk to investors. Learn about the rental market, learn what needs are being filled in your area. The more information you can get, the more opportunities youll find. This will get you going, even if it doesnt pan out in the first few projects. But if youre talking with investors, talking with renters, reading, etc. youll find other people with similar interests, and may end up with more projects going, or even more buyers.
paraphrase:
Newbie real estate investors can enter the development game by starting small with a rental project in a desirable area. They can learn from their mistakes, expand their portfolio, and eventually move on to more complex projects like acquisitions and management. Here are some strategies for getting started:
1. Research the local rental market: Find out what types of properties are in demand and what the competition looks like. Talk to local landlords, investors, and rental brokers to gather information and identify potential opportunities.
2. Network with like-minded individuals: Connecting with other investors and learning from their experiences can help you identify potential projects and partnerships. Attend local real estate events, join online forums, and participate in networking groups to expand your network.
3. Start small: Begin with a single rental property or a small development project in a low-risk area. This will allow you to gain experience and build your portfolio gradually. As you gain confidence and proficiency, you can expand your scope and take on more ambitious projects.
4. Be adaptable: The real estate development game is full of ups and downs, so it's essential to be flexible and willing to pivot when necessary. Don't be afraid to try new strategies or take on new challenges as you gain experience and confidence.
5. Keep learning: The real estate industry is constantly evolving, so it's important to stay up-to-date on the latest trends, regulations, and best practices. Continuously educate yourself through reading, attending seminars, and networking with other professionals in the field.

In summary, breaking into the real estate development game as a mom-and-pop investor requires a gradual and incremental approach. Start small, learn from your mistakes, and expand your portfolio gradually. Network with other investors, stay adaptable, and keep learning to increase your chances of success.

input:
Chris Coleman admits he would be prepared to allow Gareth Bale to sit out Wales friendlies in the future as he seeks to nurture a strong working relationship with Real Madrid.
It was a surprise to see Bale, the world's most expensive player following his
continuation:
86million move from Tottenham in September, left out of the Republic of Ireland squad for a friendly with Wales in Dublin last month.
His place was filled by Ethan Ampadu, a Chelsea midfielder, with Coleman expressing concern that Bale was not performing in the wake of his switch from White Hart Lane, and he insisted he was pleased his former club were happy with his commitment. "It is something I am always thinking about with Gareth," Coleman said. "I am looking forward to the season. I believe he is working hard. I spoke with Gareth and I believe he is working hard."
Coleman, who helped Real Madrid win four European Championships, believes Bale could yet end his international career with the Welsh national team. "You never say never, I think it is one of those things, I don't think it is beyond Gareth. I think Gareth was here for many years. It is difficult because he is going away, I would like him to stay. He is here to win trophies, he was here to win trophies here."
Coleman, whose side have been drawn in Group A alongside Austria, Slovenia, Austria and Bosnia, said he was happy with his options as he set out his preparations for Euro 2020, where
paraphrase:
Chris Coleman hinted that he might allow Gareth Bale to sit out some of Wales' friendly matches in the future as he seeks to foster a strong working relationship with Real Madrid. Bale, the world's most expensive player following his 86 million transfer from Tottenham in September, was surprisingly left out of the Republic of Ireland squad for a friendly with Wales in Dublin last month. Coleman expressed concern about Bale's form after his move from White Hart Lane and emphasized that he was content that his former club were satisfied with his commitment.
Coleman, who won four European Championships with Real Madrid, believes Bale could still end his international career with the Welsh national team. He acknowledged that Bale has been away for several years and stressed that he would like him to stay, but ultimately, he acknowledged that he can't say never. Coleman is focused on preparing for Euro 2020, where Wales has been drawn in Group A alongside Austria, Slovenia, Austria, and Bosnia. He expressed satisfaction with his options as he sets out his preparations for the tournament.

input:
Years after his death, an anonymous letter has led to a suspect in the fatal hit-and-run that killed Baylor University sophomore David Grotberg.
Gabrielle Lyons was asking for $750,000 from the university in a lawsuit she
continuation:
filed Tuesday. The money was to go to her children in lieu of funeral costs. But she ended up dropping the money claim in favor of filing the civil suit.
In April 2017, Grotberg was in a crosswalk in Waco when he was hit. He was critically injured. He later succumbed to his injuries. A local couple, Ramiro "RAM" Alazraqui and his wife, Sonia, were charged with hit-and-run. But Alazraqui is in federal immigration detention, according to Waco police. He faces death threats from his immigration attorney. His wife is in court this week. Alazraqui could face life in prison if he is found guilty of a misdemeanor count of criminal mischief. He is due back in court in September.
Waco police are still seeking information from anyone who may know what happened to Grotberg, or was in a crosswalk with him around that time. Anyone with information is asked to call police.
READ MORE: Waco police release new images of hit-and-run suspects
paraphrase:
Years after the tragic event, a mysterious letter has led investigators to reopen the case of David Grotberg's fatal hit-and-run accident at Baylor University. The suspect, Gabrielle Lyons, has filed a lawsuit against the university, demanding $750,000 in funeral expenses for her children. However, she later dropped this claim and pursued a civil suit instead.
In April 2017, Grotberg was struck by a vehicle while crossing a Waco street. He sustained critical injuries and later passed away. Two individuals, Ramiro "RAM" Alazraqui and his wife Sonia, were charged with hit-and-run, but Alazraqui is currently in federal immigration detention facing death threats from his immigration attorney. His wife is scheduled to appear in court this week, and Alazraqui could potentially face life in prison if convicted of a misdemeanor count of criminal mischief.
Waco police are still actively seeking information from anyone who may have witnessed the accident or was in the vicinity at the time. They urge anyone with knowledge to come forward and contact the authorities.
In related news, Waco police have released new images of the suspects involved in the hit-and-run incident, in hopes of generating additional leads and bringing the perpetrators to justice.

input: In all probability, the main Hazratganj crossing is likely to be named after former prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, as the executive committee of the Lucknow Municipal Corporation, in a meeting on Friday, gave power to mayor
continuation: Sumit Kumar Yadav to designate the road crossing. The move was taken in light of its significance, Yadav said. "It was important to give power to mayor Sumit Kumar Yadav. After the road is designated, its name will be finalised by us in the next one month," he said. Yadav said the traffic will be diverted from this crossing, which was also named after former Uttar Pradesh chief minister Lal Krishna Advani. The corridor was inaugurated on August 31, 2018, he said. "Traffic will be diverted from this side only. Now, the roads will be named after Vajpayee, Swami Vivekanand, Atalji, Swami Pragya, Swami Chinmayanand," he said. Yadav said only one side will get traffic diverted from Hazratganj. "The other side will get traffic diverted in case it is needed. The decision will be finalised in next one month. The new traffic lights will also be made operational from this side, he said." Yadav said this new traffic light will be inaugurated with the help of local police. "A small crowd will be invited only, if any. The crowd should strictly follow all protocols. It is
paraphrase: In all likelihood, the main crossing in Hazratganj is likely to be named after former Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, as the executive committee of the Lucknow Municipal Corporation has granted Mayor Sumit Kumar Yadav the authority to designate the road crossing. The move was taken into account due to the crossing's significance, according to Yadav. He stated that the name of the road will be finalized by the corporation within the next month. Yadav also revealed that traffic will be diverted from this crossing, which was previously named after former Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Lal Krishna Advani. He added that only one side of the crossing will experience traffic diversion, and the decision will be finalized within the next month. Additionally, new traffic lights will be operationalized from this side with the help of local police. Yadav mentioned that a small crowd will be invited to attend the inauguration of the new traffic lights, and all protocols must be strictly followed.

What Is Business-Casual or Fancy-Casual Dress Attire?
Button-up shirts and khaki slacks work for men or women.
Dress codes at work can be confounding. Offices have loosened up and introduced business
continuation:
casual attire. What does it really mean? Here are six things to consider.
What is business casual attire?
What is business-casual attire? Business-casual attire is typically characterized as casual clothing (e.g., jeans, slacks) with the business portion of the outfit (e.g., shirt or tie) tucked in or fastened. Business-casual attire may involve informal business attire (e.g., slacks, blouses) with the business portion tucked in or fastened. Business-casual attire may involve formal business attire (e.g., pants, blouses) with the business portion tucked in or fastened. Business-casual attire may involve both. Business-casual attire is typically characterized as casual clothing (e.g., jeans, slacks) with the business portion tucked in or fastened. Business-casual attire may involve formal business attire (e.g., pants, blouses) with the business portion tucked in or fastened. Business-casual attire may involve both. For example, women may choose to wear business-casual attire, with or without a blouse, when in a traditional office environment. On the other hand, a woman
paraphrase: The definition of business-casual attire can be a bit foggy, especially in today's more relaxed work environments. Essentially, it refers to clothing that's a step up from casual wear but still professional and polished. For men, this might mean button-up shirts and khaki slacks, while women can opt for blouses or tops with slacks or jeans. The key is to strike a balance between formality and comfort, with the business portion of the outfit (such as a shirt or tie) tucked in or fastened. Business-casual attire can encompass a range of styles, including informal business attire, formal business attire, and even a combination of both. Ultimately, the goal is to look professional and put-together without sacrificing comfort or individuality.

Well go through the preseason, Lynn said. I dont think itll (effect) him. Hell

input:
SALT LAKE CITY  Evan McMullin sat at a conference table in his modest campaign headquarters here one morning last week, struggling to pick which high-profile Republican had most disappointed him this year.
"Can we just say 'all of
continuation:
them?' " he said. "I'm really disappointed in Ron Paul, I'm really disappointed in Ted Cruz, I'm really disappointed in Scott Walker, I'm really disappointed in Rick Perry. I could go on."
Mr. McMullin, who was Mr. Perrys 2012 opponent, was asked: Would he back Mr. Perry again if he were the GOP presidential candidate in 2016, or even Mr. Romney, Mr. Trump or Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas? His response was surprising.
"You dont get to say that. I dont think I deserve it, he said. I dont think anyone deserves to be put in the box. Im going to let them choose."
It is rare for presidential hopefuls in recent decades to publicly distance themselves from former adversaries, especially with only 20 days left before the partys primary season begins. It is also unusual for someone with Mr. McMullins limited, understated popularity in the GOP. He is the only remaining Republican presidential candidate who, before the 2012 election, never said Mr. Romney was "the wrong choice." Now, Mr. McMull
paraphrase:
Here is a paraphrased version of the input passage:
In a small campaign headquarters in Salt Lake City last week, Evan McMullin sat at a conference table struggling to choose which high-profile Republican had disappointed him the most this year. "I could go on," he said with a sigh. McMullin, who was previously a opponent of Rick Perry's in 2012, was asked if he would support Perry in the 2016 presidential election. Despite his limited popularity within the GOP, McMullin's decision to remain neutral is a bold move that could potentially impact the outcome of the election.

input:
The Tax and Customs Board (MTA) has signed an agreement with Online accommodation and hospitality marketplace Airbnb which enables hosts to automatically report earnings.
The MTA and Airbnb held a joint press conference on Wednesday, announcing the agreement's signing as well as the
continuation:
release of its first statistics on the hospitality sector.
According to MTA head of regulatory compliance and compliance, Edward Kao, under the terms of the agreement, hosts will report earnings, including accommodation, meals, drinks and any other relevant costs, within seven days of receipt. The same seven days will be used for any subsequent periods of time if needed.
Airbnb will also offer the hosts insurance cover against any event which may exceed one week or any incident where the hosts are unable to provide accurate or complete information, or if the hosts are injured.
"The introduction of these measures is yet another step forward in our pursuit of making it easier for people to enjoy Singapore, while also making it easier for us to tackle illegal and unregulated activities in these industries, which pose threats to the tourism sector," Mr Kao said.
The agreement is part of Airbnb's ongoing commitment in Singapore to help drive tourism, while also addressing local concerns around illegal activities in these industries.
Airbnb has said it will invest in initiatives in Singapore, including initiatives which support local tourism, promote sustainable tourism, help promote new accommodation options, enhance hosts' earnings, and provide information. The company also said it is working closely with local authorities to provide relevant information,
paraphrase:
The MTA and Airbnb have signed an agreement that enables hosts to automatically report their earnings, including income from accommodation, meals, drinks, and other relevant expenses, within seven days of receipt. Under the agreement, Airbnb will also provide insurance coverage to hosts in the event of unforeseen events or incidents that may occur beyond their control, such as extended stays or incomplete reporting.
According to the MTA's head of regulatory compliance and compliance, Edward Kao, the agreement represents a significant step forward in the organization's efforts to promote responsible and sustainable tourism in Singapore. By making it easier for hosts to report their earnings and providing insurance coverage, the agreement aims to address local concerns around illegal activities in the hospitality sector while also driving tourism and supporting the local economy.
Airbnb has committed to investing in initiatives in Singapore that promote sustainable tourism, enhance hosts' earnings, and provide information to local authorities. The company is working closely with the MTA to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements and to promote a safe and enjoyable experience for all tourists.
Overall, the agreement between the MTA and Airbnb demonstrates the organization's commitment to supporting the growth of the hospitality sector in Singapore while also addressing concerns around illegal activities. By working together, the MTA and Airbnb aim to promote responsible and sustainable tourism that benefits both the local economy and the tourism industry as a whole.

continuation:
tes guard Jaelan Phillips (21) in the first half during the USC vs. USC game in the semifinals of the Pac-12 conference tournament at The Field House. USC won 70-64.
After losing in the Pac-12 tournament semifinals in 2018, the Utah Utes look like they're ready to go in 2019-20.
Utah (19-11) will welcome back six of its top seven scorers from last season, and will have two redshirts available. After losing in the tournament semifinals, Utah opened its season with victories in its next six games.
"Our season was what I expected it would be," said junior guard Jordan Harris, who finished second in scoring (16.6 ppg) and fourth in rebounds (6.0 per game) last season. "I'm happy with where we are. We had an off year. We didn't do what I wanted us to do, so I'm happy with where we are, especially with this year."
With the additions of Harris, guard Jaelan Phillips (16.0 ppg) and big man T.J. Haws (6.0 ppg), Utah should again be one of the Pac-12's top scoring

The team will also have two redshirts available. After losing in the Pac-12 tournament semifinals in 2018, Utah is looking strong heading into the new season, with victories in their first six games. According to Harris, the team's season is on track, despite not meeting their initial goals. With the addition of Harris, guard Jaelan Phillips (16.0 ppg), and big man T.J. Haws (6.0 ppg), Utah is poised to be one of the Pac-12's top-scoring teams once again.

input: Twenty-five years ago, at Minneapolis Southern Theater, Gale LaJoye created Snowflake, a one-man show featuring a sad-sack clown who turned a junk-strewn vacant lot into a place of
continuation:
joy and wonder, and a place where people could talk about whatever was troubling them. This week, LaJoye returns to his neighborhood theater in Twin Cities suburb Bloomington, Minn., where he will perform his one-man show, also called Snowflake, this time with the help of his wife, artist Barbara Woll.

LaJoyes show, which he co-created with artist Barbara Woll, was born from frustration. It became, in its first year, a favorite with many local teenagers. He still remembers, when he was about 14, being startled awake in his bed when he heard screaming from outside his window.

LaJoyes parents were asleep in his bedroom, while his sister was sleeping in her bed. At first he assumed someone was being hurt or killed, he said, thinking he needed to go outside. He jumped out of bed, grabbed his flashlight, and ran down the hall, making his way into his sisters bedroom, where he found his mothers still-sleeping sister, covered in blood, with a broken finger. His father was dead, in the bathroom. A broken window from a car or motorcycle was shattered, its shattering
paraphrase:
Twenty-five years ago, at the Minneapolis Southern Theater, Gale LaJoye premiered Snowflake, a one-man show that captivated audiences with its poignant tale of a melancholic clown transforming a desolate lot into a haven of joy and communication. This week, LaJoye revisits his hometown theater in Bloomington, Minnesota, to reprise his award-winning performance, now accompanied by his wife, artist Barbara Woll.
LaJoye's production, which he co-created with Woll, evolved from his frustration with the world. Initially, it resonated deeply with local teenagers, and LaJoye still recalls the frightening incident that inspired the show's inception. When he was just 14, he was jolted awake by cries for help from outside his bedroom window.
Upon investigating, he discovered his parents, sister, and their visiting aunt lying unconscious in their bedrooms, with his aunt sustaining a broken finger. LaJoye's father was found deceased in the bathroom, with a shattered window suggesting a car or motorcycle accident.
LaJoye's masterful portrayal of the tragic event not only highlights the fragility of life but also underscores the importance of human connection in times of crisis.

input:
There's something important that chronically indecisive people need to understand: They're not actually interested in making a decision. Since this statement flies brazenly in the face of common sense, let me restate it differently.
Indeed, as these individuals anguish
continuation:
, it is important to remember what the definition of indecisive is. It is simply, in its simplest form, when one is not making a decision.
And in this case, that definition of indecisive is simply, "I don't have a decision." It is also often confused with indecision, where people often seem indecisive when, in fact, they are making decisions. For example, here are some times when someone seems indecisive:
Im going to bedI dont want toI dont want to get out of bedI dont want to get into bedI dont want to get in bed with someoneI dont want to get in bed with someoneI dont want to eatI dont want to eatI dont want toI dont want to go to sleepI dont want to go to sleepI dont want to get out of bedI dont want to get in bedI dont want to get in bed with someoneI dont want to get in
paraphrase:
It's crucial for chronically indecisive individuals to grasp the underlying reality: They're not actually invested in arriving at a decision. Contrary to popular belief, let me rephrase this statement in a different light.
To put it simply, indecisive people are those who don't make decisions. This definition may seem counterintuitive, but it's important to understand its nuances.
In reality, indecisive is not the same as indecision. While indecision can manifest in seemingly uncertain moments, it's actually a matter of making choices. For instance, here are some scenarios when someone might appear indecisive:
They are going to bed without a clear intention. They don't want to get out of bed or engage in a particular activity. They are unwilling to eat or participate in social situations. They struggle to make decisions, leading others to believe they are indecisive.
In each of these instances, the individual is making a choice, albeit a hesitant or reluctant one. They might not always express their preferences openly, but they are still determining their course of action. By recognizing this distinction, we can better understand the complex nature of decision-making and the factors that influence it.

CALGARY, Alberta (Reuters) - Encana Corp (ECA.TO), Canadas largest natural gas producer, slashed its 2015 capital budget by a quarter on Wednesday in response to a slump in global crude oil prices.
The
continuation:
Calgary-based company also said it will use cash from a recent IPO to pay down its debts of nearly C$5 billion ($4.2 billion), which are expected to fall in 2016.
Encana, which is battling slowing growth in U.S. natural gas production, said its average daily natural gas production was 894,400 cubic feet per day in the third quarter, down 34 percent from the same period in 2014.
Encana is facing the worst gas pricing in decades, Chief Executive Officer Bill Watson said in a statement.
With current low gas prices, we need to put more capital toward growth initiatives in the natural gas business and less towards projects in oil.
Watson said this years reduced investment will result in annual cash savings of C$600 million, which will help cover annual capex of around C$1 billion. The company expects natural gas production to average 7.6 bcf per day in 2016, a 23 percent increase from this year.
Encanas current average daily natural gas production in its core Western United States basin was 774,400 cubic feet per day in the third quarter, down 36 percent from the same period in
paraphrase:
Encana, the largest natural gas producer in Canada, has reduced its capital budget for 2015 by 25% in response to the current slump in global crude oil prices. As part of its cost-cutting measures, the company will use proceeds from its recent initial public offering (IPO) to pay down its debts of nearly C$5 billion ($4.2 billion), which are expected to decrease in 2016.
According to Encana's Chief Executive Officer Bill Watson, the company is facing the worst gas pricing in decades, which has led to a decrease in its average daily natural gas production. In the third quarter, Encana's average daily natural gas production was 894,400 cubic feet per day, a 34% decrease from the same period in 2014.
To address this challenge, Watson stated that the company will prioritize growth initiatives in the natural gas business and reduce investments in oil projects. This strategy is expected to result in annual cash savings of C$600 million, which will help cover annual capital expenditures of around C$1 billion. Encana anticipates that its natural gas production will average 7.6 billion cubic feet per day in 2016, a 23% increase from this year.
In its core Western United States basin, Encana's current average daily natural gas production stands at 774,400 cubic feet per day in the third quarter, a 36% decrease from the same period in 2014.

While the Senate debated a lengthy series of amendments to the proposed malpractice reform bill, the Assembly plowed ahead and pushed the plan through committee and to a vote on the floor Tuesday night.
As the Assembly convened at 9:30 p.m
continuation:
., Governor Cuomo was making his own rounds of the Capitol, greeting lawmakers as they came into his office. As he entered, he stopped in the press area, shaking hands and giving each member a hug. Then he sat in the same office with members of his office staff.
As Cuomo left, lawmakers emerged from a hearing, looking pleased, if not giddy, to announce that they had reached an agreement on the bill. "I'm feeling very confident that if this goes through I'm looking at a very, very happy state legislature," said Assemblymember Ydanis Rodriguez, a Democrat from Manhattan.
In recent days, the Democratic governor, with his support from Republicans, pushed through his proposal, which could provide insurance coverage for medical mistakes in state-run hospital emergency rooms. The new bill was approved in just eight days, in time to go before the Senate when it meets next.
A final vote on final passage in the Senate was expected late Tuesday night, though it seemed likely that it would pass the chamber only to go back to the Assembly for further consideration. The Senate could also vote later Tuesday.
On his way back from the Capitol, Cuomo took calls from reporters, who asked him whether he was concerned with the growing
paraphrase:
As the Senate deliberated on a comprehensive series of amendments to the proposed malpractice reform bill, the Assembly remained steadfast in their pursuit of passing the plan through committee and floor vote. On Tuesday night, the Assembly convened at 9:30 p.m., with Governor Cuomo busy greeting lawmakers in his office and engaging in last-minute negotiations.
As the Assembly members gathered in the chamber, Cuomo's office staff was seen working behind the scenes to finalize the bill. Amidst the flurry of activity, Assemblymember Ydanis Rodriguez expressed his confidence in the bill's success, citing the momentum gained from recent agreements reached with lawmakers.
In a surprising turn of events, Cuomo's proposal, which would provide insurance coverage for medical mistakes in state-run hospital emergency rooms, was approved in just eight days, setting the stage for a potential Senate vote. With the new bill in place, the Senate was expected to vote on final passage late Tuesday night, with a possible revisit to the Assembly for further consideration.
As Cuomo concluded his rounds in the Capitol, he fielded calls from reporters, addressing concerns about the bill's potential impact on the state's medical system. Despite these challenges, the Governor remained optimistic, buoyed by the Assembly's swift action and the prospect of a successful vote in the Senate.

(JTA)  Five of the fatalities in the terrorist truck-ramming attack in New York City on Tuesday afternoon were Argentine tourists celebrating the 30th anniversary of their high school graduation, including one Jewish businessman.
According to Argentinas
continuation:
YNet news, Israels consulate in Buenos Aires confirmed that 41-year-old Francisco Mortera, the father of one of the victims, was one of the five Argentine citizens killed when an Uber vehicle drove into pedestrians in the neighborhood of Rockaway, which is home to many Hasidim. Three of the victims were identified as local women.
The other two victims were identified as Francisco Morteras son, 32, and his wife, a 42-year-old mother of seven. The youngest of the victims was 6.
Mortera, according to his wife, worked in finance. His son is pursuing a career in dentistry, according to Argentine news outlet Clarin. The childrens father, named Laela, was a native of Buenos Aires. His brother-in-law, named Matias, was in his 20s.
Israeli Ambassador Ron Dermer called the victims brilliant people, Israels Channel 11 news reported. The Argentine ambassador also confirmed the deaths in Israel.
Related coverage Israel Arrests Four Terrorists, Claims More Killings Likely Israel arrested four terror suspects from its southern border on Sunday, in what its military said were "
paraphrase:
Five Argentine tourists, including a Jewish businessman, were tragically killed in the terrorist truck-ramming attack in New York City on Tuesday. According to Argentine news sources, 41-year-old Francisco Mortera, the father of one of the victims, was among the five Argentine citizens who lost their lives when an Uber vehicle struck pedestrians in the Rockaway neighborhood, which is home to many Hasidic people. The other four victims included three local women and Morteras son, a 32-year-old dentistry student, and his wife, a 42-year-old mother of seven. The youngest victim was just 6 years old.
Israeli Ambassador Ron Dermer described the victims as brilliant people, and the Argentine ambassador confirmed their deaths in Israel. In related news, Israeli authorities arrested four terror suspects from the southern border on Sunday, with the military stating that more killings are likely.

input:
WhileComcast had its problems in 2015, its Universal Pictures segment had an unprecedented year specifically with franchise films.
It's not that other segments of the business struggled. Cable was strong, despite cord-cutting fears, and even
continuation:
in-home broadband enjoyed growth. Universal saw its profit grow 28% year over year, which was almost twice its 7% increase in operating profits. And its movie studio saw its profits jump 24% over the year.
Why was it so successful in its franchises? Part of it is pure coincidence: The release of these franchises is highly popular around the world. A few of them are also successful with moviegoers, while others like Jurassic World did something rare  it appealed to all audiences in countries like Russia, where attendance was low.
And while this doesnt necessarily tell us anything about the larger movie business, it does indicate that its franchises may be something of a new moneymaker. Thats what Hollywood is looking for these days  blockbusters that appeal broadly around the world.
paraphrase:
In 2015, Comcast's Universal Pictures segment experienced an exceptional year, driven by the success of its franchise films. While other segments of the business performed well, including cable and in-home broadband, which saw growth, Universal's profit soared by 28%, nearly double its 7% increase in operating profits. The movie studio's profits also jumped 24% over the year.
The success of these franchise films can be attributed to a combination of factors, including pure coincidence and the global popularity of these releases. For instance, Jurassic World managed to appeal to audiences across different regions, including countries like Russia, where attendance was relatively low.
This trend suggests that franchise films may have become a lucrative new revenue stream for Hollywood, as they have the potential to attract broad audiences across the globe.

CCI Systems of

input: New versions of two popular golf ball families hitting the market last week was not relatively big news. What did capture plenty of attention was that both are updated high-optic renditions -- each with their own spin. Mind you, non-white golf

input: This basic galette recipe can be tailored to fit whatever fruit you have on hand. The key is to scale the amount of sugar and cornstarch. Generally speaking, tart stone fruits (apricots, peaches, nectarines, pl
continuation:
ums) will yield more tart, sweet, fruitier galettes. I typically use fresh berries (mostly berries of the strawberry variety), but even if you dont, use whatever berries are in season. Add more stevia, too! It is much more subtle.

Ingredients (serves: 6)

1 pint fresh berries (1/2-3/4 of a quart)

1/4 cup fresh cornstarch

1/4 cup cane sugar (use brown or granulated)

1/4 tsp ground ginger (or just pinch of sea salt)

6 tablespoons fresh lemon juice (optional)

Preheat oven to 375 degrees. Slice the berries lengthwise into 1/2-inch thick cubes. Put berries in bowl with 1/4 cup of sugar and 1/4 cup of cornstarch. Mix it together gently. If too wet, let it sit in bowl longer, or if too stiff, whisk in 1/4 of the juice from the squeezed lemon. Combine with more/less juices from other berries if needed.

In separate bowl, whisk together together remaining 1/4 cup of sugar and 1/4 cup of cornst
paraphrase: This versatile galette recipe can be customized to suit your favorite fruit selection. Simply adjust the amount of sugar and cornstarch to accommodate the tartness and sweetness of your chosen fruit. For instance, if using tart stone fruits like apricots, peaches, nectarines, or plums, you may need to add more sugar to balance out the flavors. Conversely, if using sweet berries like strawberries, you can reduce the amount of sugar to avoid overpowering the fruit. Additionally, consider incorporating other seasonal berries to create a unique flavor profile. When mixing the berries with sugar and cornstarch, be sure to gently combine the ingredients to avoid mashing the fruit. If the mixture is too wet, let it sit for a few minutes before mixing again. If it's too dry, add a small amount of lemon juice to help bind the ingredients together. Once the berries are well combined, transfer them to a bowl and set aside until ready to bake. Preheat your oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit and slice the berries into 1/2-inch thick cubes. Place the sliced berries in a baking dish and bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the galette is tender and the fruit is caramelized. Enjoy!
