input: ST. LOUIS, MO (KTVI) - The City of St. Louis confirms three additional heat deaths, bringin the total of deaths in the city to 17. The St. Louis City Health Director is now asking the Centers for
continuation:
Disease Control and Prevention to test anyone in nursing homes where people were hospitalized with heat-related issues. This came days after St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson called on the CDC to investigate possible heat-related death in nursing homes. The mayor also called on nursing home staff members, like home nurses, to provide information to city health officials. St. Louis has seen eight heat-related deaths this year.
"In this moment, I want us to remember that heat is not just what happens in the heat of the sun, it is also what happens when you don't have air conditioning, when people don't have adequate or adequate heat, when there is chronic disease, when people are sick or elderly, when children or people with chronic medical conditions may not have air conditioning, where there are children with asthma, where people with obesity may not have air conditioning, where people with dementia may not have air conditioning. That is heat death, and we should treat it with urgency and I think we should expect that heat death should be covered in many parts of our emergency operations center. The fact is it is too hot, too often, and these are people with heat-related issues," St. Louis Public Health Director Jasmine Reed said
paraphrase:
St. Louis, MO (KTVI) - The city has confirmed additional heat-related deaths, bringing the total to 17. The St. Louis City Health Director is now requesting the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to test individuals in nursing homes where heat-related issues have occurred. This follows St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson's previous call for the CDC to investigate possible heat-related deaths in nursing homes. The mayor has also urged nursing home staff members, including home healthcare providers, to share information with city health officials. St. Louis has experienced eight heat-related deaths this year.
"In this moment, I want us to recognize that heat is not solely defined by the sun's rays, but also encompasses those without air conditioning, the elderly, young children, individuals with chronic illnesses, and those with pre-existing medical conditions," said Jasmine Reed, Public Health Director for St. Louis. "We must approach these heat-related deaths with urgency and anticipate that they will be a significant aspect of our emergency response efforts. The reality is, it's too hot too often, and these individuals face heat-related issues. We must treat these deaths with the gravity they deserve."

input: PANAMA CITY BEACH, Fla. (WJHG/WECP) - Rugby originated in England in the 19th century. For those in America who may still be unfamiliar with the sports, imagine the option offense without pads.
continuation:
It's called Rugby League, and is gaining popularity in our area.
"I love it, it really is great. It is just amazing, I love it. It is fast paced. It is very physical. It is hard to tackle, but it is also kind of fun."
Former Panama City High School rugby player, Will McAdoo, was excited when he first found out about the sport. He says, "I think it is awesome. I think it is really exciting. It is really intense, it is really intense. The first time I played, I wasn't really in shape, I was only like 185 pounds. I was kind of skinny, but it was awesome. It was awesome. It was fun. It is really fun."
In 2018, Panama City High School introduced Rugby League, which is an option rugby game with more rules. McAdoo says, "We use more running backs in it, we use more pass plays, and we use more of a scoring pass. We also use more power in our tackles, and more of the kicking game."
McAdoo says, "I think it is really good. It is a fun game. I think it is exciting. It is something
paraphrase:
Panama City Beach, Florida - Rugby, a centuries-old sport from England, is gaining traction in the area. Imagine a game without pads - fast-paced and physically demanding, yet exciting and fun. Will McAdoo, a former Panama City High School rugby player, is thrilled about the sport's growing popularity. "I think it's awesome, really exciting," he says. "It's intense, really intense. The first time I played, I wasn't in great shape, but it was still awesome."
In 2018, Panama City High School introduced Rugby League, an option rugby game with more rules and a greater emphasis on running backs, passing plays, and scoring. McAdoo explains, "We use more power in our tackles and more of the kicking game."
McAdoo is enthusiastic about the sport, describing it as "really good" and "fun." He believes it's an exciting game that's worth checking out.

performed in more than 100 stage plays, and in television he played President John F. Kennedy in HBO's "Falling Skies" before he was chosen as a "Favorite Actor" in 1983 by The Hollywood Reporter. He was also knighted in 1994. This week, Alda will receive an honorary degree of honor from Syracuse University. His appearance is one of more than 80 on this year's Tribute Tour. Here is a video from his acceptance speech at the 2007 Tonys.

Alan Alda was born in Queens, New York, in 1936, one of 11 children. His father, Michael Alda, was a doctor, while his mother, Martha McElhenney, was a schoolteacher. The family moved to Yonkers when Alda was 3, where his father worked in the United States government, while his mother was a teacher. Alda began studying acting in high school, and later enrolled in the Actors Studio. He is currently working in the new Broadway show "A Soldier's Play" which features Tony-winner Jeff Daniels, with Alan Alda (as General George McClellan) in the title role. input:
REDLANDS  Thanks to local Twilight fans, Redlands Community Hospital more than doubled the amount of blood collected at their monthly drive Tuesday.
The hospital hosted the first of two Twilight-themed blood
continuation:
drives in collaboration with Comic-Con.
A record 11,500 vials of donated red cells, which are used to treat patients, were collected in only one hour. The hospital also collected 1,500 vials of plasma, which is used in other types of procedures.
Its been quite a buzz, said Mike Thompson, head of Redlands BloodCenter. He estimated it cost them roughly $1,500 just to put the event together, but said it was more than worthwhile.
Its a big chunk of change for us, he said. And these people get a sense of satisfaction.
Redlands Twilight event came a week after Comic-Con put together its own Twilight blood drive, featuring the shows star, Robert Pattinson, in attendance. The event drew more than 1,400 people, with 200 people in attendance, and resulted in almost 1,500 vials of donated red cells, more than the hospitals previous record.
I think it was awesome. I think it was awesome, said Andrea Johnson, who came with her husband, Michael Johnson. Both women said it
paraphrase:
Redlands Reaps Rewards from Fan Blood Drive
The Redlands Community Hospital recently witnessed an overwhelming response from local Twilight enthusiasts, who turned up in large numbers to donate blood at a special drive held in collaboration with Comic-Con. The event, which took place on Tuesday, more than doubled the amount of blood collected compared to the hospital's previous record, with a total of 11,500 vials of donated red cells and 1,500 vials of plasma collected within just one hour.
According to Mike Thompson, head of Redlands BloodCenter, the event was a huge success, with the hospital collecting a record amount of blood. "It was more than worthwhile, despite the cost of organizing the event," he said, estimating that it cost around $1,500 to put the event together.
Andrea Johnson, one of the donors, described the experience as "awesome," while her husband, Michael Johnson, echoed her sentiment. "It was great to see so many people come out and support the cause," he said.
The Redlands Twilight event follows hot on the heels of a similar blood drive held by Comic-Con, which featured the show's star, Robert Pattinson, in attendance. The event drew a impressive 1,400 people and resulted in almost 1,500 vials of donated red cells, shattering the hospital's previous record.
In conclusion, the Redlands Community Hospital's Twilight-themed blood drive was a resounding success, with a significant increase in the amount of blood collected compared to previous drives. The event's success is a testament to the power of community involvement and the impact it can have on the lives of those in need.

continuation: 705 W. Water St. He said he loves working with people, especially people from other countries, and his latest venture, a seasonal spot, is a way to give back in a big way. Taft said he worked in Santa Monica with L.A. area chefs like Peter J. Riva, one of his favorite people, while he was living in Japan, where he worked in fine dining before he came back to the United States. "It was a really awesome experience. It was like going to culinary school, he said. "It was fun, it was exciting, it was challenging, it was stimulating, and I really loved it. I love working with other people from other countries. Its interesting. We meet people, share experiences, eat things from other countries, talk, and just try to get them inspired. He said hell have a variety of dishes, like a lobster cocktail with smoked bacon, crispy garlic fries, lobster, balsamic sauce and fresh garden salad. "Its sort of like if you had lobster in L.A. (and) served it in Boston, he said. "Its kind of like L
paraphrase: Marc Taft, chef and owner of Mariettas Chicken and the Egg, describes his new venture, Brine Seafood Shack, as a fusion of Cape Cod and Santa Monica cuisine. He explains that he loves working with people from diverse backgrounds and cultures, and his latest restaurant is a way for him to give back and share his passion for cooking. Taft shares that he worked with Peter J. Riva, a renowned chef in the L.A. area, while living in Japan, where he honed his skills in fine dining. He emphasizes the importance of cultural exchange and shared culinary experiences, saying, "It's interesting. We meet people, share experiences, eat things from other countries, talk, and just try to get them inspired." At Brine Seafood Shack, Taft plans to offer a variety of dishes, including a lobster cocktail with smoked bacon, crispy garlic fries, lobster, balsamic sauce, and a fresh garden salad. He likens the menu to a fusion of L.A. and Boston cuisine, saying, "It's sort of like if you had lobster in L.A. and served it in Boston."

input:
The extent of GOP efforts to prevent black people and Latinos from voting is jaw-dropping. And this Nov. 8, minority voters need to document it so America can see.
Donald Trumps offensive statements and the chaos theyve
continuation:
created in this country have fueled an onslaught of voter suppression efforts, even in states that didnt vote Democratic in 2016. Now, its more important than ever for us to record every time these same folks try to block us from exercising our basic constitutional right.
It may sound ridiculous, but its easy: Just download the app, Vote Compass. The free application, available for iPhones, is similar in function to the mobile phone applications used in some other countries. It allows people to track which campaigns are going after which constituencies in any state. It also shows them where local election boards stand in relation to voter protection. The more data available, the more accurate the application will be. If a voter is in a swing state, it may help push his or her ballot to the side. If a voter is in a solidly red state, it could help swing his or her vote in favor of Democratic policies.
In addition, people in swing states may feel more motivated to register voters, knowing that their vote could end up in the same place as Donald Trumps if its sent there. For this reason, its important to vote and show voters that your vote is significant.
paraphrase:
The GOP's efforts to restrict voting rights among minority communities are nothing short of alarming. On November 8th, it's crucial that these voters document these incidents to bring them to light and ensure America takes notice.
Trump's divisive rhetoric has fueled a wave of voter suppression tactics, even in states that didn't back the Democrats in 2016. Now, it's more imperative than ever for us to track every instance of these attempts to curtail our basic constitutional right.
To address this issue, a simple yet effective solution is available. By downloading the Vote Compass app, available for iPhones, voters can monitor which campaigns are targeting specific constituencies in any state. The app also provides insight into the stance of local election boards regarding voter protection. With more data, the app becomes more accurate, allowing voters to strategically place their ballots in swing states. Additionally, voters in these states may feel more motivated to register fellow voters, knowing their vote could potentially make a difference in the outcome.
In essence, it's important to exercise our right to vote and demonstrate its significance to inspire others to do the same.

input:
THERE were loud cheers, and a few tears as Hayley Talbot paddled her corflute kayak into Whiting Beach this morning.
With the song "Happy" playing, she raised her paddle in the air as she reached the
continuation:
shore of the wharf.
"I'm happy, I'm happy," she said, surrounded by her children, husband, mother-in-law, sister-in-law, step-father, brother-in-law, nieces, nephew, uncle and cousins.
Mrs Talbot came here as one of only five women to complete the Coast Run  one of the world's longest, longest distance kayak events  from Ballarat to Sydney. It is the fourth year of the event, which raises money and awareness of women in the maritime sector.
"It was lovely, thank you to everybody for coming," she said. "It was lovely. It was really lovely."
Her final paddle took her nearly 20km across the Murray River, with her partner, Peter, following behind. The couple were married this year in Ballarat.
Camera Icon Hayley Talbot with her daughters, Madeline (11) and Poppy (9) as she paddles her kayak from Ballarat to Sydney. Picture: Simon Schluter
Camera Icon Peter Talbot paddles with his wife. Picture: Simon Schluter
"I really enjoyed it, even if I wasn't going to go home in time
paraphrase:
As Hayley Talbot paddled her corflute kayak into Whiting Beach this morning, the sound of cheers and tears filled the air. With the upbeat tune of "Happy" playing, she raised her paddle aloft as she touched shore, surrounded by her loved ones - children, husband, mother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, brother-in-law, nieces, nephew, uncle, and cousins.
Hayley had joined the Coast Run, one of the world's longest distance kayak events, as one of only five women. This year marked the fourth anniversary of the event, which raises money and awareness for women in the maritime sector.
As she completed her final paddle across the Murray River, nearly 20km from her starting point, Hayley expressed her gratitude to her loved ones for their support. Her husband, Peter, followed behind her, and the couple recently tied the knot in Ballarat.
Despite the challenges of the journey, Hayley declared her enjoyment of the experience, even if she hadn't made it home in time.

input:
House Democrats on Friday unveiled a comprehensive elections and ethics reform package that targets what they call a "culture of corruption in Washington" and aims to reduce the role of money in politics.
Maryland Rep. Elijah Cummings, the new chairman of the House
continuation:
Oversight Committee, released the draft package, which he said was intended to "stop big money from dominating politics."
The document is called the Democracy Act, which stands for "Democracy, Accountability, Transparency, Integrity, and Governance."
The bill includes dozens of provisions, like requiring more voter information from states and setting limits on corporate lobbying spending, expanding early voting, requiring independent redistricting commissions and giving voters more control in local and state elections. The Democrats say that if they pass the bill, it could eventually move to the Senate.
Cummings, 78, has served in Congress since 1987, when he was elected by voters to Congress from Maryland. He was elected chairman of House Oversight in January. He said he will use his "incredibly important" new position to get "all of this done."
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi hailed Cummings' draft as "a bill of tremendous import."
"His draft, which he has just released, is one of the greatest threats to democracy in this Congress, with hundreds of thousands of new provisions from just one bill. This will change the game, with billions of dollars of new spending, more lobbying, more spending on consultants, more dark money, more corporate PAC money. It will
paraphrase:
House Democrats unveiled a comprehensive elections and ethics reform package on Friday, targeting what they perceive as a "culture of corruption in Washington" and aiming to reduce the role of money in politics. The draft bill, dubbed the "Democracy Act," includes dozens of provisions, such as requiring more voter information from states, setting limits on corporate lobbying spending, expanding early voting, and giving voters more control in local and state elections.
Maryland Representative Elijah Cummings, the newly appointed chairman of the House Oversight Committee, released the draft bill, stating that it was designed to "stop big money from dominating politics." Cummings, who has served in Congress since 1987, emphasized the significance of his new position and vowed to utilize it to push the bill through.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi lauded Cummings' draft as "a bill of immense importance," highlighting its potential to revolutionize the political landscape. However, some critics have expressed concerns about the bill's potential impact on democracy, citing concerns about increased spending, lobbying, and dark money.
Despite these reservations, the bill has garnered significant attention and support, with many viewing it as a crucial step towards reforming the country's electoral system and reducing the influence of special interests. As the bill moves through Congress, it is likely to face intense scrutiny and debate, with proponents and opponents alike eager to shape its final form.

input:
It took just 80 years for the Roman Empire to fall apart as a political unit.
When Theodosius the Great died in 395, he bequeathed to his two feckless sonsHonorius, a 10-year-
continuation: old, and Caligula, 14a kingdom in the west of Europe, which would eventually stretch from Belgium to southern Russia. Caligula was born in Rome in 14/15, which gives us plenty of time to ponder just how bad things could get under his father. The second Roman emperor was, in his own words, "very much inclined to corruption" (quoted in the Wikipedia article Caligula, the Younger, pg. 30). Caligula, like his father, could afford only one son, yet he was too young to rule, so his mother put him in education, where he became a successful lawyer. Caligula took office in 14/15, but things didn't get off to a good start. His wife, Julia, didn't like his "cavalier" manners, and she ended up having him killed. Caligula himself was executed in late 15, and his second son took over. As it happened, his first son, Tiberius, was also born in Rome, in late 14/15. Tiberius was already 23 when he became emperor, yet he was also just too young. He didn't inherit his father's wealth, nor did he live as a
paraphrase: Eighty years after Theodosius the Great's death in 395, the Roman Empire began to crumble as a political entity. The legacy he left behind was a divided kingdom in western Europe, consisting of Belgium to southern Russia, which was inherited by his two feckless sons, Honorius and Caligula. Caligula, born in Rome in 14/15, was known for his corrupt nature, as stated in the Wikipedia article Caligula, the Younger (pg. 30). Despite being too young to rule, Caligula became a successful lawyer through his mother's efforts. However, his life was cut short when his wife, Julia, did not approve of his "cavalier" manners and had him killed. Caligula's death marked the beginning of a turbulent period in the empire's history, as his second son, also born in Rome in late 14/15, took over but struggled to maintain stability due to his youth. Meanwhile, Caligula's older brother, Tiberius, who was already 23 when he became emperor, faced similar challenges despite inheriting his father's wealth.

input: The Chippewa County Department of Human Services (CCDHS) in Wisconsin works like most other government human services groups, providing child protection services, foster and respite care, elder abuse care, and more. However, they recently launched an
continuation: initiative in partnership with the Wisconsin Population Connection (WPC) to help them tackle one of their greatest challenges: keeping people in their communities. It is estimated that in Wisconsin, nearly 150,000 people are homeless. A key reason for this is due to the inability of many people in Wisconsins urban counties and other cities to find low cost or stable housing. The WPCs goal is to help homeless people get into stable housing. The WPCs Housing Choice Initiative (HCI) is a unique program designed to assist in homeless populations. It is structured around a fixed-rate mortgage with low rates. It requires no application fees, credit check, or any other credit requirements. The WPCs first step is to identify people with low-cost or low-cost options in their area, or in other cases, any city or town. If someone is unable to find affordable options in their area, or if someone is eligible, they are connected with the WPCs Rapid Housing Solutions program. This program is structured around fast-track options with low-interest rates, which gives the homeowner one year to find financing. If the homeowner fails to find financing within one year, the homeowner may
paraphrase: The Chippewa County Social Services Department (CCDHS) in Wisconsin is similar to other government agencies in providing essential services such as child protection, foster care, elder abuse support, and more. However, they have recently launched a collaborative initiative with the Wisconsin Population Connection (WPC) to tackle a pressing challenge: housing stability. According to estimates, nearly 150,000 people in Wisconsin are homeless, with many struggling to find affordable or stable housing in urban areas and other cities. To address this issue, the WPC's Housing Choice Initiative (HCI) offers a unique mortgage solution with low rates and minimal requirements, such as no application fees, credit checks, or credit score limitations. The WPC's initial step is to identify and connect eligible individuals with low-cost or low-cost housing options in their area or other nearby cities. If someone cannot find affordable housing in their area, they may be referred to the WPC's Rapid Housing Solutions program, which provides fast-track financing with low interest rates. This program offers homeowners a one-year grace period to secure financing. If they fail to find financing within this timeframe, the homeowner may be eligible for further support.

input:
The US president, George Bush, today called on Israel to end its 41-year occupation of Palestinian land and predicted a peace treaty would be signed by the time he leaves office.
Speaking after a meeting with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, Bush
continuation:
urged Israel to release Palestinian prisoners, build more houses in the occupied territories and resume peace talks. "I think that peace will be signed in this White House, I think that peace will be signed before I'm done," he said. "I want to encourage the Israelis to stop being aggressive."
George W. Bush, right, meets with Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas.
Bush also called on Israel to let more Palestinian construction into East Jerusalem, where he called it "an area of human drama". It is where more than 1,600 Palestinian citizens of Israel live. "It is the least that any Palestinian in this area should expect, if he is going to live in peace, in freedom." The US president also spoke of his concerns about the US-Israeli relationship, saying: "I think it is incumbent upon me to help facilitate that relationship. I think it is important that it continue to function." He warned Israel it faces "decisive moments" in its history.
His message of peace was sharply criticised by Palestinian analysts and Palestinian activists. "These statements are in contradiction with the current status of the Palestinian territories, the Palestinian people, and US policies in this respect," said Mohammed Marzooq, a member of Palestinian Liberation Organisation
paraphrase:
In a meeting with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, US President George Bush urged Israel to end its 41-year occupation of Palestinian land and predicted a peace treaty would be signed before he leaves office. Bush pressed Israel to release Palestinian prisoners, construct more houses in the occupied territories, and resume peace talks. "I believe that peace will be signed in this White House, and I believe it will be signed before I'm finished," he said, calling on Israel to stop being aggressive.
Bush also addressed the issue of construction in East Jerusalem, where over 1,600 Palestinian citizens of Israel reside. He emphasized the importance of allowing more Palestinian construction in the area, stating that it is "the least that any Palestinian in this area should expect if he is going to live in peace and freedom."
The US president also expressed his concerns about the relationship between the US and Israel, stating that it is important for him to help facilitate the relationship and ensure it continues to function. He warned Israel that it faces "decisive moments" in its history.
Palestinian analysts and activists sharply criticized Bush's message of peace, arguing that it contradicts the current situation in the Palestinian territories and US policies on the matter. Mohammed Marzooq, a member of the Palestinian Liberation Organization, stated that these statements are in contrast to the current status of the Palestinian territories, people, and US policies in this regard.

A judge ruled on Monday that the state of Massachusetts cannot sue the federal government for expanding a religious exemption to the Affordable Care Act's contraceptive mandate.
"While we are disappointed in this decision, we remain steadfast in our commitment to ensuring affordable and reliable
continuation:
health coverage for women of all backgrounds," spokeswoman Heather Walsh said in an email. "As states have been repeatedly advised, states are not required to participate in any court proceedings."
As first reported by The Washington Post, U.S. District Court Judge Allison D. Burroughs found that Congress never intended to extend "a federal entitlement" in this way.
"Congress made it crystal clear, in its own words, when it made this mandate a federal entitlement, it intended it only for state-issued insurance," Burroughs said, according to the Post. "There was nothing in the statute making it a federal entitlement or entitlement entitlement."
At issue is whether the provision in the Affordable Care Act that requires insurance companies to cover contraception constitutes an "entitlement." It is, in other words, whether it requires coverage of contraception, like it or not. As The Washington Post noted, Congress included this provision, specifically, with the intent of keeping states from implementing contraception coverage.
Burroughs is expected to release her opinion later this week. It is expected to stay in effect, pending further litigation, The Washington Post noted.
Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey (D) argued in court that expanding the contraceptive
paraphrase:
A federal judge has ruled that Massachusetts cannot sue the federal government over the expansion of a religious exemption to the Affordable Care Act's contraceptive mandate. In response, the state's attorney general, Maura Healey, has expressed disappointment but vowed to continue fighting for affordable and reliable health coverage for all women.
In her ruling, Judge Allison D. Burroughs found that Congress never intended to extend a federal entitlement to cover contraception through this provision. According to Burroughs, the statute explicitly states that the mandate only applies to state-issued insurance, and there is no language suggesting it should be a federal entitlement.
The issue at hand is whether the provision in the Affordable Care Act that requires insurance companies to cover contraception constitutes an entitlement. In other words, is it a requirement for insurance companies to cover contraception, regardless of their objections? Burroughs' ruling is expected to be released later this week, and it is expected to remain in effect pending further litigation.

ACCOMACK COUNTY, Va. -- Two classic American novels have been temporarily banned from a Virginia school district after a parent raised concerns about the use of a racial slur.
The use of the books The Adventures of Huckle
continuation:
berry Finn in Washington County School Districts elementary school curriculum was challenged, and school board members ultimately found that while it violated their school districts district values, it was not racist or demeaning toward any race.
Im glad the board of education recognized, in my opinion, this is not really racist language, said William R. Smith, Jr., a parent who raised concerns about the book. Smith said he was disappointed the board did not go further in its decision.
Smiths concerns began when he saw a photograph of children in Washington County Schools elementary school reading The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn in April. The school districts English curriculum, called Culture and Culture, was chosen to be used in Washington Countys elementary school curriculum. The book was one of six selections.
I saw the book, Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, and I was disappointed, Smith said. I am sorry this happened, Im sorry this is being used in our school.
Smith said he saw children in the photo with their faces
paraphrase:
ACCOMACK COUNTY, Va. - Two classic American novels have been temporarily removed from a Virginia school district's curriculum after a parent raised concerns about the use of a racial slur.
The novels, 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' and 'To Kill a Mockingbird', were taken out of the school district's elementary school curriculum due to objections from a parent who believed the use of the racial slur in the books was offensive.
The school board reviewed the issue and decided that while the language in the books may be considered offensive, it does not promote racism or discrimination towards any particular race.
William R. Smith, Jr., the parent who raised the concern, expressed disappointment that the board did not take a more decisive stance on the issue. Smith's concerns were sparked when he saw a photo of children in the school district's elementary school reading the books.
The school district's English curriculum, 'Culture and Culture', was adopted for use in the elementary school curriculum. The books were selected from a list of six options.
Smith expressed his disappointment in the books being used in the school, saying, "I saw the book, 'Adventures of Huckleberry Finn', and I was disappointed. I'm sorry this happened, and I'm sorry this is being used in our school."
Smith's concerns highlight the ongoing debate about the use of racial slurs in literature and their place in the classroom curriculum. While some argue that these works are important historical artifacts that should be preserved and studied, others argue that they are offensive and should be removed from the curriculum.

input:
NEW Real Madrid president Florentino Perez is on the verge of launching an audacious transfer swoop for Cristiano Ronaldo.
The 24-year-old Manchester United star was linked to the Spanish giants when Perez was last president back in 2006.
continuation:
The Portuguese star left Real Madrid to join United in 2003, with Perez reportedly keen to sign him back.
And Spanish outlet Marca claim Perez, 77, is now ready to move with the star in order to get his hands on him.
As of yet, it is said Real are only willing to offer 75m. But it is said Perez is willing to put up that offer if he can get Cristiano in a deal this summer.
In April of this year, Cristiano told his agents he was determined to stay at United.
And he confirmed he was set to sign new terms despite links with Real.
Cristiano, who made his United debut in 2003, also played with Perez in Real Madrid.
paraphrase:
Florentino Perez, the newly appointed president of Real Madrid, is on the cusp of making a bold transfer move by pursuing Cristiano Ronaldo. The 24-year-old Manchester United star was previously linked to Real Madrid when Perez was in office in 2006.
According to Spanish media outlet Marca, Perez, who is 77 years old, is eager to bring Ronaldo back to the club he previously represented. However, Real Madrid is only willing to offer 75 million euros for the star player, which may not be enough to convince him to leave Manchester United.
Despite Cristiano's desire to stay at United, the Portuguese superstar has expressed a willingness to join Real Madrid in the past. In fact, he played for Real Madrid during his earlier years in the sport, including a stint under Perez's leadership.
As of April this year, Cristiano told his agents that he was determined to remain at United, and he confirmed his intentions to sign new terms with the club despite rumors of a potential transfer to Real Madrid.
With Perez's renewed interest in signing Ronaldo, it remains to be seen whether he can successfully negotiate a deal with Manchester United to bring the star player back to Real Madrid.

Which Sheffield roads will be closed and which bus services will be affected at Tramlines this weekend?
Tramlines will lead to road closures and some bus service disruption this weekend.
The annual Tramlines music festival is almost upon us -
continuation:
and while Sheffield is used to getting a big party into town in the early hours of the morning, it's one of the few times when thousands of people from further afield make the trip for a daytime gig.
With more than 1,700 people expected to enjoy the free-form set-up from 1pm, the extra traffic congestion, extra noise, disruption, litter, and noise, and the consequent nuisance to neighbours, is one of the things Tramlines is trying to avoid this year.
It seems, therefore, that Tramlines will be leading into the town centre in stages, rather than all at once, with roads in and around the town centre closing before 1pm, with trams running only from 6pm onwards.
It seems, therefore, that Tramlines will be leading into the town centre in stages, rather than all at once, with roads in and around the town centre closing before 1pm, with trams running only from 6pm onwards.

paraphrase:
Here are the road closures and affected bus services during Tramlines this weekend:
Tramlines will lead to road closures and some bus service disruption this weekend. The festival will be held in stages, with roads in and around the town centre closing before 1pm, and trams running only from 6pm onwards.
Approximately 1,700 people are expected to attend the festival, leading to additional traffic congestion, noise, and litter. To minimize the impact on neighbors, the festival will be staggered into the town centre in stages.
Road closures around the city include:
* A63
* A638
* A636
* A636A
* A638
* A638
* A638A

Please note that these road closures and bus service disruptions are subject to change and may be updated as more information becomes available.

input:
A woman wears Google Glass at an unrelated book presentation and media event on June 10, 2014 in Berlin, Germany.
If there's anything the Ellen Pao trial showed, it's that sexism is still alive in Silicon Valley. But some tech companies
continuation:
may have more progressive policies.
As sexism rears its ugly head more openly in tech, women are looking for more protection from it. Now, Google Glass, Facebook, Apple, LinkedIn, Reddit and Pinterest are all allowing women to wear eyewear while working.
In late August, Google Glass was made more available to women. The eyewear became more available on Facebook (in late August, women could apply for it) and Apple in September. The same month, Facebook, LinkedIn, Reddit, Pinterest and Tumblr also began allowing women to wear Glass. On Tuesday, Reddit also became the first social media company to announce that women would now be allowed to wear Glass in its offices, according to Recode.
"What we've found with Glass is just from the early user tests, it just makes things easier for women, in general, especially young women. It just gives them more flexibility, more power, more choice, more agency, more control, more opportunities to shine and show what they are working on in any given moment," said Lianna Guggenheim, Facebook's head of Glass, in September, according to Recode. "A male engineer in Glass doesn't have that, either. He's just
paraphrase:
A woman dons Google Glass at a book presentation and media event in Berlin, Germany on June 10, 2014, underscoring the ongoing fight against sexism in Silicon Valley. The Ellen Pao trial, in particular, highlighted the persistence of gender-based discrimination in the tech industry. In response, some tech companies have adopted more progressive policies, including Google Glass, Facebook, Apple, LinkedIn, Reddit, and Pinterest, which now allow women to wear eyewear while working.
In late August, Google Glass became more accessible to women, and Facebook, Apple, and LinkedIn followed suit in September. Reddit, Tumblr, and other social media platforms have also made moves to support gender equality in the workplace, with Reddit announcing that women will now be allowed to wear Glass in its offices.
According to Lianna Guggenheim, head of Glass at Facebook, the technology provides women with greater flexibility, power, choice, agency, and opportunities to showcase their work. While male engineers may also benefit from Glass, the impact is particularly significant for women, who often face gender-based barriers in the tech industry. By embracing gender-inclusive policies and practices, these companies aim to create a more equitable and innovative work environment.

input:
A British Columbia engineering science professor has developed a high-resolution scanner that he says will revolutionize how eye diseases are diagnosed to prevent vision loss.
Prof. Marinko Sarunic of Simon Fraser University said doctors currently use low-resolution scanners that
continuation:
are difficult to use, are often too expensive or expensive for everyday use. But he said his technology, which uses light to measure cornea shapes and other objects, can be used in doctors offices.
These scanners are often too expensive, too cumbersome, or inconvenient, or difficult to use. Theyre also used in hospital settings where people dont want to go or need something more portable, he said in an interview.
My scanners are small, light, and easy-to-use. They are also really fast, accurate, and convenient.
Sarunic said his device is currently available in about 20 medical offices. The technology will cost around $1,500, he said, or more if he needs to upgrade it.
While he said its too early to say exactly when he hopes to begin using it, he said it will help him help doctors in various settings.
I think it will help them in various clinical settings. Well see what happens with this in the next couple of years, he said.
Sarunic, a professor in the department of mechanical, industrial, civil and environmental
paraphrase:
A groundbreaking scanner developed by a Simon Fraser University professor is poised to revolutionize the diagnosis and prevention of eye diseases. Prof. Marinko Sarunic's high-resolution scanner uses light to measure cornea shapes and other objects with unprecedented accuracy, making it an ideal tool for doctors' offices.
Currently, low-resolution scanners are the norm in eye care, but they are often cumbersome, expensive, or difficult to use. This has led to a need for more portable and convenient options. Sarunic's innovation addresses these issues, making it easier for doctors to diagnose and treat eye diseases in a variety of settings.
The scanner is small, light, and easy to use, making it a more practical choice for everyday use. Its high accuracy and speed also make it an attractive option for doctors. According to Sarunic, the technology is currently available in about 20 medical offices and will cost around $1,500, with the possibility of upgrading it for additional features.
While it's too early to predict exactly when the technology will be widely used, Sarunic is optimistic about its potential impact on the field. He believes the scanner will help doctors in various clinical settings and looks forward to seeing its development in the next couple of years.
As a professor in the department of mechanical, industrial, civil and environmental engineering, Sarunic brings a unique perspective to the field of eye care. His expertise in engineering and technology has enabled him to create a device that could greatly improve the diagnosis and treatment of eye diseases.

input:
Beaumont decided to officially do something about this important but admittedly first-world problem.
Deservedly or not, millennials get blamed for a lot of things, not least of all the slow demise of the flagship beer. Called everything from f
continuation:
idgety millennial hipster brews to "crappy" in-your-face, these brews are mostly pales of mediocrity. A few even seem to be named after things you don't like, like St. Louis' IPA, or Philadelphia's "Creamy."
And yet, despite their flaws, these pales of mediocrity are, in many ways, still the only craft beer style available at nearly every bar. But one city has found a way to use craft beer in its own unique way. For this city, it seems, it's always something new, something newish, something just plain stupid.
paraphrase: Beaumont determined to address a pressing yet seemingly trivial issue, decided to tackle the maligned millennial beer trend. Critics allege that the youthful generation has contributed to the demise of traditional beers, branding them as subpar and inconsequential. However, despite their shortcomings, these mass-produced beers remain ubiquitous in most establishments. Yet, one city has discovered an innovative approach to brewing, consistently introducing novel, and sometimes whimsical, craft beer styles. This city appears to embrace creativity and experimentation in its beverage scene, embracing the "stupid" and "newish" with enthusiasm.

input: Roxie Zwicker and her friends jokingly call themselves good witches from the North. The joke isnt about the fact that they are, indeed, witches with good intentions. They are. The joke is about
continuation: what happens when witches try to control, manipulate, or otherwise meddle with weather patterns. This is what happened in the case of The Weatherman, one of the first movies in which witches were played by women, from 1934 to 1949. The movie, based on the novel, The Witch of East End, is one of the earliest films to showcase witches in a light-hearted way. Its also a film with a message, one that feminists around the world are still dealing with, more than 80 years later. The movies male protagonist, a weatherman named Ben Murphy, faces constant harassment from his female coworkers due to his weather predictions. After Murphy learns of his own sexuality, he is ostracized and his coworkers  including a witch named Roxie Zwicker  dont want him around. But Murphys boss, Bill McDaniel (George Stevens), is concerned with his performance, while his coworkers, mainly his sister, are concerned with his sexuality. So he forces Murphy into working alongside them. If youre unfamiliar with this movie, which many people think of as too dark or inappropriate, just watch it. Its really just a silly fun movie. It
paraphrase: Roxie Zwicker and her companions affectionately refer to themselves as North's benevolent witches. This playful label disguises their actual naturethey are genuine witches with good intentions. The joke lies in the futility of witches' attempts to manipulate the weather. This narrative becomes even more intriguing when applied to the 1934-1949 film "The Weatherman," which pioneered depicting women as witches in a lighthearted manner. This movie, adapted from the novel "The Witch of East End," tackles a theme that is still relevant today, eight decades laterfeminism. The male protagonist, Ben Murphy, faces persistent teasing from his female colleagues due to his weather forecasts. However, after Murphy discovers his sexual orientation, he is ostracized, and his coworkers, including Roxie Zwicker, shun him. Despite their reservations, Murphy's superior, Bill McDaniel (George Stevens), is concerned about his work performance, while his sister is more interested in his sexual orientation. McDaniel ultimately forces Murphy to work alongside them. For those unfamiliar with this movie, which some find too dark or inappropriate, I suggest watching it. It's an entertaining and lighthearted film that is sure to provide a delightful viewing experience.

input: SPRINGFIELD -- The Department of Children and Family Services began issuing layoff notices to 600 employees on Friday with the aim of paring its workforce by 375 positions while still meeting its legal obligations to care for abused and neglected children and provide other services
continuation:
.

"I am really, really sorry this happened, and I'm really sorry it happened in April, before people really knew what was going on," said DCFS Executive Secretary Terri K. Collins. "I think it was really devastating."

"It is a bad day in this office when layoffs are announced, especially in April, because it is hard to hear about layoffs," Collins said. "I believe this is a difficult time in terms of the decisions, especially in terms of this particular area. I think it will help us move in a more efficient way, making us more effective."

The layoffs, which took effect immediately, will save the department nearly $1.3 million in annual costs. The department will save money in other areas, Collins said, including eliminating consultants, paying off outstanding contracts and paying more than $500,000 more in administrative costs.

"We are looking at options for where the money is needed. We are looking at other cuts, other efficiencies, and other ways to save money," Collins said. "I don't think it will hurt us."

In recent years, the department's spending rose, while its revenue stayed flat. To make ends meet, state
paraphrase:
The Department of Children and Family Services recently began notifying 600 employees of impending layoffs as part of a broader effort to downsize its workforce by 375 positions. According to DCFS Executive Secretary Terri K. Collins, the decision was made to streamline the department's operations and become more financially efficient, despite the potential impact on employees.
Collins acknowledged the difficult nature of the decision, particularly given the timing of the layoffs in April. However, she remains optimistic that the cost savings achieved through the layoffs will help the department become more effective in its mission to protect abused and neglected children and provide other essential services.
The layoffs took effect immediately, resulting in an annual cost savings of nearly $1.3 million. To make up for the reduced staff, the department plans to explore other areas of efficiency, such as cutting consultant contracts, paying off outstanding debts, and redirecting funds to more critical areas.
While acknowledging the challenges ahead, Collins remains confident that the department can adapt and continue to provide vital services to the community.

input: Analysis - The prime minister was a media darling in New York, while at home the opposition ramped up attacks over the Meka Whaitiri affair and chased ministers along the trail of the Derek Handley emails. Peter Wilson looks at a busy week
continuation:
in politics in New Zealand.

Wednesday, January 28, 2009

An extraordinary week in politics in New Zealand.

In Washington, Peter Wilson reports from the US capital.

In Auckland, Andrew Devine gives us a report from Parliament.

In Christchurch, Bill English gives us his latest update from his time in New York.

In Dunedin, Steve Rennie gives us a report from his trip to Washington.

In Wellington, Wayne Maki gives us a report from his trip to Washington.

Auckland, January 28: The United States Ambassador to New Zealand, Michael R. Fitzgerald, said this week that his Government was "fully committed" to its commitment under the treaty with New Zealand of an enduring friendship.

"I am pleased to report that I am confident of the prospects of the treaty in Congress and I think of it more often than I used to when I was in Auckland, when I did press briefings. It is still important. It is still one of our major diplomatic achievements. It is a tangible legacy of our friendship," he said in a radio interview with Radio NZ.

"I don't think anyone here should expect it to go away.
paraphrase:
This week in New Zealand politics was extraordinary, with the Prime Minister earning praise in New York while the opposition intensified attacks on the Meka Whaitiri affair and pursued ministers regarding the Derek Handley emails. Peter Wilson provides an in-depth report from the US capital, while Andrew Devine, Bill English, Steve Rennie, and Wayne Maki bring us updates from Parliament, Washington, and their respective travels.
In Washington, United States Ambassador to New Zealand Michael R. Fitzgerald expressed his government's commitment to the treaty of enduring friendship between the two nations, stating that he is confident of its prospects in Congress and sees it as a lasting legacy of their partnership.
In related news, the Prime Minister's visit to New York received positive coverage, with the Ambassador noting that the Prime Minister is often in his thoughts, particularly when he is in Auckland for press briefings. Despite this, the opposition has maintained its focus on the Meka Whaitiri affair and the Derek Handley emails, demonstrating the ongoing scrutiny faced by the government.

input: Father of the Nation' is an honorific bestowed on individuals who are considered the most important in the process of the establishment of a country or a nation. They are instrumental in the birth of their nations by way of liberating them from colonial or other occupation
continuation:
. The father of the nation is also regarded as one of the founders of his own nation. In many cases, he is identified as 'Mahatma Gandhi', while in others, his name is simply 'Father of India'. The Father of the Nation is also referred to as Father of the Republic in many cases. He was also considered a hero by many.

Most of them are identified in history as either the Prime Minister or the president of their respective nations, while some are described as 'Father of His Country' or 'Father of His Country'. The definition of a Father of his Country is determined by the nationalities which are regarded as his people. The father of his country is also associated with various types of duties. He is expected to take an active part in various national activities like organizing various ceremonies, laying the foundation of temples, performing rituals, etc. He also is expected to promote national harmony, freedom from foreign interference, etc. He is considered as an ambassador of his people. He also is expected to encourage them in any possible way. He also is expected to advise them of possible policies. He is expected to advise them of the kind of people, places, etc. which he considers worthy of visiting. He is
paraphrase:
The term "Father of the Nation" is a revered honorific bestowed upon individuals who played a pivotal role in the formation and establishment of a country or nation. These individuals are responsible for liberating their nations from colonial or foreign occupation, and are often regarded as founders or key figures in their country's history.
Some notable examples of individuals who have been referred to as "Father of the Nation" include Mahatma Gandhi, who is widely recognized as the Father of India, and other figures such as Abraham Lincoln, who is regarded as the Father of His Country.
The role of a Father of the Nation encompasses various responsibilities, including participating in national ceremonies and rituals, promoting national harmony and unity, and advising their people on matters such as policy and governance. They are also expected to act as ambassadors for their nation, promoting its values and interests abroad.
In summary, the term "Father of the Nation" is a respected and significant honorific that recognizes the immense contributions of individuals who played a crucial role in shaping their country's history and identity.

input:
The Green Bay Packers and Minnesota Vikings tied at 29-29 after a whirlwind final drive and overtime.
The Packers appeared to make the game-sealing interception in the fourth quarter, but the play was overturned by a penalty on Clay Matthews for driving
continuation:
the ball while facing a third-and-20.
A replay later showed Matthews made contact with Adrian Peterson, but head-butting him was legal, and he wasnt called for unnecessary roughness.
Green Bay failed in its first attempt on fourth-and-goal at the 1-yard line, when Brett Hundley was tackled from behind in the end zone by Marcus Sherels. After two more runs failed, the Packers had third-and-29 from the Vikings 1.
Peterson gained 3 yards, which set up Matt Bryants 42-yard field goal in overtime. After a Packers timeout, Mason Crosby kicked a 51-yarder in the first overtime, tying it 29-29.
Both defenses made big plays in the first half. The Vikings took a 3-0 lead when Brett Maher kicked a 45-yard field goal with 1:57 remaining in the first quarter. The Packers took over from their own 24 with 1:49 remaining in the first. On third-and-18, Aaron Rodgers threw an incomplete pass to Randall Cobb. That was the Packers only sack of Bradford. He was hit six times.
Hundley made his first career
paraphrase: The Packers and Vikings engaged in a thrilling back-and-forth contest, with both teams showcasing their resilience and determination. After a furious final drive and overtime, the score was tied at 29-29, with the Packers appearing to have sealed the game with an interception, only to have it overturned by a penalty. The Vikings made the most of their opportunities, with Adrian Peterson gaining crucial yards and Mason Crosby kicking a game-tying field goal in overtime. The defenses played a key role in the first half, with the Vikings taking an early 3-0 lead and the Packers only recording one sack of Bradford despite facing six hits. In the end, it was a dramatic 51-yard field goal by Crosby that sent the game into overtime, setting the stage for an exciting conclusion.

input: A classic British memoir gets the full costume drama treatment with this beautifully crafted World War I drama, although it never quite transcends the "beloved book" tone, remaining so worthy that it only rarely springs to life. The acting is sharp, as
continuation:
it should be, but it seems like this was really set in 1918, with some of the acting more naturalistic. The only oddity is when we meet one of the soldiers (Tom Hardy), dressed in a blue-grey uniform with green facings, and he is obviously a member of one of the French regiments. The story is told in flashbacks, mainly of the younger soldiers, with scenes of action. The action is done in chronological order, although it is never clear which soldiers are in which scenes. It was directed by Paul King, with help from Terry Gilliam. It was released on 8/7/1916, just two days before Armistice Day. The audio is French. A release date of 8/26/16. (D/T)

Monday, August 11, 2008

In this modern update, the war in Europe is going on, just like it always has, with armies of various countries going back and forth, and the United States still backing its allies. But it also has its own special conflicts, which sometimes intersect with the other conflicts. This was done in the 1930's, and it was directed by Samuel Fuller, with help from Kenneth Grahame. This was released
paraphrase: In this period drama, a classic British memoir is given a fresh interpretation, transporting viewers to the battlefields of World War I. Although the tone remains steadfastly loyal to the source material, the acting is sharp and naturalistic, bringing the characters to life in a way that feels organic and authentic. The film's unique approach to storytelling, told through flashbacks of the younger soldiers, adds depth and complexity to the narrative. Despite some occasional oddities in costume design, the film is well-crafted and engaging, with a release date of August 7, 1916, just two days before Armistice Day. The audio is in French, adding an extra layer of authenticity to the experience. (D/T)

The fumes contain cyanide, according to Crews.
The building houses approximately 11 condominiums on the fourth and fifth floors, while the second and third floors are reserved for offices.
