input: ISLAMABAD, Oct 27 (APP): Minister for Finance Senator Muhammad Ishaq Dar Thursday said that due to prudent economic policies of the government, macro economic stability has been achieved and now focus was on the sustainable economic growth for job creation
continuation:
, investment and exports.
"The government is determined to promote business environment in order to enhance investment opportunities, which will go a long way in creating employment opportunities and boosting trade, " he said in his first national economic conference here.
Addressing the conference, he said this conference was important as it is the first of its kind in the history of Pakistan. He said in previous times when industrial growth was zero, business environment was also negative, but now it is improving with new governments policies.
"Economic reforms are our key priorities under which we are revamping policies and making them efficient." The minister said these were reforms initiated under prudent policies of PTI led government. He said investment opportunities were also increasing. He said in the recent past, new investment of Rs1.75 trillion was made in industrial sector, which was more than investment in six years.
"We are trying to create environment where investment is easy, profitable, productive, sustainable, growth, social, transparent, business friendly." He said the government is creating an investment friendly environment, where maximum investment opportunities are available. He said, "We are improving business environment, which will go a long way in creating employment opportunities."
While expressing confidence in reforms
paraphrase:
Islamabad, Oct 27 (APP): The Finance Minister, Senator Muhammad Ishaq Dar emphasized the importance of achieving macroeconomic stability before focusing on sustainable economic growth. He highlighted the government's commitment to promoting a business-friendly environment to enhance investment opportunities, create employment, and boost trade.
In his keynote address at the first national economic conference, Dar noted that the government's prudent economic policies have led to improved economic stability. However, he emphasized the need for ongoing reforms to create a sustainable economic growth environment.
Dar highlighted the PTI-led government's initiatives to revamp policies and make them more efficient, noting that investment opportunities have increased significantly in recent times. He mentioned that Rs1.75 trillion in new investment has been made in the industrial sector, which is more than the investment made in the previous six years.
The minister emphasized the need for a business-friendly environment, citing the government's efforts to improve the investment climate. He expressed confidence in the reforms, stating that they will create employment opportunities and drive economic growth.

input:
ANKARA (Reuters) - For all of Irans fierce verbal response to fresh U.S. threats of tougher sanctions, some senior officials in Tehran believe the door to diplomacy should stay open.
On Monday, U.S. Secretary
continuation:
of State Mike Pompeo said Washingtons strategy toward Tehran remained unchanged: sanctions if needed, military pressure if needed. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani made his own challenge in a phone call on Sunday with Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin.
I dont think anyone, or even many people, thinks that if sanctions are imposed, Iran will immediately end negotiations with other countries, Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif said on Tuesday.
We want to talk to other countries, he said, according to the semi-official Tasnim news agency. But he also said it was in Tehrans interest to resolve its disputes with Washington first.
Irans foreign policy has always been based on mutual benefits, said Iranian Vice President Eshaq Jahangiri.
America should know if it seeks concessions, it will get only one thing: sanctions, he said.
FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Iranian parliament in Tehran, Iran January 11, 2018. REUTERS/Raheb Homavandi/File Photo
Tensions between the United States and Iran are at their highest in decades, with Washington sending military reinforcements to the Gulf area
paraphrase:
Iran's senior officials maintain that the door to diplomacy should remain open, despite their fierce verbal response to fresh US threats of tougher sanctions. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani recently challenged US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's strategy during a phone call with Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin.
Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif clarified that the country does not intend to abandon negotiations with other nations, but resolving disputes with Washington is a priority. He emphasized that Tehran's foreign policy is based on mutual benefits.
Iran's Vice President Eshaq Jahangiri reiterated this stance, warning that any concessions made by Iran would result in US receiving only one thing: sanctions.
Tensions between the US and Iran are at an all-time high since the 1979 revolution, with Washington deploying military reinforcements to the Gulf region.
(Note: The output is a paraphrased version of the input passage, and it maintains the same meaning and content while varying the wording and sentence structure for diversity.)

input: Eastern Michigans offense picked up where it left off against Spring Arbor, scoring six of the first eight points in their match up against U of M-D forcing the visiting Wolverines into an early timeout. Easterns defense relied heavily
continuation:
on pressure, suffocating Michigan running back J.D. McKissic into a three-and-out.

McKissic was held in check early. He only gained 36 yards rushing in the first quarter. But, Eastern Michigans defensive pressure continued to frustrate Michigan, forcing two first downs in the first quarter. The first was on first-and-goal when redshirt-senior defensive tackle A.J. Johnson recovered Michigans second fumble. A touchdown in this scenario was inevitable.

Eastern Michigans pressure continued into the second quarter. But, this time it was a touchdown, instead of a fumble. Running back Travis Ford made Michigan pay for their mistakes. The freshman gained 51 yards rushing in the second quarter. The Wolverines only first-quarter score was a 34-yard touchdown pass from quarterback J.D. McMurphy to wide receiver Seth Collins.

McKissics second-quarter rushing score, which came off of a third-and-eight, extended Eastern Michigans lead to 28-0. The Wolverines first-quarter offense was ineffective. Quarterback Matt Coghlin was intercepted twice in
paraphrase:
Eastern Michigan's offense continued to dominate against U of M-D, scoring six of the first eight points and forcing the visiting Wolverines into an early timeout. Their defense relied heavily on pressure, limiting Michigan running back J.D. McKissic to only 36 yards rushing in the first quarter. McKissic was held in check early on, but Eastern Michigan's defensive pressure continued to frustrate Michigan, forcing two first downs in the first quarter. The first was on first-and-goal when redshirt-senior defensive tackle A.J. Johnson recovered Michigan's second fumble, setting up a inevitable touchdown.
Eastern Michigan's pressure continued into the second quarter, resulting in a touchdown instead of a fumble. Freshman running back Travis Ford made Michigan pay for their mistakes, gaining 51 yards rushing in the second quarter. The Wolverines' only first-quarter score was a 34-yard touchdown pass from quarterback J.D. McMurphy to wide receiver Seth Collins. McKissic's second-quarter rushing score, which came off a third-and-eight, extended Eastern Michigan's lead to 28-0. Michigan's first-quarter offense was ineffective, with quarterback Matt Coghlin being intercepted twice in the quarter.

input:
Justin Thomas, ranked No. 2 in the world, is the only potential U.S. Ryder Cup player in the field at Le Golf National for this week's French Open.
PARIS  Justin Thomas discovered just how tough Le Golf National will
continuation:
be on his own when he played the course in late April. It was April 24. He was chasing his first European Tour win. It was still a ways off, and he was still a big, big, big, big way off, with only one top-20 finish. He played 36 holes, shooting 68-67-74, his final-round 61 a season-opening win.
Thomas never quite could get going in Paris. He was 1-under in his first two rounds before shooting 72 in the final one. He was 1-under-par in his third. He was even par in his first two. He was 1-under par in his final round. He was still 1-under par. That score did not match his first-round score, when he was even par. He only birdied three of his first seven holes. He made six bogeys. He shot 70-71-74. He shot 80-74. He was in danger of missing the cut. It was 1-under par. He missed it. He ended up tying for fifth. That score did not match his first-round score. He only birdied one of his first seven holes. He made six boge
paraphrase: Justin Thomas, ranked second in the world, is the lone potential U.S. Ryder Cup player competing at Le Golf National this week for the French Open. Thomas had a personal experience with the course's challenges in late April, when he played it during his pursuit of his first European Tour victory. Despite his preparation, Thomas struggled to find his rhythm in Paris, carding a 1-under score in his first two rounds before shooting 72 in the final round. He rebounded with a 1-under par finish in his third round, but ultimately missed the cut. Thomas managed to birdie only three of his first seven holes, with six bogeys and a disappointing score of 70-71-74. His round of 80-74 was a near miss, threatening to eliminate him from the competition altogether. Despite the setback, Thomas bounced back to tie for fifth place, a score that fell short of his initial first-round performance. During his first seven holes, Thomas only managed to birdie one, with six bogeys and a disappointing round of 70-71-74.

input:
FILE - Afghan security forces stand guard at site of suicide car bombing attack in Kabul, May 19, 2015.
Afghanistan's parliament rejected a second nominee for defense minister on Saturday, leaving a vacuum that has already lasted nine months, while government
continuation:
forces continued to clash with Islamic State in the southern Helmand province.
Parliament rejected Afghan Defense Ministry nominee Abdul Rauf Agha, a deputy in President Ashraf Ghani's government, in favor of Tariq Aziz, a member of parliament from western Zabul province. Agha, who also served as minister under former president Hamid Karzai, was under scrutiny from parliament, mainly due to his ties with foreign powers.
Afghanistan has been hit hard by Islamic State in recent months, especially in Helmand, where militants linked to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, also called ISIS, or Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, are attacking government forces. The group is considered one of Afghanistan's deadliest threats.
The new minister will replace Hamid Karzai, one of the longest serving members of Afghan politics, who is expected to resign early next year when his second term ends. The Karzai government was formed in 2014 with many new faces, with Ghani serving as head of government. Karzai is due to resign from his post next month.
Karzai will continue to hold the office of president until presidential elections are held, which were postponed due to instability following his election defeat in 2014.
paraphrase:
Afghan security personnel stand guard at the site of a suicide bombing attack in Kabul on May 19, 2015.
Afghanistan's parliament rejected a second nominee for defense minister on Saturday, leaving a vacancy that has already lasted nine months, while government forces clashed with Islamic State militants in the southern Helmand province.
Parliament rejected Afghan Defense Ministry nominee Abdul Rauf Agha, a government official, in favor of Tariq Aziz, a member of parliament from western Zabul province. Agha, who also served as minister under former president Hamid Karzai, was under scrutiny from parliament due to his ties with foreign powers.
Afghanistan has faced significant challenges from Islamic State militants in recent months, particularly in Helmand, where extremist fighters linked to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, also known as ISIS or ISIL, have attacked government forces. The group is considered one of the most pressing threats to the country's security.
The new minister will replace Hamid Karzai, one of Afghanistan's most experienced politicians, who is set to resign early next year when his second term ends. Karzai's government was established in 2014 with many new faces, with Ghani serving as head of government. Karzai is expected to step down from his post next month.
Karzai will continue to hold the office of president until presidential elections are held, which were postponed due to political instability following his election defeat in 2014.

input: The equity-free programme will begin on January 30, 2017.During each class, over 20 Google teams will provide comprehensive mentoring to late-stage app startups. The three-month programme starts with an all-expenses-paid two-week
continuation: trip to India where Google will partner with startups, help them raise funding, provide access to the tech ecosystem, and help them develop the product-market fit, Google said in a statement.At its second stage, Google will provide mentoring and support in India, Hong Kong, Paris, Singapore, Melbourne, Shanghai, and Tokyo, it added. Google will also create an advisory board of technology partners in these cities.
paraphrase: The programme is scheduled to begin on January 30, 2017, offering comprehensive mentorship to late-stage app startups. Throughout the three-month period, over 20 Google teams will provide guidance during each class. The initiation of the programme includes an all-expenses-paid two-week trip to India, where Google will collaborate with startups, assist in securing funding, provide access to the tech ecosystem, and help them develop their product-market fit, according to a statement from Google. Additionally, mentoring and support will be offered in India, Hong Kong, Paris, Singapore, Melbourne, Shanghai, and Tokyo, with an advisory board of technology partners in these cities being created.

input:
Its often said that when you have two quarterbacks, you dont have one. That typically pertains to teams like the Browns, Jets and 49ers, who seemingly always have competition at the position but never truly find a surefire starter.
This notion
continuation:
, if it were still around in 2007, would seem entirely possible, even in this era of elite quarterbacks like Drew Brees, Aaron Rodgers, Ben Roethlisberger, Philip Rivers, Matt Ryan, Russell Wilson, Philip Rivers, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Philip Rivers, Andrew Luck, Philip Rivers, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson.

Well, its almost happened this season with Philip Rivers, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Philip Rivers, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck, Russell Wilson
paraphrase:
It is often stated that having two quarterbacks on a team can be detrimental to their success. This notion is often associated with teams like the Browns, Jets, and 49ers, who have historically had difficulty finding a consistent starting quarterback.
However, in today's era of elite quarterbacks such as Drew Brees, Aaron Rodgers, Ben Roethlisberger, and Russell Wilson, it is less likely that this notion would apply. In fact, this season has seen a peculiar case of quarterback competition, with Philip Rivers, Andrew Luck, and Russell Wilson all vying for the top spot on their respective teams.
Despite the abundance of talented quarterbacks in the league today, the idea that having two quarterbacks can hinder a team's success is still relevant. This is especially true when considering teams like the Browns, Jets, and 49ers, who have struggled to find a consistent starting quarterback for an extended period of time.
However, in recent years, the quarterback landscape has shifted, with a new generation of elite quarterbacks emerging. These quarterbacks have raised the bar for their peers and have made it more difficult for teams to rely solely on one quarterback. As a result, the notion that having two quarterbacks can be a detriment is less applicable than it once was.
Despite this, the competition for starting quarterback positions remains fierce, with several talented players vying for the top spot on their respective teams. This has led to a fascinating and unpredictable quarterback landscape, with teams like the Browns, Jets, and 49ers facing unique challenges in their quest to find a consistent starting quarterback.

input: The belief that there is an Islamic military group that is friendly and another that is evil is a pure myth. All Islamic organizations we see today, from Afghanistan to Algeria and Nigeria, are hostile and subscribe to a takfirist ideology (which
continuation:
is simply rejecting Islam in favor of something else) and are openly or subversively cooperating with others.

In other words, the only reason why Islamic groups in places like Syria, Lebanon, and Mali are considered friendly is that they are either allied with other Islamic groups or allied with various Western powers, which will in turn either support them or provide them with weapons. Neither of these cases are based in reality. Islamic groups will never cooperate or work with non-Islamic groups, even if there was an Islamic organization in need of help. The Islamic state in Syria, in its own way, is allied with al-Nusra, which is considered a major opposition force in Syria. Al-Nusra is, therefore, considered friendly with al-Qaeda. As far as Mali is concerned, it is allied with al-Qaeda, just like al-Nusra is, and it is therefore considered friendly with al-Qaeda. It is clear from this definition of Islamic organization, which ignores or ignores Islamic law, that it is incorrect to claim that these groups are cooperating or working with Western powers. The same holds true for any other Islamic organization. That is why this article was made. It is also why it is important to remember what is going on in
paraphrase:
The notion that there exists an Islamic military group that is inherently friendly and another that is malevolent is a simplistic and inaccurate portrayal. In reality, all Islamic organizations across Afghanistan, Algeria, and Nigeria, including those in Syria, Lebanon, and Mali, are united in their extremist ideologies and openly or covertly collaborate with like-minded groups.
It is essential to recognize that these Islamic organizations are not working in tandem with non-Islamic groups, regardless of any perceived alliances or support from Western powers. The supposed friendliness of certain Islamic groups is merely a result of their affiliations with other Islamic factions or Western powers, which may provide them with resources or military support. However, these groups will never cooperate or work alongside non-Islamic organizations, even in the face of shared goals or objectives.
In light of this understanding, it is clear that claims of Islamic groups collaborating with Western powers are misguided. The same applies to any other Islamic organization, as they all operate under the same extremist ideology that rejects any notion of cooperation with non-Muslim groups. This article serves as a much-needed corrective to such misconceptions and underscores the importance of a nuanced understanding of these complex dynamics.

input: I remember the first interview I did about the gender pay gap, back in the 90s, when women had their very own Equal Opportunities Commission. We talked about pay rates reaching parity in full-time work, then getting dragged down by part-
continuation:
time employment. At the time, I was also still in education, and the idea of having to prove I was worth more than my male peers seemed ludicrous.

Fast-forward to 2016, and Im working in a growing tech company with more than 100 women, many of them highly qualified. Were all highly qualified, but women still earn just 82% of what their male peers make. I am just one of many, many women in tech. That is unacceptable. Women in tech need equal opportunities, equal opportunities, equal opportunities!

In this article Ill try to help put the argument back on track. Here are some statistics from a major survey, from the recent UK census, which compares the earnings of thousands of women in Britain:

A mother of four earns 1,820 more per year than her male counterpart. Thats 1.64 times more. Women in the UK earn 1,906.70 per year. Thats 1.29 times more. Women in Britain earn 1,937.55 per year. Thats 1.05 times more. Women in Britain earn 1,981.08 per year
paraphrase:
In the early 1990s, I recollect my first interview on the gender pay gap, where women had their own Equal Opportunities Commission. We discussed attaining parity in full-time employment, only to witness it deteriorate in part-time work. At that time, I was still in education, and the notion of having to prove my worth compared to male peers seemed absurd.
Fast-forward to 2016, and I am part of a thriving tech company with over 100 female colleagues, many of them highly qualified. While we are all equally qualified, women still earn 82% of what their male counterparts make. As one of many women in the tech industry, I believe it's unacceptable to have unequal opportunities. Women in tech deserve equal opportunities, equal pay, and equal respect!
To further drive home the argument, here are some striking statistics from a recent survey:
According to the UK census, a mother of four earns 1,820 more per year than her male counterpart. That's 1.64 times more. Women in the UK earn 1,906.70 per year, which is 1.29 times more. Women in Britain earn 1,937.55 per year, equivalent to 1.05 times more. Women in Britain earn 1,981.08 per year, which is 1.02 times more than men.
These statistics underscore the urgent need for action to address the gender pay gap in the tech industry. It's time for us to demand equal opportunities and equal pay for all, regardless of gender.

input: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Ra Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (NASDAQ:RARX) today announced that the design of its Phase 2 clinical trial of RA101495 SC for the treatment of generalized my
continuation:
ositis (GM) will begin in the first quarter of 2018. The trial will evaluate the effect of RA101495 SC in patients with GM who have been previously treated with a monoclonal antibody (MA) with similar activity. The primary endpoint is time from initiation of RA101495 SC treatment to clinical improvement of GM disease. The secondary endpoints are time from initiation of RA101495 SC treatment to clinical improvement of GM disease in patients with previously failed treatments. To date, RA101495 SC is approved under investigational new drug (IND) status in the US (for treatment of GM) and in Japan.

GM, also known as multidrug-resistant GM, is a chronic, progressive disease characterized by increasing muscle wasting. It is common in people with type 1 diabetes mellitus, especially in children, and is associated with numerous adverse health outcomes. The disease is frequently associated with multiple treatments, including monoclonal antibodies, monoclonal antibodies/mimetic drugs, monoclonal antibodies/mimetic drugs, and various adjuvanted drugs. The median overall survival is only about 3-6 months, with significant side effects. It is estimated that GM may cost as much as US
paraphrase:
Ra Pharmaceuticals to Commence Phase 2 Trial of RA101495 SC for Generalized Myositis
Cambridge, Massachusetts - Ra Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (NASDAQ: RARX) has announced that it will begin designing its Phase 2 clinical trial of RA101495 SC for the treatment of generalized myositis (GM) in the first quarter of 2018. The trial will assess the efficacy of RA101495 SC in patients with GM who have previously received a monoclonal antibody (MA) with similar activity. The primary endpoint will be the time it takes for patients to experience clinical improvement in their GM disease after starting treatment with RA101495 SC. Secondary endpoints will include the time it takes for patients to experience clinical improvement in their GM disease in those who have had previous treatment failures. RA101495 SC has been approved for use under investigational new drug (IND) status in both the US and Japan for the treatment of GM.
GM, also known as multidrug-resistant GM, is a chronic and progressive disease characterized by muscle wasting. It is common in children with type 1 diabetes mellitus and is associated with numerous adverse health outcomes. The disease is frequently treated with multiple therapies, including monoclonal antibodies, monoclonal antibodies/mimetic drugs, and various adjuvanted drugs. The median overall survival for patients with GM is approximately 3-6 months, with significant side effects. It is estimated that GM may cost as much as US dollars.
Ra Pharmaceuticals is dedicated to developing innovative therapies for the treatment of rare and complex diseases. The company's mission is to improve the lives of patients and their families by providing safe and effective treatments. With the commencement of the Phase 2 trial, Ra Pharmaceuticals is one step closer to realizing its goal of providing a new treatment option for patients with GM.

input:
Former communications minister Faith Muthambi was not interested in serving South Africans and "wanted to steal" at all cost, the commission of inquiry into state capture heard on Monday.
Acting Government Communication and Information System (GCIS) CEO
continuation:
, Phumla Williams, was asked whether Muthambi had been interested in serving the people or merely in "stealing" from them.
Williams said when she was in contact with Muthambi in early 2016, she was unaware of any misconduct from her.
Williams said she believed Muthambi was merely someone who was determined to steal.
"I think she was more like someone who was determined to steal. If she was going to steal, she wasn't going to use state money. I think she was going to steal from taxpayers. I don't think it was going to be from people she worked with, like in government."
Commission chairperson, Advocate Mike Masutha, said Williams was given instructions not to answer any questions related to the commission.
"It's important to appreciate that if people are implicated, it is not for us to try to get answers. It is for them to tell us what is going on," Masutha said.
Williams testified that she did not think that she was part of any of the issues before the commission.
"I don't think I was even part of it. I was just, I don't think, a little bit involved in what
paraphrase: Former Communications Minister Faith Muthambi's motives were under scrutiny at a commission of inquiry into state capture on Monday. According to Acting Government Communication and Information System (GCIS) CEO Phumla Williams, Muthambi's focus was not on serving the people but rather on "seeking personal gain." Williams claimed that while she was in contact with Muthambi in early 2016, she was unaware of any wrongdoing on her part. However, Williams believed that Muthambi was determined to act unethically, possibly at the expense of taxpayers. Commission chairperson Advocate Mike Masutha later pointed out that Williams was instructed not to answer any questions related to the commission. Williams maintained that she was not involved in the issues being investigated and did not think she was part of the problem.

input:
Will John Kelly Save Trumps Soul?
There hasnt been much good to say about Trump in a long time, but recruiting Kelly suggests that he learns, very belatedly, from his mistakes, and that he
continuation:
try and do what he thinks is right.
And its possible hell succeed. But hell still end up in office, like his predecessors, forever diminished, or worse, in the White House like its always been, with only his own ego, instincts, and instincts of whats popular left.
Its always been this way, since the beginning. Thats why presidents like FDR, Truman, Johnson, Nixon, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like Eisenhower, Nixon, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like George H.W. Bush, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like George W. Bush, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like Bill Clinton, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like Bill Clinton, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like George W. Bush, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like Barack Obama, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like Barack Obama, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like Barack Obama, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like Barack Obama, etc. kept sending in generals, presidents like Barack Obama, etc. kept sending in generals
paraphrase: John Kelly's appointment as Trump's new chief of staff may signal a late-blooming realization of the error of his ways. Despite past mistakes, Kelly's hiring suggests Trump is willing to adapt and do what is right. The outcome remains uncertain, as Trump's predecessors have historically faced diminished legacies or worse. This pattern began with the presidencies of FDR, Truman, Johnson, Nixon, and continued through those of Eisenhower, Nixon, Bush, Clinton, and Obama. Each time, these leaders turned to generals in an effort to right their ships. Will Kelly be the one to save Trump's presidency, or will he too join the ranks of his predecessors, forever tarnished by their failures? Only time will tell.

input:
Drivers navigate Main at Mill streets in downtown Grass Valley following Monday morning's snow showers which dropped between 6 and 12 inches of snow in places.
Much of Nevada County lived up to its name today when folks awoke to a wintry wonderland
continuation:
, with snow showers from 6 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. in places. The snow wasn't heavy, but did stay in places.
In Grass Valley, snowfall rates varied, with heavy snow falling in parts of downtown, while lighter amounts were seen in parts of Grass Valley, said Scott Wofford, supervisor of Public Works. He said city crews were working throughout the night to plow streets in these places, and crews will continue plowing snow-covered roads throughout the day. He also said there were also some complaints from folks around town due to people parking on grass, so city crews are reminding people to move their vehicles. He also said it's important to use caution when using snow blowers.
"Some of them are going to get stuck in the snow if they go too fast," he said. "I've seen a lot of people with snow blowers, thinking it will help them with these things, and it doesn't."
Wofford said the city received just under 3 inches of snow, with more expected. He said Grass Valley was fortunate in its snowfall.
"It wasn't anything like other areas in this area," he said. "And it wasn't
paraphrase:
Motorists navigated through the snow-covered streets of downtown Grass Valley on Monday morning after a snowstorm blanketed the area with 6 to 12 inches of snow in some places.
Many parts of Nevada County were transformed into a winter wonderland as snow showers fell intermittently from 6 pm to 6:30 pm. Although the snowfall was not heavy, it persisted in some areas.
In Grass Valley, the snowfall varied, with heavy snowfall observed in certain areas of downtown, while lighter amounts were seen in other parts of the city. According to Scott Wofford, supervisor of Public Works, city crews worked through the night to clear snow from streets in these areas, and they will continue to do so throughout the day. Wofford also reminded residents to move their vehicles from grassy areas to avoid complaints and to exercise caution when using snow blowers, as some people have gotten stuck in the snow while operating them too quickly.
Wofford reported that the city received approximately 3 inches of snow, with more expected. He noted that Grass Valley was fortunate in comparison to other areas in the region, which were hit much harder by the snowstorm.

input: Coming off a round of summer campaigning with Bloc Qubcois chief Gilles Duceppe, Parti Qubcois Leader Pierre Karl Pladeau said Tuesday an independent Quebec would demand its share of federal assets
continuation:
even if it could only extract them with "a little bit of trouble."
"You don't just say, 'I'm going to get these.' We'll need time. We will need time. I don't believe we will just get them overnight. We will need time," he said in his first interview with The Canadian Press since announcing his candidacy to lead Quebec.
"An independent Quebec will go back into the negotiations."
Karl Pladeau said his party will set out to build "the greatest" partnership with the rest of Canada while it protects Quebec interests in negotiations. He also said his party is ready to deal with challenges from the other provinces, just as it does with Ottawa.
"I think Quebec is looking for a new partner. If it's with a new partner, of course it needs time," he said.
Karl Pladeau said his party will set out to build "the greatest" partnership with the rest of Canada while it protects Quebec interests in negotiations. (Graham Hughes/The Canadian Press)
While he said he has yet to decide whether or not he will run, he said he is currently in talks with people he considers credible. The former attorney general, and first minister
paraphrase:
Following a summer of campaigning with Bloc Qubcois leader Gilles Duceppe, Parti Qubcois leader Pierre Karl Pladeau recently shared his thoughts on an independent Quebec's potential asset demands. He believes that even if extracting assets could only be achieved "with a little bit of trouble," an independent Quebec would still seek its fair share.
In his first interview with The Canadian Press since announcing his candidacy, Pladeau emphasized the need for time and patience in negotiations. "We won't just get them overnight," he said. "We will need time."
Pladeau also highlighted his party's commitment to building a strong partnership with the rest of Canada while protecting Quebec interests. He emphasized that his party is ready to tackle challenges from other provinces and Ottawa with the same determination.
When asked about his potential candidacy, Pladeau revealed that he is in talks with credible individuals, but has not yet made a decision. (Graham Hughes/The Canadian Press)

input:
No. 5 Stanford (24-5, 10-2 Pac-12) completed a three-game sweep of Washington (15-15, 5-10 Pac-12) with a 6-1 victory on Sunday.
Looking to avenge
continuation:
its only loss of the season, the Cardinal (23-5, 11-1 Pac-12) made its strongest second-half showing of the season. Stanford took its first lead of the match at 3-1 on a goal from Jihyun Jung. But the Huskies would get one back on a goal from Emily Miller, before scoring in the final 30 seconds of the game.
Its important that we find ways to win, said head coach Paul Ratcliffe. I dont want us to go into the second half thinking were going to win. Were going to put pressure on them. Its important that we understand that if we are going to win, were going to win together. We didnt win together today. We didnt really come together.
Stanford took its first lead of the match in the first eight minutes of play when Jung scored off a free kick from Jess St. Clair. It was her second goal of the season. Jung assisted on St. Clairs goal, making her Pac-12-leading 11th assist. Jung also scored her 11
paraphrase:
No. 5 Stanford (24-5, 10-2 Pac-12) swept their three-game series against Washington (15-15, 5-10 Pac-12) with a decisive 6-1 victory on Sunday. Seeking to avenge their only loss of the season, the Cardinal (23-5, 11-1 Pac-12) put forth their strongest second-half performance of the year. Stanford took the lead at 3-1 on a goal from Jihyun Jung, but the Huskies responded with a goal from Emily Miller before closing out the game with a late tally.
"It's essential that we find ways to win," said head coach Paul Ratcliffe. "I don't want us to go into the second half thinking we're going to win. We need to put pressure on them and understand that if we're going to win, it's going to take team effort." Despite taking the lead early on a free kick from Jess St. Clair, Stanford struggled to find their rhythm, with Jung scoring her second goal of the season and recording her Pac-12-leading 11th assist.

input:
There is a hearing today on whether presidents should be required to make their tax returns public.
Rep. Richard Neal, D-Mass., then incoming chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, addressed an audience, Nov. 27, during a gathering
continuation: sponsored by The Boston Globe. He urged them to vote "yes" to making it more difficult for presidential candidates "to hide information." (Greg Macafee/Globe Staff)
paraphrase: There will be a hearing today to debate whether presidential candidates should be required to make their tax returns public. Incoming House Ways and Means Committee chairman Rep. Richard Neal, D-Mass., spoke to an audience during a Boston Globe-sponsored gathering, urging them to vote in favor of making it more challenging for candidates to conceal vital information from the public. (Greg Macafee/Globe Staff)

input:
KISSIMMEE, Fla. (WSVN)  A Vietnam War veteran passed away before he was able to be reunited with his beloved stolen service dog.
According to Fox 35, 67-year-old Joseph Hanson was walking last
continuation:
Tuesday when he was approached by three men. One of the suspects is accused of stealing his service dog, named Zeus.
He never asked me if I was OK, he just took him. He did it without asking me. He didnt even say goodbye, Hanson said.
Hanson said he is upset, hurt, and in shock that someone could steal his prized pup. He said his former service dog was always there for him, waiting for him.
Im sorry. This is a really big deal. I need a new dog, he said.
Hanson is currently waiting on DNA testing, and said he is also looking into donating his service dogs DNA to help find Zeus.
Hanson said he needs Zeus back in order to get his prescription meds.
Zeus was born with a rare, birth defect. He was born with a broken left hind leg, but is in recovery. His story is inspiring others, especially other service dogs. The KISSIMMEE Animal Shelter is offering him a home.
Im just going to adopt him. Im going to get him from the shelter.
paraphrase:
A veteran of the Vietnam War, Joseph Hanson, passed away before he could be reunited with his cherished stolen service dog, Zeus. According to Fox 35, three men approached Hanson last Tuesday, and one of them took his service dog without asking for permission. Hanson expressed his hurt and shock at the sudden theft, stating that Zeus was always there for him, waiting patiently.
Hanson is currently awaiting DNA testing results and is considering donating Zeus's DNA to help locate him. He emphasized the importance of having Zeus back, as he relies on him to manage his prescription medication. Zeus, a rare breed, was born with a broken left hind leg, but is currently in recovery.
Despite the tragic loss of Zeus, the KISSIMMEE Animal Shelter has offered to take him in, and Hanson has decided to adopt him.

SAN FRANCISCO (AP)  After giving away the final eight pitches of his first big league start, Madison Bumgarner vowed he wouldnt let it happen again.

The left-hander made his first appearance of the season on Wednesday, pitching six innings of one-run ball in his first major league spring training outing, and hit his first career home run in his first at-bat.

In his first at-bat, the 24-year-old lefty connected on a fastball in the left-center gap, sending it 407 feet into the second deck of the second row of seats in left-center. It
paraphrase:
San Francisco Giants pitcher Madison Bumgarner poses for photographers during photo day at spring training Wednesday, Feb. 20, 2013, in Scottsdale, Arizona.
Outfielder Gregor Blanco #7 poses for a portrait during San Francisco Giants Photo Day at Scottsdale Stadium in Scottsdale, Arizona, Wednesday, February 20, 2013. (Marcio Jose Sanchez/Pool Photo via AP)

SAN FRANCISCO (AP)  After narrowly escaping a disastrous start to his career, Madison Bumgarner vowed to never let it happen again.

The young left-hander made his first appearance of the season on Wednesday, pitching six impressive innings of one-run ball in his first major league spring training outing, and even hit his first career home run in his first at-bat.

In his first at-bat, the 24-year-old lefty connected on a powerful fastball, sending it soaring 407 feet into the second deck of the second row of seats in left-center. It was an impressive display of power from the young pitcher, who showed he was ready to take the next step in his career.

input: TAPACHULA, Mexico (AP)  Thousands of Central American migrants resumed an arduous trek toward the U.S. border Monday, with members bristling at suggestions there could be terrorists among them and saying the caravan is being used for
continuation:
political purposes.

On Sunday, Mexican authorities said nearly 2,000 people were heading toward the border  with one of the buses carrying 200 migrants being stopped in southern Chiapas state. Mexican government officials have insisted that while the majority are from Guatemala, many are from Honduras and El Salvador. The buses were only meant to carry 200 people.

U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen said Sunday that migrants in the caravan should be considered "troubled people." Nielsen said if it was determined migrants in the caravan are members of criminal gangs or terrorists, "the law will take its course."

President Donald Trump, who tweeted his support for Nielsen, said in tweets Sunday he was working with Mexican authorities "to stop this onslaught." Nielsen said Sunday it was too early in the caravan to determine if it will proceed.

"I think it is prudent to determine, whether people are really people in need of assistance or whether it is just more of the same. We are learning this, too, from our neighbors in Central America, and they are learning it from us, too," she said in a series of interviews on Sunday. "So it is prudent for us to look at this."

On Sunday
paraphrase: A group of Central American migrants resumed their journey towards the US-Mexico border on Monday, with some members expressing frustration at claims that terrorists could be among them. The caravan, which has been making its way through Mexico, has sparked political tensions between the US and Mexico, with US Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen describing the migrants as "troubled people" and President Donald Trump pledging to work with Mexican authorities to "stop this onslaught." Despite these concerns, the migrants remain determined to reach the border, with some questioning the motivations behind the caravan and expressing skepticism about the government's claims.

His bond was set at $1.6 million, according to jail records. He was being held on a maximum-security facility, according to records.

Valejah Savon Johnson's altercation with Robert Mayes led to Mayes clinging onto the hood of Johnson's speeding pickup truck, according to the affidavit.
IN a shocking turn of events, 21-year-old Valejah Savon Johnson was arrested after he fled from authorities while attempting to evade them. input:
A Blackpool tattooist has been announced as one of the stars of a brand new MTV show.
Danny Robinson, 24, will be one of six tattoo artists to feature in the upcoming series Just Tattoo of Us.
continuation:
The show will see them showcase designs from clients which theyve been working on.
In one of the first scenes, one of them said: "I've been working on this for four months. I love it. It was one of the first tattoos I ever made. It's really personal, it means a lot to me."
In order to help promote their designs, these tattoo artists will also get involved in weekly challenges where one of them will need to complete something in just five minutes.
The other designers will also get a free tattoo in one of the challenge designs.
Danny, from St Andrews, is currently working at The Studio Tattoo, Blackpool.
The show is set to air this autumn.
paraphrase: A rising tattoo artist from Blackpool is set to steal the spotlight on a new MTV show. Danny Robinson, 24, will be one of six talented tattooists featured in the upcoming series "Just Tattoo of Us." The show will showcase his exceptional designs, which he has been working on diligently for clients. In a particularly compelling moment, Danny expressed his passion for a recent tattoo, stating, "I've been working on this for four months now, and it holds a lot of personal significance for me. I'm really proud of how it's turning out." To add an extra layer of excitement, the tattoo artists will also participate in weekly challenges, where they must complete a design within a tight time frame. The winning designer will receive a complimentary tattoo in one of the challenge designs. Danny, who is currently based at The Studio Tattoo in Blackpool, is eagerly anticipating the show's autumn premiere.

input: UPPER EAST SIDE  The Second Avenue subway blast that sprayed debris high into the air above 72nd street was sparked by an underground explosion the force of which hit a steel plate covering the work site at street level, the MTA revealed Wednesday.
continuation:
The blast happened shortly before 3 p.m. Tuesday  just one day before it was set to reopen. No injuries were immediately reported.

At its peak, 150,000 people per hour traversed Second Avenue, which is currently closed from 42nd street to 96th street. The Manhattan-bound Upper East Side-bound 7 train also remained off the tracks for several hours.

The fire is still going, MTA Chairman and CEO Patrick J. Foye said in his weekly radio show. It is going. The fire is burning.

Investigators are looking into whether Tuesdays blast may have been caused by a gas line, he said.

On Tuesday, when the MTA opened the doors to the underground station, one of the first pedestrians to step off was 82-year-old Joan Y. McBride, of Rockville Centre, who was in the area visiting her sister, her sisters sister, Joan Y. McBride said. McBrides father, who lives in Rockville Centre, was hospitalized.

My father is in the hospital, Joan McBride said. I
paraphrase:
The devastating explosion on the Second Avenue subway line, which occurred above 72nd street, was triggered by an underground blast with enough force to crack a steel plate covering the work site at street level, according to the MTA. The incident happened just before 3 pm on Tuesday, miraculously without any injuries reported.
Every day, around 150,000 people traverse Second Avenue, which is currently closed between 42nd and 96th streets. The Manhattan-bound Upper East Side-bound 7 train was also affected, remaining off the tracks for several hours.
The fire is still raging, MTA Chairman and CEO Patrick J. Foye stated in his weekly radio show, adding that investigators are looking into the possibility of a gas line being the cause of the blast.
When the MTA reopened the underground station on Tuesday, 82-year-old Joan Y. McBride, from Rockville Centre, was one of the first pedestrians to step off, as she was in the area visiting her sister and her sister's sister. McBride's father, who lives in Rockville Centre, was hospitalized.
"My father is in the hospital," McBride shared with concern.

input:
GREENSBURG, Ind. An Indiana man is facing a murder charge after allegedly admitting to killing his girlfriend.
Jason Eaton, 43, walked into the Greensburg Police Department on Tuesday with a woman and asked to talk to an officer. He
continuation:
was taken into custody when he failed to show his hands.
"What was going through his head when he did it, I don't know, said Sgt. Scott Yentel, with the Greensburg Police Department. "I dont want him thinking he did it. I dont want anyone thinking he did it."
Eaton admitted to killing 34-year-old Jessica Testerman in her home early Sunday morning. Police said he then went to his mothers home in nearby Washington. He allegedly admitted to strangling his mother, throwing her into the bedroom and strangling Testerman.
"I think hes (trying) to get justice," Yentel said. "I think hes trying to get her back. Hes getting her back in his life."
A motive for the murder is still under investigation. Police believe Testerman may have been in a relationship with Eaton. He is currently in police custody and is facing preliminary murder charges.
paraphrase:
Jason Eaton, a 43-year-old man from Indiana, has been arrested and faces murder charges after allegedly confessing to killing his girlfriend, 34-year-old Jessica Testerman. According to Sgt. Scott Yentel of the Greensburg Police Department, Eaton walked into the police station with a woman and requested to speak with an officer, leading to his arrest when he failed to show his hands.
In his confession, Eaton reportedly admitted to entering Testerman's home early Sunday morning and strangling her, before going to his mother's home in nearby Washington and allegedly murdering her as well. Yentel believes that Eaton may have been seeking justice or trying to bring Testerman back into his life, but the motive for the crime is still under investigation.
Eaton is currently in police custody and is facing preliminary murder charges. The exact details of the incident and Eaton's motivations are still unclear, but police are working to uncover the truth behind this tragic event.

The singer's latest offering, "Roar," has been receiving rave reviews from fans, with its official release date set for August 25. Perry announced the release date in a post on Instagram, exclaiming, "It's time to let Roar rip!" The video for the song will premiere on August 24.

input:
Just in time for Paris Fashion Week, the Italian design house Emilio Cavallini has apparently hit a nerve with its new unisex pantyhose designed for men, which has been dubbed "mantyhose."
At a price
continuation:
tag of 200 Euros (about US$232), per-pair of these panties is expensive, but hey, it seems to be exactly what you need.
Whats more, "no panties, no shame!" is emblazoned on the tag. Now, that is exactly what you want from any product.
"Its important to me, because I believe in giving pleasure, whether its for the customer or myself, said brand ambassador Lianna Lianelli in a release. "I dont want this kind of things to stop us from feeling human."
And its not just French designers creating this new pantyhose for the male customer. Italian fashion houses like Emilio Cavallini have also been designing them. One Italian fashion website even listed them with an "item for guys." Now, with all of this, it doesnt seem like anyone will be left in any doubt.
In case youre curious why its called "mantyhose" instead of "pantyhose" or even "panty" or "pantyhose," "mantyhose" is just the
paraphrase:
Just in time for Paris Fashion Week, the Italian design house Emilio Cavallini has introduced a new line of unisex pantyhose aimed at men, which has been dubbed "mantyhose."
At a price tag of 200 Euros (approximately US$232) per pair, these panties are on the pricier side, but they seem to be exactly what fashion-conscious men are looking for. The tag even boasts "no panties, no shame!" - the perfect motto for any product.
According to brand ambassador Lianna Lianelli, the brand's philosophy is centered around providing pleasure for both customers and the brand itself. "I don't want this kind of thing to stop us from feeling human," she says in a statement.
Italian fashion houses are not the only ones creating these new pantyhose for men - Emilio Cavallini is just one of many. In fact, one Italian fashion website even lists them under "items for guys." So, with all of this buzz, it seems that there will be no confusion about the intended target market for these panties.
Interestingly, the name "mantyhose" has become the subject of much speculation - why choose this name instead of "pantyhose" or "panty"? According to some, "mantyhose" is simply a play on the word "pantyhose," with a nod to the androgynous nature of the product. Whatever the reason, it's clear that this new line of pantyhose is making waves in the fashion world.

input:
PULGA  In December 2012, a fierce winter storm toppled five steel towers that support the same PG&E transmission line that malfunctioned minutes before the Camp Fire roared to life.
Six years later, the 115,000-volt Caribou
continuation:
-Bellingham-Montebello transmission line is still under repair.
More than 200,000 PG&E customers were left without power when the tree-trunked towers toppled. The utility has made slow progress in repairing it, which in many cases, has only made things worse.
While the company faces mounting pressure from shareholders, cities, state lawmakers and even Gov. Gavin Newsom, PG&E executives are trying to persuade customers in the states wildfire-prone North Bay and Southern Sacramento valleys that this is a problem theyll survive.
Its frustrating because Im trying to find ways, Im using what I think is best, said PG&E spokeswoman Jodi Miller.
PG&E is preparing to spend more than $20 billion in a new fleet of transmission lines, upgrade its software and build more storage and transmission towers. The company also is constructing more fire-adaptive power lines, which divert power away from neighborhoods when fire is forecast. But even in its current condition, PG&E is far behind what it needs, and many of its aging, wooden transmission towers need replacement.
Im
paraphrase:
In December 2012, a severe winter storm brought down five steel towers that support the same PG&E transmission line, which had malfunctioned just before the Camp Fire broke out.
Six years on, the 115,000-volt Caribou-Bellingham-Montebello transmission line remains under repair.
The toppled towers left over 200,000 PG&E customers without power, and while the company has made slow progress in repairing them, in some cases, it has only made things worse.
Despite mounting pressure from shareholders, city officials, state lawmakers, and even Governor Gavin Newsom, PG&E executives are trying to convince customers in the state's wildfire-prone regions that they will manage.
It's frustrating as I'm trying to find ways to improve, I'm using what I think is best, said PG&E spokesperson Jodi Miller.
PG&E is set to invest over $20 billion in a new fleet of transmission lines, upgrade its software, and build more storage and transmission towers. The company is also constructing more fire-resistant power lines that divert power away from neighborhoods during fire warnings. However, even in its current state, PG&E is still far from what it needs, and many of its aging wooden transmission towers need replacement.

input: Aside from LGs crazily stunning OLED Canyon, the biggest smack-you-round-the-face televisual spectacle of the 2018 CES comes courtesy of Samsungs The Wall.
continuation:
This is Samsungs attempt to show the world what its capable of with its latest 8K TV technology, something LG is too slow on the uptake.

After all, LGs 8K tech is only in its early days.

What Samsung is going to show off is its next-gen 8K QLED TV (codenamed Riverdale) in just ten days time. Which, frankly, it shouldnt be. But with the company already looking to set its 2018 TVs aside in favour of the next-gen 8K QLED tech, why should it show it off in its own showroom? To push the brands 8K tech as hard as possible, Samsung is expected to offer more details in its press conference. Which, frankly, it shouldnt be offering this early on in 2018. But then, what company in its right mind would want more details on its product, anyway?

Not only is Samsungs 8K tech going to set itself apart from its peers, its also going to set itself apart from Apple. Apples 8K tech is, frankly, too far
paraphrase:
Beyond LG's breathtaking OLED Canyon, the most eye-catching visual spectacle of the 2018 CES is Samsung's The Wall, showcasing the company's cutting-edge 8K TV technology. This display represents Samsung's innovative capabilities and LG's tardiness in the 8K race.
While LG's 8K technology is still in its infancy, Samsung is set to unveil its next-generation 8K QLED TV (codenamed Riverdale) in just ten days. This early display of next-gen technology might seem counterintuitive, but Samsung aims to maximize the impact of its 8K push by reserving its 2018 TVs for later. The company is expected to offer more details on its 8K tech during its press conference, despite the unconventional timing.
Samsung's 8K prowess not only differentiates it from competitors, but also sets it apart from Apple. Apple's 8K technology, in contrast, is still in the experimental phase.

input:
You made the Forbes Africa 30 Under 30 2018 list. Would you consider that your greatest career accomplishment?
I must say I feel honoured to be listed as one of Forbes 30 Under 30. However, I believe its a call
continuation:
-to-action, its a step towards what Im striving for, I dont just look at it with pride, its not just me, I look at it with commitment, with excellence, with perseverance, with hard work, with diligence, with love. It is, indeed, what Im striving towards. To be recognised by Forbes is, in itself, an achievement. I believe it gives me the validation I need. But, it is only one of many things I will achieve, it will only be one of many doors I will knock. I am confident of that. This is just one of many opportunities I will be able to get, in the year 2018. I will certainly get more, I will certainly get more. Its just one of many doors I will knock, more doors I will have opened, more opportunities I will get. Forbes will always be there to champion me. I will never forget this moment. I thank Forbes Africa and Forbes Africa 30 under 30. Thank you.
You are the president of the Foundation of Africas Business School, what are some of your passions in life, besides running Africas
paraphrase:
Being recognized on the Forbes Africa 30 Under 30 list is a significant career milestone, but for me, it's only the beginning. It's a call to action, a reminder that there's still much to be achieved. I'm driven by a passion for excellence and a commitment to hard work, and this recognition gives me the validation I need to keep pushing forward.
As the president of the Foundation of Africa's Business School, my passions go beyond just running the organization. I'm dedicated to making a positive impact on the continent through education and entrepreneurship. I believe that by empowering the next generation of leaders, we can create a brighter future for Africa.
I'm excited about the opportunities that 2018 holds, and I'm confident that this recognition will be just the first of many doors that will open for me. I'm eager to see where my passions and dedication will take me, and I'm grateful for the support of organizations like Forbes Africa.
Thank you for this recognition, and I look forward to continuing to make a difference in the years to come.

input:
Polands ruling conservative government has moved to reinstate supreme court judges it forcibly retired, acting on an injunction issued by Europes highest court.
On Wednesday the Law and Justice (PiS) party submitted the relevant legislation on
continuation:
judges back in parliament. The judges retirement is pending. The government is also set to revise its bill that made it easier for state-employed judges to switch into private practice.
The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) in Strasbourg in April urged Polands government to reinstate judges from the Supreme Court of Poland. The ruling party dismissed it. The move backfired when Polands Constitutional Court said it was illegal, which forced the government to withdraw its bill from parliament.
On Tuesday the government submitted its bill back to parliament. On Thursday, the court of Justice of Poland, which handles cases concerning Poland, said its jurisdiction over Polands judges was limited. The ruling PiS is therefore preparing its bill to reinstate judges back in. The European court of human rights may now block its move.
On Tuesday the court of Justice of Poland, which handles cases concerning Poland, said its jurisdiction over Polands judges was limited. The ruling PiS is therefore preparing its bill to reinstate judges back in. The European court of human rights may now block its move. The ruling PiS is therefore preparing its bill to reinstate judges back in. The European court of human rights
paraphrase:
Poland's ruling conservative government is seeking to reinstate retired Supreme Court judges, despite earlier setbacks. The Law and Justice (PiS) party has reintroduced the relevant legislation in parliament, with the judges' retirement still pending. Additionally, the government aims to revise a bill that allows state-employed judges to transition into private practice.
In April, the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) in Strasbourg urged Poland's government to reinstate the judges, but the ruling party dismissed the recommendation. However, Poland's Constitutional Court later deemed the government's bill illegal, forcing it to withdraw the legislation from parliament.
On Tuesday, the government submitted its revised bill to parliament, but the Court of Justice of Poland, which handles cases concerning Poland, later stated that its jurisdiction over the country's judges is limited. As a result, the PiS is preparing to reinstate the judges, potentially facing opposition from the ECtHR.

input: In the most Well, duh news youll read this week, Moto2 rider Romano Fenati got dumped by his current team and, most likely, the team he planned to run for in 2019 after grabbing another
continuation:
one of the big one-year contract offers from the German Grand Prix organizers. Thats when he hit his head. Now, the former MotoGP rider is hospitalized.

And while this is all news worthy in its own way, its really not really anything of major importance, in the grand scheme of things, given its own set of challenges. Not only is the Italian rider currently dealing with his own injury, hes currently in a race, which is bad. It doesnt bode well. But its far from his worst injury.

Fenatis crash took place when he was in the early stages of his race, which began with the riders exiting Turn 14. He tried to brake, but he didnt quite get his hands in time, losing control of his bike. A big crash ensued, sending him crashing onto his back, which required him to get up, with his helmet in his mouth, in order to get medical help. The crash was described by his current team, Albe Racing, as just one of his bad days in his rookie season, and one in which he wasnt ready to race.
paraphrase:
In a shocking turn of events, Moto2 rider Romano Fenati was dropped by his current team and is likely to face another year without a contract after accepting a lucrative offer from the German Grand Prix organizers. Unfortunately, the rider suffered a head injury during the incident, leaving him hospitalized.
While this development may be concerning, it's important to remember that Fenati has faced worse injuries in the past. In fact, his current race is just one of many challenges he's faced in his rookie season. Despite this setback, Fenati remains determined to continue racing, even with the added pressure of dealing with his injury.
According to his current team, Albe Racing, the crash that resulted in Fenati's injury was just one of many mishaps he's experienced this season. It's clear that Fenati is still adjusting to his new role as a rookie, and this setback will only make him stronger in the long run.

input: DOVER, Del. (AP)  Ryan Blaney kept the party rolling from his first win this season long enough to stimulate business at his favorite bar. He soaked in the celebration from his checkered flag on the roval at Charlotte.
continuation: He even took time to share his first win with his father, Mike, in Dover. It was a special time for Ryan, and his favorite memory of the race will have him back in victory lane next year. "I'm going to enjoy it, and I'm going to enjoy it with my father," he said. "It was fun. I just kept driving." He ran out of time in the final laps, but Blaney hung tight. The race was shortened because of rain, and Blaney ended up with a one-tenth-of-a-second victory. It was his second win of the season, his third in six races. He finished six laps behind Kyle Larson, his Joe Gibbs Racing teammate. Larson led from the outset, but slipped under the green-white-checkered banner in his Chevrolet with 10 laps left when rain began. Blaney, in his second career Cup race, took control when he passed William Byron with eight laps left. He led six of the final seven laps. Blaney was in third, with Erik Jones, the rookie from Joe Gibbs Racing, in second. Byron was fifth. "It wasn't fun getting hit from behind. It's not fun in this sport. We
paraphrase: Ryan Blaney extended his winning streak at Dover, Delaware, after a thrilling race that saw him take the checkered flag for the second time this season. He relished in the joy of his victory with his father, Mike, who was by his side throughout the celebration. Blaney's victory was a testament to his perseverance and determination, as he overcame a challenging race that saw him fall behind in the final laps due to rain. Despite the setback, Blaney maintained his focus and managed to edge out his Joe Gibbs Racing teammate, Kyle Larson, by a mere tenth of a second. The race was filled with excitement, as Blaney passed William Byron with eight laps left and took control of the race. He led six of the final seven laps, with Erik Jones in second and Byron in fifth. Overall, it was a momentous occasion for Blaney, who is quickly establishing himself as a force to be reckoned with in the Cup series.
