Security always comes down to securing applications.
The whole point of firewalls is to hide internally deployed network applicationsassumed to have exploitable vulnerabilities somewherefrom the outside world.
The main weakness of firewalls is that they are
continuation: static. No one is going to maintain the firewall or its configuration. This is why firewalls are always updated. This is why firewalls are always managed. This is why firewalls are expensive. It is why firewalls are difficult. It is why firewalls are expensive in that firewalls often have significant annual maintenance costs. It is why firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that firewalls are expensive in that
paraphrase: Protecting applications is the central concern when it comes to security. Firewalls are designed to conceal internal network assets from potential threats by creating a barrier between the internal network and the outside world. However, the primary flaw of firewalls is their static nature, as they are often neglected and left unmanaged, leading to frequent updates and maintenance costs. This is why firewalls are expensive, as they require ongoing maintenance to ensure they remain effective. Despite these challenges, firewalls remain a crucial component of network security, providing a crucial layer of protection against external threats.

input: Attorney General William Barr's inclusion of the phrase does not exonerate in his summary on Sunday afternon of the Mueller report has become a much-needed security blanket for liberal journalists. For the past 24 hours, CNN analysts, commentators
continuation:
, and critics have been jumping in with demands for Muellers findings to be made public.

CNN legal correspondent Van Jones says Mueller should release his findings. "My opinion is Mueller is going to say he didnt find obstruction of justice. Hell say he didnt find a conspiracy."  Manu Raju (@mkraju) April 22, 2019

As with many of CNNs more aggressive coverage of the Mueller report, its defenders appear to want it leaked. CNN legal correspondent Van Jones said Sunday: My opinion is Mueller is going to say he didnt find obstruction of justice. Hell say he didnt find a conspiracy. That is just one of many statements from pundits, former lawmakers, legal analysts, and Democrats who are pushing for more transparency from Mueller.

Former Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli, in a rare moment of candor, also said he wants Muellers report released. Cuccinelli, who was one of Virginias earliest legal cases, said, I am in favor of releasing Robert Muellers report if hell go beyond just his report
paraphrase:
Attorney General William Barr's inclusion of the phrase "does not exonerate" in his summary of the Mueller report has become a much-needed safety net for liberal journalists. In the past 24 hours, CNN analysts, commentators, and critics have been clamoring for Mueller's findings to be made public.
CNN legal correspondent Van Jones believes that Mueller will conclude he did not find obstruction of justice, and will also say he did not find a conspiracy. Jones tweeted, "My opinion is Mueller is going to say he didnt find obstruction of justice. Hell say he didnt find a conspiracy." This sentiment is echoed by many other pundits, former lawmakers, legal analysts, and Democrats who are calling for greater transparency from Mueller.
Former Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli has also joined the chorus, stating, "I am in favor of releasing Robert Mueller's report if he will go beyond just his report." This push for more information highlights the intense curiosity and scrutiny surrounding the Mueller report, and the desire of many to understand the findings in greater detail.

input:
A public policy group says states should not rush into leasing existing road assets to the private sector.
In a report released Tuesday, March 24, the Philadelphia-based Pew Center on the States urged states considering public-private partnerships for infrastructure to exercise caution
continuation:
.
The report, which looked at road projects in 11 states, also found states should also consider using private investment vehicles, which include special purpose vehicles, joint ventures, joint ventures with cities or local governments and revenue sharing from toll road projects.
"As states look to implement strategies that are more innovative, flexible and efficient, it is also important to take into account possible negative outcomes, especially given current financial pressures," it said.
PennDOT is working with its partners, including the Virginia Department of Transportation and the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, to develop a state-level report on how private partners could help with local transportation needs. The report will cover options like toll roads, alternative use and local share of revenue. PennDOT is also looking into options like using toll revenue for projects like I-95-Southeastern Extension or other expansion projects.
"I think it really is going to be important for us to look at what are the pros and cons of each of these models, look at where we are and look at what is needed in the future," PennDOT Secretary Leslie Hoffman said. "I think these models really need to be considered in the next five to ten years, rather than looking 20 years into the future."
paraphrase:
A recent report by the Pew Center on the States has warned states against rushing into leasing their existing road assets to the private sector. The report, released on Tuesday, March 24, urges states considering public-private partnerships for infrastructure to exercise caution and carefully weigh the potential benefits and drawbacks.
The report highlights the importance of considering alternative private investment vehicles, such as special purpose vehicles, joint ventures, and revenue sharing from toll road projects. However, it also notes that states should be mindful of possible negative outcomes, especially in light of current financial pressures.
In Pennsylvania, PennDOT is working with its partners to develop a state-level report on how private partners could help address local transportation needs. The report will explore options such as toll roads, alternative uses of revenue, and local share of revenue. Additionally, PennDOT is exploring the use of toll revenue for projects like the I-95-Southeastern Extension or other expansion projects.
According to PennDOT Secretary Leslie Hoffman, it is crucial for states to carefully consider the pros and cons of each model and look at what is needed in the future. Hoffman believes that these models should be considered in the next five to ten years rather than 20 years into the future.

input: LOS ANGELES  The primary backer of an effort to get a ban on circumcision on the ballot in Santa Monica is abandoning her push, saying the proposed legislation had been misrepresented as an effort to impinge on religious freedom. A similar measure in San
continuation:
Francisco will move forward.

Cora Tilton, president of the Women of Valor chapter, said she is abandoning her push because her intention was never to infringe on religious freedom. Tilton, a former Marine Corps infantry officer, said she just wanted to ensure people were educated.

It seems like the city is misrepresenting what were doing, Tilton said. I just want to inform people of what it really is.

Tilton said the organization will pursue its own measure in 2022. The group, which is backed by an Orthodox Jewish mother and a male member of Congress, was attempting to force passage of a law in L.A. County. That proposal was also put on the ballot this year, and was defeated. But advocates in other jurisdictions are looking at similar options.

On Monday, Tilton announced she is abandoning her push. The reason was unclear, and could not immediately be confirmed. The L.A. chapter will hold a news conference, she said, later this week.

Tiltons campaign was backed in part by Rep. Ken Calvert, R-Corona. He described Tilton in a news
paraphrase:
Cora Tilton, the leader of the Women of Valor chapter, has announced that she is abandoning her effort to ban circumcision in Santa Monica due to concerns that the proposed legislation has been misrepresented as an attack on religious freedom. Despite the setback, similar measures are still moving forward in other cities, including San Francisco.
Tilton, a former Marine Corps infantry officer, revealed that her intention was never to infringe on religious freedom, but rather to educate the public about the issue. However, she feels that the city has misrepresented the group's efforts and plans to pursue her own measure in 2022.
The organization is backed by an Orthodox Jewish mother and a male member of Congress, and their goal is to pass a law in L.A. County. Although their proposal was defeated in this year's ballot, advocates in other areas are exploring similar options.
On Monday, Tilton announced that she is abandoning her campaign, and the reasons for this decision remain unclear. The L.A. chapter will hold a news conference later this week to provide further details.
Rep. Ken Calvert, R-Corona, has been a vocal supporter of Tilton's campaign, describing her as a dedicated advocate for the cause. Despite the setback, Calvert remains optimistic about the future of the movement.

input:
Ocala Walmart shooting: Pictured, David Johnson.
Ocala Walmart shooting: Pictured, David Johnson, alleged individual who sho dead, Carli Cronin.
Ocala Walmart shooting: Carli Cronin shot and killed
continuation:
, her brother. Facebook photo.
A man killed three people, including his mother, in an apparent shooting rampage at a Walmart in Ocala, authorities said.
Carli Cronin, 24, was one of those killed in the shooting, which occurred just before 7 p.m. Saturday in the Walmart Supercenter at 8600 NW 36th St. in Ocala, said Scott Strenge, chief deputy for the Marion County Sheriffs Office.
The suspected shooter, identified as David Johnson, 46, was also found dead in the shooting, Strenge said. Two of Johnsons daughters were injured in the shooting, he said. Johnson, who worked for Avis Budget Group, was the son of his wifes cousin, Strenge said. Johnson was born in Georgia, he said. He declined to say whether Johnsons wife was also in the Walmart, but said authorities are looking into whether she was in the area at the time of the shooting.
Cronin, according to her mother, was her daughters godmother, according to The Record. Cronin was killed in her car in which she was driving, her mother said.
paraphrase:
The Ocala Walmart shooting resulted in the tragic loss of three lives, including that of the suspected shooter, David Johnson. Pictured, Johnson and Carli Cronin, one of the victims. Johnson's daughters were also injured in the incident. According to authorities, the shooting occurred around 7 pm on Saturday at the Walmart Supercenter on NW 36th St in Ocala.
Carli Cronin, a 24-year-old victim, was mourned by her family and friends, including her mother, who described her as her daughter's godmother. Cronin was killed in her car, where she was driving at the time of the shooting.
The suspected shooter, David Johnson, 46, was also found dead in the shooting. Johnson, who worked for Avis Budget Group, was the son of his wife's cousin, according to authorities. The motive behind the shooting remains unclear, but authorities are investigating whether Johnson's wife was in the area at the time of the incident.
The Ocala Walmart shooting is a heart-wrenching reminder of the devastating consequences of gun violence, leaving behind families and loved ones forever changed.

input: The Promise: Using the Apple device's built-in accelerometers, the Dynolicious application measures vehicle acceleration (0-60 mph, 1/4-mile trap speed and elapsed time, etc), and cornering and braking grip. With that
continuation:
information, Dynolicious can create custom courses with variable obstacles, terrain obstacles and courses with or without obstacles or terrain.

How it works: The application allows users to track various car characteristics like wheel weight, power plant, engine, engine performance, wheel vibration, brake power, steering performance, gear ratios, air pressure, air temperature, air temperature, wheel braking force, engine power, transmission pressure, transmission torque, air pressure, brake pressure, engine torque, engine speed, engine revs, transmission ratio, transmission shift, powertrain temperature, brake temperature, gear ratio, engine power, transmission torque, transmission ratio, transmission shift, engine speed, engine revs, transmission ratio, engine torque, engine power, transmission ratio, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, engine speed, engine revs, transmission ratio, transmission shift, engine torque, engine power, transmission ratio, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift, transmission shift
paraphrase:
Using the Apple device's integrated accelerometers, the Dynolicious application measures vehicle acceleration, cornering, and braking grip. With this data, Dynolicious generates custom courses featuring variable obstacles, terrain obstacles, and courses without any obstacles or terrain.
The application allows users to track various car characteristics, including wheel weight, power plant, engine, engine performance, wheel vibration, brake power, steering performance, gear ratios, air pressure, air temperature, brake temperature, and more.
By utilizing the Apple device's built-in accelerometers, Dynolicious provides a comprehensive analysis of the car's performance, including engine power, transmission torque, transmission ratio, and more. The application also allows users to monitor the car's temperature, air pressure, and brake pressure, providing a detailed overview of the vehicle's overall performance.
In addition, Dynolicious offers users the ability to customize their courses with variable obstacles, terrain obstacles, and courses without any obstacles or terrain. This allows users to test their driving skills and push their vehicles to the limit.
Overall, Dynolicious provides a cutting-edge solution for car enthusiasts who want to analyze and improve their driving skills, while also offering a unique and engaging experience for those who enjoy racing and car culture.

input: Shopify (NYSE: SHOP) is the poster boy for growth stocks: Shares of the cloud-based e-commerce platform have returned a staggering 441% since listing in mid-2015. It's not easy to replicate
continuation:
this kind of growth, but this could be a new generation of growth-oriented startups, which don't typically need the money.

These types of startups typically look to tap into other, larger opportunities, or try new things. That said, Shopify is a company that is simply following its own business model. It has already demonstrated success in e-commerce, as demonstrated in this chart:

The chart above shows how much more Shopify is growing, despite growth slowing due to rising competition, with revenue growing at its slowest rate in a year in Q2. The e-commerce company is also still generating profits, which gives it considerable wiggle room when it comes to using share buybacks to increase its stock price. (And, of course, the company is profitable due in large part to its massive cash hoard of $716 million.) That is, its stock is still cheap.

And that, of course, is where the growth investors are focused. For investors looking to pick stocks, it is important to look beyond current profits and growth. For investors looking to buy these growth stocks, they need to focus on growth with profit. Shopify is one of those companies.

Analy
paraphrase:
Shopify (NYSE: SHOP) is a prime example of a growth stock, having returned an impressive 441% since its mid-2015 listing. However, replicating this type of growth may prove challenging, as this new generation of growth-oriented startups often has access to alternative avenues for expansion. Shopify, however, has managed to thrive in the e-commerce space, as evident in the following chart:
The chart illustrates how Shopify's growth has slowed due to increasing competition, yet the company still manages to generate profits, providing ample room for share buybacks to boost its stock price. Moreover, its massive cash reserve of $716 million significantly contributes to its profitability. This is particularly crucial for investors seeking growth stocks, as they must consider a company's capacity for long-term growth and profitability beyond its current profits. Shopify is an excellent representation of this approach.

Serena Williams returns a shot during a match at the Western & Southern Open tennis tournament in Mason, Ohio.
For the first time in a long time there is actually more than a modicum of interest in the women's side of a Grand

input: At 29, Gretchen Daily is a rising star of population biology. She works at both UC-Berkeleys Energy and Resources Group and Stanford Universitys Center for Conservation Biology on a fellowship specifically created for her. Daily recently made
continuation:
a significant career shift when she left the former to start the latter, which is currently funding her work. (And if she didnt need more reasons to love the world, she will get to talk about it this afternoon at TEDxBerkeley.)

At 28, she became the first member of her graduate school class (an honors thesis) to graduate with honors. The degree was earned by working her way through grad school, which began in August of 2016 when she received her bachelors degree in biology from UC-Berkeley. Now shes working on a masters degree in Population Biology.

It was important to me that I didnt end up like my professor, she says, so I was like, Oh, I should get a graduate degree.

But when it came time for her to find a masters program, she didnt find what she was looking for. The only program she found was the one she already was going to, so she did it. A few months later, she ended up back in her former job.

I kind of didn
paraphrase:
At 29, Gretchen Daily is a rising star in the field of population biology, with dual appointments at UC Berkeley's Energy and Resources Group and Stanford University's Center for Conservation Biology. She was recently awarded a fellowship specifically tailored to her work. Daily made a notable career shift by leaving her former position to start her own venture, which is currently funding her research. (She will also be discussing her work this afternoon at TEDxBerkeley.)
At just 28 years old, Daily became the first member of her graduate school class to graduate with honors. She earned her bachelor's degree in biology from UC Berkeley in August 2016 and is now working on a master's degree in population biology.
Daily's decision to pursue a graduate degree was driven by a desire to avoid following in the footsteps of her professor. "I didn't want to end up like my professor," she remarks. Despite not finding the perfect master's program, Daily ended up back in her former job a few months later.
In her own words, Daily "kind of fell back into" her previous role, but her current pursuits are setting her on a new path in the field of population biology.

input:
The Massachusetts baseball team was looking to build some momentum heading into the final stretch of the 2016 by winning its second to last nonconference game remaining on the schedule Wednesday afternoon in Lowell.
The Minutemen got down early with UMass Lowell scoring two
continuation:
runs in the first inning off freshman Mike Kravchenko, but the Minutemen were able to claw back, thanks in large part to three hits off of junior Andrew Scott, tying the game in the third.
After giving back an early lead, the Minutemen were able to put together a complete game victory in a 6-1 win over the visiting River Hawks.
It was the third straight win for Boston College, which is just one win shy of tying its school record with its fifth win in six games.
Kravchenko was pitching in his first collegiate game and came into the game with a 6.42 ERA this season, allowing 23 runs in just 8.1 innings.
The freshman was looking for his first collegiate win, although he ended up with six strikeouts, allowing one earned run. He was also credited with six hits allowed in 8.1 innings.
Junior Michael Ynoa, also pitching in his first collegiate game, was able to keep things even with Scott. Ynoa faced just three hitters and allowed one earned run in 3.1 innings. He recorded two strikeouts, allowed just one hit, while giving up one earned run.
Senior Brett Haller was also able to find success
paraphrase:
The Massachusetts baseball team was eager to gain momentum heading into the final stretch of the 2016 season by securing a crucial victory in their second-to-last nonconference game on Wednesday afternoon in Lowell.
The Minutemen found themselves in an early deficit, as UMass Lowell tallied two runs in the first inning against freshman pitcher Mike Kravchenko. However, the Minutemen fought back valiantly, thanks in large part to three timely hits off of junior pitcher Andrew Scott, tying the game in the third inning.
Boston College was able to put together a complete game victory, emerging with a 6-1 win over the visiting River Hawks.
It was the third consecutive win for the Eagles, who are now just one victory shy of tying their school record with their fifth win in six games.
Kravchenko, making his collegiate debut, showed promise with six strikeouts and six hits allowed in 8.1 innings, despite a 6.42 ERA this season.
Junior pitcher Michael Ynoa, also making his debut, kept things even with Scott, allowing one earned run in 3.1 innings with two strikeouts and just one hit allowed.
Senior pitcher Brett Haller also contributed to the team's success, recording two strikeouts and allowing just one earned run in his outing.

Class A No. 6 Lincoln Southwest dominated city rival Lincoln North Star 7-0 on Tuesday in boys soccer. Isaiah Shaddick netted three goals for the Silver Hawks, while Luke Monson recorded two assists.
Southwest goalkeepers Dylan Trid

input:
Hamid Ismailovs EBRD Literature Prize-winning Uzbek novel puts Central Asian literature in focus.
On December 31, 1937, 20th-century Uzbekistans most popular novelist, Abdulla Qodir
continuation: , wrote his masterpiece, Leningrad. Today, with a novel written in Uzbek language called Atabek-Akh, he is hailed in Uzbekistan as a national hero. His novel, which is based on the life of Soviet dissident-turned-activist Lev Onashov, has been translated into over 20 languages and sold around the world. It is one of Atabek-Akhs more contemporary works, one that places Central Asian culture in the wider world. The novel focuses on Onashovs rise from working-class village life in rural Kazakhstan in 1905 to his eventual imprisonment, in Siberia, in 1917. It follows Onashovs imprisonment, his death, and his aftermath. The novels central plot concerns the lives of three young characters: Onashov, his wife (Sariya), and her mother (Agha), with whom Onashov stays after he is released from Siberia. The novels portrayal of these characters is one of Uzbekistans major export products: Atabek-Akh focuses on its three characters and, despite its modernistic setting, gives little indication of its social status. For Uzbekistan, At
paraphrase:
Abdulla Qodir's award-winning Uzbek novel sheds light on Central Asian literature.
On December 31, 1937, a renowned Uzbek writer of the 20th century, Abdulla Qodir, penned his magnum opus, Leningrad. Today, his latest work, Atabek-Akh, is hailed as a national treasure in Uzbekistan. This novel, written in the Uzbek language, has been translated into numerous languages and gained popularity worldwide. It is one of Atabek-Akhs more contemporary works, offering a fresh perspective on Central Asian culture. The novel follows the life of Lev Onashov, a Soviet dissident turned activist, from his humble beginnings in a rural Kazakhstani village in 1905 to his imprisonment in Siberia in 1917. The story then delves into Onashov's captivity, his ultimate demise, and the aftermath of his legacy. The novel's central plot revolves around the lives of three young characters: Onashov, his wife Sariya, and her mother Agha, whom he befriends upon his release from Siberia. Unlike many contemporary works, Atabek-Akh provides an in-depth portrayal of these characters, highlighting Uzbekistan's cultural exports. Despite its modern setting, the novel offers little indication of the characters' social standing, further solidifying Uzbekistan's literary reputation.

input: THE economic plan being chartered during the ongoing 2017-2018 budget debate aims to stabilise the countrys finances, Deputy Prime Minister K Peter Turnquest said yesterday, as he underscored the continued need to reduce discretionary spending
continuation:
.

Turnquest made the remarks in the House of Representatives when responding to members concerns raised about the size of government expenditure in 2017-18.

It is, therefore, important that the government, in this years spending program, focuses on improving government spending, he said.

Turnquests remarks came in response to concerns from members of both major political parties about what they described as what the Ministry of Finance is proposing.

There are many things in the document, which is quite frankly quite wide in its approach, Turnquest said.

It is, therefore, important that it is, I think, prudent for the government, when we are putting this program together, in order to understand what is the spending priorities in terms of government spending, he said.

Turnquest said government expenditure will be reduced as expenditure is rationalized.

In terms of government expenditure, it is important that government expenditure is rationalized, he said.

Turnquest said it is prudent in the current environment where public finances are challenging, with expenditure projections, to reduce discretionary spending in this year
paraphrase: The government's 2017-2018 budget proposal aims to stabilize the country's finances by reducing discretionary spending, Deputy Prime Minister K Peter Turnquest emphasized during a House of Representatives debate. Addressing concerns from members of both major political parties, Turnquest highlighted the need for the government to prioritize its spending in order to understand the allocation of resources. He acknowledged that expenditure projections are challenging in the current environment and emphasized the importance of rationalizing government spending to ensure fiscal sustainability. Turnquest underscored the need for the government to be prudent in its spending, particularly in light of the ongoing budget debate.

input:
Media|Trump to Skip Correspondents Dinner. But Talk Radio? Hes In.
Trump to Skip Correspondents Dinner. But Talk Radio? Hes In.
Donny from D.C., you
continuation: re looking at a major upset in this weeks presidential debate. Last night, president-elect Trump refused to participate in the White House Correspondents Association dinner, opting instead to appear on stage alongside newly elected Gov. Mike Pence (R-IN) in lieu of dinner hosts. And, while it was only his second choice, he was still one of the only guests in attendance. But in his place, we were left with the new faces of talk radio: Rush Limbaugh, Sean Hannity, and Bill Kristol. A major win in the 2016 election, in other words, from a president-elect. Here are highlights from the big event, with one notable exception: radio talk-show hosts. (See video, above.)
paraphrase:
Trump Abstains from White House Correspondents' Dinner, but Talk Radio Shines.
In a surprise move, President-elect Trump opted to skip the annual White House Correspondents' Association dinner, instead choosing to appear on stage with newly elected Vice President Mike Pence (R-IN). While some may see this as a snub to the traditional dinner, it instead highlights the growing influence of talk radio hosts in shaping the political landscape. Leading figures such as Rush Limbaugh, Sean Hannity, and Bill Kristol were in attendance, bringing their unique perspectives and opinions to the forefront. Despite Trump's absence, the talk radio hosts proved to be the real stars of the evening, offering a fresh perspective on the election and its aftermath. (Watch video above for highlights.)

input:
A GP clinic in Edinburgh which is changing to a telephone assessment system three days a week has warned its 6,000 patients they could be turned away.
The changes at the Links Medical Centre come into force on Wednesday, May 1.
A statement
continuation:
said: "The decision was made in order to meet current demands on NHS services which are already stretched.
"We understand it will inconvenience many of our patients but it is needed if NHS staff are to meet demand. We are sorry."
A GP practice in Edinburgh which is changing to a telephone assessment system three days a week has warned its 6,000 patients they could be turned away. The changes come into force on Wednesday, May 1. (Credit: Splashnews.com) More
Dr Stuart Kitching said it was important NHS staff could meet increasing demands.
"It is important that we are able to meet demands of growing demand, including in GP practices.
"As many people are aware, this year will see more people with cancer, chronic conditions, and other conditions. The more people are seen, the easier it is to treat them. We feel this is an important step in that direction."
The new system will see a GP clinic "offer" an appointment from 8am to 8pm weekdays. The appointment time will be set for the patient in advance, which will help them avoid waiting times.
It will also see GP appointments made available 24/7, seven days a week.
Read more:
paraphrase: A Edinburgh GP clinic is introducing a telephone assessment system three days a week, warning its 6,000 patients they may be turned away. The change comes into effect on May 1 and is intended to meet growing demands on NHS services. Dr. Stuart Kitching emphasizes the importance of meeting increasing demands, particularly in GP practices, as the number of people with cancer, chronic conditions, and other ailments continues to rise. The new system will offer appointments from 8am to 8pm Monday through Friday, with the appointment time set in advance to minimize waiting times. Additionally, GP appointments will be available 24/7, seven days a week. (Source: Edinburgh GP Clinic to Introduce Telephone Assessment System)

age Chiles, Austin's Jake Treso, Houston's Hunter Williams, Lakewood Ranch's Tanner Morris, Lonestar's Drew McElwee and Shreveport's T.J. Williams were among the winners of 2018. Here are highlights of the 2018 winners, plus other awards:

The female/female winners will go to Lakewood Ranch High School, where it will be judged by members from Houston High School. Both winners will move onto Houston High School.
In the female
paraphrase:
This year's Rodeo Uncorked! Best Bites competition is bringing back some familiar faces in the judging process, with behind-the-scenes changes elevating certain winners from previous years into the spotlight. Here are some highlights of the 2018 winners, along with other notable awards:
Pearland's Gage Chiles, Austin's Jake Treso, Houston's Hunter Williams, Lakewood Ranch's Tanner Morris, Lonestar's Drew McElwee, and Shreveport's T.J. Williams were among the winners of 2018. input:
LOWER PAXTON TOWNSHIP, DAUPHIN COUNTY, Pa. - Police are reminding people of the importance of reporting crimes to police and not just posting about them on social media.
If you're a social media user,
continuation:
you've probably heard the phrase "You only live once". But, what happens when the life you're living is under constant scrutiny from social media? It's called "Living on Social Media" and police departments are taking notice.
Police are reminding people of the importance of reporting crimes when they happen.
Police said the trend of sharing photos of crimes with people who are only sharing it in hopes of getting them in trouble, puts victims in danger. Police are reminding people of the importance of reporting crimes when it happens.
"We're concerned about putting people in harm's way by sharing these types of things, especially something that happened within their neighborhood, within their community, which is even if it was someone in an apartment, or in someone's home, it's really important to us, that the victims know what happened, what was said, what was done, so they can feel safe with what happened in their neighborhood, in their community," said Upper Dauphin Township Police Chief Michael Kellett.
Police said social media posts like these are often times just making people feel uncomfortable. Kellett said it's important for victims of crimes to feel like they have support from their community.
"It's really important that
paraphrase:
In Lower Paxton Township, Dauphin County, Pennsylvania, police are urging residents to report crimes directly to them instead of only sharing them on social media. The trend of posting about crimes on social media, known as "Living on Social Media," can put victims in danger and hinder the investigation process.
Police Chief Michael Kellett emphasized the importance of providing victims with information about the crime, including what happened, what was said, and what was done. He stressed that victims should feel supported by their community, and that social media posts can often create an uncomfortable atmosphere.
Kellett urged residents to prioritize the safety of victims by reporting crimes directly to the police, rather than relying on social media for information. By doing so, victims can feel more secure and supported in their community.
In summary, the police are encouraging residents to take an active role in ensuring the safety of their community by reporting crimes directly to them, rather than sharing them on social media. This approach helps to protect victims and ensure a more effective investigation process.

input: Erin Cordray is radiography program director at Community College of Baltimore County. What does a radiographer's job entail? Radiography uses X-ray radiation to create images of the tissues, organs, bones and vessels that make up the human
continuation: body. The images help doctors find cancer, disease and trauma. A few years ago, she was working at the hospital, but found her interest in teaching led her to join the College of Radiology faculty. She is one of two new faculty members from around the country recruited from medical colleges. The other is from Arizona, where he will teach in the School of Imaging Technology. (Wesley L. Phillips/for The Washington Post)
paraphrase: Erin Cordray is the director of the radiography program at Community College of Baltimore County. Can you tell us what a radiographer's job entails? Radiography uses X-rays to create images of the tissues, organs, bones, and vessels inside the human body. These images help doctors diagnose and treat diseases, including cancer, injuries, and trauma. A few years ago, Cordray was working as a hospital radiographer, but her passion for teaching led her to join the faculty of the College of Radiology. She is one of two new faculty members from across the country who were recruited from medical schools to teach in the School of Imaging Technology. (Wesley L. Phillips/for The Washington Post)

input:
Immensely wealthy and powerful men like Peter Thiel and Elon Musk want to live forever. But at what cost?
In a 2011 New Yorker profile, Peter Thiel, tech-philanthropist and billionaire, surmised that probably the
continuation:
only downside is that you get sort of lonely. He went on to say, youre going to want something more in life, just like the average human. But according to researchers, its exactly this desire for companionship and fulfilment  rather than solitude  that is making us crave immortality.
Thiel, who is one of the early proponents of the idea that technology could be harnessed to extend human life, recently wrote that, Technology is poised to change human existence forever. But in other ways, hes been far from a voice of reason.
In 2015, while running a Silicon Valley startup called Palantir, he hired his brother-in-law, Mat Kaltenborn, a veteran Silicon Valley executive, to run his foundation. At that time, Kaltenborn co-founded a startup called NeuroSky, which is developing advanced brain-computer interfaces that will enable people to control robotics with just their thinking. Kaltenborn also co-founded The Neuro, which is a tech incubator based in Silicon Valley. Kaltenborn is also one of the co-founders of The Neuroradiology Institute, which is conducting
paraphrase:
Wealthy and influential individuals like Peter Thiel and Elon Musk crave immortality, but at what cost? In a 2011 New Yorker profile, Thiel suggested that the only downside may be feeling lonely, as one would still desire fulfillment and companionship. However, researchers argue that it is the desire for human connection rather than solitude that drives this desire for immortality.
Thiel, a prominent advocate for harnessing technology to extend human life, has stated that technology is poised to revolutionize human existence. Yet, he has been criticized for his unreasonable views, such as hiring his brother-in-law, Mat Kaltenborn, to run his foundation while running a Silicon Valley startup called Palantir. Kaltenborn has co-founded several companies, including NeuroSky, which is developing advanced brain-computer interfaces to control robotics with thoughts, and The Neuroradiology Institute, which is conducting research in the field.
While Thiel's ambition is admirable, it is essential to consider the ethical implications of extending human life indefinitely. The desire for immortality may lead to unrealistic expectations and unethical means of achieving it. It is crucial to have a balanced approach to technology and to prioritize the well-being of individuals and society as a whole.

input:
Now that flood waters have begun to recede, Texas victims of Tropical Storm Harvey face another challenge: eviction notices. Even worse, some people are still on the hook for rent on apartments they cant live in.
Sheri Ilo
continuation:
zas friend, Emily Rinaldi, was among many Houstonians who took in her mother after she became homeless when her roof was blown off by Harvey. Rinaldi also took in Ilozas son. But Ilozas lease is ending soon. Now, she faces eviction from her apartment in Cypress, and shes looking for a new place, too. Iloza doesnt expect to find anything before January, when her lease ends. But if she cant find a new place, she says, she will be left homeless.
I dont know what Im going to do, Iloza says. I feel like I am going to have nowhere to go.
Evictions can hurt people with little income  which is often the case in Harveys aftermath. It also hits people like Iloza hard. It costs more to live in a neighborhood where people dont want to live, she says. Now she faces eviction, she says, in addition to losing her home.
A look at the aftermath of Harvey in Houston
Since Harvey, tens of
paraphrase:
As the floodwaters recede in Texas, Tropical Storm Harvey's victims are facing a new challenge: eviction notices. Many individuals, including Sheri Iloza's friend Emily Rinaldi, have taken in relatives who became homeless after their homes were damaged or destroyed by the storm. However, these good Samaritans are now facing the possibility of eviction themselves, as their leases are set to expire soon. Iloza, in particular, is struggling to find a new place to live, as her lease in Cypress is ending soon and she doesn't expect to find anything before January. If she can't find a new place, she fears she will be left homeless.
Evictions can be particularly difficult for those with limited financial resources, which is often the case in the aftermath of a disaster like Harvey. For Iloza, the situation is particularly challenging, as she faces eviction in addition to losing her home. She believes that living in a neighborhood where people don't want to live costs more, making it even harder to find affordable housing.
Overall, the aftermath of Harvey in Houston has brought new challenges for those affected, including the threat of eviction. Tens of thousands of people have been displaced by the storm, and the process of rebuilding and recovery is expected to be long and difficult.

input:
The island lifestyle may have unknown benefits, as Hawaii residents are the only ones in the country with an average life expectancy of 81 years.
Experts recommend that adults get at least seven hours of sleep per night, but 44.7% of Hawaiians
continuation:
get fewer than six hours of sleep, according to 20162017 Sleep in Hawaii Surveys. Thats nearly twice the average national average of 30.6%, which means people are spending extra time in bed or using other methods to try to get more sleep.
Some are still trying. A survey released in January from the Sleep Foundation, Sleep in Hawaii, found that 42% of adults in Hawaii said getting seven or more hours of sleep per night was important, compared to only 7% of US adults. Nearly 30% of Hawaiian adults get fewer than seven hours of sleep per night.
In 2016, a new Hawaii initiative called Sleep Matters Hawaii asked respondents if theyd like to help increase sleep quality in Hawaii. It found that 64% of Hawaiian adults want state lawmakers to pass policies that promote sleep, while 28% of Hawaii adults want more sleep-related laws. About 30% of respondents said they are currently sleep-deprived.
Its hard to sleep when things are going so well. And thats a myth. We need sleep, said Rachel Rolfe, executive director of the Sleep Foundation. The truth is, people are getting too little sleep,
paraphrase:
While the Hawaiian lifestyle may hold some hidden advantages, the state's residents are the only ones in the country with an average life expectancy of 81 years. However, a recent survey found that a significant portion of Hawaiians, 44.7%, get less than six hours of sleep per night, which is nearly twice the national average of 30.6%. This suggests that people in Hawaii may be struggling to get the quality sleep they need.
According to a survey conducted by the Sleep Foundation, a notable 42% of Hawaiian adults consider getting seven or more hours of sleep per night to be crucial, while only 7% of US adults share this sentiment. However, despite this awareness, nearly 30% of Hawaiian adults still get fewer than seven hours of sleep each night.
In 2016, a Hawaii-based initiative called Sleep Matters Hawaii surveyed respondents on their sleep habits and found that 64% of Hawaiian adults support state lawmakers passing policies that promote sleep, while 28% want more sleep-related laws. Moreover, around 30% of the respondents reported feeling sleep-deprived.
Despite the state's seemingly idyllic lifestyle, it appears that getting adequate sleep remains a challenge for many Hawaiians. As Rachel Rolfe, executive director of the Sleep Foundation, notes, "We need sleep." It's important to prioritize sleep to maintain good health and well-being.

input: Its no secret that ride-hailing company Uber has been concerned about its competitors in the race to build autonomous cars. But text messages released as part of Ubers ongoing litigation with Googles self-driving car project
continuation:
show that Ubers concerns about rivals may go beyond just its own.

In September 2016, according to court records, Ubers president of engineering sent an email to his teammates in which he outlined some of Googles shortcomings. He wrote, in part: Google seems to believe that its autonomous vehicles are here to stay. I dont agree with that. He also wrote: At least it seems like Google is making this happen We just need to convince them its worth it.

And in April of 2018, Ubers head of car program, Andrew MacFarlane, sent an email, according to court records, with a copy of an email sent by his colleague, Mike Schroepfer, discussing Ubers concerns with Googles new automated driving car. Ubers software engineer described Schroepfers email, which he called the worst email Ive seen from Google in decades, as something in which Googles head of software wrote: Ubers in big trouble. The engineer also accused Googles
paraphrase: It appears that Uber has been focused on rival companies in the autonomous vehicle race, particularly Google. According to text messages revealed in Uber's ongoing litigation, the company's president of engineering expressed concerns about Google's self-driving car project in 2016, suggesting that Uber does not believe Google's technology is a long-term solution. In one email, the president wrote that Google seems to think its autonomous vehicles are here to stay, but he disagrees. In another email, the head of Uber's car program expressed concerns about Google's new automated driving car, with a colleague describing the email as "the worst I've seen from Google in decades." Despite these concerns, Uber has been working to improve its own autonomous vehicle technology and compete with its rivals in the market.

input:
An NYPD administrative judge and its firearms review panel criticized the conduct of three police officers involved in the 2012 shooting death of a Bronx 18-year-old, records obtained by the Daily News show.
The judge's decision involving Officer Richard Haste, who
continuation:
shot Gregory Bell in the head on Dec. 6, 2012, was unusual  he found Haste violated Bell's Fourth Amendment rights. The panel found Haste did not need to use deadly force.
In the panel's report, the NYPD said it found evidence in Bell's body of his violent criminal past. The NYPD said Haste violated Bell's Fourth Amendment rights when he saw him, while Bell was armed, in his doorway. Bell, who was carrying a small, plastic handgun, was attempting to flee. He dropped his gun when he saw Officer James Clark approach. Haste used deadly force to get him under control, according to police. Bell died from his gunshot wound.
H Haste, Bell 'were armed and running from me,' NYPD administrative judge found Officer Richard Haste violated the teenager's Fourth Amendment rights when he saw him, while he was armed, in his doorway, according to police.
Clark was charged in Bell's death in 2015 with second-degree manslaughter and second-degree criminal possession of a controlled substance. paraphrase:
An NYPD administrative judge and its firearms review panel have criticized the actions of three police officers involved in the 2012 shooting death of an 18-year-old Bronx man, according to records obtained by the Daily News.
The judge's decision involving Officer Richard Haste, who shot the man in the head, was unusual as he found Haste violated the man's Fourth Amendment rights. The panel found Haste did not need to use deadly force.
In the panel's report, the NYPD revealed that it found evidence of the man's criminal past in his body. Haste violated the man's Fourth Amendment rights when he saw him, who was armed, in his doorway, according to police. The man, who was carrying a small handgun, was attempting to flee when he was shot by Haste. He died from his gunshot wound.
Haste found the man and Bell were armed and running from him, the NYPD administrative judge found. Officer Richard Haste violated the teenager's Fourth Amendment rights when he saw him, who was armed, in his doorway, according to police.
Officer James Clark was charged in Bell's death in 2015 with second-degree manslaughter and second-degree criminal possession of a controlled substance. Clark was acquitted of murder in April 2018 when the case was dropped without prejudice. Clark was also charged with second-degree attempted murder. The NYPD declined to comment on the matter.

input: The Fleurieu & Kangaroo Island Region 7 hosted its annual Champion of Champions match last Saturday at Yankalilla Bowling Club on what turned out to be a great day for bowls. In the Men's Fours, the Kangaroo
continuation: Island Senior League played off one side with one handicap. Both sides took the match with ease, beating the other by a score of 125-94. The match was led by Bill Hall and Ben Rimmer with scores of 32-10-0-18, 42-18-0-37. Both were also members of The Adelaide Club.In the Women's Fours, Yankalilla played off with one handicap, with Yankalilla Senior League members Barbara Hall with scores of 45-23-0-31, 41-16-0-36, 36-23-0-35, 42-28-0-38. The Kangaroo Island Senior League took the match with scores of 123-61-0-51. Barbara Hall and Joan Rimmer were joint winners of the ladies matches. paraphrase: The Fleurieu and Kangaroo Island Region 7 hosted their annual Champion of Champions match last Saturday at Yankalilla Bowling Club, where the sun shone brightly. In the Men's Fours, both sides emerged victorious with scores of 125-94, led by Bill Hall and Ben Rimmer with impressive scores of 32-10-0-18 and 42-18-0-37, respectively. They are also members of The Adelaide Club. The Women's Fours saw Yankalilla play with one handicap, with Barbara Hall recording scores of 45-23-0-31, 41-16-0-36, 36-23-0-35, and 42-28-0-38. The Kangaroo Island Senior League took the match with scores of 123-61-0-51, with Barbara Hall and Joan Rimmer being joint winners of the ladies' matches. input: BlackBerry Ltd. has signed a deal to acquire U.S. artificial intelligence and cybersecurity company Cylance for US$1.4 billion in cash. The Ontario-based company called Cylance a pioneer in applying artificial intelligence, algorithmic
continuation:
detection, cybersecurity, natural language generation and human analytics in the enterprise.
In addition to adding software applications, BlackBerry will use artificial intelligence and machine learning to automate cyber-security investigations, cybersecurity incident response, regulatory compliance, enterprise application security and privacy investigations. BlackBerry will also use Cylance's technologies, which also include machine learning, "for its mobile application security strategy, enterprise mobility management strategy, and mobile device management strategy."
"Cylance's deep expertise in cybersecurity detection will accelerate BlackBerry's mobile application security strategy, enterprise mobility management strategy, and mobile device management strategy," said BlackBerry CEO John Chen. "Cylance is an ideal partner to further strengthen BlackBerry's enterprise-class cybersecurity suite."
Cylance is working with more than 20 enterprise customers, including 20 of the Fortune 100. The company is growing fast, with more than 350 employees, mostly based in San Francisco. "As an early investor in BlackBerry, it is an honor to join them in this next phase of BlackBerrys evolution," said Cylance CEO Jeff Clarke in a press release. "Our technology is making an important difference in protecting companies critical assets.
Chen is also looking toward further international expansion. BlackBerry is already
paraphrase:
BlackBerry Ltd. has secured a deal to acquire U.S.-based Cylance, a leading AI and cybersecurity company, for $1.4 billion in cash. Based in Ontario, Cylance is renowned for its innovative approaches to AI, algorithmic detection, cybersecurity, natural language processing, and human analytics in the enterprise.
With the acquisition, BlackBerry plans to integrate Cylance's cutting-edge technologies into its software applications, leveraging AI and machine learning to automate cybersecurity investigations, incident response, regulatory compliance, and privacy investigations. The company will also utilize Cylance's expertise to enhance its mobile application security, enterprise mobility management, and mobile device management strategies.
BlackBerry CEO John Chen believes that Cylance's robust capabilities will significantly augment BlackBerry's enterprise-grade cybersecurity offerings. "Cylance's exceptional talent in cybersecurity detection will accelerate BlackBerry's mobile application security, enterprise mobility management, and mobile device management strategies," Chen said. "Cylance is an ideal partner to further strengthen BlackBerry's cybersecurity suite."
Cylance is currently working with over 20 enterprise customers, including 20 of the Fortune 100. With a workforce of over 350 employees primarily based in San Francisco, the company is experiencing rapid growth. "As an early investor in BlackBerry, it is an honor to join them in this next phase of their evolution," said Cylance CEO Jeff Clarke in a press release. "Our technology is making a meaningful contribution to protecting companies' critical assets."
Chen also expressed interest in expanding BlackBerry's international presence. With existing operations in over 175 countries, BlackBerry aims to further expand its global reach.

input: MEDELLIN, Colombia  Chiles Palestino qualified for the third round of the Copa Libertadores on Tuesday after beating Colombian side Independiente Medellin on penalties to win the second leg of the second round at
continuation:
Estadio Atletico Paranaense. The Chileans will next face Ecuadors Independiente. The winners of Chile-Indy will meet in the third round. Chile leads the aggregate scoreline 3-1.

Brazils Fluminense earned its second successive second-round berth in the Copa Libertadores when it edged Ecuadorian side Ecuadorian in a penalty shoot-out in Tuesdays second leg at Estadio Atletico Mineiro. The match ended 1-1 after extra time. Fluminense will next meet Argentinas River Plate. Fluminense leads the aggregate scoreline 3-0.

Colombian side Independiente Medellin drew with Brazils Internacional in the second leg of their second-round tie in Ecuador. The match ended in a 1-1 draw in Ecuador. Independiente Medellin will next meet Ecuadors Independiente in the second round. The match will be played in Ecuador. Independiente Medellin leads the aggregate scoreline 3-1.

Chiles Palestino qualified for the third round of the Copa
paraphrase:
Medellin, Colombia - Palestino advanced to the third round of the Copa Libertadores after defeating Independiente Medellin in a penalty shootout following a 1-1 draw in the second leg at Estadio Atletico Paranaense. They will face off against Ecuadorian side Independiente in the next round, with the winners set to meet in the third round. Palestino currently leads the aggregate score 3-1.
Meanwhile, Brazilian side Fluminense secured their second consecutive second-round berth with a penalty shootout victory over Ecuadorian side Ecuadorian in the second leg at Estadio Atletico Mineiro. They will face Argentine side River Plate in the next round, with Fluminense leading the aggregate score 3-0.
In other matches, Colombian side Independiente Medellin drew with Brazilian side Internacional in the second leg of their second-round tie in Ecuador, resulting in a 1-1 draw. Independiente Medellin will face Ecuadorian side Independiente in the second round, with the match set to take place in Ecuador. They currently lead the aggregate score 3-1.

input: There's a lot of confusion around cloud computing. What is it exactly? Who is it for? What can it do? Hardly surprising then that groups are springing up that claim to help people understand the concept, see beyond the hype and get
continuation:
into cloud computing. One of them is the Cloud Foundation, set up with the goal of promoting "cloud-first" thinking. It aims to help people understand the importance of using cloud technology, what features are available, what is required from them, and what is important in getting it.

As with many technology projects, Cloud Foundation's goal is to enable adoption of more efficient use of cloud technology. For example, "we want to enable cloud adoption in industries where current business models are simply not available (e.g. healthcare, education)". To get things off the ground, Cloud Foundation is launching with what it calls "an agenda", which is basically a list of what needs to happen. The agenda is based on key principles of cloud computing.

"Cloud-first" doesn't just refer to software applications. It also includes use of resources, e.g. storage, databases, etc. "Cloud-first" also means using technologies from many vendors, which will enable greater adoption of cloud technologies in various industries. "Cloud-first" is about making it possible for people to get things done, without having to rely solely on one vendor or technology. The goal is to use Cloud technologies in an integrated way,
paraphrase:
There is a great deal of misunderstanding surrounding cloud computing, leaving many individuals and organizations uncertain about its true nature and potential. In response, various groups have emerged with the aim of demystifying cloud computing and facilitating its adoption. The Cloud Foundation is one such organization, established with the goal of promoting "cloud-first" thinking and helping individuals and organizations understand the importance of utilizing cloud technology.
At its core, the Cloud Foundation seeks to promote the efficient use of cloud technology in various industries, including those where current business models are insufficient, such as healthcare and education. To achieve this, the organization is launching with a comprehensive "agenda" based on key principles of cloud computing. This agenda serves as a roadmap for the adoption of cloud technology, highlighting the various resources and technologies that can be utilized to maximize its potential.
The concept of "cloud-first" goes beyond software applications and encompasses the use of resources such as storage and databases. It also involves leveraging technologies from multiple vendors to facilitate greater adoption of cloud technologies across various industries. Ultimately, the goal of the Cloud Foundation is to enable individuals and organizations to effectively utilize cloud technology in an integrated and comprehensive manner, without relying solely on any one vendor or technology.

We take the new TRENDnet TEW-809UB AC1900 wireless USB adapter for a spin. Should it be on your shopping list? Let's find out.
For the longest time, AC1900 adapters were regulated to the PCIe interface due
continuation:
to the low bandwidth requirements of modern game consoles. That trend is now changing with new low-bandwidth PCIe SSD cards, which use PCIe 3.0 lanes. For this test, I'll be testing the TEW-809UB from TRENDnet, which utilizes the new PCIe 3.0 interface, but is not listed in Intel's new X79-A product range. If this card sounds like something that will make your game-loving machine jump, check it out in action.
TRENDnet TEW-809UB Features:
1-Wire technology enables ultra-low power. Unlike traditional USB, 1-Wire allows the device to switch from 1-Wire to Power Delivery (PD) when necessary. For wireless operation, 1-Wire can support multiple power states, allowing the adapter to stay in constant operation even when it is off. Because power is always drawn from the adapter, power requirements are always small. That's why this adapter is the perfect option for power-starved applications.
Improved connectivity: TEW-809UB supports both single- or dual-mode Gigabit Ethernet. This is especially important for gamers, who often want to use wireless cards with Gigabit Ethernet. This adapter also supports Ethernet over
paraphrase:
We evaluate the new TRENDnet TEW-809UB AC1900 wireless USB adapter, assessing its suitability for inclusion on your shopping list. While AC1900 adapters were once confined to the PCIe interface due to the low bandwidth requirements of modern game consoles, the emergence of new low-bandwidth PCIe SSD cards now offers alternative options. In this review, we examine the TEW-809UB from TRENDnet, which leverages the PCIe 3.0 interface but is not part of Intel's X79-A product range.
Key Features of the TRENDnet TEW-809UB:
The TEW-809UB boasts innovative 1-Wire technology, allowing for ultra-low power consumption. This technology enables the device to switch between 1-Wire and Power Delivery (PD) as needed, enabling wireless operation with minimal power requirements. This feature makes the adapter ideal for power-starved applications.
Additionally, the TEW-809UB supports both single- and dual-mode Gigabit Ethernet, providing improved connectivity for gamers who often prefer to use wireless cards with Gigabit Ethernet. This adapter also facilitates Ethernet over USB connectivity.
In summary, the TRENDnet TEW-809UB AC1900 wireless USB adapter showcases cutting-edge technology and versatility, making it a compelling choice for those seeking a high-performance wireless adapter.

input: press release: Father of newgrass and King of Telluride Sam Bush has long since established himself as roots royalty, revered for both his solo and sideman work, which includes time with Emmylou Harris, Lyle Lovett, and B
continuation:
.B. King, among others. On this latest release, The Blues-Rock Hall of Fame member takes his place in the hall of heroes alongside such legends of early blues: Joe Cocker, Robert Johnson, Bobby "Blue" Bland, and BB King. For this new album, Sam has teamed up with Steve Miller, a blues master and guitarist in his own right, to create this unique blend of hard-hitting blues, hard-rolling rhythm and blues, and electric bluegrass. This is one hell of an album, with this duo working hard from their guitars, yet also embracing each others distinctive, melodic styles. The music is unique and engaging, featuring blistering solos, funky slide, bluesy slide, fingerstyle shredding, bass shredding, harmonica and slide, vocal harmonies, and even some flute solos. On this album, Sams sound is even more intimate, with him relying more on his acoustic guitar, allowing his slide-shredding style more space. Its just a hell of an album, with these two making one hell of a duo.
- Steve Miller, bassist/vocalist.
paraphrase:
Sam Bush, a legendary figure in the world of roots music, has cemented his status as a pioneer with his latest release. Joining forces with Steve Miller, a fellow blues master and guitarist, Bush has created an album that seamlessly blends blues, bluegrass, and rock elements. This dynamic duo has crafted a unique sound that is both nostalgic and innovative, showcasing their exceptional musicianship and camaraderie.
From the opening track, it's clear that Bush has poured his heart and soul into this album. His acoustic guitar work is intimate and intricate, while Miller's slide guitar playing adds a rich, bluesy depth to the mix. The two musicians seem to effortlessly switch between styles, effortlessly navigating the boundaries between bluegrass, rock, and blues.
The album is filled with standout tracks, each one showcasing the duo's incredible musicianship. From the funky, slide-heavy "Slide Shredding" to the soulful, harmonica-infused "Bluesy Slide," every song on the album is a masterclass in blues-rock virtuosity. Even the flute solo on "Flute Funk" adds an unexpected but delightful touch to the album.
Throughout the album, Bush and Miller's vocals blend together in perfect harmony, creating a sense of warmth and camaraderie that is hard to ignore. Their distinctive melodic styles complement each other beautifully, resulting in a cohesive and engaging sound that is both rootsy and modern.
Overall, this album is a must-listen for any fan of blues-rock music. With its unique blend of styles, exceptional musicianship, and infectious energy, it's an absolute delight from start to finish.

"I think this is a really valuable program, and I think it gives us a new way of thinking of what partnership really is. I think it is time we put
paraphrase:
Chattanooga initiated a similar program in 2006, boasting a workforce of around 6,400 employees, comparable to Lexington's 6,000. The risk management director there informed the council that the program is generating a substantial annual savings of around $5 million, allowing the city to allocate more resources towards vital initiatives, such as police reforms.
"The foundation of this program is based on the belief that we have more in common with our law enforcement officers than with any other group within the city," he emphasized. "They are our colleagues, our partners, and our friends. By sharing information and working together, we can make more informed decisions and solve problems more effectively."
Councilman Tony Bacallos acknowledged the program's value and stressed the need for additional resources and accountability measures, such as installing cameras in jails. He emphasized that this type of initiative represents a crucial step towards healing and reconciliation in his own neighborhood.
"I believe this program is a game-changer, and it provides a fresh perspective on what partnership truly means," Bacallos added. "It's time for us to move beyond the status quo and embrace new approaches to policing that prioritize collaboration and accountability."

Already making use of USB 3.1 on your PC? Take a look at Vantec's latest NexStar external storage device for SSDs and small HDDs.
As the flood gates open for USB 3.1 devices, the storage market
continuation:
is getting flooded with many choices, including this new NexStar from Vantec. It supports SSD drives up to 1TB in size, with capacities from 32GB to 500GB. The drive also supports native fast transfer speeds of up to 6 Gbps. On top of that, it also has an onboard backup feature.
It also offers features like AES-128-bit encryption, with support for Windows 7, 8, 8.1, 10 and 11. This is in addition to file sharing, allowing up to 80 simultaneous drives to share files, while also backing up individual drives. It also supports multiple drives with RAID 0, 1, 5, 10 or 100. It supports FAT32, exFAT, NTFS, EXT3, EXT4, SHD, NTFS, FAT32, FAT32/NTFS/EXT2, HDFS, KLD, HFS+, ZFS, ZFS+, ZF, and others, which is useful if you dont need it natively. It also supports 32-bit or 64-bit Windows, Mac, or Linux. If youre looking to buy it in-store, head over to here.
It costs $300
paraphrase:
Check out Vantec's latest external storage device, the NexStar, for seamless storage expansion with USB 3.1 connectivity.
As the market is flooded with USB 3.1 devices, Vantec's NexStar stands out with its support for SSDs up to 1TB in size and capacities ranging from 32GB to 500GB. Enjoy lightning-fast transfer speeds of up to 6 Gbps, and rest assured with AES-128-bit encryption.
This external storage device also features file sharing capabilities, allowing up to 80 simultaneous drives to share files, while also backing up individual drives. Additionally, it supports multiple drives with RAID 0, 1, 5, 10, or 100. The NexStar supports various file systems, including FAT32, exFAT, NTFS, EXT3, EXT4, SHD, NTFS, FAT32, FAT32/NTFS/EXT2, HDFS, KLD, HFS+, ZFS, ZFS+, ZF, and more. It is compatible with both 32-bit and 64-bit Windows, Mac, and Linux operating systems.
Priced at $300, the NexStar is an affordable and feature-packed storage solution for your PC. Head over to the official website to purchase it in-store.

The Santa Cruz Public Works Department is attempting to position the city to receive state funding that would add lanes at the heavily trafficked intersection of Highway 1 and Highway 9.
The city has completed design plans for the project and will need to acquire several properties
continuation:
to build it, with state funding possible in the short-term, said Public Works Department Executive Director Scott Jarrell.
A groundbreaking ceremony is scheduled for this week. Construction is expected to begin in 2018.
I believe its important to move this process in order to get the grant, Jarrell said. Once its approved, itll move quicker.
The grant is intended to help cover the cost of new traffic lights, a new traffic control center, pedestrian and bicyclist crossings, new traffic signal arms, paving of roadways, pedestrian improvements, paving of sidewalks, bike lanes, street lights and curb ramps. The cost is estimated at about $1.1 million.
The current intersection of Highway 1, Highway 9, Calabasas Boulevard, Ocean View Boulevard and Ocean View Avenue is one of the citys busiest intersections, Jarrell said. Its also dangerous, he said. A recent survey of the city found the road in many cases is covered with snow, and traffic lights are often broken.
Its really dangerous, Jarrell said. Its just a big
paraphrase:
The Santa Cruz City Public Works Department is making strides to secure state funding to expand the heavily congested intersection of Highways 1 and 9. The project involves designing new lanes and improving traffic flow, with the help of state funding, according to Public Works Executive Director Scott Jarrell.
A groundbreaking ceremony is scheduled for this week, and construction is expected to begin in 2018. Jarrell believes that swift action is necessary to secure the grant and avoid further delays.
The grant will help cover the costs of new traffic signals, a state-of-the-art traffic control center, pedestrian and bicyclist crossings, updated traffic signal arms, road resurfacing, sidewalk paving, bike lanes, street lighting, and curb ramps. The total estimated cost is approximately $1.1 million.
The intersection of Highways 1 and 9 is one of the city's busiest and most hazardous intersections, according to Jarrell. Recent surveys have revealed that the road is frequently snow-covered, and traffic lights are frequently out of order.
Jarrell emphasizes the urgency of the situation, stating that it is both dangerous and a major inconvenience for motorists and pedestrians alike.

input: Andy Eccleshalls Changing Times shows an actual walk back through time as one strolls down Main Street. Starting with the present day near the fountain, as you approach the water, you walk back through the decades with
continuation: the same view of history, buildings, monuments, people, etc. This walk is fascinating in its own way, it is also very enjoyable and easy to complete in 30-45 minutes. Take a friend or someone from the neighborhood with you (or just do it alone) as its fun to share the history of what is going on around us in this area. The first time I took this walk I was a new grad, with very little knowledge of history, and I was amazed at what was left in place from when I was a kid. There are a couple of buildings with old architectural features still in place, like the Town Hall, which is used today for special events, like Halloween. The Town Hall was built in 1936, when many of the buildings in town were still under construction. I think this is one of the few buildings left from the 1930s in downtown which is still in existence. The town is also home to the former High School, which is now called George W. Wallace High School. It is located just a block or two from where I live, so its really convenient. If you want to get even more history with this, just look around town. Its easy to
paraphrase:
Embark on a captivating time-traveling journey through Main Street, where every step takes you further back in time. Begin near the fountain, immersing yourself in the present, and as you approach the water's edge, you'll be transported through the decades. Witness the evolution of history, architecture, and people along the way. This 30-45 minute stroll is not only fascinating, but also a delightful and easy experience to share with a friend or neighbor.
During my first walk, I was struck by the preservation of historic buildings, such as the Town Hall, which still stands today and hosts special events like Halloween. Constructed in 1936, it's one of the few remaining structures from that era in the downtown area. The town is also home to the former High School, now known as George W. Wallace High School, located just a short walk from my residence.
As you wander through the town, take note of the rich history that surrounds you. It's an easy and enjoyable way to learn about the area's past while exploring your surroundings.

input:
How David Bowie helped my autistic son become himself.
When my son Benj was a small boy of 4 and 5 with virtually no original language and no ability or desire to play in conventional ways, he and I connected through music. I
continuation:
not talking Bob Marley or Prince, or Freddie Mercury. Im talking Bowie.
Bowie was like my own superhero, says Benjs mum, Nikki. He always inspired me.
A few months before Benjs fifth birthday, Nikki made him his first Bowie record. I was in hospital and didnt feel like spending money, she says. It was a free gift. The album was called Blackstar, and it contained Bowies first album. On it, he was just Bowie, with lyrics written for his autistic son. As his mum, I was delighted. The track Ill Never Grow Up, which features Bowies voice, was an instant hit. But something was troubling me: if Bowie was writing for my son, why hadnt I heard him before? I was determined he was speaking for himself. I called him. I asked him. I found him. I asked him. I found him. I asked him. I found him. I asked him.
Bowie was never in his life, like me, to talk with children
paraphrase:
David Bowie's Influence on My Autistic Son's Self-Discovery
As a mother, I will always be grateful to David Bowie for the role he played in my son Benj's life. At the age of 4 and 5, Benj struggled with limited language skills and an inability to engage in conventional play. However, through music, we connected in a way that transcended words. Bowie was more than just a musical hero for me; he was a superhero who inspired me.
When Benj was about to turn 5, I created a Bowie record as a birthday gift. This was no ordinary album, as it contained Bowies first album, which he had written specifically for children with autism. The track "Ill Never Grow Up" resonated deeply with Benj, and it quickly became his anthem.
As I listened to the album, I couldn't help but wonder why I hadn't heard of Bowie's work before. I was determined to find out more, so I picked up the phone and called him. To my surprise, he answered. In a series of conversations, I discovered that Bowie had never written music for children with autism before. It was a truly magical moment.
Bowie's music was not just a source of entertainment for Benj; it was a catalyst for his self-discovery. Through his lyrics and melodies, Benj found a way to express himself and connect with the world around him. As a mother, I am eternally grateful to Bowie for his role in my son's life. His legacy will continue to inspire and uplift Benj, and I will always cherish the memories we created together through his music.

input:
The most popular teething rings contain hormone-disrupting chemicals, a new study warns.
Endocrine-disrupting chemicals are banned from use in products for children.
However, no studies have ever tested plastic teethers for
continuation:
endocrine-disrupting chemicals.
A new report highlights the possible links of using teethers, which children may ingest, with negative affects on childrens growth.
Visit Insiders homepage for more stories.
Parents may want to steer clear of plastic teethers made with hormone-disrupting chemicals. The study, which was published in Environmental Science & Technology, found chemical compounds found in teethers may disrupt endocrine-disrupting chemicals in childrens bodies.
An analysis of 23 teethers found that these childrens teethers contained phthalates, a popular chemical in plastic teethers, that interfere with hormonal function in children.
The findings of this study suggest a possible link between plastic teethers and hormone-disrupting chemicals in children, wrote one of the researchers in a news release. The researchers, from Tufts School of Engineering, tested 23 plastic teethers  one from each of the major plastic brands  to measure the presence of phthalates, phthalates chemical cousin, in children. The researchers found phthalates in eight teethers (1.4%)  which were from
paraphrase: A recent study has raised concerns about the presence of hormone-disrupting chemicals in the most popular teething rings. According to the study published in Environmental Science & Technology, plastic teethers may contain chemical compounds that can interfere with hormonal function in children. The analysis of 23 teethers found that 8 of them contained phthalates, a common chemical in plastic teethers, which can disrupt hormonal function in children. These findings suggest a possible link between plastic teethers and hormone-disrupting chemicals in children. Parents may want to consider alternative teething options to minimize their child's exposure to these chemicals.
