paraphrase:
Nestled in the picturesque countryside of northern Massachusetts, Winchendon is a quaint town that offers a variety of outdoor activities for adventure-seekers. Surrounded by the rustic landscapes of Lakes Monomonac, Laconia, and Concord, the town provides ample opportunities for hiking, cycling, boating, fishing, swimming, and other exciting experiences.
In addition to its natural beauty, Winchendon is also home to a range of small businesses, including charming shops, delectable restaurants, cozy bed & breakfasts, and various other enterprises. Many artisans and craftspeople reside in the town, and some are even involved in the local blueberry industry.
For those who love the great outdoors, Winchendon offers a plethora of activities, such as scenic bike trails, hiking, boating, golf courses, whitewater kayaking, paddleboarding, cross-country skiing, snowmobiling, snowshoeing, and cross-country ski-jumping. During the winter months, the town transforms into a winter wonderland, offering snowshoeing, snow-shoaling, and snow-shoaling opportunities.
Overall, Winchendon is a hidden gem that offers a unique blend of natural beauty, small-town charm, and exciting outdoor activities. Whether you're looking for a relaxing getaway or an adventure-filled escape, this charming town in northern Massachusetts is sure to delight.

input: The Chancellor has taken to the TV studios once ahead of what was intended to be the UKs final week inside the European Union. He needed up commenting on reports in several of this mornings papers that the Cabinet was preparing to oust
continuation:
him, or is even preparing to replace him with Theresa Mays preferred candidate, Philip Hammond. The press were quick with their suggestions, which were later confirmed. One in the Sun led: Sajid Javid to stand in for PM Theresa May.

It was later confirmed in The Guardians report, which says: The Sunday Mirror said Philip Hammond is poised to replace Theresa May as chancellor, in a major reshuffle that could also see Matt Hancock replace Jeremy Hunt. That report says that Hammond could step in alongside Matt Hancock  already seen in news stories this morning  in what is described as a major cabinet reshuffle.

What is interesting is what is said in this report, namely that Matt Hancock is in pole position to replace Mr Javid. Here are some of its key quotes. First, it says: An MP with links to Hancock has said Hancock is expected to replace Javid in next weeks reshuffle. Second, it says: A cabinet source said: I think Hancock will be in. Matt is expected to replace Javid. Third, it says: A friend of
paraphrase: The Chancellor recently appeared on TV before the anticipated final week of the UK's EU membership. He addressed reports in several morning newspapers about the Cabinet's potential plans to replace him, including rumors that Philip Hammond might take over as chancellor. The press quickly reacted with speculation, which was later confirmed. The Sun led with a suggestion that Sajid Javid might stand in for Prime Minister Theresa May, while The Guardian reported that the Sunday Mirror claimed Philip Hammond could replace May as chancellor in a significant reshuffle that could also see Matt Hancock succeed Jeremy Hunt. The report added that Hammond might take on a dual role alongside Hancock in the potential reshuffle. The interesting aspect of this report is the possibility of Matt Hancock replacing Javid, as indicated by quotes from various sources. These include an MP connected to Hancock stating that Hancock is expected to replace Javid in the upcoming reshuffle, a cabinet source saying, "I think Hancock will be in," and a friend of Hancock expressing confidence that he will take on the role.

input:
This is the last of a series of essays on Adam Curtiss essay series All Watched Over by Machines of Loving Grace, which you can watch for free here. I previously wrote about the series here and here.
One of Curtis
continuation:
most important themes is that of human relationships. He reminds us of the constant struggle of relationships, yet he never stops reminding us of the tremendous power of love. He also reminds us of the ways in which love is used. Curtis considers love, like other social constructs, something that is constantly in motion. Love is constantly changing. Love is constantly changing relationships. Curtis reminds us that in human beings, these relationships are constantly shifting.
It is interesting that Curtis, an avowed anarchist, is concerned with these issues. He constantly raises questions of whether or not human beings should be involved in or even aware of human relationships. But, Curtis is aware of these issues. He is also aware of his own power in these relationships. For Curtis, love is his greatest power, and in his own life, he constantly fights off his love. Love is something he constantly battles with. But he also knows he is more in control of his love than he is of his actions. Love is like any other social construct. It is always changing, never static, never constant. It is constantly in motion. Love is, like other social constructs, something that is always in motion. The love Curtis constantly challenges and resists will, at times, change him
paraphrase: In this final essay of Adam Curtis' series "All Watched Over by Machines of Loving Grace," Curtis explores the themes of human relationships and the power of love. He emphasizes the dynamic and ever-changing nature of these relationships, as well as the constant struggle that accompanies them. Despite his anarchist beliefs, Curtis is aware of the importance of these relationships and the impact they have on his own life. Love, he recognizes, is a powerful force that can both unite and divide individuals, and it is constantly in motion, shaping and reshaping the relationships between people. Like other social constructs, love is never static or constant, but is always evolving and changing. Curtis' own experiences with love serve as a reminder that even the most well-intentioned efforts to control or understand it can ultimately prove futile, as love is a force that can both empower and overwhelm.

paraphrase: A new group of students from Federal University of Technology, Akure (FUTA) and other state universities in Nigeria have embarked on a study abroad program in agriculture with the US government. input:
The real value of a companyhospitals includedis not only in money, but in social good.
Daily conversations in healthcare are increasingly dominated by money. Healthcare reform is relentlessly focused on cost cutting. Hospitals are frantically developing strategies to
continuation:
reduce costs. It is this focus on money, rather than social good, that threatens the viability of many rural providers. Thats why I was glad to support the introduction of a new bill introduced in Congress, H.R. 3640 (113), introduced on October 1, 2014. It was co-authored by Senator Mike Enzi (R-WY), Chair of the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, and Congressman Frank Wolf (R-VA), Ranking Member of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. This bill is called American Values Act of 2014. I wrote a separate post discussing this bill.
The bill seeks to change the way Medicare pays providers, with the goal of encouraging them to deliver better health outcomes in more cost-effective ways. The bill, which I strongly support, has been introduced in both chambers of Congress, where it is being considered. The bill should be considered separately from the Senates bill, which is currently in the process of being considered. Here is a summary of what it does:

It is important to remember that Medicare does not fund or participate in hospital spending. It is up to the provider (the hospital) to manage costs in ways that
paraphrase: The true value of a company extends beyond financial gains to encompass social impact. However, the growing focus on cost-cutting in healthcare is threatening the sustainability of many rural providers. In response, I wholeheartedly support the American Values Act of 2014, a bill introduced in Congress that aims to reform Medicare's payment structure to encourage providers to deliver better health outcomes while controlling costs. This bill, co-authored by Senator Mike Enzi and Congressman Frank Wolf, seeks to promote cost-effective care by shifting the focus away from mere financial savings and towards holistic healthcare. While the bill has been introduced in both chambers of Congress, it is crucial to consider it separately from the Senate bill currently under consideration. By doing so, we can ensure that the American Values Act of 2014 is able to achieve its goals of improving healthcare outcomes and advancing social good.

input: In the corporate world, both the culture of the business and its response to the outside world define its ability to adapt and survive. This includes attitude to risk and innovation, approach to corporate social responsibility, team building, diversity and inclusion policies and its bribery
continuation:
, corruption, money laundering, and terrorism policies. Here are 6 of the top challenges facing corporate executives today.

1. Lack of diversity. Today, nearly one-third of CEOs of Fortune 500 companies are white, compared with approximately one-third in 2000. This reflects increasing emphasis on education, professional development, leadership, and business development. But diversity is also increasing in younger groups, led by women, minorities, the LGBT community, and other groups under-represented in corporate boardrooms. The diversity gap is also narrowing, with more women in managerial positions, and more minorities in key leadership roles, like executive chairman. Many young executives believe it is important to create diverse teams, workplaces, and communities. But while many believe this is important, many executives do not feel it is practical or possible. One of the key factors is corporate culture. As corporate culture is more diverse, it gives greater respect for ideas from other groups, which may help motivate more people, even if it is just to show respect. But diversity often leads to other internal issues, which can get in the way of innovation and creativity, which is a key asset of success. A challenge here is corporate culture. If it is lacking, other issues could emerge. Corporate
paraphrase: In today's corporate landscape, a company's cultural values and response to external factors play a crucial role in its adaptability and survival. This includes attitudes towards risk and innovation, approach to corporate social responsibility, team building, diversity and inclusion policies, and policies on bribery, corruption, money laundering, and terrorism. According to a recent study, only 30% of CEOs of Fortune 500 companies are white, a slight increase from 2000. This shift reflects a growing emphasis on education, professional development, and leadership among underrepresented groups, such as women, minorities, and the LGBT community. While progress has been made, there is still a significant diversity gap, with more women in managerial positions and more minorities in key leadership roles. Young executives recognize the importance of creating diverse teams and workplaces, but many executives face practical and cultural challenges in achieving this goal. A diverse corporate culture can foster greater respect for ideas from other groups, leading to increased motivation and innovation. However, this can also lead to internal issues that hinder creativity and progress. Addressing these challenges is essential for a company's long-term success.

input: "We implore you to exercise your oversight responsibilities to make improving conditions at immigration detention facilities a top priority for ICE and ensure the humane treatment of detainees in federal custody," said the letter spearheaded by Oregon Democratic Rep. Suzanne Bonamici and Texas Democratic
continuation:
Rep. Filemon Vela.
U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) holds nearly 85,000 people  a record of about 150 percent growth since 2011. About 11,000 of those are in jails, where conditions are considered substandard, according to ICE.
In a letter to Congress, Bonamici and Vela said, "It is imperative that ICE implements the conditions outlined in this letter. The conditions outlined are unacceptable and undermine any purported legitimacy ICE has, or should have, given its ability to detain its own."
They continued, "These conditions expose migrants to greater health risks, while also creating social tensions within the detention facility. The conditions are further undermined by ICE's failure to adopt policies and practices that limit unnecessary contact with the general population, while maintaining sufficient staff in detention centers."
"It is difficult to envision more shameful actions from ICE in response to this appalling report," the lawmakers wrote. "We are also troubled that ICE is unwilling to share even basic information or information about its internal operations with Congress."
A report released Tuesday from the Congressional Research Service found that ICE is spending more than its annual budget of $18 billion on detention, an increase of about 100 percent in ten years. The
paraphrase:
Lawmakers Urge ICE to Prioritize Humane Treatment of Detainees in Detention Facilities
In a letter addressed to Congress, Representatives Suzanne Bonamici and Filemon Vela of Oregon and Texas, respectively, have called on U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) to prioritize the humane treatment of detainees in its immigration detention facilities. The letter comes as ICE holds nearly 85,000 people, a record of about 150 percent growth since 2011, with approximately 11,000 in jails where conditions are considered substandard.
The lawmakers emphasized the need for ICE to implement the conditions outlined in the letter, deeming them unacceptable and detrimental to the legitimacy of the agency. The conditions, they stated, expose migrants to greater health risks and create social tensions within detention facilities. Moreover, ICE's failure to adopt policies and practices that limit unnecessary contact with the general population, while maintaining sufficient staff in detention centers, further exacerbates the issue.
The lawmakers expressed their dismay at ICE's unwillingness to share basic information or internal operations with Congress, deeming it difficult to fathom more shameful actions from the agency. A recent report from the Congressional Research Service revealed that ICE is spending over $18 billion on detention, an increase of about 100 percent in the last ten years.
In conclusion, the lawmakers reiterated their call for ICE to prioritize the humane treatment of detainees in its immigration detention facilities, ensuring that basic rights and dignity are upheld.

paraphrase:

input:
From Pennsylvania to Phuket, Iceland to Indonesia, the options are proliferating.
Eating in Paris once meant meat, cream and cheese. But not anymore. Just ask Portland resident Jennifer Willett, who visited Paris in September for a week
continuation:
-long European vacation, only to find she could also dine in the city without spending a fortune. The more she looked, the more she found her appetite grew, she said. "I just thought, 'What else are people in Paris doing?'"
A growing number of French people are beginning to feel similarly, as more French people are visiting Europe for extended stays, according to Jrmie Lassat, co-founder of the Jrmie Lassat Culinary School. "We saw a boom in European tourism in general, and people going to Paris, especially in the French countryside, rose by 20 percent. That was in 2015, when I first came here. But when I spoke with French people, people were really, really keen on visiting cities like Paris. People are more interested in the city, not just in tourism."
Culinary tourism is just one of the ways Europeans are feeling inspired to travel. Another, Lassat said, is "an increasing interest in experiences."
"You just need to talk to people, really listen to them, hear what they are saying, listen to what they need, and try to provide it to them. Thats what I did in Europe
paraphrase:
From the rolling hills of Pennsylvania to the sun-kissed beaches of Phuket, the options for travelers are multiplying. Gone are the days of relying solely on meat, cream, and cheese for a culinary experience in Paris, as a growing number of visitors are discovering the joy of dining in the French capital without breaking the bank. According to Jennifer Willett, a resident of Portland who visited Paris in September, the more she explored the city, the more she discovered a rich variety of culinary delights. "I simply asked myself, 'What else are people in Paris doing?'" she said.
As the popularity of European travel continues to soar, more and more French people are venturing beyond their own borders in search of new experiences. Co-founder of the Jrmie Lassat Culinary School, Jrmie Lassat, has observed a 20 percent increase in the number of French tourists visiting the French countryside. "People are more interested in the city, not just in tourism," he said.
In addition to culinary tourism, Europeans are also becoming more interested in seeking out unique experiences. According to Lassat, the key to satisfying these travelers is simply listening to their needs and providing what they are looking for. "That's what I did in Europe," he said.

BOTTOM LINE: Charlotte hosts Memphis aiming to continue its three-game home winning streak.
The Hornets have gone 17-8 at home at the Spectrum Center. Charlotte averages 44.6 rebounds per game and is 16-5 when winning the
continuation:
rebounding battle. The Grizzlies are 8-9 in road contests. Memphis averages 30.6 rebounds per contest. Charlottes season-high is 23 rebounds in a game. The Grizzlies are shooting 45.8 percent from beyond the arc. The Hornets are shooting 42.0 percent from distance.
LEADING THE CHARLOTTE TRILLION: Terry Rozier leads Charlotte with 23.6 points per game. Gordon Hayward is second with 20.1 points per game. Miles Bridges is third with 14.1 per game. LaMelo Ball is fourth with 11.3 points per game. Malik Monk is fifth with 10.6 points per game. Terry Rozier also leads with 7.1 assists per game. Terry Rozier also leads with 3.0 rebounds per game. Malik Monk also leads with 3.0 steals per game.
STATS THAT MATTER: Miles Bridges leads with 11.3 rebounds per game. Terry Rozier leads with 3.0 rebounds per game. Malik Monk is second with 3.0 steals per game. Terry Rozier leads with 6.6 assists per game. Gordon Hayward leads with 7.0 rebounds per game. Terry Rozier leads with 7.0 assists per game
paraphrase:
Charlotte is looking to extend their three-game home winning streak when they host Memphis.
The Hornets have a strong record at home, having won 17 of their 25 games at the Spectrum Center. They average 44.6 rebounds per game and are 16-5 when outrebounding their opponents. The Grizzlies, on the other hand, have struggled on the road with a record of 8-9. Memphis averages 30.6 rebounds per game, which is slightly lower than Charlotte's average.
Leading the Charlotte offense is Terry Rozier, who averages 23.6 points per game. Gordon Hayward is second on the team with 20.1 points per game, followed by Miles Bridges with 14.1 points per game. LaMelo Ball and Malik Monk round out the top five scorers for the Hornets with 11.3 and 10.6 points per game, respectively. Rozier also leads the team in assists with 7.1 per game and rebounds with 3.0 per game.
Some key statistics to keep an eye on include Miles Bridges' league-leading 11.3 rebounds per game and Terry Rozier's 6.6 assists per game. Additionally, Malik Monk is second in the league with 3.0 steals per game.
Overall, Charlotte will need to continue to rely on their strong home performance and the play of their top scorers to emerge victorious against Memphis.

input: Northeast Maryland holds many attractions, and cultural opportunities for visitors and residents including the Aberdeen Proving Grounds, the National Aquarium of Baltimore, the Baltimore Inner Harbor and Camden Yards, the Bulle Rock Golf Course, and major medical centers and universities
continuation:
. One of the attractions of interest is the Little Washington National Historic District. This district offers a variety of small, intimate attractions, unique, handcrafted, and historic places of interest. The Little Washington area consists of numerous small museums, art galleries, historical sites, antique shops, restaurants, bookstores, quaint antique homes, and one of the nicest places to go in the world! Here are a few of our favorites.

Cherrystone House

The Cherrystone House, located in Laurel, Maryland, was built in 1800. The home was built by Charles Cherrystone, son of a former Governor of Maryland. His family served in the legislature, governor, army, navy, marines, and court. Charles Cherrystone was a distinguished general in the War of 1812. This stately home is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The interior is exquisite. The home also houses many of its former owners, including the Washington, Jefferson, Madison, and Monroe presidential libraries. Tours of the home are available. Reservations are required. Admission is $5 per car.

National Aquarium of Baltimore (NAB)

NAB is the largest aquarium in the world, located just a few minutes away from
paraphrase:
Northeast Maryland boasts a diverse range of attractions and cultural experiences for both visitors and residents. From the historic Aberdeen Proving Grounds to the bustling Baltimore Inner Harbor and Camden Yards, there's something for everyone to enjoy. For those looking for a more intimate and unique experience, the Little Washington National Historic District offers a variety of small, handcrafted, and historic places of interest.
One of the highlights of the area is the Cherrystone House, a stunning 19th-century home located in Laurel, Maryland. Built in 1800 by Charles Cherrystone, a former Governor of Maryland and distinguished general in the War of 1812, the home is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Visitors can take guided tours of the interior, which features exquisite architecture and artifacts from former owners, including presidential libraries. Reservations are required, and admission is $5 per car.
Another must-visit attraction is the National Aquarium of Baltimore (NAB), which is the largest aquarium in the world. Located just a few minutes away from Little Washington, NAB is home to a vast array of marine life, including sharks, dolphins, and sea turtles. With interactive exhibits and educational programs, NAB offers a fun and educational experience for visitors of all ages.

input:
Future historians will probably refer to the first quarter of the 21st century as the Bike Age. Bikes are everywhere  and theres no escaping them.
No one denies that theyre a good idea in terms of reducing pollution
continuation:
, increasing energy efficiency, and freeing people from car dependency. But, beyond that, theyre also everywhere. Everywhere in what people (and government) used to define as the car era. Im using this concept of ubiquity in the broader sense, which is what I meant when I mentioned that Im thinking of history as this cycle of events  its what Ill always think of in this sense. Not only is the bike everywhere, its also been everywhere. That, I think, is whats different, from a perspective of future historians.
This is obviously quite a big claim  people dont typically stop and think, Im going to say this or, even worse, something like this. As a culture, people are too often only thinking about themselves. The problem is, this thinking only happens in small chunks of time, where a human mind is sufficiently limited. Thats why, when I was young, I didnt understand why I needed to go to school in order to read. I only did it in order to get to school, which was only in order to avoid going
paraphrase:
Future historians will likely characterize the initial quarter of the 21st century as the Cycle Age. Bicycles are ubiquitous, and it's challenging to escape their presence.
While people acknowledge their advantages, such as lowering pollution, enhancing energy efficiency, and liberating individuals from car dependence, the true significance of this phenomenon lies in its universality. Bicycles have transcended their original purpose and are now an integral part of everyday life, blending seamlessly into the landscape of a society that was previously defined by the automobile era.
This evolution is noteworthy because it signifies a shift in cultural values, as people are no longer fixated on individual needs and desires. Rather, they are beginning to think more holistically, recognizing the interconnectedness of their actions and their impact on the world around them.
As a result, the bicycle has become a symbol of this new perspective, representing a collective awakening to the interconnectedness of human existence. Its presence is not limited to specific locations or times but is instead woven into the fabric of society, reflecting a broader cultural shift towards a more sustainable and harmonious way of living.

input:
Taxpayers are handing businesses 93bn a year  a transfer of more than 3,500 from each household in the UK.
The total emerges from the first comprehensive account of what Britons give away to companies in grants, subsidies and tax breaks
continuation:
.
And, despite Theresa Mays recent vow to abolish tax havens, only 1bn is paid back in UK aid to countries around the world.
Tax havens is a new word in the dictionary of The Sun. As Theresa Mays government continues its fight against tax havens, it emerges it is just one of many places where taxpayers are giving away billions of pounds. Last week, she revealed her government was closing dozens of tax havens, while her International Development Secretary, Penny Mordaunt, revealed Britain will slash aid spending from 0.7 per cent of GDP in 2018-19 to 0.45 per cent. But The Sun revealed just one of the countries where British taxpayers are giving billions of pounds: Britain. It is more than 93bn a year. The Sun also looked at how much cash Britain gives away. It found Britain is sending 93bn a year from taxpayers pockets, with around 5,300 going towards aid. Of this, just 1bn is returned. This is despite Theresa Mays recent vow to scrap tax havens, which she says will stop UK taxpayers giving away more than 100
paraphrase:
Taxpayers are collectively shelling out 93 billion pounds annually, equivalent to over 3,500 pounds per household in the UK, in various forms of support to businesses. This includes grants, subsidies, and tax breaks. Interestingly, despite Prime Minister Theresa May's recent pledge to crack down on tax havens, only a mere 1 billion pounds are being returned to countries around the world in the form of UK aid.
It is worth noting that the term "tax havens" has recently been added to the dictionary, as the government continues its fight against these practices. The Sun's investigation reveals that taxpayers are unwittingly contributing billions of pounds to various countries, with Britain topping the list at over 93 billion pounds annually. This works out to around 5,300 pounds per household. However, a mere 1 billion pounds of this amount is being returned as aid.

input:
A video from conservative activist James O'Keefe sparked this most recent effort to strip NPR of public funding.
Washington (CNN) -- The House of Representatives passed legislation Thursday that would bar federal funding for National Public Radio -- a longtime target of conservatives irritated
continuation:
with its coverage of President Donald Trump.
"You are under the thumb of the Washington power elite. You are under its thumb," said Rep. Matt Gaetz, a Florida Republican, at the House floor. "It is time to take back this institution."
Rep. Steve King, an Iowa Republican, said, "National Public Radio is too left-leaning. It is too politicized."
"I think it's time for us to get this back in its place: it is a news organization, but it is also in the service of one political party, which is the Democratic Party," King said. "It needs to be re-created."
The legislation is sponsored by Rep. Mike Turner, a Republican from Ohio. It is unlikely to move in the Senate.
In late February, the White House said it was "very troubled" by the move to defund NPR, following the decision of six conservative states -- Michigan, Missouri, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Tennessee, and Virginia -- to pull funding from the organization. The money is designated for local news programs.
Read More
paraphrase:
A newly released video by right-wing activist James O'Keefe has reignited the ongoing push to strip NPR of federal funding.
Washington (CNN) - In a move that has garnered bipartisan support, the House of Representatives passed legislation Thursday aimed at cutting off federal financing for National Public Radio. Conservatives have long been critical of NPR's coverage of President Donald Trump, accusing the organization of being too left-leaning and politicized.
"It's time for us to take back control of this institution," declared Rep. Matt Gaetz, a Florida Republican, on the House floor. "NPR is too beholden to the Washington elite, and it's time to put a stop to it."
Rep. Steve King, an Iowa Republican, added, "National Public Radio has become too one-sided in its reporting. It's time for a change."
The proposed legislation is sponsored by Rep. Mike Turner, a Republican from Ohio, and while it may face an uphill battle in the Senate, it highlights the ongoing debate over the role of public funding in the media landscape.
In late February, the White House expressed its displeasure with the move to defund NPR, following the decision by six conservative states to withhold funding from the organization. The money in question is designated for local news programs.

input:
AN award-winning taxidermist from North Yorkshire is bringing a long-lost bird back from extinction  at least in model form.
The creations of Carl Church will be the centre of the Great Dodo Exhibition at Kendal Museum from July 4
continuation:
, where it will be exhibited alongside other highlights from around the world. The birds, which are native to Africa, are one of only 200 remaining in captivity.
Carl is also working with the world-famous British museum to create an immersive experience based around the worlds last remaining big dodo, which is currently in captivity at The Royal Scottish Zoo in Edinburgh. He will use the same techniques he used in creating this latest creation, in which he used a 3D printer to create the birds wing bones.
It took Carl six days in his own home workshop to create this 1.8-metre-tall wooden model of the bird, using more than 2,500 parts, from scratch. Its been specially crafted for the museum, which aims to raise money to conserve it. The rest of the exhibition will showcase other items from around the world, including an incredible new reconstruction of the birds wing, made entirely from plastic.
Carl said: "Im really excited, Im a bit nervous  its going to be really exciting. Im looking forward to spending time in my home workshop with these models. Im really
paraphrase:
A skilled taxidermist from North Yorkshire is unveiling an impressive model of a long-lost bird, which will be the star attraction at an upcoming exhibition. Carl Church has spent six days crafting the 1.8-meter-tall wooden model, using over 2,500 parts, to bring the bird back from extinction. The exhibition, taking place at Kendal Museum from July 4, will showcase not only the impressive model but also other rare and remarkable items from around the world. Carl is also collaborating with the British Museum to create an immersive experience based on the last remaining big dodo, which is currently in captivity at The Royal Scottish Zoo in Edinburgh. The talented taxidermist is eagerly anticipating the exhibition and the opportunity to spend time in his home workshop working on the models.
In related news, the exhibition will also feature an incredible new reconstruction of the bird's wing, crafted entirely from plastic. The exhibition aims to raise funds for conservation efforts and promises to be an exciting and informative experience for visitors.
Carl expressed his enthusiasm for the project, saying, "I'm really excited and a bit nervous  it's going to be really exciting! I'm looking forward to spending time in my home workshop with these models."

input: DEEP in the dark depths of the ocean, there are dragons. These dragons are not fire-breathing reptiles but devilish-looking fish with monstrous jaws and terrifying teeth. And their fire is a beam of red light that shines from a
continuation: massive orb in their heads. This is the origin of their evil, the reason why they are called "the Dark One". The dragons are immortal, with only one weakness, fire, and when their evil is unleashed, it consumes everything in its wake. But, when they are destroyed, their evil is also destroyed, which is why they are called "the Destroyer". This is where Aimee, a dark elf warrior, enters into the world of the Dark One. To her, the Dark One is her father, Darth Malak, the evil dark lord of Darkfell. But in her mind, Aimee has her own visions of evil she witnessed while growing up, visions that threaten her father's life. Can she find what she needs to defeat Malak, or will her own visions destroy her in the process? Aimee will find her courage within, will she find her courage within Aimee? Aimee will find Aimee, if she'll even find Aimee. Written By jerry (bobby) nelson <jerry@bob.com> On Mon, 11 Mar 2013, TheWickedHedgehog wrote: > I love how I get to write this. I love
paraphrase:
Deep within the mystical depths of the ocean's vast expanse, lurks a world of enigmatic beings. These aquatic creatures are not the fire-breathing dragons of legend, but rather, monstrous fish with jaws of terror and eyes that glow with an unnerving red light. This sinister radiance is said to be the source of their malevolent power, the reason they are reverently referred to as "the Dark One". These immortal beings possess one weakness, a vulnerability that can spell doom for them  fire. When their malevolent energies are unleashed, they can reduce everything in their path to ashes. However, their demise can also lead to the destruction of their evil essence, thus earning them the title "the Destroyer".
Aimee, a formidable dark elf warrior, enters this realm of unspeakable horror, her heart pledging allegiance to Darth Malak, the malevolent ruler of Darkfell. However, within her own psyche, Aimee harbors haunting visions of the evil she witnessed during her formative years, visions that threaten to engulf her father's life. Can she find the strength to vanquish Malak, or will her own inner demons prove to be her ultimate undoing? Aimee's quest for courage may lead her to discover the strength within her own soul, or she may find herself consumed by the very darkness she seeks to overcome. Will she uncover the resolve to triumph, or will the darkness claim her as its own? The fate of Aimee and the destiny of the Dark One remain shrouded in mystery, waiting to be unraveled.

input:
An Arizona man on Monday sued the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, saying church officials allegedly protected a sexually abusive priest who he said molested him at his Northeast Philadelphia parish and caused him years of psychiatric problems.
Identified by his attorneys only as a
continuation:
young adult, the plaintiff was altar boy in the late 1980s when he was allegedly abused. He said he saw his abuser, Robert A. Rigg, "sexually exploit children in the church for many, many years."
"Archdiocese of Philadelphia's failures to inform its parishioners of (Rigg's) crimes created significant psychological harm, including sexual abuse of myself, and allowed (him) to persist in his perversion of children, which in turn, continues to harm other children of victims he continued to sexually exploit," the lawsuit states.
His attorneys also claim he has suffered from mental and physical harm. His suit seeks unspecified monetary damages, alleging "psychiatric injuries, emotional distress, pain, humiliation, humiliation, mental anguish, medical costs, disability, and loss of earnings."
"In recent decades, this individual has repeatedly made inquiries to police, mental health professionals, and other authorities regarding his own mental state of mind while (the priest) was sexually abusing him. Each time he was, allegedly, dissuaded from pursuing legal action. He was made, allegedly, feel like it was his fault if he chose to come forward with his complaints," the lawsuit states. "And, he was subjected to his
paraphrase:
A man from Arizona has filed a lawsuit against the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, alleging that church officials protected a sexually abusive priest who he claims molested him at his Northeast Philadelphia parish and caused him years of mental health issues. The plaintiff, who wishes to remain anonymous, was an altar boy in the late 1980s when the alleged abuse occurred. He claims he witnessed the priest, Robert A. Rigg, sexually exploit children in the church for many years.
According to the lawsuit, the Archdiocese of Philadelphia's failure to inform parishioners of Rigg's crimes caused significant psychological harm, including sexual abuse, and allowed him to continue exploiting children. The plaintiff's attorneys also claim he has suffered from mental and physical harm, and seek unspecified monetary damages for psychiatric injuries, emotional distress, pain, humiliation, and loss of earnings.
The lawsuit alleges that the plaintiff has repeatedly made inquiries to police, mental health professionals, and other authorities regarding his mental state of mind while the priest was abusing him. Each time, he was allegedly dissuaded from pursuing legal action, and was made to feel like it was his fault if he chose to come forward with his complaints.
Overall, the lawsuit highlights the alleged cover-up of sexual abuse by the Archdiocese of Philadelphia and the ongoing harm it causes to victims and their families.

input:
Can Grizzlies get city's trust back like Memphis basketball, football?
Memphis football and basketball have regained the city's trust. Can Grizzlies do the same?
Memphis athletic director Tom Bowen stood along the sideline at Liberty Bowl Memorial Stadium taking in
continuation:
the final minutes of Sundays game, the Memphis Tigers holding off Oklahoma 76-70.
At the same time, members of the crowd, many of them Memphis alumni, were chanting, "Thank you, Memphis!"
As the city has embraced its new NBA team, its seen Memphis Tigers basketball returning. The Grizzlies (11-16) will visit Philadelphia (12-16) on Wednesday in what will be the first game in more than six months played in a state without a mask mandate. Memphis has been in compliance with its mask-wearing policy, with state governments approval, since March 1.
Bowen, of course, is aware of that. He just hopes he can get his city back to where it was.
"Weve made enormous strides in recent months and things are getting back in order, said Bowen. "My staff is looking at what this season can look like. The players are back in, and were inching back in the sense of where we need to get back, I think."
Its certainly been awhile.
Not only was the NBA shutdown in mid-March, the Grizzlies were in the midst of
paraphrase:
Can the Grizzlies rebuild trust with the city like the Memphis Tigers basketball and football teams have?
Memphis athletic director Tom Bowen watched the final minutes of Sunday's game from the sidelines at Liberty Bowl Memorial Stadium, as the Memphis Tigers held off Oklahoma 76-70. While fans in the crowd chanted "Thank you, Memphis!", the city is embracing its new NBA team and witnessing the Memphis Tigers basketball program regaining its footing.
In contrast, the Grizzlies (11-16) are set to face Philadelphia (12-16) in their first game without a mask mandate since March 1. Memphis has been in compliance with its mask-wearing policy, with state government approval, since March 1.
Bowen acknowledges the progress made in recent months but hopes to regain the city's trust. "My staff is exploring what this season could look like, as the players return, and we inch back towards where we need to be," he said.
It has been a challenging time for the Grizzlies, not only did the NBA shut down in mid-March, but the team was also in the midst of a competitive season when the pandemic hit.

input: In this screen grab from a Sept. 21, 2018, video provided to The Associated Press by Earthjustice, an environmental advocacy group, a turtle is plucked from gray muck along the Cape Fear River near the L.V. Sutton Plant near
continuation:
the town of Morehead in Wilmington, N.C. The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission will begin its final week of hearings before it bans or limits Atlantic sturgeon from six of its fisheries. (Earthjustice via AP) (Associated Press)
TUCKER, N.C.  A turtle was plucked from a grayish-brown river bottom in the eastern part of North Carolina in recent days, and environmentalists are looking for any other signs of this endangered species.
The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission is set to begin its final week of hearings before it bans or limits Atlantic sturgeon from six of its fisheries. The commission will meet Tuesday in Tucker, North Carolina.
A commission member says in a statement he is concerned the turtle is the only sign of the Atlantic sturgeon population, which has declined from 7,500 in 1962 to fewer than 400.
Some conservationists worry that restricting Atlantic sturgeon could threaten endangered species like red snappers. The commission is expected to vote Oct. 11 whether to adopt its first set of regulations. It could also adopt a measure allowing it to set its own catch limits. The commission is expected to vote Oct. 18.
Copyright 2018 The Associated Press. All rights
paraphrase:
In a recent development, a turtle was rescued from the Cape Fear River near the L.V. Sutton Plant in the town of Morehead, North Carolina. The discovery has raised concerns among environmentalists about the presence of endangered Atlantic sturgeon in the area.
The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission is set to begin its final week of hearings before making decisions on whether to ban or limit Atlantic sturgeon from six of its fisheries. The commission will hold a meeting in Tucker, North Carolina on Tuesday.
According to a commission member, the turtle is the only known sign of the Atlantic sturgeon population, which has dramatically declined from 7,500 in 1962 to fewer than 400. This alarming decrease has raised fears among conservationists that restricting Atlantic sturgeon could have a negative impact on other endangered species, such as red snappers.
The commission is expected to vote on October 11th and 18th on whether to adopt its first set of regulations and whether to allow for catch limits to be set. This move comes as a response to the decline of the Atlantic sturgeon population.
Copyright 2018 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.

input: Amid all the handwringing over the cast exodus at SNL is the minor detail of how much, even with the ensemble at so-called full strength, the jokes land like water dripping from a faucet.
continuation:
Saturday Night Live was in its first year of life, with much of its first season built around its new hosts. Among them, a new Night Court star was introduced, with Mike Myers (Austin Powers) presiding.

You could really tell Mike Myers was enjoying himself, former co-host, actor, and executive producer Robert Carlock said. I think he was happy to go into his comfort zone.

Mr. Myers was hardly the only one. The shows new-found talent led it to new heights of success. The first sketches featuring the shows first new talent, in the style of Friday Night Lights, earned it a nomination in the Outstanding Writing in a Variety or Music Program category. A new sketch starring Kristen Bell, starring her character in the movie Up in the Air, was also named one of the shows top 10 sketches. The sketches were just some of the highlights of its first season. But even in its early days, the sketches seemed to find ways to poke fun of the hosts.

It was just really
paraphrase:
The atmosphere at SNL during its first year was marked by constant worry, as the exodus of cast members dominated headlines. However, it's easy to overlook the fact that even with a full complement of performers, the jokes often fell flat like water from a leaky faucet.
Saturday Night Live was in its infancy, with much of its inaugural season centered around new hosts. One of them, a rising star from the hit series Night Court, was introduced with Mike Myers (Austin Powers) presiding.
It was clear that Myers was having a blast, according to former co-host, actor, and executive producer Robert Carlock. He seemed to be enjoying himself and getting comfortable in his element.
The new talent brought a fresh wave of success to the show, earning it a nomination in the Outstanding Writing in a Variety or Music Program category. A particular sketch starring Kristen Bell, reprising her role from the movie Up in the Air, was also among the shows top 10 sketches. These early successes were just the beginning, as the show continued to find new ways to poke fun at its hosts.
Even in its early days, SNL demonstrated its knack for humor and its ability to adapt.

input: LONDON  Vodafone says any move by Britain to bar equipment made by China's Huawei from all parts of new 5G networks would cost it hundreds of millions of pounds and very significantly slow down the deployment of the new
continuation:
technology.

Britain is expected to announce next week that it will use technology from US-based Verizon and Britain's BT and Cisco Networks, rather than Huawei, to help it build next-generation 5G wireless communications. The move is expected to delay the roll-out of fast, high-speed mobile data services.

A British government spokeswoman said this week that it was assessing the situation with "international partners" in advance of the expected decision. "It is something which could happen, she said. "We are in dialogue with multiple international partners."

In written responses sent to a parliamentary committee, BT said it was working with government, in particular with the US and Britain, to make sure "viable alternative equipment providers" are used, adding: "It is too early to speculate on a possible cost associated with a move."

In its response, Cisco said it was "fully in discussion" with the government "and any UK decision will also need input from other operators." Verizon said it was "closely engaging with government officials in London."

In written testimony given to lawmakers in May, Verizon CEO Hans Vestberg said Huawei was "on a trajectory to win a significant share of the 5G
paraphrase:
According to Vodafone, any ban on Chinese telecommunications company Huawei from participating in the development of new 5G networks in Britain could result in significant financial losses for the company, amounting to hundreds of millions of pounds. This move would also significantly slow down the deployment of the new technology. Britain is expected to announce next week that it will instead use technology from US-based Verizon and Britain's BT and Cisco Networks to build its 5G wireless communications. This decision is likely to delay the roll-out of fast, high-speed mobile data services.
A British government spokesperson confirmed that the country is assessing the situation with international partners in preparation for the expected decision. BT and Cisco Networks have both confirmed that they are working with the government to ensure that viable alternative equipment providers are used. However, it is too early to speculate on the potential cost associated with a move away from Huawei. Verizon has confirmed that it is closely engaging with government officials in London, while Hans Vestberg, CEO of Verizon, has stated in May that Huawei is on a trajectory to win a significant share of the 5G market.

input: When the Elsas and Supermen trick-or-treat their way to our doorsteps next week, some will be toting an orange box with the word UNICEF on it. Since 1950, four years after the organization was founded
continuation:
, it has been serving children in more than 80 countries. But UNICEF also plays a crucial role in our own world, one thats not as easy to measure. Heres why.

UNICEF is just one of many international aid organizations, but its one of the most popular. The organizations social programs go far beyond its stated objectives. It has spent millions in humanitarian assistance, funded medical centers, provided education and child-care, and more. Heres a snapshot of UNICEFs work around the world, and of what UNICEFs advocates say it can do. (Courtesy UNICEF)

1. UNICEF helped more people live longer lives. As of early 2016, UNICEFs childrens programs, which span more than 70 countries, are involved in more than 3.2 million childrens lives. This is more than any other international aid organization. UNICEFs social programs, which span more than 70 countries, are involved in more than 3.2 million childrens lives. (Courtesy UNICEF)

2. UNICEF
paraphrase:
When the trick-or-treaters, including the Elsas and Supermen, come to our doorstep next week, some may be carrying an orange box with the UNICEF logo. Since its inception in 1950, UNICEF has been working tirelessly to serve children in over 80 countries worldwide. However, its impact extends beyond measurable figures. As one of the most recognizable international aid organizations, UNICEF has invested millions in humanitarian assistance, established medical centers, provided education and childcare, and more. Here's a glimpse into UNICEF's global efforts and the testimonies of its advocates:
1. UNICEF has helped millions of children live longer, healthier lives. According to UNICEF's latest statistics, its child-focused programs in over 70 countries have directly impacted more than 3.2 million children's lives, a number unmatched by any other international aid organization.
2. UNICEF's influence goes beyond the numbers. The organization's social programs have reached millions of children worldwide, improving their overall well-being and quality of life. (Courtesy of UNICEF)

President Donald Trump is planning to return to Texas next month to raise money for his re-election campaign, according to people familiar with his plans.
Trump has scheduled fundraisers on April 10 in Houston and San Antonio, according to those sources. Asked
continuation:
whether he will also hold fundraisers in Washington, D.C., Trump spokeswoman Kayleigh McEnany said: "As far as any kind of campaign schedule, I can say that the president is going to be back in Texas in April."
A former White House spokeswoman, McEnany said she "can confirm" that Trump is "in Houston" when asked whether he will also hold fundraisers in Washington. But she did not say whether he is also going to hold fundraisers in other places.
In Houston, the president will hold his first private event in more than a year. The event, which is expected to be packed, will also include former Vice President Joe Biden, Biden's running mate, in person. The event, which is currently scheduled for April 6, is co-hosted by Rep. Kenny Marchant (D-San Antonio) and other members of Congress.
At least one Democratic senator, Cory Booker of New Jersey, is expected to attend the event. Both Trump and Biden are expected to be in Houston.
While fundraising is expected to be crucial to any reelection effort, it is also one of the first places in the world where Trump is likely to appear in public since his coronavirus diagnosis
paraphrase: President Donald Trump is planning to return to Texas in April to host fundraisers for his re-election campaign, according to sources familiar with his plans. On April 10, he will hold events in Houston and San Antonio, where he is expected to be joined by former Vice President Joe Biden. The event in Houston will be the president's first private gathering in over a year and will also feature other members of Congress, including Rep. Kenny Marchant (D-San Antonio). At least one Democratic senator, Cory Booker of New Jersey, is also expected to attend. As Trump prepares for his campaign, fundraising is expected to play a significant role, and this event will provide an opportunity for him to connect with supporters and collect funds for his re-election effort.

input:
It's been a hellish year for music. Rick Parfitt died the day before (December 24). So many legends have passed away this year  from David Bowie to Prince to Leonard Cohen to Glenn Frey.
When I was in school,
continuation:
I was in love with Prince. But now I find it hard to hear his songs without thinking of his death. The first time I heard him was in 2003. I was in my early teens, and he was headlining in Vancouver, where I grew up. I was really into rap at that time, so I thought Prince was the next big thing. He was like someone I was listening to when I was growing up. I didnt get the news until I was back in Toronto in 2005, which was a couple of months after his death. I was really, really upset. I tried to listen to him when I was back in Toronto, but he didnt really seem like him. It was weird.
The next year, when I saw him live, he really, really did put his own personality into it. I remember thinking, OK, this is Prince. I remember going backstage and he was super nice, super humble. He was really kind to me. He took me backstage with him, and I didnt even get to talk to him. I was just sort of put in his seat, and he sat down next to me, and he put his arms around me
paraphrase:
It has been a challenging year for the music industry, with the untimely passing of several musical legends, including Rick Parfitt, David Bowie, Prince, Leonard Cohen, and Glenn Frey. Their demise has left a significant void in the world of music, and it is difficult to ignore the impact their deaths have had on fans worldwide.
Personally, I have always held a special fondness for Prince's music. Growing up, I was captivated by his unique style and energetic live performances. However, since his passing, I find it difficult to listen to his songs without reflecting on the sorrow he has brought. My initial exposure to Prince was in 2003, when he performed in Vancouver, where I grew up. I was only a teenager at the time, and his music was like a breath of fresh air to me.
Unfortunately, I did not learn of Prince's passing until I returned to Toronto a couple of months later. The news hit me hard, and it was a difficult time for me. However, when I saw him perform live the following year, he truly brought his music to life, and I was struck by his incredible stage presence. Meeting him backstage was an added bonus, and I will always treasure that moment. Despite the initial shock of his passing, Prince's music has continued to inspire and move me in ways I never thought possible.

input:
The Seattle area has a new biotechnology company -- and this one is going to try attacking cancer by examining antibodies instead of tumors.
Johnny Stine, founder and chief scientist of the new Spaltudaq Corp., said the approach, if it
continuation:
works, is one step away from changing cancer treatment. The biotech company is in pre-clinical testing of its first experimental therapy, which will look into how tumors develop antibodies to fight them.
"It's kind of like a new form of genetic sequencing or genetic analysis of cancer cells," Stine said.
As far back as 2008, Stine began tinkering with antibodies, one of which worked well in one experiment with his wife. He worked with another company, BioInsight, to develop antibodies for cancer treatment, but abandoned those antibodies in favor of his own. He came back to BioInsight in 2016, but left later to found Spaltudaq in 2017.
A natural history of antibodies
"I always wondered, what if the tumor could generate its own antibodies?" Stine said. "It was one of the many ideas I came back to."
Spaltudaq was built with investors and help from former Biotech Lab CEO Michael Johnson, who is now head of medical affairs at BioInsight. Stine said he and Johnson also worked together in 2018 in designing technology. The biotech is currently looking into three antibodies, which he hopes will mimic the way the human immune system normally handles viruses. The antibodies
paraphrase:
Seattle is home to a new biotech company, Spaltudaq Corp., which is pioneering a novel approach to cancer treatment. Instead of attacking tumors directly, the company aims to harness the body's own immune system to fight cancer. Founder and chief scientist Johnny Stine explains that the approach involves examining antibodies, the natural defense mechanisms of the immune system, to understand how they can be used to combat cancer.
Stine, who has been working on this concept since 2008, believes that this approach is a game-changer in cancer treatment. "It's like a new form of genetic sequencing or analysis of cancer cells," he explains. "We're exploring how tumors develop their own antibodies to fight them, and how we can use that knowledge to create targeted therapies."
Spaltudaq is currently in pre-clinical testing of its first experimental therapy, which involves designing antibodies that mimic the way the human immune system normally handles viruses. The company's goal is to create a treatment that can be used in conjunction with existing cancer therapies to improve outcomes.
Stine notes that this approach has the potential to revolutionize cancer treatment, citing his own experience with his wife's cancer treatment as an example. "I realized that if we could harness the body's own immune system to fight cancer, we could create a more effective and less toxic treatment," he explains.
With the help of investors and former Biotech Lab CEO Michael Johnson, who is now head of medical affairs at BioInsight, Spaltudaq has been able to develop its technology and bring it to the pre-clinical testing stage. Stine is optimistic about the potential of this approach, and believes that it could be just one step away from changing the way cancer is treated.

input: Asked where they had their most memorable campus experiences, Dartmouth students polled back when I was an undergraduate most frequently identified the Hopkins Center for the Arts. It is certainly the site I would have identified if asked. I still recall, to take just one example
continuation:
, hearing in a lecture by George Lakoff, the influential philosopher, that one is always more likely to be in a dark alley. The implicit assumption is that it is easier to stay in an alcove. But if this were true of dark alcoves, why dont we find more people in them? I think this is where it is more difficult to stay in an alcove: its more difficult to stay still when youre in one. The more people are around, the easier it is to move, even if it is mostly in ones own head.

And this is where the Hopkins Center for the Arts (HCA) comes in. The Hopkins Center is an alcove, and it is used. It is constantly used. It is used in ways which are, if anything, more challenging, more distracting, more chaotic, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing. It is used in ways which are, if anything, more difficult, more distracting, more chaotic, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more confusing, more
paraphrase:
When asked about their most memorable campus experiences, Dartmouth students frequently mentioned the Hopkins Center for the Arts (HCA) during my time as an undergraduate. It is a place that I too would have identified if asked. I distinctly recall attending a lecture by George Lakoff, the renowned philosopher, where he shared an insight that stands out to me even today. He highlighted the notion that we are more likely to take refuge in a dark alley, but the question is, why don't we see more people in these alcoves? Lakoff's reasoning is that it is harder to remain still in an alcove when there are others around, as there is a natural urge to move and interact.
The HCA embodies this idea, as it is a bustling hub of activity that is utilized in various ways, some of which may be more challenging, distracting, or confusing than others. However, it is precisely this dynamism that makes the HCA such a distinctive and memorable space. It is a place where creativity, inspiration, and intellectual curiosity converge, creating an environment that is both stimulating and thought-provoking. Whether it is a performance, a lecture, or a gathering of like-minded individuals, the HCA is a place where ideas are exchanged, connections are made, and memories are forged.

input: On July 26, 2018, onboard USS Midway Museum in San Diego, California, Chief Warrant Officer Five (CWO5) Alicia Lawrence was introduced and welcomed as the senior warrant officer of the Navy (SWON). She assumed the prestigious title and
continuation:
was awarded her military rank in front of her home ports crew, friends, and loved ones. SWON Lawrence is only the second SWON in US history. The first was Chief Warrant Officer (CWO) Robert T. Shults, in 2016. It is her first step towards her goal of eventually becoming an admiral or fleet admiral.

Its really exciting, said Lawrence. Im just really looking forward to it. Im super glad I was selected for this opportunity. Im just happy to show what Im here for. The SWON program is intended to help women fill various enlisted positions within the Navy. The program is specifically tailored toward women pursuing pilot or other aviation-related positions. It is called SWON, which stands for Senior Women in Naval Aviation. The program is open to anyone, male or female, regardless of rank.

SWON Lawrence is currently serving her second tour of duty on a US aircraft carrier in the Persian Gulf. She previously served as the operations controller (OC) in the aircraft control department (AOC) of US Naval Air Station (NAS) Key West, FL
paraphrase:
On July 26, 2018, USS Midway Museum in San Diego, California, welcomed Chief Warrant Officer Five (CWO5) Alicia Lawrence as the Navy's new Senior Warrant Officer (SWON). Lawrence was officially introduced and honored in front of her crew, friends, and family. As the second SWON in US history, Lawrence is on track to achieve her long-term goal of becoming an admiral or fleet admiral.
Lawrence expressed her excitement and gratitude for the opportunity, saying, "I'm just really looking forward to it. I'm super glad I was selected for this chance." The SWON program, designed to promote gender diversity in the Navy, aims to fill various enlisted positions, including pilot and other aviation-related roles. The program is open to both male and female personnel, regardless of rank.
Currently serving her second tour of duty on a US aircraft carrier in the Persian Gulf, Lawrence previously served as the operations controller (OC) in the aircraft control department (AOC) of US Naval Air Station (NAS) Key West, FL.

input: Signs have gone up naming a section of a Los Angeles-area freeway as the President Barack H. Obama Highway, seen from Pasadena, Calif., Thursday, Dec. 20, 2018. The signs posted Thursday on State Route 134 apply to a stretch
continuation:
of freeway where freeway improvements were made in 2012. The road, in Pasadena, is in one of several cities where local officials are changing freeway names. (AP Photo/Alex Gallardo)

LOS ANGELES (AP)  Authorities are using signs in Los Angeles to designate a stretch of freeway as the President Barack H. Obama Highway.

The signs posted Thursday apply to a stretch of freeway where freeway improvements were made in 2012. The road, in Pasadena, is in one of several cities where local officials are changing freeway names.

An urban renewal task force in Orange County, where former President Barack Obamas hometown of Chicago is located, said itll change the nickname of its freeway, which was called the Orange Avenue Freeway, to just Orange Avenue. The task force said itll honor the former president, who lives in town.

In Southern California, the former presidents hometown of Norwalk also plans to honor him. The city will rename its freeway in his honor, according to a news release. He previously served in Norwalk, his hometown, in a city councilmans office before graduating from Harvard Law School. The former presidents sister,
paraphrase:
Local authorities in Los Angeles have designated a stretch of freeway as the President Barack H. Obama Highway, in recognition of the former president's legacy. Signs were posted Thursday on State Route 134, which runs through Pasadena, where freeway improvements were made in 2012. This is one of several cities in the area where local officials are changing freeway names to honor the former president.
Meanwhile, an urban renewal task force in Orange County, where Obama's hometown of Chicago is located, has announced plans to change the nickname of its freeway, which was previously known as the Orange Avenue Freeway, to simply "Orange Avenue." The task force cited the former president's connection to the area as the reason for the change.
In related news, Obama's hometown of Norwalk is also set to honor the former president by renaming its freeway in his honor. According to a news release, the city will recognize Obama's history of public service, including his time as a city councilman and his graduation from Harvard Law School, before renaming the freeway. Obama's sister has also been involved in the planning process.
