Then, she will move out of
paraphrase:
Hilary Duff's Ex-Husband Mike Comrie 'Shocked' by Divorce Decision, Still in Disbelief
Hilary Duff's unexpected divorce filing in August came as a shock to her ex-husband Mike Comrie, who is still trying to process the news. According to sources close to the couple, Comrie is "in disbelief" over Duff's decision to end their 10-year marriage, and is reportedly feeling upset and shortchanged by the split.
While Duff has made it clear that she does not want any financial support from Comrie, the former couple's divorce agreement is still being worked out. The couple shares two young children, 3-year-old son Luca and 6-year-old daughter Banks, and Duff is currently focused on getting her home in order and preparing the children for the upcoming school year.
Despite the challenges ahead, Duff remains optimistic about the future and is committed to creating a healthy and stable environment for her children. As the couple continues to navigate their divorce, it is clear that Duff is determined to prioritize the well-being of her family above all else.

input:
Eden Hazard was facing an extended ban for kicking out at a ball boy after the Football Association charged him over his sending-off in Chelsea's Capital One Cup exit at Swansea.
Belgian playmaker Hazard was already set to serve an automatic three
continuation:
-game suspension with his second yellow card in eight days when his latest incident occurred in Chelsea's 5-1 thrashing of Swans.
And despite Chelsea's 1-0 win, Hazard will miss the club's trip to Norwich this weekend and also faces FA Cup action with a potential ban handed down.
A FA statement read: "Following a charge of violent conduct in relation to an incident involving Chelsea's Eden Hazard, Chelsea Football Club has been charged with an offence of violent conduct.
"The FA will determine if a formal hearing is required or if a punishment will be served immediately. The incident happened in the first-half of the match."
Hazard was involved in a clash with a young Swans fan following a first-half tackle in which he kicked out at his opponent. The Chelsea star was shown a second yellow card following his clash with the fan.
The incident is not the first time Hazard's actions have sparked debate in recent times.
In November, Hazard was sent off following a clash with Arsenal fans following Chelsea's 1-1 draw.
Speaking before the game, Chelsea boss Antonio Conte insisted his star forward was "in his head" during his red card incident in mid-December.
And
paraphrase:
Eden Hazard faced the possibility of a lengthy ban after being charged by the Football Association for his altercation with a ball boy during Chelsea's Capital One Cup exit at Swansea.
The Belgian playmaker was already set to serve an automatic three-game suspension after receiving two yellow cards in eight days, and his latest incident only added to his troubles. Hazard will miss Chelsea's trip to Norwich this weekend and could face further punishment, including a formal hearing and additional disciplinary action.
A FA statement confirmed that Chelsea had been charged with an offence of violent conduct following the incident, which occurred in the first half of the match. Hazard was involved in a heated exchange with a young Swans fan after a first-half tackle, and was shown a second yellow card for his actions.
This is not the first time Hazard has found himself at the center of controversy in recent months. In November, he was sent off following a clash with Arsenal fans after Chelsea's 1-1 draw, and his red card incident in mid-December sparked concern among his coach, Antonio Conte.

input: NAFTA's environmental watchdog voted unanimously not to investigate oil sands tailings ponds pollution, despite recommendations from staff to launch a probe. It's the third time a NAFTA probe has been blocked by the Canadian government, pending a decision on Canada's controversial
continuation:
energy program.

NAFTA enviro watchdog recommends environmental probe into Alberta oilsands tailings ponds, despite recommendations from staff to launch investigation. It's the third time a NAFTA probe has been blocked by the government, pending a decision on Canada's controversial energy program. 2:02

A parliamentary committee reviewing NAFTA rejected a motion from NDP MP Niki Ashton to "pursue further in-depth investigations" into Alberta's oil sands tailings ponds, which are used to bury waste produced by the province's energy industries.

Ashton said the government failed to provide adequate information to support its proposal, despite repeated requests from her own NDP committee.

The government said it was disappointed with Ashton's motion.

"The motion failed in its technical nature," said government spokeswoman Karine Jean-Louis. "It should not have been sent."

NAFTA reviews environmental concerns on a case-by-case basis.

Ashton said she was disappointed that the government did not feel it could get more information from Alberta.

"I was disappointed in the decision to block this motion, which was made on behalf of Canadians and it was made on behalf of Canadians' concerns about these facilities," she
paraphrase:
The North American Free Trade Agreement's (NAFTA) environmental watchdog recently voted unanimously against investigating oil sands tailings ponds pollution, despite recommendations from staff to launch an inquiry. This marks the third time a NAFTA probe has been blocked by the Canadian government, while a decision on the country's controversial energy program remains pending.
A parliamentary committee reviewing NAFTA rejected a motion to further investigate Alberta's oil sands tailings ponds, which are used to bury waste produced by the province's energy industries. The government expressed disappointment with the motion, stating that it failed in its technical nature and should not have been submitted.
NAFTA reviews environmental concerns on a case-by-case basis, and Ashton expressed disappointment that the government did not feel it could gather more information from Alberta. She believes the decision to block the motion was made on behalf of Canadians and their concerns about these facilities.

input:
Dinshaw Billimoria and Sulochana in Ardeshir Iranis Heer Ranjha made in 1929. Photo: Courtesy Donnabelle Garga.
India might be celebrating the centenary of cinema this year,
continuation: but Indias cinema-goer culture is far from 100 years. A mere 3% of Indias population is even able to vote in general elections. The same is true of Indias cinema-goer culture, which is in its infancy. Just this year, films were screened in barely one-fourth of Indias cinema halls. More than 400 films in 2020. It is therefore time to look back, at how this cinema-goer culture began, what it is still lacking, and what it could yet achieve. Ardeshir Iranis Heer Ranjha is a perfect case in point. This film, which was made in 1929, has barely any dialogue. It is purely the story of one of Indias greatest revolutionaries, Heer Ranjha, played with utmost authenticity by Dilip Kumar, a veteran actor. It is also one of Indias earliest movies. It is also one of Indias greatest movies. The only plot device is Ranjhas desire to get married. The rest of the movie is filled with the excitement of the journey from Delhi, which, in 1930, was still only the capital of one
paraphrase:
In 1929, Dinshaw Billimoria and Sulochana's cinematic adaptation of Heer Ranjha showcased a pioneering effort in Indian cinema. Courtesy of Donnabelle Garga's photo, the film provides a glimpse into the early days of Indian cinema, which is still in its formative stages.
Despite India's centennial celebration of cinema, the country's cinema-goer culture has yet to reach maturity, with only 3% of the population eligible to vote in general elections attending cinemas. Similarly, a mere one-fourth of India's cinema halls screened films in 2020, indicating a limited reach of cinema in the country. However, this lack of penetration presents an opportunity to reflect on the origins of Indian cinema, its shortcomings, and its potential.
Ardeshir Irani's Heer Ranjha, released in 1929, serves as an illuminating case study. The film, starring Dilip Kumar as Heer Ranjha with remarkable authenticity, depicts the tale of one of India's most influential revolutionaries. Notably, the movie contains minimal dialogue, emphasizing the journey of Heer Ranjha from Delhi, which, at the time, was the capital of a single state.
This early Indian film, one of the earliest and greatest in the country's cinematic history, highlights the significance of Heer Ranjha's desire to get married as the primary plot device. The movie's success lies in its ability to captivate audiences with the excitement of the journey, rather than relying on complex plot twists.
In conclusion, while India celebrates its century of cinema, there is still much to be discovered and achieved in the country's cinema-goer culture. By examining the origins of Indian cinema and the potential for growth, we can unlock the secrets of this captivating art form and foster a more vibrant cinematic culture.

input:
A RADICAL shake-up, including a new school in Basingstoke, may be necessary to combat poor exam results, the deputy leader of the borough council believes.
Councillor Ranil Jayawardena says too many children in
continuation:
St Alwyns Primary School, in St Michaels High School, St Michaels High School, St Michaels Primary School, or in the current Basingstoke Primary School are getting poorer as time goes by.
He said: Im concerned if this continues, especially with the current generation, it will create an exodus of people. Its been going downhill in St Alwyns.
But he admitted many of the current problems in the schools were due to the Governments approach of making pupils sit examinations year after year, instead of focusing on what is important.
Cllr Jayawardena said: I think its a mistake. If we just want kids to get into school, its not working. We want to provide them with the education they need, and if its exams year-in, year-out, then its going to leave them feeling it. We need to find something new.
He said there was need for a new approach to education, which he believed could be found in the form of more flexibility in exams.
paraphrase:
To address the persistent poor exam results at Basingstoke's schools, a radical overhaul may be necessary, according to the deputy leader of the borough council, Councillor Ranil Jayawardena. He believes that the current education system is failing students, as they are being tested year after year without receiving the necessary education they require.
Cllr Jayawardena expressed his concern that the constant focus on exams is leading to a decline in student performance, particularly among the current generation. He believes that this trend will lead to an exodus of people from the area if it continues unchecked.
However, he acknowledged that some of the current problems in the schools are a result of the government's emphasis on exams, rather than focusing on what is truly important in education. Cllr Jayawardena suggested that a more flexible approach to exams could be the solution to this problem.
By introducing more flexibility in exams, students will be able to learn and develop their skills in a more holistic manner, rather than simply preparing for a series of standardized tests. This could help to improve student performance and overall education quality in Basingstoke's schools.

input:
Catholic Charities Southern Maryland Food Bank says it is in desperate need of pasta, rice, canned food and other dry goods.
A food bank in Southern Maryland that supplies many smaller food pantries and charities was gratified to get some donations following a
continuation:
recent shooting, but are still short of what they need.
"With the shootings in Pittsburgh, there is quite a bit of need, which is why I was pleased with what happened here when someone dropped off this kind of emergency aid, said Mikey Sullivan, president of Catholic Charities Southern Maryland Food Bank.
"And this kind of generosity, this kind of willingness to help, is why we are here, he said. This is just a tremendous need."
The shooting occurred while Sullivan was getting his volunteers ready. As he stood outside in the cold weather, waiting for more people to arrive, he heard what he first thought was fireworks.
"You could tell the shooting was more severe. Then I looked up and it was like an avalanche, he said. "At first I was just thinking, 'Oh God, what just happened?' But what happened next made me cry."
A man, later identified as Robert Bowers, came out of his home with semi-automatic weapons, firing into the crowd of worshippers. He was killed by police. At least seven people were injured in the shooting, which left members of the Pittsburgh area shocked.
Sullivan said the donated items from
paraphrase: Catholic Charities Southern Maryland Food Bank is urgently in need of essentials such as pasta, rice, canned goods, and other dry goods to support their efforts in providing aid to those affected by the recent shooting in Pittsburgh. Mikey Sullivan, the food bank's president, expressed gratitude for the donations received, but emphasized the ongoing need for support. "This kind of generosity is why we are here," he said, acknowledging the critical nature of the situation. The shooting, which occurred while Sullivan was preparing volunteers, left several people injured and the community in shock. Despite the challenges, Sullivan remains committed to providing support to those in need.

input: The vast majority of the 45 Amazon.com customers who have reviewed Bloomberg Businessweek writer Brad Stones new book, The Everything Store: Jeff Bezos and the Age of Amazon, gave it five stars. Lone among them, however, is a
continuation:
reader who was disappointed. Michael Smith wrote:

I expected more of this book. I came away with one sentence: this was a big, big book. It is big in the sense of big ideas, big facts, big facts with big ideas. It is big in the sense of massive, important ideas. I expected a little more in the way of hard, cold facts, facts with cold facts. (p. 30)

It is tempting to conclude, based on Smiths reading, that Stone should just have been more faithful in his coverage. But if you look beyond the surface of his review, it seems rather interesting that Smith, one of the books key critics, is bothered in this way. Stones argument is one of transparency, which is one of the big themes in The Everything Store. The book is really about, Stone says, Bezoss desire to show whats going on in his companys world and its many subsidiaries. And he also seems to show little sign of any skepticism: he complains, for example, that Bezos doesnt say anything in any of his recent press statements about issues like human trafficking, government
paraphrase: The majority of Amazon.com customers who reviewed Brad Stone's book, "The Everything Store: Jeff Bezos and the Age of Amazon," gave it a perfect five-star rating. However, one reviewer, Michael Smith, had a different opinion. Smith expressed disappointment with the book, stating that he expected more substance and hard facts. Despite this criticism, Stone's argument about transparency and the books themes of big ideas and facts remain noteworthy. Smith's review, in fact, highlights the significance of Stone's coverage, as he seems to be bothered by the lack of skepticism in Bezos's press statements regarding issues like human trafficking and government.

input:
A new album is set for release later this year.
TLC have announced their first ever UK show, taking to Londons Koko on May 9. Tickets will be on sale this Friday (March 24).
Since the death of
continuation:
mother of six Brenda Reid in 2012, TLC have remained mum with many rumours surrounding her absence. The bands latest album, Lets Get It On (2009), which saw the band go back to their funk-influenced, R&B sound, never hit UK shores.
In September 2012, it was rumoured Reid was going to release a solo album under her stage name, Brenda Reid, named Brenda Reid Live. She never confirmed or denied the news, other than to say she was working on material. The following year, Reid said she was working with producer Ben Gibbard.
In November 2012, Reid stated her current album, Lets Get It On, was about my divorce, life, love, sex, sex, sex. Reid later confirmed shed released her first album in six years.
TLC released Lets Get It On in September, 2008, making them one of the first big R&B acts to release an album in eight years. It was TLCs third UK No. 1 album, and also reached No. 1 in Ireland, Austria, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Singapore, Poland,
paraphrase:
TLC is gearing up to release a new album later this year, much to the excitement of their loyal fan base. The group has announced their first ever UK concert, taking place at London's Koko on May 9, with tickets going on sale this Friday, March 24.
Despite the passing of band member Brenda Reid in 2012, TLC has remained tight-lipped about her absence, with many rumors circulating about her fate. However, the band's latest album, Lets Get It On (2009), which saw a return to their funk-influenced R&B sound, never made its way to UK shores.
In September 2012, rumors emerged of Reid releasing a solo album under her stage name, Brenda Reid, titled Brenda Reid Live. While she neither confirmed nor denied the news, Reid did reveal that she was working with producer Ben Gibbard.
In November 2012, Reid spoke about her current album, Lets Get It On, stating that it was about my divorce, life, love, sex, sex, sex. She later confirmed that she had released her first album in six years.
TLC released Lets Get It On in September 2008, making them one of the first major R&B acts to release an album in eight years. The album reached No. 1 in several countries, including the UK, Ireland, Austria, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Singapore, Poland, and more.

input:
WASHINGTON  Republican David Yancey won a drawing to break a tie in the disputed 94th District race in Newport News Thursday however his opponent is expected to challenge the decision, possibly seeking yet another recount.
Control of the House of Delegates is
continuation:
in limbo and the GOP currently holds only one of the 20 seats in Virginia. If Yancey's win holds up, GOP House members will pick up at least one in Virginia in next year's midterm elections. Democrats could also claim more seats in Virginia.
A final vote tally in the House is expected in early January.
In the 90th District race in Virginia Beach, Democrat Bobby Scott, currently holds a seven-vote edge. If Yanceys win is invalidated, the Virginia Board of Elections could order a recount, which may go even further in Scotts favor.
paraphrase: Republican David Yancey emerged victorious in the contentious 94th District race in Newport News, but his opponent is poised to contest the decision. The outcome could have significant implications for control of the House of Delegates in Virginia, with the GOP currently holding just one of the state's 20 seats. If Yancey's win is upheld, the party may gain an additional seat in next year's midterm elections. Alternatively, Democrats could potentially claim more seats in Virginia. A final tally of votes in the House is expected in early January. In a separate race in Virginia Beach, incumbent Democrat Bobby Scott holds a slim seven-vote lead, and a potential recount could further solidify his position.

input: WASHINGTON  The professions expected to show one of the biggest job growth rates in 2017 and the largest growth in sheer number of jobs will be trade skills, according to a year-end report from CareerBuilder and labor market data provider Emsi.
continuation:
Employment in trade industries is expected to more than double in 2017, with more than 3 million jobs expected in sectors from construction to shipping, according to CareerBuilders annual Future Jobs Outlook. That would exceed 2016s 2.26 million jobs in trade.

Trade also will contribute more jobs in transportation, warehousing, education and health care, the report says.

The rise in jobs in trade is expected to push wages in this sector above pre-recession highs, said CareerBuilders Greg Foran, executive chairman, in a statement.

Employment in construction will rebound, adding more than 1.3 million jobs in 2017. Education will gain more than 650,000 jobs, and health care will add more than 600,000.

This years outlook is even more upbeat than 2016s report, which was even more upbeat, said Jaret Seiberg, managing director at Emsi. The strength of trade-related sectors in 2017 is due in part to the growing economy and robust construction and education industries.

Trade will create more jobs in transportation, warehousing, education and
paraphrase:
The job market is expected to experience significant growth in 2017, with trade industries leading the way. According to CareerBuilder and labor market data provider Emsi, employment in trade sectors is expected to double in number, with over 3 million jobs expected in fields such as construction, shipping, and education. This is a significant increase from the 2.26 million jobs in trade reported in 2016.
The growth in trade jobs is expected to drive wages higher, with the sector expected to exceed pre-recession highs, according to CareerBuilder's Greg Foran. Construction is also expected to rebound, adding over 1.3 million jobs in 2017, while education and healthcare will add over 650,000 and 600,000 jobs respectively.
Emsi's Jaret Seiberg notes that this year's outlook is even more optimistic than last year's, with the strength of trade-related sectors due in part to a growing economy and robust construction and education industries. As a result, trade will create more jobs in transportation, warehousing, education, and other fields.

input:
Noah Cyrus had no desire to follow her sister Miley Cyrus into a pop music as a child because she was so focused on becoming an equestrian.
In addition to acting in several TV shows, the 18-year-old star was
continuation:
also a horse trainer. The former Disney star found her niche and chose her profession over pursuing other interests, such as acting.
After graduating from school, she didnt think of pursuing a career in music, either.
"I was just really into equine culture. I loved performing and I loved working with horses, and I was super into it. I also was like, I dont want to be in show business. I just want to be a horse trainer, she said. I didnt really want anything else in life, other than horses.
I didnt really want to pursue any other career options or anything like that, she continued. I didnt really want any other options.
After learning about her passion, she took her lessons and performed in amateur rodeos and sold her first pony, which she named Lady Macbeth, according to People. By the time she was 14, she was performing in her first-ever major show in Las Vegas. By her final year of college, she had signed her first deal with Elektra Records.
Cyrus was one of the first artist
paraphrase:
As a young girl, Noah Cyrus had no interest in following in her sister Miley's footsteps in the music industry. Instead, she was fixated on becoming an equestrian, devoting herself to horse training and acting in various TV shows. Her passion for horses was so strong that she eschewed other career options, including music, and focused solely on equine culture.
Cyrus' love for horses was evident from a young age, and she spent countless hours honing her skills as a horse trainer. She even sold her first pony, Lady Macbeth, to raise funds for her passion. Her dedication paid off when she was just 14 years old, as she performed in her first major show in Las Vegas. By the time she completed college, she had signed her first record deal with Elektra Records.
Despite her success in the music industry, Cyrus has maintained her connection to her equestrian roots, and her passion for horses remains unwavering. She is one of the few artists who have managed to balance their love for music with their love for horses, and her unique perspective has earned her a devoted fan base.

input:
Taipei Mayor Ko Wen-je, center, shakes hands with temple-goers during a visit to the Taipei Songshan Fengtian Temple yesterday, the second day of the Lunar New Year holiday.
Taipei Mayor Ko Wen-je
continuation:
, center, shakes hands with temple-goers during a visit to the Taipei Songshan Fengtian Temple yesterday, the second day of the Lunar New Year holiday. (Chiang Ying-ying/Associated Press)
Taiwan is preparing to welcome in its second major wave of visitors this week, with millions flocking to temples, parks and museums in the final days of the Lunar New Year.
Tourists in cities and towns in Taiwan are setting off from early this week, heading first to a Buddhist monastery, temples, art galleries, gardens, temples, parks and museums, many of them in scenic scenic spots in Taiwan.
Tourists visiting museums in Taiwan are advised to wear masks, stay socially distant, use hand sanitizer, use common sense, avoid crowded places, limit interactions with others, and practice hand hygiene. It said hand-sanitizer should be available in all public places.
Taiwans tourism sector is one of its major industries, and its government hopes it will help prop up its economy. Tour operators in Taiwan are required to register with its tourism department. The Tourism Ministry says more than 160,000 foreigners came to Taiwan in the January-February period, and it expects this week
paraphrase: Taipei Mayor Ko Wen-je greets devotees during a visit to the Taipei Songshan Fengtian Temple on the second day of the Lunar New Year celebrations. As millions of tourists flock to Taiwan's temples, parks, and museums in the final days of the holiday, the country's tourism industry remains a vital component of its economy. To ensure the safety of visitors, tour operators in Taiwan are required to register with the tourism department and adhere to strict guidelines, including wearing masks, practicing social distancing, and using hand sanitizer. According to the Tourism Ministry, over 160,000 foreign visitors arrived in Taiwan during the January-February period, with the influx expected to continue throughout the week.

input:
Cecil Brunsons life in the air  and the guile he showed in the Vietnam War  will be honored Saturday at the Tennessee Aviation Hall of Fame.
Growing up in Memphis, Lt. Col. Cecil Brunson only
continuation:
dreamed of going into the military. He was just 10 years old when he ran away from home to go off to school in Nashville, Tenn. At one time, he was in the first class of Tennessees first flight school, a one-year program at Fort Campbell. He even made it to flight school with his father.
I was one of his favorite flight boys, said his mother, Ruby. I think he just was drawn to flying.
Ruby and her family loved to fly, too, especially her husband, Mike, and his brothers. Mike was a pilot for United Airlines. It was when he saw an advertisement for the Tennessee Aviation Hall of Fame in 1962, when his brothers were still in aviation school, that he called his mother. He never looked back. He retired from United in 1972 with almost 20,000 flight hours. His brothers were inducted into the Hall of Fame in 1996.
Mike was just one of them, Ruby said. I think he saw something in me, I dont know. He just saw something, I dont know. He was one of the boys. He really loved flying.
paraphrase:
Cecil Brunson's airborne exploits and cunning in the Vietnam War will be remembered on Saturday at the Tennessee Aviation Hall of Fame.
Raised in Memphis, Lieutenant Colonel Cecil Brunson had a lifelong ambition to join the military. As a mere 10-year-old, he left home to attend school in Nashville. He later enrolled in Tennessee's first flight school, where he even shared the skies with his father.
According to his mother, Ruby, Cecil was drawn to flying from a young age. "He was just one of my favorite flight boys," she said, her voice filled with fondness.
Ruby and her family were no strangers to aviation, with her husband Mike and his brothers all pilots for United Airlines. Mike was so enamored with the Tennessee Aviation Hall of Fame that he retired from his position in 1972 with an impressive 20,000 flight hours under his belt. His brothers were inducted into the Hall of Fame in 1996.
Ruby credits Mike's passion for aviation for their family's involvement in the industry. "I think he saw something in me, I just don't know what it was," she said, her voice filled with warmth. "He just saw something, I don't know. He was one of the boys." Mike's love for flying was unwavering, and it is a testament to his dedication that he remained in the industry for so many years.

input:
Thirty-four states  half with Republican governor  have seized upon the massive infusion of Medicaid expansion revenue.
Imagine an 18 wheeler pulling up to one of the five Mississippi River bridges and dumping 45 crates 4 feet tall and of $100 bills
continuation:
its been done before.
At this moment, Missouri is working its way through its first check. The check came in the mail this week, with Missouri Treasurer Scott Fitzpatrick  who is one of the six Democratic House members from Mississippi in office  in attendance.
Its just been nice to be in Mississippi, Fitzpatrick said. Its been kind of special, and it was nice to get some money back.
Its been a big week in Missouri, which, just a few days ago, saw its Republican-controlled legislature pass a bill that would impose new limits on the states Medicaid program. That bill was quickly vetoed by Gov. Mike Parson, whose own party is pushing hard to repeal expansion, which is expanding in Mississippi, Missouri, Arkansas, Oklahoma and Utah. The money, in fact, is already here. Its just being distributed.
Heres the story, with money distributed in states, with other links where relevant.
Mississippi Gov. Tate Reeves signed his states bill into law  just as it was getting ready to be sent from the state House of Representatives, with
paraphrase:
Thirty-four states, including Missouri, have capitalized on the significant influx of Medicaid expansion funds. Envision an 18-wheeler pulling up to one of the five Mississippi River bridges and unloading 45 crates filled with $100 bills - a scenario that has occurred before.
In Missouri, the state's first check has arrived, with Treasurer Scott Fitzpatrick, one of six Democratic House members from Mississippi, in attendance. Fitzpatrick expressed his gratitude for being in Mississippi, calling it a "special" experience and appreciating the financial return.
Recent developments in Missouri have been noteworthy, as the Republican-led legislature passed a bill aimed at limiting the state's Medicaid program, only to have it vetoed by Gov. Mike Parson. Parson's party is actively pushing for the expansion of Medicaid, which is currently underway in Mississippi, Missouri, Arkansas, Oklahoma, and Utah. The funds are already being distributed, and this story will be updated with further information as it becomes available. (Sources: Missouri Treasurer's office, Gov. Mike Parson's office)

input:
It's hard not to be charmed by his new perkier outlook on life.
Married life may have mellowed British wind-up merchant Example in recent years, but when you're a popstar it must be hard not to divulge
continuation: too much of your private life when under pressure. But it appears he is still working hard. He is preparing for his first solo performance in almost 20 years in August.
paraphrase: Example, the once quirky and witty British comedian, has transformed into a more mellow and introspective individual since tying the knot. Although he may have relaxed since his marriage, the pressure of being a popstar demands a certain level of privacy and secrecy. However, he remains committed to his craft, diligently preparing for his upcoming solo performance in August, marking a significant milestone in his career.

input:
Pedro Gonzalez faces up to 48 years in prison for allegedly attempting to beat Dita Richterova to death.
Friends have set up a GoFundMe page for Dita Richterova, who was severely beaten during an attack at the Brush
continuation:
y Mountain Lodge in Fort Collins, Colorado.
Pedro Gonzalez, 30, was charged with attempted first-degree murder in Richterovas death. The police released video of him attacking Richterova, which was recorded from a window overlooking the action.
Friends say Richterova suffered from schizophrenia, which made her difficult to manage. At least one of her daughters, Alisa, told the Fort Collins Coloradoan Richterova suffered from paranoia, paranoia psychosis, psychosis, anxiety, depression, post-traumatic stress disorder, dementia, and schizotypy.
A friend of Richterovas said she became ill in early August and was admitted to hospital, where she was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. The friend said Richterova was released back into her own residence, where her sister called police in late August. A friend said Richterova was later found in a pool of blood. She was transferred to a hospital.
After the video was released, Richterovas sister, Lila Richterova, was in court, pleading with her brothers attorney, Gregory McFarland, to offer a reason why she didnt go with him when he left her alone
paraphrase:
Dita Richterova's friends have established a GoFundMe page to support her after she was severely beaten during an attack at the Brushy Mountain Lodge in Fort Collins, Colorado. Pedro Gonzalez, 30, has been charged with attempted first-degree murder in connection with Richterova's injury. Police released video footage of the incident, which was recorded from a nearby window.
According to friends, Richterova had been experiencing mental health issues, including schizophrenia, paranoia, depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder, and dementia. One of her daughters, Alisa, revealed that Richterova had been diagnosed with these conditions in early August, before she was released from the hospital. However, she was later found in a pool of blood and was rushed to the hospital.
During a court appearance, Richterova's sister, Lila, pleaded with the prosecutor to provide a justification for why she did not accompany him when he left her alone. The incident has raised concerns about the safety and well-being of individuals with mental health conditions, particularly in light of the recent attack.
